Schwartz|title=PopMatters.com review|date=October 23, 2012}}</ref>\n}}\n| label            = {{flatlist|\n* [[Lost Highway Records|Lost Highway]]\n* Axster Bingham\n}}\n| associated_acts  = {{flatlist|\n* [[The Dead Horses]]\n* [[T Bone Burnett]]\n}}\n}} \n}}\n\n'''George Ryan Bingham'''  (born March 31, 1981) is an American singer, songwriter, and guitarist whose music spans multiple genres.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gold |first1=Scott |title=Raw and Genuine |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2008-mar-30-ca-bingham30-story.html |newspaper=LA Times |date=March 30, 2008 |access-date=June 27, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Hajek |first1=Daniel |title=From Rodeo To Radio: Ryan Bingham's Wild Ride |url=https://www.npr.org/2013/12/29/256347468/from-rodeo-to-radio-ryan-binghams-wild-ride |newspaper=NPR.org |publisher=NPR |access-date=June 27, 2019}}</ref> He is currently based in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web|first=Tom |last=LanHam |title=Ryan Bingham is happier out of Hollywood spotlight |url=https://www.sfexaminer.com/entertainment/ryan-bingham-is-happier-out-of-hollywood-spotlight/ |work=SFExaminer |date=March 2019 |access-date=June 21, 2019}}</ref> As of 2019, Bingham has released six studio albums and one live album, the last four of which were released under his own label, Axster Bingham Records.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Isaac |first1=Nico |title=Ryan Bingham: Tomorrowland |date=September 17, 2012 |url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2012/09/ryan-bingham-tomorrowland.html |publisher=Paste Magazine |access-date=June 27, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Horowitz |first1=Hal |title=Ryan Bingham: Fear and Saturday Night |url=https://americansongwriter.com/2015/01/ryan-bingham-fear-saturday-night/ |website=American Songwriter |date=January 20, 2015 |access-date=June 27, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Skinner |first1=Jared |title=Ryan Bingham: Ryan Bingham Live |url=https://www.popmatters.com/ryan-bingham-ryan-bingham-live-2495408357.html |website=PopMatters.com|date=November 28, 2016 |access-date=June 27, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Beaugez |first1=Jim |title=How Ryan Bingham's Album 'American Love Song' Addresses Border Politics |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/ryan-bingham-new-album-american-love-song-793600/ |website=RollingStone Magazine |access-date=June 27, 2019 |date=February 12, 2019}}</ref>\n\nOriginally from [[Hobbs, New Mexico]], Bingham grew up across the Southwestern United States. He joined the rodeo circuit as a bull rider in his teens.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Schlanger |first1=Talia |title=Ryan Bingham's Rugged And Raw 'American Love Song' |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/world-cafe/2019/06/03/729258867/ryan-binghams-rugged-and-raw-american-love-song |newspaper=NPR.org |publisher=NPR |access-date=June 27, 2019 |date=June 3, 2019}}</ref> Bingham learned music on a guitar gifted to him by his mother at age 16, initially playing after [[rodeo]]s for his friends.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Essmaker |first1=Tina |title=Ryan Bingham MUSICIAN SONGWRITER |url=http://thegreatdiscontent.com/interview/ryan-bingham |website=The Great Discontent |access-date=June 27, 2019 |date=January 15, 2013}}</ref> Eventually, he began playing in small bars and honky tonks across the West, landing him in Los Angeles. Bingham signed his first record deal with [[Lost Highway Records]] (UMG) in 2007.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Deusner |first1=Stephen |title=Ryan Bingham & the Dead Horses: Roadhouse Sun |url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2009/06/ryan-bingham-the-dead-horses-roadhouse-sun.html|publisher=Paste Magazine |access-date=June 27, 2019 |date=June 4, 2009}}</ref>\n\nAfter receiving critical acclaim for his first two studio releases on Lost Highway Records, 2007's ''[[Mescalito (album)|Mescalito]]'' and 2009's ''[[Roadhouse Sun]]'', Bingham went on to collaborate with Grammy-winning producer [[T Bone Burnett]] on the soundtrack for the acclaimed 2009 film ''[[Crazy Heart]]'', including notably cowriting and performing the film's award-winning theme song, \"[[The Weary Kind]]\". The title track earned Bingham an Academy Award, Golden Globe Award, and [[Critics' Choice Movie Award|Critics' Choice Award]] for \"Best Song\" in 2010,<ref>[http://2010.aclfestival.com/band/ryan-bingham 2010 ACL Festival: Ryan Bingham Official Bio] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110423115919/http://2010.aclfestival.com/band/ryan-bingham |date=April 23, 2011 }}</ref> as well as a Grammy Award for \"Best Song Written for a Motion Picture, Television or Other Visual Media\" in 2011.<ref>{{cite news |first=Gerrick |last=Kennedy |title=Grammy Awards: Ryan Bingham nabs a trophy, still puts on pants 'one leg at a time' |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2011/02/grammy-awards-.html |work=Los Angeles Times |date=February 13, 2011 |access-date=July 5, 2011}}</ref> The [[Americana Music Association]] also honored Bingham with the organization's top [[Americana Music Honors & Awards|award]] in 2010 as \"Artist of the Year\".<ref>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Talbott |title=Ryan Bingham Wins Big at Americana Awards |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2010-09-09-americana-awards_N.html  |work=USA Today |date=September 9, 2010 |access-date=July 5, 2011}}{{dead link|date=July 2014}}</ref>\n\nBingham's most recent album, ''[[American Love Song]]'', was released on February 15, 2019. A ballad from that album, \"Wolves\", was inspired in part by the [[March For Our Lives]] students who were dealing with grown men and women questioning their integrity on social media.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Newman |first1=Melinda |title=Ryan Bingham on His Haunting New Song 'Wolves' and Launching His Own Music Festival: Exclusive |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8487093/ryan-bingham-new-song-wolves-western-festival |magazine=Billboard |publisher=Billboard Magazine |access-date=June 27, 2019 |date=November 29, 2018}}</ref> The song was also featured on the TV series ''[[Yellowstone (American TV series)|Yellowstone]]''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Yellowstone \u2013 S1E7 Soundtrack A Monster Is Among Us |url=https://www.what-song.com/Tvshow/100345/Yellowstone/e/112379 |website=What-Song |access-date=June 27, 2019}}</ref> Bingham sang \"Wolves\" as the series' character, Walker, whom he plays on the show.<ref name=\"Yellowstone\" />\n\nIn April 2019, Bingham partnered with [[Live Nation (events promoter)|Live Nation]] to launch his own music festival, The Western. The inaugural event took place over two days in [[Luckenbach, Texas]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Rascoe |first1=Rachel |title=Faster Than Sound: Ryan Bingham Warms Up His Western Festival |url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2019-04-19/faster-than-sound-ryan-bingham-warms-up-his-western-festival/ |website=Austin Chronicle |access-date=June 28, 2019 |date=April 19, 2019}}</ref>\n\n== Early life ==\nBingham was born in Hobbs, New Mexico. His family relocated to the [[Midland\u2013Odessa]] area of [[West Texas]], before eventually moving to [[Houston]]. He attended high school primarily in Houston at [[Westfield High School (Harris County, Texas)|Westfield High School]].\n\nBingham's mother purchased his first guitar when he was 16 years old. Although he was fascinated by music, he left his guitar dormant in his closet. Roughly a year later, Bingham hitchhiked back west to [[Laredo, Texas]], in hopes of landing a job with his father, carrying the guitar with him on the trip. Bingham's father enjoyed having neighbors over on their porch to drink beer, and one of them taught him a classical Mariachi song called \"La Malaguena\" in segments. Though he loved playing the song, it was the only one he would learn during his time in Laredo.\n\nHe relocated to [[Stephenville, Texas]]. There, he began learning more music while also riding on the rodeo team at [[Tarleton State University]]. It was in Stephenville that he would write arguably his most well-known hit \"Southside of Heaven\" in a trailer house. He also began to play local gigs there, namely a local golf course and a few small bars.\n\nWhile in Stephenville, Bingham had a friend who caught wind of a job in [[Paris]], France, with the Wild West Show at the [[Disney Parks, Experiences and Products|Disney Resort]]. He bought a one-way ticket with $100 in his pocket. Upon arrival, he was informed that the manager with whom he had a mutual friend was no longer with the company, and he found himself stranded with his guitar and old rigging bag from his rodeo days. Luckily, he found some friends-of-friends within the Disney programs and began playing music in local parks for tips.\n\nEventually, he saved enough money to get back to Texas and moved in with a rodeo buddy near [[Fort Worth]]. His friend had a brother (Matthew \"Papa\" Smith) who cut hair during the day and played drums as a hobby. After an introduction and impromptu gig at an empty bar in Fort Worth, he and Papa would go on to be the founding members of Ryan Bingham and the Dead Horses.<ref name=3DotMag>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8PLUyADYR_w|title=Ryan Bingham Interviewed by 3DotMag|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref> [[Marc Ford]] of the [[Black Crowes]] was one of the few people in the bar that night. He approached Bingham after the gig with an offer to record an album.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.popmatters.com/ryan-bingham-conquers-fear-and-loathing-to-rock-the-american-dream-2495463954.html|title=Ryan Bingham Conquers Fear and Loathing to Rock the American Dream|date=December 2, 2015|website=PopMatters.com|language=en|access-date=February 23, 2019}}</ref><ref name=wellREDpodcast>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stitcher.com/s?eid=58246765|title=#100 \u2013 The 100th Episode Celebration w/ Ryan F***ing Bingham! from wellRED podcast|website=Stitcher.com}}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\nAfter issuing self-released \"Wishbone Saloon\" and \"Dead Horses\", the latter distributed by [[Lone Star Music]], Bingham was signed to [[Lost Highway Records]], which issued his first major label debut with ''Mescalito'' on October 2, 2007, produced by former [[Black Crowes]] guitarist [[Marc Ford]]. ''Texas Music Magazine'' has opined that Bingham \"talks and sings with a whiskey-and-cigarette throat that screams hard living. Hard in a way that can make a 29-year-old sound like a 50-year-old [[Tom Waits]].\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.binghammusic.com/ |title=Ryan Bingham's website, quoting the magazine article |website=Binghammusic.com |date=July 9, 2014 |access-date=July 27, 2014}}</ref> Bingham spent several years on the rodeo circuit. He began [[bull riding]] in his late teens.<ref>{{cite web|last=McCartney |first=Kelly |url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/news/article/58968/no-bull-ryan-bingham-trades-in-rodeos-for-nightclubs/ |title=Pop Matters website interview with Ryan Bingham |website=Popmatters.com |access-date=July 27, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,3028,GAC_26071_5781672_,00.html |title=Artists: Artists A to Z: Ryan Bingham Biography: Great American Country |website=Gactv.com |date=June 27, 2014 |access-date=July 27, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120211171659/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,3028,GAC_26071_5781672_,00.html |archive-date=February 11, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nBingham's former band, The Dead Horses, was composed of Matthew \"Papa\" Smith ([[drums]]), Corby Schaub (guitar and [[mandolin]]) and Marc Ford's son Elijah ([[bass guitar|bass]]). The bass player on ''Mescalito'' was Jeb Venable (a.k.a. Jeb Stuart), with Joe Allen credited as well, plus a contribution from [[John Bazz]] on [[upright bass]]. Bingham appeared with the [[Drive-by Truckers]] on ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' in October 2007. The first single from ''Mescalito'', titled \"Southside of Heaven\", was released on November 30, 2007. The second single was entitled \"Bread and Water\".\n\nOn June 2, 2009, Ryan Bingham and The Dead Horses released their second studio album titled ''[[Roadhouse Sun]]'' via Lost Highway Records. It was once again produced by [[Marc Ford]].\n[[File:Ryan Bingham - Roadhouse Sun Image.jpg|thumb|left|Ryan Bingham from his 2009 release \u2013 Roadhouse Sun]]\n\nBingham performed two songs for the soundtrack of the movie ''[[Crazy Heart]]'', including \"I Don't Know\" and the theme song, \"[[The Weary Kind]]\". The song was co-written by Bingham and producer, T Bone Burnett. Bingham also played a small role in the film. On January 17, 2010, Bingham was awarded the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Song|Golden Globe for Best Original Song]] for \"The Weary Kind\". The song also won the 2010 [[Academy Award for Best Original Song]],<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://oscar-watch.ew.com/2010/02/02/oscar-nominations-announced/ |title=Oscar nominations announced |year=2010 |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly|ew.com]] |access-date=February 2, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100205043942/http://oscar-watch.ew.com/2010/02/02/oscar-nominations-announced/ |archive-date=February 5, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1633370/jeff-bridges-ryan-bingham-t-bone-burnett-win-oscars-for-crazy-heart.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100311182223/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1633370/jeff-bridges-ryan-bingham-t-bone-burnett-win-oscars-for-crazy-heart.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 11, 2010|title=Jeff Bridges, Ryan Bingham, T Bone Burnett Win Oscars for Crazy Heart|date=March 8, 2010|work=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]]|access-date=March 8, 2010}}</ref> the 2010 Grammy award for [[Best Song Written for a Motion Picture, Television or Other Visual Media]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/ryan-bingham|title=Ryan Bingham|date=May 22, 2018|website=Grammy.com}}</ref> as well as Song of the Year at the 9th Annual [[Americana Music Association]] awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sesac.com/News/News_Details.aspx?id=1362|title=ARTISTRY WINS DURING 9th ANNUAL AMERICANA MUSIC ASSOCIATION HONORS & AWARDS, Ryan also played at the ACL festival in 2011|date=September 10, 2010|website=Sesac.com|access-date=September 13, 2010}}</ref>\n\nBingham rejoined with his band the Dead Horses to release their third studio album, ''[[Junky Star]]'', on August 31, 2010. The album debuted in the Top 20 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] Chart<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/#/album/ryan-bingham-the-dead-horses/junky-star/1386221|title=Billboard \u2013 Music Charts, News, Photos & Video|website=Billboard.com}}</ref> & in the Top 10 on the Billboard Rock Album Chart,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/#/charts/rock-albums?chartDate=2010-09-19|title=Billboard \u2013 Music Charts, News, Photos & Video|website=Billboard.com}}</ref> making ''Junky Star'' Bingham's highest charting and most successful release to date.\n\nIn 2012, Bingham parted ways with the Dead Horses and record label Lost Highway Records to release his fourth studio album, ''[[Tomorrowland (Ryan Bingham album)|Tomorrowland]]'', on his own Axster Bingham Records label.<ref name=\"pastemagazine.com\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2012/09/ryan-bingham-tomorrowland.html|title=Ryan Bingham: Tomorrowland|date=September 17, 2012|website=Pastemagazine.com}}</ref> Bingham co-produced the album with musician/producer [[Justin Stanley]]. The first single released from ''Tomorrowland'' was \"Heart of Rhythm\". Both the single and the official lyric video debuted on Americansongwriter.com on July 30, 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://americansongwriter.com/premiere-ryan-bingham-heart-of-rhythm-lyric-video/evan-schlansky/|title=Premiere: Ryan Bingham, \"Heart of Rhythm\" (Lyric Video) |website=Americansongwriter.com|date=July 30, 2012}}</ref> Bingham's second ''Tomorrowland'' single \"Guess Who's Knockin\" debuted on rollingstone.com on September 6, 2012.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/song-premiere-ryan-bingham-guess-whos-knocking-237864/|title=Song Premiere: Ryan Bingham, 'Guess Who's Knocking'|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=September 6, 2012}}</ref> The official music video for \"Guess Who's Knocking\" premiered on pastmagazine.com October 4, 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/blogs/av/2012/10/video-premiere-ryan-bingham.html|title=Video Premiere: Ryan Bingham \u2013 \"Guess Who's Knocking\"|date=October 4, 2012|website=Pastemagazine.com}}</ref>\n\nIn 2013, Bingham's song \"For Anyone's Sake\" appeared in the closing credits of the feature film ''[[Joe (2013 film)|Joe]]'', starring [[Nicolas Cage]]. Bingham wrote the song for the film, and it was released as part of the film's original soundtrack in April 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/joe-original-motion-picture-soundtrack/847533862|title=Joe (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) by Jeff McIlwain & David Wingo|date=April 8, 2014|website=Itunes.apple.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00J7MEKD0/ref=dm_ws_sp_ps_dp|title=Joe|website=Amazon.com}}</ref> In the same year, Bingham also wrote and recorded \"Until I'm One With You\", the theme song for [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] TV drama series ''[[The Bridge (2013 TV series)|The Bridge]]''. The song is Bingham's first screen track since his Academy Award win for best theme song in 2010. \"Until I'm One with You\" was released as a digital single on Bingham's own Axster Bingham Records label on June 25, 2013.<ref name=\"billboard.com\">Phil Gallo, [http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1568109/ryan-bingham-pens-theme-for-fxs-bridge-first-screen-track-since-oscar-win \"Ryan Bingham Pens Theme For FX's 'Bridge'; First Screen Track Since Oscar Win\"], ''Billboard.com'', 06/25/13</ref>\n\nIn 2014, Bingham starred opposite [[Imogen Poots]] in the independent film ''A Country Called Home'', directed and co-written by his wife, Anna Axster. Bingham also wrote and recorded the film's title track \"A Country Called Home\". The song was released digitally through Bingham's own label, Axster Bingham Records, on May 6, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/a-country-called-home-single/1104417328|title=A Country Called Home \u2013 Single by Ryan Bingham|date=May 6, 2016|website=Itunes.apple.com}}</ref>\n\nBingham's fifth studio album ''[[Fear and Saturday Night]]'' was recorded mostly live at Plyrz Studio outside of Los Angeles, California.<ref name=\"nodepression.com\">{{cite web |url=http://nodepression.com/album-review/ryan-bingham-returns-fear-and-saturday-night |title=Ryan Bingham Returns with 'Fear and Saturday Night' &#124; No Depression |website=nodepression.com |access-date=January 15, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150318220543/http://nodepression.com/album-review/ryan-bingham-returns-fear-and-saturday-night |archive-date=March 18, 2015 |url-status=dead}}</ref> The album was co-produced by Jim Scott and released through Axster Bingham Records on January 20, 2015. The album's first single \"Radio\" was released on December 9, 2014. In a 2016 interview with [[Rolling Stone magazine]], Bingham shared, \"'Radio' is a song I wrote about the thoughts, memories, and emotions that roll through my mind. The radio that's constantly playing in your head, night and day.\"<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/watch-ryan-binghams-intense-live-radio-video-112878/|title=Watch Ryan Bingham's Intense Live 'Radio' Video|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=September 30, 2016}}</ref>\n\nOn August 6, 2016, Bingham recorded his first live album, ''Ryan Bingham Live'', at Whitewater Amphitheater in [[New Braunfels, Texas]]. The album was released on October 21, 2016. The entire Whitewater Amphitheater show was also filmed and streamed live by [[Amazon Music]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ftw.usatoday.com/2016/10/song-premiere-ryan-bingham-crowd-favorite-sunrise-off-new-live-album|title=Song Premiere: Ryan Bingham crowd favorite 'Sunrise' off new live album|website=Ftw.usatoday.com|date=October 18, 2016}}</ref>\n\nBingham released a song titled \"Back By the River\" on ''The Musical Mojo of [[Dr. John]]: A Celebration of Mac and his Music'', in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Press Play: New Music|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/weekend/pressplay/press-play-new-music/article_2197869b-6827-5d5e-8a0b-45232cf5bc84.html|website=Tulsaworld.com|access-date=September 14, 2016}}</ref>\n\nIn 2018\u20132020, Bingham has a guest role in the [[Western (genre)#Contemporary Western|contemporary Western]] television show, ''[[Yellowstone (American TV series)|Yellowstone]]'', as Walker, an itinerant [[ranch hand]].<ref name=\"Yellowstone\">{{cite web |title=Yellowstone \u2013 Season 1 \u2013 TV Series {{!}} Paramount Network |url=https://www.paramountnetwork.com/shows/yellowstone/iutiiw/season-1 |access-date=June 22, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Yellowstone \u2013 Season 2 \u2013 TV Series {{!}} Paramount Network |url=https://www.paramountnetwork.com/shows/yellowstone/e7flgl/season-2 |access-date=June 22, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Yellowstone \u2013 Season 3 \u2013 TV Series {{!}} Paramount Network |url=https://www.paramountnetwork.com/shows/yellowstone/g4h152/season-3 |access-date=September 20, 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn December 2018, Bingham announced that he would be releasing his sixth studio album ''American Love Song'' in February 2019.\n\nIn March 2020, Bingham began posting various covers and released songs on his Youtube channel in a series known as the Cantina Sessions throughout the [[COVID-19 pandemic|COVID-19 Pandemic]], he continued such until the end of 2020.\n\n== Reception ==\nBingham has appeared as a guest on [[Bob Harris (radio)|Bob Harris]]'s Country Show on the [[BBC Radio 2|BBC's Radio 2]]. Daryl Easlea, writing for the BBC's folk and country review, said: \"Bingham will be one of the names to drop in 2008, with an album that sounds as if it's been unearthed from 1972.\"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/jg54/|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120723012944/http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/jg54|url-status=dead|title=BBC \u2013 Music \u2013 Review of Ryan Bingham \u2013 Mescalito|first=Daryl|last=Easlea|website=Bbc.co.uk|archive-date=July 23, 2012|access-date=February 17, 2020}}</ref>\n[[File:Ryan Bingham Ron Baker 3.jpg|thumb|left|Ryan Bingham & Joe Ely \u2013 Antone's during SXSW 2008 \u2013 Austin, TX.]]\n''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine gave ''Mescalito'' three out of five stars and wrote that Bingham \"earns his sepia-toned album cover with a dusty wood-and-steel sound, and despite being twenty-five, sings like [[Steve Earle]]'s dad.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/16496481/review/18057124/mescalito?rating=11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090114090514/http://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/16496481/review/18057124/mescalito?rating=11 |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 14, 2009 |title=Mescalito : Ryan Bingham : Review |publisher=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=July 27, 2014}}</ref>\n\n''[[PopMatters]]'' review of ''Tomorrowland'' awarded the album with 8 out of 10 stars. Greg M. Scwartz, writing for PopMatters wrote, that \"The one-time pro rodeo rider turned Texas troubadour has blues, country, and Americana influences that are certainly still there. But at his core, Bingham has always been a rock 'n' roller and ''Tomorrowland'' features him rocking at his best.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/164086-ryan-bingham-tomorrowland/ |title=Ryan Bingham: Tomorrowland < PopMatters |website=www.popmatters.com |access-date=January 15, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025002058/http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/164086-ryan-bingham-tomorrowland/ |archive-date=October 25, 2012 |url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n''Tomorrowland'' was also reviewed by Nico Isaac from [[Paste (magazine)]]. Isaac wrote: \"Tomorrowland is like a good, ol' fashioned rock anthem of kiss-my-asschaps autonomy... One thing's for sure Tomorrowland- the album and the red-blooded, rattlesnake-eating rebellious attitude\u2014is no place for the weary kind.\"<ref name=\"pastemagazine.com\" />\n{{Clear}}\n\n== Personal life ==\n\nRyan's mother drank herself to death and his father died by suicide. Bingham's \"Never Far Behind\" from his ''[[Tomorrowland (Ryan Bingham album)|Tomorrowland]]'' album is about his parents.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ryan Bingham Interviewed by 3DotMag|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8PLUyADYR_w|website=Youtube.com|access-date=September 14, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Newman|first1=Melinda|title='Fear and Saturday Night': How Ryan Bingham Defeated Darkness on Surprising New LP|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/fear-and-saturday-night-how-ryan-bingham-defeated-darkness-on-surprising-new-lp-20150120|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=September 14, 2016|date=January 20, 2015}}</ref>\n\nHe announced at his performance in [[Austin, Texas]], on March 5, 2015, that he and his wife were expecting their first child in the summer of 2015. Bingham's song \"Broken Heart Tattoo\" from ''[[Fear and Saturday Night]]'' is a reflection about what he would like to say to his unborn child.<ref>from an interview on Americana Music Show, No. 238, published March 24, 2015</ref>\n\nOn June 29, 2021, Bingham filed for divorce from his wife, Anna Axster, after 12 years of marriage. In September 2021, it was revealed that the couple's former Topanga Canyon home was sold for $2.45 million. The home was originally purchased by the couple in 2013 for $1.36 million. Bingham and Axster have three children together.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Gold|first1=Scott|title=Raw and Genuine|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2008-mar-30-ca-bingham30-story.html|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|access-date=November 17, 2016|date=March 30, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Smyers |first=Darryl |url=http://blogs.dallasobserver.com/dc9/2010/10/qa_ryan_bingham_talks_growing.php |title=Q&A: Ryan Bingham Talks Growing Up in Texas, Sharing His Name with George Clooney and Coming to Grips With Winning an Oscar &#124; Dallas Observer |website=Blogs.dallasobserver.com |date=October 7, 2010 |access-date=July 27, 2014}}</ref>\n\nSince April 2023, Bingham and his female fellow ''Yellowstone'' co-star [[Hassie Harrison]] have been in a relationship. They were married on October 7, 2023.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/tv/story/2023-04-13/yellowstone-hassie-harrison-ryan-bingham-dating-laramie-walker|title='Yellowstone' couple confirms there is 'more than a spark' between them in real life|last=Carras|first=Christi|work=Los Angeles Times|date=April 13, 2023|language=en}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Parker_McCollum","to":"Parker McCollum"}],"pages":{"46321863":{"pageid":46321863,"ns":0,"title":"Parker McCollum","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musician}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Parker McCollum\n| image           = File:Parker McCollum picture 1.jpg\n| image_size      =\n| landscape       =\n| alt             =\n| caption         = McCollum in 2014\n| birth_name      = Parker Yancey McCollum\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1992|6|15}}\n| birth_place     = [[Conroe, Texas]], U.S.\n| origin          = [[Austin, Texas]], U.S.<ref name=\"erlewine\"/>\n| genre           = {{flatlist|\n* [[Americana (music)|Americana]]<ref name=\"erlewine\">{{cite web |last1=Erlewine |first1=Stephen Thomas |title=Artist Biography - Parker McCollum |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/parker-mccollum-mn0003377460/biography |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=June 12, 2022}}</ref>\n* [[Texas country]]<ref name=\"pmcb Chronicle\"/>\n* [[neotraditional country]]<ref name=\"DJ\">{{cite web|url=https://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/review-parker-mccollum-stays-true-to-his-roots-on-gold-chain-cowboy-album/article|title=Review: Parker McCollum stays true to his roots on 'Gold Chain Cowboy' album|last=Papadatos|first=Markos|publisher=Digital Journal|date=January 2, 2022|access-date=March 26, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220329015619/https://www.digitaljournal.com/entertainment/review-parker-mccollum-stays-true-to-his-roots-on-gold-chain-cowboy-album/article|archive-date=March 29, 2022|url-status=live}}</ref>\n}}\n| occupation      = {{flatlist|\n* Singer-songwriter\n* musician\n}}\n| instrument      = {{flatlist|\n* Guitar\n* harmonica\n* vocals\n}}\n| years_active    = 2013\u2013present\n| label           = {{flatlist|\n* PYM Music\n* [[Universal Music Group Nashville#MCA Nashville|MCA Nashville]]\n}}\n| website         = {{URL|http://parkermccollum.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Parker Yancey McCollum''' (born June 15, 1992)<ref name=\"pmcdedge\"/> is an American [[Country music|country]] singer-songwriter based in Texas. The owner of PYM Music, he released his first single and EP in 2013;<ref name=\"pmccsonicbids\"/> his debut album, ''The Limestone Kid'', was released on February 24, 2015.<ref name=\"pmcaAbout\"/> ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'' gave the release 3.5/5 stars, writing that \"it's too early to declare ''The Limestone Kid'' debut of the year, but it's already one to beat\", and comparing McCollum's music to [[Charlie Robison]]'s.<ref name=\"pmcb Chronicle\"/> McCollum and his backing band announced a 2015 tour<ref name=\"pmcaAbout\"/> of Texas in support of the album,<ref name=\"pmcdedge\"/> performing at events such as [[Redgorilla|RedGorilla Music Fest]].<ref name=\"pmceNashville\"/> McCollum released the EP ''Probably Wrong: Session One'' on July 7, 2017, and followed it with ''Probably Wrong: Session Two'' on September 8, 2017. The full ''Probably Wrong'' album was released on November 10, 2017. His major-label debut album, ''[[Gold Chain Cowboy]]'', was released July 30, 2021.\n\n==Early life==\nParker McCollum was born in 1992<ref name=\"pmcdedge\"/> and raised in [[Conroe, Texas]], near [[Houston]].<ref name=\"pmcdedge\"/> Early in his life he listened to [[classic country]] musicians such as [[Willie Nelson]], [[Buck Owens]], and [[Porter Wagoner]],<ref name=\"pmcdedge\"/> and his family introduced him to [[Red Dirt (music)|red dirt musicians]] such as [[Cross Canadian Ragweed]], [[Pat Green]], and [[Chris Knight (musician)|Chris Knight]].<ref name=\"pmccsonicbids\"/> Working summers on a cattle ranch with his grandfather,<ref name=\"pmcilonestar\"/> McCollum was further exposed to artists such as [[Bob Dylan]], [[Townes Van Zandt]], and [[Steve Earle]].<ref name=\"pmccsonicbids\"/> McCollum has referred to [[neotraditional country]] pioneer and fellow Texan [[George Strait]] as his musical hero, and has covered several Strait songs in his performances.<ref name=\"young\">{{cite web |last1=Young |first1=Casey |title=Parker McCollum Pays Tribute To His Musical Hero, George Strait, With Cover Of \"Carrying Your Love With Me\" |url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2022/03/11/parker-mccollum-pays-tribute-to-his-musical-hero-george-strait-with-cover-of-carrying-your-love-with-me/ |website=WhiskeyRiff |access-date=June 12, 2022}}</ref><ref name=\"guerra\"/>\n\nIn elementary school McCollum learned violin and played in the school orchestra,<ref name=\"pmccsonicbids\"/> and he started learning guitar at age thirteen.<ref name=\"pmcilonestar\"/> At thirteen he also began writing his own music,<ref name=\"pmcgAmericana\"/> mixing genres such as [[Texas country music]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]], and [[indie rock]].<ref name=\"pmccsonicbids\"/> According to McCollum, he was greatly influenced by his older brother Tyler's lyrics and songwriting.<ref name=\"pmcgAmericana\"/> After performing at a number of local [[open mic]]s with his guitar,<ref name=\"pmccsonicbids\"/> he started learning harmonica at age fifteen.<ref name=\"pmcilonestar\"/> By sixteen he was securing gigs at local venues<ref name=\"pmccsonicbids\"/> and continued to work on his material through high school, [[The Woodlands College Park High School]].<ref name=\"pmccsonicbids\"/><ref name=\"pmcilonestar\"/> After graduation he moved to [[Austin, Texas]],<ref name=\"pmcgAmericana\"/> where he began attending college.<ref name=\"pmccsonicbids\"/>\n\n==Music career==\n\n===Singles and ''A Red Town View'' (2013\u20132014)===\nMcCollum continued to perform as a singer-songwriter while living in Austin and he went on his first tour with the Texas band Six Market Blvd. The tour inspired the lyrics for his first single, \"Highway\",<ref name=\"pmccsonicbids\"/> which was released on June 5, 2013, and later included on his debut EP ''A Red Town View''. Released on November 19, 2013, the EP was produced by Corby Schaub, who is also known as the former guitarist for [[Ryan Bingham]].<ref name=\"pmccsonicbids\"/>\n\n===''The Limestone Kid'' (2015)===\nMcCollum's debut album ''The Limestone Kid'' was recorded at Cedar Creek Recording in Austin,<ref name=\"pmcilonestar\"/> and includes styles such as [[Americana (music)|Americana]],<ref name=\"pmceNashville\"/> Texas country, and [[folk-rock]].<ref name=\"pmcilonestar\"/> McCollum handles vocals, acoustic guitar, and harmonica,<ref name=\"pmceNashville\"/><ref name=\"pmcilonestar\"/> and his Austin-based backing band included Kurt Grien on lead guitar, Jason Newberry on bass, Will Hoback on drums, and Charlie Magnone on keyboards and piano.<ref name=\"pmcilonestar\"/> Multi-instrumentalist Corby Schaub produced the album.<ref name=\"pmcilonestar\"/> [[Lloyd Maines]] contributed [[pedal steel guitar]].<ref name=\"pmcftwangvile\"/>\n{{ external media\n| float  =right\n| video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YoenMoqckUE Parker McCollum \u2014 Meet You In The Middle Live at The Saxon Pub] (Feb 2015)\n| video2 =  \n}}\n\nMcCollum wrote or co-wrote nine of the eleven tracks,<ref name=\"pmcilonestar\"/> and two of the songs were written by McCollum's family members.<ref name=\"pmceNashville\"/><ref name=\"pmcilonestar\"/> Many of the lyrics are about his experiences growing up in [[Limestone County, Texas]],<ref name=\"pmcilonestar\"/><ref name=\"pmcftwangvile\"/> and the album's title is a reference to the nickname he earned working summers at a Limestone County ranch.<ref name=\"pmcdedge\"/> The first single on the album, McCollum's original track \"Meet You in the Middle\", was released to Texas radio prior to the album.<ref name=\"pmceNashville\"/>\n\nThe debut album ''The Limestone Kid'' was released on February 24, 2015.<ref name=\"pmcaAbout\"/> ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'' gave it 3.5/5 stars, writing that \"it's too early to declare ''The Limestone Kid'' debut of the year, but it's already one to beat\", and comparing him to [[Charlie Robison]].<ref name=\"pmcb Chronicle\"/> ''Texas Music Pickers'' wrote that \"[McCollum's] stories are not all happy, or sad, or even have resolution; they're just straight-forward accounts of life. It's like [[Todd Snider]] meets [[Whiskeytown]].\"<ref name=\"pmchtexasmusicpickers\"/> \"High Above The Water\" reached the top 50 of the Texas Regional Radio Report.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://indieextreme.com/success-stories/|title=Indie Extreme \u2013 Success Stories|work=Indie Extreme|access-date=April 7, 2020}}</ref>\n\nMcCollum and his backing band announced a tour<ref name=\"pmcaAbout\"/> of Texas in support of the album,<ref name=\"pmcdedge\"/> with February and March dates set for venues in [[Houston]], Austin, and [[Fort Worth]]. The band performed at the [[Redgorilla|RedGorilla Music Fest]], and Texas Crawfish and Music Festival in [[Spring, Texas]].<ref name=\"pmceNashville\"/> He won the T-Birds Songwriter Award, and in 2015 performed at Larry Joe Taylor's Texas Music Festival.<ref name=\"larry\"/>\n\n===''Probably Wrong'' (2017)===\nMcCollum released an EP titled ''Probably Wrong: Session One'' on July 7, 2017.<ref name=\"pickers\">{{cite web |url=http://www.texasmusicpickers.com/parker-mccollum-right-probably-wrong-session-one/ |title=Parker McCollum Does it Right with \"Probably Wrong: Session One\"|date=July 6, 2017 |first=Chris |last=Fox |work=Texas Music Pickers}}</ref> It was his first release to appear on the ''Billboard'' charts, debuting at No. 6 on Heatseekers Albums,<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/heatseekers-albums/2017-07-29|title=Heatseeker Albums |date=July 27, 2017|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]}}</ref> No. 14 on Independent Albums,<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/independent-albums/2017-07-29|title=Independent Albums |date=July 27, 2017|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]}}</ref> and No. 15 on Country Album Sales , with 2,000 copies sold in the US in its first week.<ref name=\"roughstock july 2017\">{{cite news |url=http://roughstock.com/news/2017/07/42043-top-10-country-albums-sales-chart-july-17-2017 |title=Top 10 Country Albums Sales Chart: July 17, 2017 |first= Matt |last= Bjorke |date=July 17, 2017 |work=Roughstock }}</ref> ''Probably Wrong Session Two'' was released shortly thereafter on September 8, 2017.<ref name=\"two\">{{cite web |url= https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/probably-wrong-session-two-ep/id1272777581 |title=Probably Wrong: Session Two \u2013 EP: Parker McCollum |work=iTunes}}</ref> The full 10-track ''Probably Wrong'' album was released on November 10, 2017, and includes all the previous sessions which features the singles \"I Can't Breathe\" and \"Misunderstood\", plus two new tracks, including \"Hell of a Year\". The full ''Probably Wrong'' album was produced by Grammy Award-winning Lloyd Maines.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} McCollum toured through the end of 2017 to promote his newest releases.\n\n===MCA Nashville===\nMcCollum signed with [[Universal Music Group]] on June 27, 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://musicrow.com/2019/06/parker-mccollum-joins-universal-music-group-nashville-roster/|title=Parker McCollum Joins Universal Music Group Nashville Roster|date=June 2, 2019|access-date=September 2, 2019}}</ref> His first single under the label was \"[[Pretty Heart]]\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://radiotexaslive.com/listen-up-parker-mccollum-drops-new-song-pretty-heart/|title=Listen Up! Parker McCollum Drops New Song 'Pretty Heart'|last=Logan|first=Buddy|website=Radio Texas, Live!|access-date=September 2, 2019}}</ref> On October 16, 2020, McCollum released the EP ''Hollywood Gold''.<ref name=\"HG\">{{cite web|url=https://www.umgnashville.com/news/parker-mccollum-set-to-release-new-ep-hollywood-gold-october-16/|title=Parker McCollum Set to Release New EP ''Hollywood Gold'' October 16|date=September 29, 2020|work=[[Universal Music Group Nashville|UMG Nashville]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnewsradioonline.com/music-news/2020/10/16/as-he-releases-his-new-ep-parker-mccollum-brings-home-some-h.html|title=As he releases his new EP, Parker McCollum brings home some 'Hollywood Gold' of his own|first=Carena|last=Liptak|access-date=October 16, 2020|work=[[ABC News Radio]] Online}}</ref>\n\n=== ''Gold Chain Cowboy'' (2021) ===\nOn July 30, 2021, McCollum released his third studio album to mostly positive reviews. ''Country Swag'' states that this album is \"sonically more polished than his first two albums\", and that what \"Parker McCollum does best on ''Gold Chain Cowboy'' is refrain from sounding like everyone else on country radio.\"<ref>{{Cite web|last=Bernheim|first=Lucie|date=2021-07-30|title=Parker McCollum: 'Gold Chain Cowboy' \u2013 Album Review|url=https://countryswag.com/parker-mccollum-gold-chain-cowboy-album-review/|access-date=2022-02-02|website=CS|language=en-US}}</ref>\nIn March 2022, he went on to win the New Male Artist of the Year at the American Country Music Awards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.acmcountry.com/noms|title = Academy of Country Music &#124; Winners|website=Acmcountry.com}}</ref>\n\nIn March 2022, McCollum performed for the first time at the [[Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo]] to an attendance of 73,243.<ref name=\"guerra\">{{cite news |last1=Guerra |first1=Joey |title=Rodeo Review: Conroe's Parker McCollum strikes gold with RodeoHouston debut |url=https://preview.houstonchronicle.com/rodeo/rodeo-review-parker-mccollum-strikes-gold-with-16997909 |access-date=June 12, 2022 |work=[[Houston Chronicle]] |date=March 13, 2022}}</ref>\n\n=== ''Never Enough'' (2023) ===\nOn August 5, 2022, McCollum released \"[[Handle on You]]\" as the lead single from his second major label studio album (fourth overall), ''[[Never Enough (Parker McCollum album)|Never Enough]]''. He subsequently released the tracks \"Stoned\", \"I Ain't Going Nowhere\", and \"Speed\" as promotional singles.\n\n==Musical style and influences==\nParker McCollum's music incorporates genres as diverse as [[blues]], [[roots rock]],<ref name=\"pmchtexasmusicpickers\"/> [[Soul music|soul]], and [[folk rock]], though his albums have primarily been described as [[country music|country]]<ref name=\"pmccsonicbids\"/> and [[Americana (music)|Americana]]. His music has received rotation on Americana radio stations in particular, and he has referenced Americana singer-songwriter [[Ryan Bingham]] as a significant influence. Other stylistic influences include [[alternative country]] musician [[Ryan Adams]], blues and folk artist [[Townes Van Zandt]], pop-rock artist [[John Mayer]], and country musician [[George Strait]].<ref name=\"pmccsonicbids\"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/parker-mccollum-handle-on-you-makin-tracks-interview-1235135424/|title=Makin\u2019 Tracks: Parker McCollum Gets a \u2018Handle\u2019 on His George Strait Influences| website=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=September 7, 2022|access-date=March 23, 2023|author=Tom Roland}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|+\n! scope=\"col\" rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:10em;\"| Title\n! scope=\"col\" This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Robert_Earl_Keen","to":"Robert Earl Keen"}],"pages":{"1479650":{"pageid":1479650,"ns":0,"title":"Robert Earl Keen","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Use American English|date=July 2023}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2023}}\n{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (born 1956)}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image            = Robert Earl Keen at the Redneck Country Club, June 30, 2018 MG 1357 (41334326940) (cropped).jpg\n| caption          = Keen in 2018\n| background       = solo_singer <!-- includes singer-songwriters -->\n| birth_name       = \n| alias            = \n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1956|1|11}}\n| origin           = [[Houston]], [[Texas]], U.S.\n| instrument       = Vocals, guitar, mandolin\n| genre            = [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[country music|country]], [[alternative country]]\n| occupation       = Singer, songwriter\n| years_active     = 1984\u20132024\n| label            = [[Dualtone]], [[Arista Records|Arista]], [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill]], [[KOCH Records|KOCH]], [[Lost Highway Records|Lost Highway]], Rosetta\n| website          = {{URL|RobertEarlKeen.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Robert Earl Keen''' (born January 11, 1956)<ref>{{Cite web |last=Rose |first=Mike|date=January 11, 2023 |title=Today's famous birthdays list for January 11, 2023 includes celebrities Mary J. Blige, Amanda Peet |url=https://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/2023/01/todays-famous-birthdays-list-for-january-11-2023-includes-celebrities-mary-j-blige-amanda-peet.html |access-date=January 10, 2023 |website=[[Cleveland.com]]}}</ref> is an American [[Country music|country]] singer-songwriter and entertainer. Debuting with 1984's ''No Kinda Dancer'', the Houston native has recorded 20 full-length albums for independent and major record labels.  His songs been [[Cover version|covered]] by artists including [[George Strait]], [[Joe Ely]], [[Lyle Lovett]], [[The Highwaymen (country supergroup)|The Highwaymen]] and [[Nanci Griffith]].<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web |date=June 29, 2022 |title=Lyle Lovett \u2013 Anthology Volume One Cowboy Man |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/8995236-Lyle-Lovett-Anthology-Volume-One-Cowboy-Man |access-date=June 29, 2022 |website=Discogs \u2013 Music Database}}</ref><ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web |date=June 29, 2022 |title=George Strait \u2013 One Step At A Time |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/3611380-George-Strait-One-Step-At-A-Time |access-date=June 29, 2022 |website=Discogs \u2013 Music Database}}</ref><ref name=\":4\">{{Cite web |date=June 29, 2022 |title=Joe Ely \u2013 Love And Danger |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/9026871-Joe-Ely-Love-And-Danger |access-date=June 29, 2022 |website=Discogs \u2013 Music Database}}</ref><ref name=\":5\">{{Cite web |date=June 29, 2022 |title=Highwaymen \u2013 The Road Goes On Forever |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/4378780-Highwaymen-The-Road-Goes-On-Forever |access-date=June 29, 2022 |website=Discogs \u2013 Music Database}}</ref><ref name=\":6\">{{Cite web |date=June 29, 2022 |title=Nanci Griffith \u2013 Lone Star State of Mind |url=https://www.discogs.com/release/1882329-Nanci-Griffith-Lone-Star-State-Of-Mind |access-date=June 29, 2022 |website=Discogs \u2013 Music Database}}</ref> Keen has toured in the U.S. and abroad.\n\n== Early life and education ==\nKeen was born and grew up in [[Houston]], [[Texas]], United States.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|page=214}}</ref> As a teenager, he was an avid reader who excelled in writing and literature classes. Keen was a fan of the British rock band [[Cream (band)|Cream]], and was influenced by country music by artists [[Willie Nelson]], [[Norman Blake (American musician)|Norman Blake]], [[Jesse Winchester]], [[Foggy Mountain Boys|Flatt and Scruggs]], [[Bill Withers]], [[Gary Stewart (singer)|Gary Stewart]], and [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]].<ref name=\"skanse\">{{Cite news|last=Skanse|first=Richard|title=Robert Earl Keen: A Man Apart|newspaper=Lone Star Music Magazine|access-date=January 4, 2013|url=http://www.lonestarmusic.com/magazine/mag_html/septoct11/coverstore.html}}</ref>\n\nAfter graduation from Sharpstown High School, Keen started playing guitar himself shortly thereafter, learning to play classic country covers out of a songbook the summer before starting college at [[Texas A&M University]] in [[College Station, Texas]].<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\" /> He graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in English in 1978 and began writing songs and playing [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] and folk music with friends, including his childhood friend (and future longtime [[fiddle]] player in his band) Bryan Duckworth. During his college years Keen lived with future musician [[Lyle Lovett]].<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\" />\n\n== Career ==\n[[File:Robert Earl Keen (2).jpg|thumb|Keen performing in 2007]]\nIn 1978, Keen graduated from Texas A&M and moved to [[Austin, Texas]].<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\" /> He performed in nightclubs and live music venues in Austin, including [[Cactus Cafe]], Emma Joe's, Alamo Lounge and [[Liberty Lunch]], [[Anderson Fair Retail Restaurant|Anderson Fair]] in Houston, and [[Gruene Hall]] in [[New Braunfels]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hodson |first=Christy |date=July 8, 2014 |title=Cactus Cafe & Bar |url=https://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/entries/cactus-cafe-bar |access-date=May 30, 2022 |website=Handbook of Texas Online |publisher=Texas State Historical association}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Weber |first=Andrew |date=July 17, 2020 |title=PHOTOS: Here's A Look Back At Austin Through The Lens Of Photographer Lisa Davis |work=KUT |url=https://www.kut.org/austin/2020-07-17/photos-heres-a-look-back-at-austin-through-the-lens-of-photographer-lisa-davis |access-date=May 30, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Freeman |first=Jon |date=June 4, 2020 |title=Robert Earl Keen to Play Social-Distanced Shows at Texas Club |magazine=Rolling Stone |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/robert-earl-keen-gruene-hall-coronavirus-1010093/ |access-date=May 30, 2020}}</ref> In 1983, Keen won the New Folk competition at the Kerrville Folk Festival in [[Kerrville, Texas]].<ref name=\"davis\">{{Cite news|last=Davis|first=John T.|title=Robert Earl Keen: Can you patch together a feeling that's going to stick with somebody ten years from now?|newspaper=No Depression|url=http://archives.nodepression.com/2005/05/can-you-patch-together-a-feeling-thats-going-to-stick-with-somebody-ten-years-from-now|access-date=January 10, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141122100717/http://archives.nodepression.com/2005/05/can-you-patch-together-a-feeling-thats-going-to-stick-with-somebody-ten-years-from-now/|archive-date=November 22, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\":0\">{{Cite news |last=Erwin |first=Hank |date=May 20, 2022 |title=A Culture 50 Years in the Making: The Kerrville Folk Festival Experience |work=The Austin Chronicle |url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2022-05-20/a-culture-50-years-in-the-making-the-kerrville-folk-festival-experience/ |access-date=May 30, 2022}}</ref> That same year, he began making his self-produced first album, ''[[No Kinda Dancer]]''.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\" />\n\nFollowing the release of this album in 1985, Keen moved to Nashville with his future wife, Kathleen Gray. He signed a publishing deal, a new independent label deal, and signed with a national booking agent.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Sale |first=Anna |date=May 20, 2015 |title=Robert Earl Keen Quit Nashville and Stayed Married |work=Death, Sex & Money |url=https://www.wnycstudios.org/podcasts/deathsexmoney/episodes/death-sex-money-robert-earl-keen |access-date=May 30, 2022}}</ref> While in Nashville, Keen and Gray worked at [[Hatch Show Print]] shop.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Sherraden |first=Jim |title=Hatch Show Print: The History of a Great American Poster Shop |publisher=Country Music Foundation |year=2001 |isbn=978-0-8118-2856-7 |pages=109}}</ref>\n\nKeen returned to Texas in 1987 and released his second album, ''[[The Live Album]]'', in 1988, followed by his third album, ''[[West Textures]]'' in 1989.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Sale |first=Anna |date=May 20, 2015 |title=Robert Earl Keen Quit Nashville and Stayed Married |work=Death, Sex & Money |url=https://www.wnycstudios.org/podcasts/deathsexmoney/episodes/death-sex-money-robert-earl-keen |access-date=May 30, 2022}}</ref> ''West Textures'' featured the first recording of Keen's signature song, \"The Road Goes on Forever.\"<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\" /> Fellow Texan [[Joe Ely]] recorded the song on his 1993 album ''Love and Danger'', along with another Keen song, \"Whenever Kindness Fails\".<ref name=\"mcleese\">{{Cite news |last=McLeese |first=Don |title=Straight outta Bandera: For Robert Earl Keen, music and business coexist at home, deep in the heart of Texas |newspaper=No Depression |access-date=January 5, 2013 |url=http://archives.nodepression.com/1998/11/straight-outta-bandera/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130719130938/http://archives.nodepression.com/1998/11/straight-outta-bandera/ |archive-date=July 19, 2013 }}</ref> Keen's own version of \"Whenever Kindness Fails\" appeared on his fourth album, 1993's ''A Bigger Piece of Sky.'' In 1994, he released ''[[Gringo Honeymoon]]'' followed by ''[[No. 2 Live Dinner]] in 1996''.<ref name=\"mcleese\" />\n\nKeen has continued to write and record music, while also maintaining a prodigious tour schedule.<ref name=\":8\">{{Cite news |date=June 27, 2022 |year=2022 |title=Live 75 |pages=8\u20139 |work=Pollstar}}</ref> His 1997 album, ''[[Picnic (album)|Picnic]]'', marked the beginning of his on-again, off-again relationship with major labels (both that album and 1998's ''[[Walking Distance (album)|Walking Distance]]'' were issued on Arista Records, and 2001's ''[[Gravitational Forces]]'', 2009's ''[[The Rose Hotel]]'' and 2011's ''Ready for Confetti'' were released on Lost Highway Records). Keen's other albums include 2003's ''[[Farm Fresh Onions]]'' (Audium/Koch Records) and 2005's ''[[What I Really Mean]]'' and 2006's ''[[Live at the Ryman]]'' (both on E1 Music). The producers with whom he has worked on those albums have included [[John Keane (record producer)|John Keane]], [[Gurf Morlix]], Gary Velletri, and [[Lloyd Maines]]. In 2022, his concert tour was listed as one of the most successful in the world.<ref name=\":8\" />\n\nHis band includes:\n*Bill Whitbeck \u2014 bass, upright bass, vocals\n*Tom Van Schaik \u2014 drums, vocals\n*Brian Beken \u2014 fiddle, acoustic guitar, electric guitar\n\nIn August of 2011, Keen was contacted by a member of U.S. Navy about a fan of his, Petty Officer First Class Jason Workman of Seal team 6, who had been killed on August 6, 2011, with 29 other Brave Americans in Wardak Province, Tanji Valley, Afghanistan. Keen went to the memorial service for POFC. Workman and played his signature song I\u2019m coming home. Keen covered all of his own expenses for travel and only wanted to show a token of his gratitude to a fan who made the ultimate sacrifice for his country. {{cn|date=December 2023}}\n\nIn January 2022, Keen announced that he would stop touring and performing publicly after September 2022.<ref>{{cite web |title=\"Time Flies\" \u2013 A message from Robert Earl Keen |first=Robert Earl |last= Keen |date=January 14, 2022 |website=robertearlkeen.com |url=https://www.robertearlkeen.com/news/time-flies |access-date=March 26, 2022}}</ref> His final tour was named the \"I'm Coming Home Farewell Tour\" and the final leg was played September 1, 3 and 4 at [[John T. Floore Country Store|Floore's Country Store]] in [[Helotes, Texas]]. Approximately 3,000 people attended the last show on September 4 for nearly two-and-a-half hours.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=\"Robert Earl Keen has played his final show. He's not kidding. |first=Josh |last= Crutchmer |date=September 5, 2022 |magazine=Rolling Stone |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/robert-earl-keen-retires-final-concert-1234586837/ |access-date=September 7, 2022}}</ref> Despite the claims of playing his final shows and farewell tour, Keen proceeded to do several shows in 2023<ref>{{cite web |title=Robert Earl Keen Isn't Un-Retiring, But He Is Re-Appearing |date=July 17, 2023 |website=savingcountrymusic.com |url=https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/robert-earl-keen-isnt-un-retiring-but-he-is-re-appearing/ |access-date=May 7, 2024}}</ref> and lists a 2024 tour on his website<ref>{{cite web |title=\"Robert Earl Keen\" |first=Robert Earl |last= Keen |website=robertearlkeen.com |url=https://www.robertearlkeen.com/tour |access-date=May 7, 2024}}</ref> with a dozen stops. Instagram posts on Keen's account containing photos from his \"I'm Coming Home Farewell Tour\" were later edited to remove reference to the \"farewell\" part of the tour.<ref>{{cite web |title=\"Robert Earl Keen\" |first=Robert Earl |last= Keen |website=instagram.com |url=https://www.instagram.com/p/Ch-G10grelV/ |access-date=May 7, 2024}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Studio albums [[Lubbock, Texas]], [[United States]]\n| death_date      =\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]|[[Folk music|folk]]|[[alternative country]]|[[folk rock]]|[[country folk]]}}\n| occupation      = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter}}\n| instrument      = {{hlist|Vocals|fiddle|autoharp|ukulele|tenor guitar}}\n| label           = [[ATO Records|ATO]]<ref>{{Cite web |last=Soto |first=Alfred |date=August 3, 2022 |title=Amanda Shires: Take It Like a Man |url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/amanda-shires-take-it-like-a-man/ |access-date=September 27, 2022 |website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]] |language=en-US}}</ref>\n| years_active    = 1997\u2013present\n| current_member_of = [[The 400 Unit]], [[The Highwomen]]\n| spouse = {{marriage|[[Jason Isbell]]|2013|2024|reason=div}}\n| website         = {{URL|amandashiresmusic.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Amanda Rose Shires''' (born March 5, 1982) is an American [[singer-songwriter]] and [[fiddle]] player. Shires has released seven solo albums starting in 2005, her most recent being ''[[Take It Like a Man (Amanda Shires album)|Take It Like a Man]]'' in 2022. In 2019, she founded a country music supergroup called [[The Highwomen]] alongside [[Brandi Carlile]], [[Maren Morris]] and [[Natalie Hemby]] and has also performed as a member of the [[Bob Wills|Texas Playboys]], [[Thrift Store Cowboys]], and [[Jason Isbell & the 400 Unit]], as well as in a duo with [[Rod Picott]]. Along with Jason Isbell & the 400 Unit, Shires won the [[Grammy for Best Americana Album|Grammy Award for Best Americana Album]] for their 2017 album ''[[The Nashville Sound]]''.<ref name=\":0\"/><ref>{{Citation|title=60th Annual Grammy Awards|date=2020-08-17|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=60th_Annual_Grammy_Awards&oldid=973533069|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2020-09-23}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nFollowing her parents' divorce, Shires' childhood was divided between the Texas cities of [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]] and [[Mineral Wells, Texas|Mineral Wells]].<ref name=\"Chron\">{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/entertainment/article/Amanda-Shires-makes-expressive-connection-1687085.php|title=Amanda Shires makes expressive connection|work=[[Houston Chronicle]]|first=Andrew|last=Dansby|date=May 3, 2011|access-date=December 22, 2011}}</ref>  Her mother is a retired nurse. She also used to be a [[barrel racing|barrel racer]] at [[rodeo]]s.<ref name= prodigy/> Her father owns a [[wholesaling|wholesale]] [[plant nursery|nursery]] in Mineral Wells and has a hobby of [[gold prospecting]] in [[Alaska]].<ref name= prodigy/>  She is distantly related to noted photographer Erica Shires, who produced the video for the song \"Swimmer\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/amanda-shires-swimmer-video/|title=Amanda Shires, 'Swimmer' \u2013 Video Premiere|first=Alanna|last=Conway|date=June 24, 2011|website=Tasteofcountry.com|access-date=April 5, 2012}}</ref>\n\nAt the age of 10, she happened to be with her father while he was shopping for hunting gear at a [[pawn shop]] in Mineral Wells.<ref name= prodigy>Dougherty, Steve (August 1, 2013). \"[https://search.proquest.com/docview/1416700072/D6846C06CEC743A5PQ/1 Amanda Shires: A Texas Prodigy Steps Out; She's on the Road With a New Album, Sometimes Appearing with Husband Jason Isbell]\". ''The Wall Street Journal''.</ref><ref name= wilson>Wilson, Calvin (August 15, 2004). \"[https://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/music/amanda-shires-strikes-the-right-balance/article_d7991de5-4dff-5eca-9887-e500b166e766.html Amanda Shires strikes the right balance]\". ''St. Louis Post Dispatch''.</ref> She saw an inexpensive Chinese-made [[fiddle]] for sale and her father agreed to buy it for her on the condition that she learn to play it.<ref name= prodigy/><ref name= wilson/><ref name=\"CST\">{{cite web|url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/column.asp?xid=331|title=Amanda Shires, September 2009|work=[[Country Standard Time]]|first=Rick|last=Cornell|date=September 2009|access-date=December 22, 2011}}</ref> It took a while for her to play it well; she usually practiced outside because her dog had a habit of howling while she played.<ref>Thanki, Juli (September 15, 2016). \"[https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2016/09/16/amanda-shires-celebrates-new-album-americanafest/88533538/ Amanda Shires celebrates new album at AmericanaFest]\". ''Tennessean''.</ref>  When she was 12, she started taking fiddle lessons in Lubbock from Lanny Fiel, who knew Frankie McCourter from the [[Texas Playboys]].<ref name= half>Burton, Tommy (August 27, 2014). \"[http://www.jacksonfreepress.com/news/2014/aug/27/amanda-shires-half-fictitious-fiddler/ Amanda Shires: Half-Fictitious Fiddler]\". ''Jackson Free Press''.</ref> She then started learning fiddle from McCourter and was later invited to play at the band's shows.<ref name= half/> At the age of 15, she joined the [[Texas Playboys]], the former backing band for [[Western swing]] legend [[Bob Wills]].<ref name=\"Tex\">{{cite web|url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/2011-05-01/artistinterview.php|title=Amanda Shires|work=[[Texas Monthly]]|first=Jeff|last=Salamon|date=May 2011|access-date=December 22, 2011|format=free registration required}}</ref>\n\n==Musical career==\n[[File:Amanda Shires 2016.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Shires performing in 2016]]\nShires released her first solo album, the mostly instrumental ''Being Brave'', in 2005.  Four years later, having relocated to [[Nashville]],<ref name=\"Tex\" /> she released ''West Cross Timbers'' and in the same year released ''Sew Your Heart with Wires'', a collaboration with [[Rod Picott]].  Her next solo album, ''Carrying Lightning'' was released in 2011, followed by ''Down Fell The Doves'' in August 2013 and ''My Piece of Land'' in September 2016. The latter proved to be Shires' breakthrough, gaining her a nomination from the [[Americana Music Association]].\n\nShe toured extensively with Picott from 2006.<ref name=\"Tenn\">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2011/07/03/rod-picott-and-amanda-shires-stay-in-sync-as-touring-partners-couple/|title=Rod Picott and Amanda Shires stay in sync as touring partners, couple|last=Cooper|first=Peter|date=July 3, 2011|access-date=December 22, 2011|work=[[The Tennessean]]}}</ref>  She has also performed and recorded with [[Jason Isbell & the 400 Unit]], [[Devotchka]], [[Chris Isaak]], [[Thrift Store Cowboys]], [[Todd Snider]], [[Blackberry Smoke]], and [[Justin Townes Earle]].<ref name=\"NJ\">{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/music/index.ssf/2011/04/singer_and_violinist_amanda_sh.html|title=Singer and violinist Amanda Shires to appear in Asbury Park|first=Tris|last=McCall|author-link=Tris McCall|date=April 22, 2011|access-date=December 22, 2011|work=[[The Star-Ledger]]}}</ref>\n\nIn 2011, she appeared in the movie ''[[Country Strong]]'' as one of the musicians backing singer Kelly Canter, played by [[Gwyneth Paltrow]].<ref name=\"spin\">{{cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2011/05/amanda-shires-carrying-lightning-101-distribution/|title=Amanda Shires, 'Carrying Lightning'|first=David|last=Menconi|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|access-date=December 27, 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn 2011, Shires began attending [[Sewanee: The University of the South]], a small liberal arts university in [[Sewanee, Tennessee]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.texasmonthly.com/the-culture/no-strings-attached/|title=No Strings Attached|date=July 15, 2013|website=Texasmonthly.com}}</ref> She graduated with a Master's of Fine Arts in Poetry in 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.clarionledger.com/story/magnolia/entertainment/2018/06/19/mississippi-music-fondren-host-nashville-artist-amanda-shires/691031002/|title=Amanda Shires: From driving her van to sleeping in her own tour bus|newspaper=[[The Clarion-Ledger]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nashvillelifestyles.com/entertainment/music/exclusive-interview-with-amanda-shires/|title=Exclusive interview with Amanda Shires|first=Luke|last=Levenson|date=September 14, 2016|website=Nashville Lifestyles}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://ew.com/music/2018/07/31/amanda-shires-to-the-sunset-interview/|title=How poetry and fear influenced Amanda Shires' new album, 'To The Sunset'|magazine=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref>\n\nIn 2012, Shires was named Artist of the Year by ''Texas Music'' magazine, appearing on the publication's cover.\n\nShires won the Emerging Artist of the Year Award at the 2017 [[Americana Music Honors & Awards]]. In 2017, she supported [[John Prine]] on his worldwide tour alongside Isbell for select dates. In 2018, Shires announced that she was working on a new album, ''To The Sunset'' due for release on August 3, 2018<ref>{{Cite tweet |user=amandashires|number=987059026520363009|title=August 3 y'all!|first=Amanda|last=Shires|date=April 19, 2018}}</ref> which, like ''My Piece of Land'', would be produced by [[Dave Cobb]]. Isbell revealed on Twitter that [[Gillian Welch]] and [[David Rawlings]] will make a guest appearance.<ref>{{Cite tweet|user=JasonIsbell|number=951993213887369216|title=Gillian came by to sing on the @amandashires album today and it was so good buddies [Image]|first=Jason|last=Isbell|date=January 12, 2018}}</ref> As a member of the 400 Unit, Shires won the [[Grammy Award for Best Americana Album]] for ''[[The Nashville Sound]]''. Shires contributed to ''[[The Tree of Forgiveness]]'', the 2018 album by [[John Prine]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/allsongs/2018/02/08/584219320/john-prine-to-release-his-first-album-of-new-songs-in-13-years|title=John Prine To Release His First Album Of New Songs In 13 Years|website=NPR|date=8 February 2018|last1=Ganz|first1=Jacob}}</ref> ''To The Sunset'' was released on August 3, 2018.\n\nIn 2019, Shires formed the country group [[The Highwomen]], along with [[Brandi Carlile]], [[Natalie Hemby]], and [[Maren Morris]]. \"Redesigning Women\" was the first single from their [[The Highwomen (album)|self-titled debut album]] released on September 6, 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/the-highwomen-redesigning-women-video/|title = The Highwomen Light the Ultimate Bonfire in 'Redesigning Women' Video &#91;Watch&#93;| date=19 July 2019 }}</ref> Following her 2021 holiday album ''For Christmas'', Shires released her seventh solo album ''[[Take It Like a Man (Amanda Shires album)|Take It Like a Man]]'' on July 26, 2022.\n\n==Musical style==\nDavid Menconi of the magazine ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' said that Shires \"sings [...] like an earthbound [[Emmylou Harris]]\",<ref name=\"spin\" /> and her vocals have been likened to those of [[Dolly Parton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2011-11-25/amanda-shires-carrying-lightning/|title=Amanda Shires \u2013 Music Review|work=[[Austin Chronicle]]|date=November 25, 2011|access-date=December 22, 2011|first=Jim|last=Caligiuri}}</ref><ref name=\"WSJ\" />  The imagery in her songwriting has been compared to that of [[Tom Waits]].<ref name=\"Chron\" /><ref name=\"WSJ\" />  Although her principal instrument is the fiddle, she also plays the [[ukulele]].<ref name=\"WSJ\">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703778104576287120887903538|title=Amanda Shires, Texas Playgirl|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=April 29, 2011|access-date=December 22, 2011}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nShires began dating fellow musician [[Jason Isbell]] in 2011.  The couple married on February 23, 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lubbockonline.com/entertainment/2012-07-25/happily-engaged-shires-makes-return-appearance-hometown#.USsmWB29nng|title=Happily engaged Shires makes return appearance in hometown|work=Lubbock Avalanche-Journal|date=July 25, 2012|access-date=February 25, 2013|first=William|last=Kerns}}</ref> and had their first child<ref>{{Cite tweet|first = Amanda |last=Shires Isbell|user=amandashires|number=640666061235486720|title=So happy and grateful to have Mercy Rose Isbell in the world. \ud83d\udcf7- @nateburrell|access-date = 2015-11-17}}</ref> on September 1, 2015.<ref name=DemChronicle-TourPreview-2015>{{cite news|last1=Spevak|first1=Jeff|title=Jason Isbell: The craft of sadness at Water Street|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/lifestyle/columnist/spevak/2015/05/19/jason-isbell-craft-sadness-water-street/27567259/|access-date=1 June 2015|work=[[Democrat & Chronicle]]|date=19 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Instagram-Baby-2015>{{cite web|last1=Isbell|first1=Jason|title=jasonisbell on Instagram: \"Today\"|url=https://instagram.com/p/7GRGleFDyh/ |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/s/instagram/7GRGleFDyh |archive-date=2021-12-24 |url-access=registration|website=[[Instagram]]|access-date=1 September 2015|date=1 September 2015}}{{cbignore}}</ref> She was previously in a relationship with singer [[Rod Picott]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://glidemagazine.com/168681/amanda-shires-interview/|title=Amanda Shires Strikes Solo Magic On 'My Piece of Land' & Talks Family Life with Husband Jason Isbell|first=Lee|last=Zimmerman|date=August 18, 2016|access-date=June 2, 2021|work=Glide Magazine}}</ref>  In December 2023, Isbell filed for divorce from Shires.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/jason-isbell-amanda-shires-file-divorce-1234948340/|title=Jason Isbell Files for Divorce From Amanda Shires|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|first=David|last=Browne|date=February 7, 2024|accessdate=February 8, 2024|url-access=limited}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Solo albums===\n*''Being Brave''
