years_active    = 2009\u20132014\n| label           = sensibility<!-- label stylized with a non-capital s -->, [[Columbia Records|Columbia]]\n| associated_acts =\n| website         =\n| current_members =\n| past_members    = * [[Joy Williams (singer)|Joy Williams]]\n* [[John Paul White]]\n}}\n\n'''The Civil Wars''' were an American musical duo composed of [[Joy Williams (singer)|Joy Williams]] and [[John Paul White]]. Formed in 2008, The Civil Wars won four Grammy Awards prior to their 2014 breakup.<ref name=HR>{{cite news|last1=Bernstein|first1=Ian|title=The Civil Wars' Self-Titled Album: What the Critics Are Saying|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/civil-wars-titled-album-what-599905|access-date=August 30, 2014|publisher=the Hollywood Reporter|date=August 6, 2013}}</ref><ref name=wp>{{cite news|last1=Yahr|first1=Emily|title=The Civil Wars break up for good but try to let fans down as gently as possible|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/style-blog/wp/2014/08/06/the-civil-wars-break-up-for-good-but-try-to-let-fans-down-as-gently-as-possible/|access-date=August 30, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=August 6, 2011}}</ref>\n\n==History==\n===2008\u20132010===\nBoth Williams and White had solo careers prior to meeting at a songwriting workshop in Nashville in 2008. Williams had recorded several moderately successful albums and was signed as a songwriter to Warner/Chappell; White had independently released ''The Long Goodbye''\u2014which was originally set to be released through a deal with Capitol Records\u2014and was writing for EMI Music.  At the workshop, approximately 25 songwriters were assembled by music publishers to write [[hit singles|radio singles]] for an unnamed band later identified as the country group [[Gloriana (band)|Gloriana]].  Williams and White were randomly paired to write together, and quickly discovered an affinity.  In a 2012 interview, Williams said that \"when he started singing it was like I knew where he was going to go before he went there.\"  In the same interview, White said that when he and Williams \"started singing together, there was this weird click; it was like there was a dance going where I knew I could lead her but she could lead me, too.\" Following the workshop, White and Williams made immediate plans to meet again.  They wrote the song \"Falling\" during their first session, which took place at Williams' house.<ref name=\"How We Met\">{{cite news|last1=Richman|first1=Simmy|title=How We Met: Joy Williams & John Paul White|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/how-we-met-joy-williams--john-paul-white-7574200.html|access-date=August 27, 2014|work=The Independent|date=March 18, 2012}}</ref><ref name=\"Nashville Scene - Long Bio\">{{cite news|last1=Gold|first1=Adam|title=How The Civil Wars fought for artistic independence and broadsided Music Row|url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashville/how-the-civil-wars-fought-for-artistic-independence-and-broadsided-music-row/Content?oid=2673301|access-date=August 30, 2014|publisher=Nashville Scene|date=November 10, 2011|archive-date=August 8, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808042903/http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashville/how-the-civil-wars-fought-for-artistic-independence-and-broadsided-music-row/Content?oid=2673301|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nLooking for a name for the project, Williams came up with the Civil Wars, which has no historical meaning, but rather is based on the quote \"be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a great battle\" attributed to [[Ian Maclaren]].<ref>{{cite web|url= https://quoteinvestigator.com/2010/06/29/be-kind/|accessdate=29 September 2021|title= Be Kind; Everyone You Meet is Fighting a Hard Battle|website=[[Quote Investigator]]|date=June 29, 2010 }}</ref> According to Williams, \"as I was thinking about the music we make, that sense of battle seemed applicable.\"<ref name=\"New York Times\">{{cite news|last1=McKinley|first1=James C.|title=Their Year of Living Almost Famously|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/26/arts/music/talking-to-joy-williams-and-john-paul-white-of-the-civil-wars.html|access-date=August 30, 2014|work=The New York Times|date=October 25, 2011}}</ref>  The duo performed for the first time as The Civil Wars at the French Quarter Cafe in Nashville on April 7, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Reverte|first1=Michelle|title=Interview: Joy Williams and John Paul White of The Civil Wars|url=http://laist.com/2011/06/13/the_civil_wars.php|website=laist.com|publisher=The LAIST|access-date=August 29, 2014|date=June 13, 2011|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140609031600/http://laist.com/2011/06/13/the_civil_wars.php|archive-date=June 9, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>  Williams' former producer [[Charlie Peacock]] was in attendance, and impressed by their dynamics and on-stage chemistry, began working with them the following day.<ref name=\"Charlie Peacock Interview\">{{cite web|last1=Inglis|first1=Sam|title=The Civil Wars chose to avoid the usual studio trickery for their debut album, and have reaped great success as a result.|url=http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/apr12/articles/the-civil-wars.htm|website=soundonsound.com|publisher=Sound on Sound|access-date=August 29, 2014|date=April 2012}}</ref>  On April 8, 2009, Shalom Aberle recorded The Civil Wars' second live show, opening for [[Will Hoge]] at [[Eddie's Attic]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Civil Wars - Live at Eddie's Attic (Credits)|url=http://www.discogs.com/Civil-Wars-Live-At-Eddies-Attic/release/2745375|website=discogs.com|date=June 30, 2009 |publisher=Discogs|access-date=September 1, 2014}}</ref> Eight of the songs that were recorded that night were on ''[[Live at Eddie's Attic]]'', which was released through Sensibility Music on June 30, 2009 as a free download on The Civil Wars' website.  In addition to a live and demo version of \"Falling\", the record included \"Poison & Wine\", covers of [[Leonard Cohen|Leonard Cohen's]] \"[[Dance Me to the End of Love]]\", and [[Sade (band)|Sade's]] \"[[No Ordinary Love]]\", and \"If I Didn't Know Better\", which was later covered in an episode of ''[[Nashville (2012 TV series)|Nashville]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Black|first1=Elizabeth|title=Why Is The Music Of Nashville So Good? A Look At The Songs And Songwriters From The Show's First Three Episodes|url=http://www.vh1.com/music/tuner/2012-10-25/why-is-the-music-of-nashville-so-good-a-look-at-the-songs-and-songwriters-from-the-shows-first-three-episodes/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028094621/http://www.vh1.com/music/tuner/2012-10-25/why-is-the-music-of-nashville-so-good-a-look-at-the-songs-and-songwriters-from-the-shows-first-three-episodes|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 28, 2012|website=vh1.com|publisher=VH1|access-date=August 29, 2014|date=October 25, 2012}}</ref> Released through Sensibility Music, a recording, marketing, licensing and management company established by Williams and her husband, Civil Wars manager Nate Yetton, ''Live at Eddie's Attic'' had been downloaded more than 700,000 times as of 2014.\n\nIn November 2009, \"Poison & Wine\" was used in its entirety as a music bed for a pivotal montage at the end of a sixth-season episode of ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]''. At the time, the song was available only on ''[[Live at Eddie's Attic]]''. White, Williams and Yetton found out about the placement only four days prior to the episode's airing.  They uploaded the newly recorded version of the song to iTunes, and created a music video for \"Poison & Wine\" in an afternoon.  As the video was being put online, Williams and White were watching the ''Grey's Anatomy'' episode, and the uploading was completed almost to the second that the last note of the song played.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Civil Wars: A Chance Meeting, An Internet Sensation|url=https://www.npr.org/2011/02/12/133686499/the-civil-wars-a-chance-meeting-an-internet-sensation|website=npr.org|publisher=NPR|access-date=August 29, 2014|date=February 12, 2007}}</ref>  Through ''Grey's Anatomy'', The Civil Wars were exposed to a substantial national audience, which included [[Taylor Swift]], who declared her love for The Civil Wars via [[Twitter]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wyland|first1=Sarah|title=The Civil Wars Have a Superfan in Taylor Swift|url=http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2011/02/04/the-civil-wars-have-a-superfan-in-taylor-swift/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110209035606/http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2011/02/04/the-civil-wars-have-a-superfan-in-taylor-swift/|url-status=dead|archive-date=February 9, 2011|website=blog.gactv.com|publisher=Great American Country|date=February 4, 2007}}</ref> \"Poison & Wine\" was released a week after ''Grey's Anatomy'' aired, and debuted at #4 on the iTunes Singer/Songwriter chart.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Civil Wars, Lucy Schwartz|url=http://calendar.boston.com/athens_ga/events/show/157286665-the-civil-wars-lucy-schwartz|website=calendar.boston.com|publisher=Boston Magazine|access-date=August 29, 2014|date=February 7, 2011}}</ref>  The duo toured consistently throughout 2009 and 2010.<ref name=gigography>{{cite web|title=Civil Wars Gigography|url=http://www.songkick.com/artists/2500436-civil-wars/gigography?page=1|website=Songkick.com|access-date=August 30, 2014}}</ref>\n\n===2011===\n[[File:The Civil Wars, Dublin.JPG|thumb|The Civil Wars performing at The Sugar Club, [[Dublin]] in September 2011]]\nWilliams, White, and Peacock returned to the Art House to record The Civil Wars debut album, ''[[Barton Hollow]], '' which was released on February 1, 2011.  Recorded in the studio's sanctuary and in the more conventional Studio A Live Room, the production was built around vocals, acoustic guitar and piano, with drums, percussion and [[Overdubbing|overdubs]] largely absent. Aided in part by a January appearance on ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'' and support from Swift, [[Hillary Scott]] of [[Lady A]], and [[Sara Bareilles]], ''Barton Hollow'' was the #1 downloaded album on iTunes the week it was released.  It also charted at #1 on the [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] Digital Albums chart, #1 on the Billboard Folk Albums chart, #2 on the Rock Albums Chart, and at #10 on the ''Billboard 200''.<ref name=Billboard>{{cite web|last1=Billboard Staff|title=The Civil Wars Billboard (aggregated content)|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/394095/civil-wars|website=billboard.com|publisher=Billboard|access-date=August 29, 2014}}</ref><ref name=\"Wash Post\">{{cite news|last1=Stewart|first1=Allison|title=Be specific: The Civil Wars talk about life as country-folk's newest phenoms|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/click-track/post/be-specific-the-civil-wars-talk-about-life-as-country-folks-newest-phenoms/2011/05/20/AFL8jn7G_blog.html|access-date=August 29, 2014|newspaper=Washington Post|date=May 20, 2011}}</ref><ref name=AP>{{cite news|last1=Associated Press|title=Taylor's tweet helps The Civil Wars win fans|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2011/03/17/1057752/taylors-tweet-helps-the-civil.html|access-date=August 29, 2014|agency=AP|publisher=News Observer|date=March 17, 2011|archive-date=September 11, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140911185311/http://www.newsobserver.com/2011/03/17/1057752/taylors-tweet-helps-the-civil.html|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n''Barton Hollow'' received significant critical acclaim. The [[BBC]] wrote \"A timeless, anachronistic record, ''Barton Hollow'' could be from 30 years ago, or it could be from 30 years hence. What\u2019s certain, though, is that you truly feel it in the here and now,\" while the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' wrote \"With care and delicacy, they curate their notes, stitching together a sound that's sharp, arch and almost achingly fine.\"<ref>{{cite news|last1=Farber|first1=Jim|title=The Civil Wars 'Barton Hollow' album review: 'Grey's Anatomy' 'Poison and Wine' hit makers haunt|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/civil-wars-barton-hollow-album-review-grey-anatomy-poison-wine-hit-makers-haunt-article-1.137815|access-date=August 29, 2014|work=New York Daily News|date=February 1, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Pearlman|first1=Mischa|title=The Civil Wars Barton Hollow Review|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/jrnv|website=bbc.co.uk|publisher=BBC|access-date=August 29, 2014}}</ref> The album appeared on the \"Best of 2011\" lists for [[NPR Music]],<ref>(2011, December 8) [http://npr.org/2011/12/05/142860882/50-favorites-b-e NPR Music: 50 Favorite Albums of 2011]. NPR. Retrieved December 10, 2011.</ref> ''[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rollingstone.com/music/photos/readers-poll-the-best-new-artists-of-2011-20120102 |title=Readers' Poll: The Best New Artists of 2011 Pictures |publisher=Rolling Stone |access-date=August 7, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120429153206/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/photos/readers-poll-the-best-new-artists-of-2011-20120102 |archive-date=April 29, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> and ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'',<ref>Smith, Grady. (December 24, 2011) [http://ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20326356_20555036_21096371,00.html#21096374 15 Breakout Stars of 2011] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006104608/http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20326356_20555036_21096371,00.html#21096374 |date=October 6, 2014 }}, ''Entertainment Weekly''. Retrieved December 25, 2011.</ref> among others, and it was listed at #9 in the \"Top 10 of Everything in 2011\" in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Suddath|first1=Claire|title=The Top 10 Everything of 2011|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2101344_2101364_2101591,00.html|access-date=August 29, 2014|publisher=TIME|date=December 7, 2011}}</ref>\n\nFor most of the year, White and Williams toured the US and Canada non-stop.  In May and June, they toured with [[Adele]], who wrote on her blog, \"I have the complete honour of having a band called The Civil Wars on the tour at the moment. They are by far the BEST live band I have EVER seen.\"<ref>{{cite web|last1=Adele|title=Adele: The Civil Wars|url=http://www.adele.tv/blog/298/the-civil-wars|website=adele.tv|publisher=Adele (Blog)|access-date=August 29, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903101207/http://www.adele.tv/blog/298/the-civil-wars|archive-date=September 3, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref> They toured with Adele in Europe later in the year, prior to the international release of ''Barton Hollow''.  By October, ''Barton Hollow'', which was released independently through Sensibility, had sold more than 195,000 copies.<ref name=gigography />  In November, The Civil Wars put out a 4-song EP, ''Tracks in the Snow''.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Civil Wars: Tracks in the Snow|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/tracks-in-the-snow-mw0002263886|website=allmusic.com|publisher=All Music|access-date=August 30, 2014}}</ref>\n\nThe Civil Wars were nominated for a 2011 [[Country Music Association]] Award in the Vocal Duo of the Year category,<ref name=\"Adele\">Smyth, David (October 2, 2011) [http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/music/article-23992938-the-adele-effect.do The Adele Effect] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103104342/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/music/article-23992938-the-adele-effect.do |date=January 3, 2012 }}, ''Evening Standard'' (London). Retrieved October 18, 2011.</ref><ref>Freeman, Jon (September 6, 2011) [http://musicrow.com/2011/09/cma-nominations-first-round CMA Nominations Revealed]. Retrieved 2011-11-11, from MusicRow.com</ref> and in the Duo/Group of the Year and Emerging Artist of the Year categories for the [[Americana Music Honors & Awards|Americana Music Awards]].<ref>Fahey, Linda (October 18, 2011) [https://www.npr.org/2011/10/05/141016659/the-mix-americana-music-awards The Mix. Americana Music Awards]. NPR. Retrieved October 18, 2011.</ref> They received the Vanguard Award at the 49th Annual ASCAP Country Music Awards,<ref>[http://www.ascap.com/press/2011/1006_TheCivilWars.aspx The Civil Wars. ASCAP Vanguard Award]. ASCAP. October 6, 2011. Retrieved October 18, 2011.</ref>\n\nAlso in 2011, Williams and White teamed with Taylor Swift and [[T-Bone Burnett]] to write \"[[Safe & Sound (Taylor Swift song)|Safe & Sound]]\", a track for ''[[The Hunger Games: Songs from District 12 and Beyond]]''.  The song,  performed by The Civil Wars and Swift, and produced by Burnett, was written and recorded in a single day.  It was released on iTunes in the US December 26.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vena|first1=Jocelyn|title=Taylor Swift's 'Safe & Sound' Came Together 'Organically'|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1679213/taylor-swift-safe-and-sound-civil-wars/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903191529/http://www.mtv.com/news/1679213/taylor-swift-safe-and-sound-civil-wars/|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 3, 2014|website=mtv.com|publisher=MTV|access-date=August 30, 2014|date=February 13, 2012}}</ref>\n\n===2012===\n[[File:The Civil Wars 2012.jpg|thumb|The Civil Wars in 2012]]\nWhite and Williams again began the year on tour.  In February in Los Angeles, The Civil Wars won two Grammy Awards for ''Barton Hollow'':  Best Folk Album and Best Country Duo/Group Performance.  They performed part of \"Barton Hollow\" on the Grammy telecast, and introduced Swift, who played \"[[Mean (Taylor Swift song)|Mean]].\"<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vena|first1=Jocelyn|title=Taylor Swift Hits Stage With Civil Wars At Grammys|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1679095/grammys-2012-taylor-swift-performance/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903172855/http://www.mtv.com/news/1679095/grammys-2012-taylor-swift-performance/|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 3, 2014|website=mtv.com|publisher=MTV|access-date=August 30, 2014|date=February 2, 2012}}</ref>  In March, ''Barton Hollow'' was released internationally and Williams and White completed their first European tour. Later in the year, just as ''Barton Hollow'' was certified gold in the US,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Paulsen|first1=Dave|title=The Civil Wars 'Barton Hollow' certified gold, band celebrates at Grimey's|url=http://blogs.tennessean.com/tunein/2012/09/13/the-civil-wars-barton-hollow-certified-gold-band-celebrates-at-grimeys/|access-date=August 30, 2014|publisher=The Tennessean|date=September 13, 2012}}</ref> they began working on their second full-length album with Charlie Peacock,<ref name=\"NPR Ann P\">{{cite web|last1=Powers|first1=Ann|title=Watch The Civil Wars Live Up To Their Name In A Behind-The-Scenes Video|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/therecord/2013/07/15/201089924/watch-the-civil-wars-live-up-to-their-name-in-a-behind-the-scenes-video|website=npr.org|publisher=NPR|access-date=August 30, 2014|date=July 15, 2013}}</ref> which they wrote while on the road at the suggestion of [[Rick Rubin]], who also produced a track for the album.<ref name=\"Rolling Stone break up\">{{cite news|last1=Gold|first1=Adam|title=Civil Wars' Joy Williams: 'We Haven't Been on Speaking Terms'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/civil-wars-joy-williams-we-haven-t-been-on-speaking-terms-20130805|access-date=August 30, 2014|publisher=Rolling Stone|date=August 5, 2013}}</ref> On October 28, White and Williams began their first extensive tour in the UK and Europe.<ref name=gigography />  On November 6, after a performance at the Roundhouse in London, they announced that they were cancelling the remaining tour dates, due to \"internal discord and irreconcilable differences of ambition.\"<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dauphin|first1=Chuck|title=Civil Wars Cancel Tour, Citing 'Internal Discord'|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/474286/civil-wars-cancel-tour-citing-internal-discord|access-date=August 30, 2014|publisher=Billboard|date=November 6, 2012}}</ref><ref name=\"NYT break up\" /> They offered no further explanation, although in a 2013 interview with ''The New York Times'', Williams said their last performances were \"excruciating.\"<ref name=\"NYT break up\">{{cite news|last1=McKinley|first1=James C.|title=The Break Up Album, 9 Months After|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/04/arts/music/from-the-civil-wars-an-aptly-named-album.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|access-date=August 30, 2014|work=The New York Times|date=August 2, 2013}}</ref>\n\n===2013===\nIn January, Williams and White released ''The Civil Wars: Unplugged on VH1'' exclusively through [[iTunes Store|iTunes]]. The seven-song album was recorded when The Civil Wars did a VH1 Unplugged set in early 2012.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Graham|first1=Mark|title=Relive The Magical Civil Wars Unplugged Set Over And Over Again|url=http://www.vh1.com/music/tuner/2013-01-15/the-civil-wars-vh1-unplugged/|website=vh1.com|publisher=VH1|access-date=August 30, 2014|date=January 15, 2013|archive-date=September 3, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903171721/http://www.vh1.com/music/tuner/2013-01-15/the-civil-wars-vh1-unplugged/|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn February, Williams, White, Swift and Burnett won the Grammy Award for Best Song Written For Visual Media for \"Safe & Sound\", which was also nominated for a [[Golden Globe]]. The following month, it was announced that The Civil Wars had teamed with Burnett to record the soundtrack for ''[[A Place at the Table]]'', a documentary that examined the role hunger plays in the lives of American families. Burnett and The Civil Wars recorded 14 new songs\u2014together and separately\u2014for the soundtrack. The proceeds from the soundtrack, recorded in Austin in 2011, were donated to the Participant Foundation. It was released on February 26.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rogers|first1=D. Patrick|title=The Civil Wars team With T Bone Burnett for A Place at the Table Documentary Soundtrack, Donate Proceeds to Charity|url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashvillecream/archives/2013/02/13/the-civil-wars-team-with-t-bone-burnett-for-a-place-at-the-table-documentary-soundtrack-donate-proceeds-to-charity|access-date=August 30, 2014|publisher=Nashville Scene|date=February 13, 2013|archive-date=September 11, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140911133740/http://www.nashvillescene.com/nashvillecream/archives/2013/02/13/the-civil-wars-team-with-t-bone-burnett-for-a-place-at-the-table-documentary-soundtrack-donate-proceeds-to-charity|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n''[[The Civil Wars (album)|The Civil Wars]]'', the album that White and Williams had begun recording with Peacock in mid-2012, was released in August through Sensibility/Columbia. White remained at his home in Florence, Alabama with his wife and four children, while Williams and Peacock did interviews to support the release. Peacock said that the strain was evident from the start of the recording process, and that White and Williams seemed to be pulling in different directions. Williams disclosed that she and White hadn't spoken since the record was completed.<ref name=\"Rolling Stone break up\" /><ref name=\"NYT break up\" />  The album entered the US ''Billboard'' charts and the digital charts at No.&nbsp;1, and debuted in the UK at No.&nbsp;2. ''Barton Hollow''\u2014which spent five weeks in the Top 40\u2014moved to the top position on the catalog charts.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Grein|first1=Paul|title=Week Ending Aug. 11, 2013. Albums: The Civil Wars, On Hiatus And On Top|url=https://music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart-watch/week-ending-aug-11-2013-albums-civil-wars-145540604.html|website=yahoo.com|publisher=Yahoo!|date=August 14, 2013}}</ref>\n\n''Between the Bars'', a four-song EP that covered [[Elliott Smith]]'s title track, [[Portishead (band)|Portishead's]] \"Sour Times\", [[Michael Jackson]]'s \"[[Billie Jean]]\" and [[The Romantics]]' \"[[Talking in Your Sleep (The Romantics song)|Talking in Your Sleep]]\" was released in the late 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Boilen|first1=Bob|title=The Civil Wars Cover Elliott Smith|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/allsongs/2014/02/05/272133904/the-civil-wars-cover-elliott-smith|website=npr.org|publisher=NPR|access-date=August 30, 2014|date=February 6, 2014}}</ref>\n\n===2014===\nIn February, White and Williams won their fourth Grammy, this time for the track \"From This Valley\" from ''The Civil Wars''. It won for Best Country Duo/Group Performance.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Civil Wars Win Best Country Duo/Group Performance|url=http://www.grammy.com/videos/the-civil-wars-win-best-country-duogroup-performance-0|website=Grammy.org|access-date=August 30, 2014|date=January 26, 2014}}</ref>\n\nThe Civil Wars announced that they would permanently part ways on August 5, and offered a free download of \"[[You Are My Sunshine]]\" as a parting gift.  Williams wrote: \"I am saddened and disappointed by the ending of this duo, to say the very least. JP is a tremendous musician, and I will always be grateful for the music we were able to create together.\" White's statement read: \"I would like to express sincere thanks to all who were a part of the arc of The Civil Wars\u2014from the beginning, to the end, and all points in between.\"<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gibson|first1=Megan|title=The Civil Wars Officially Split Up|url=http://time.com/3085522/the-civil-wars-officially-split-up/|access-date=August 30, 2014|publisher=Time|date=August 5, 2014}}</ref>\n\n===2023===\nIn 2023, they individually participated in a [[Re-recording (music)|re-recording]] of \"[[Safe & Sound (Taylor's Version)|Safe & Sound]]\" with Taylor Swift, credited under their individual names.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2023/music/news/taylor-swift-unreleased-new-songs-eras-tour-1235556815/|title=Taylor Swift Is Dropping Four Unreleased Songs Ahead of Her Eras Tour Start|first=Julia|last=MacCary|website=Variety.com|date=March 16, 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|The Civil Wars discography}}\n* ''[[Barton Hollow]]'' (2011)\n* ''[[The Civil Wars (album)|The Civil Wars]]'' (2013)\n<!-- If a discography exists, only studio albums should be listed -->\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"John_Bunzow","to":"John Bunzow"}],"pages":{"41894038":{"pageid":41894038,"ns":0,"title":"John Bunzow","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American country music singer-songwriter|bot=PearBOT 5}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = John Bunzow\n| image           =\n| image_size      =\n| birth_name      =\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1951|05|02}}\n| birth_place     = [[Portland, Oregon]]\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre           = [[Americana (music)|Americana]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1995\u2013present\n| label           = [[Liberty Records|Liberty]], ZoDog, Sideburn\n| associated_acts = [[Pete Anderson]]\n| website         = {{url|www.johnbunzow.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''John Bunzow''' (born May 2, 1951<ref name=\"whitburn\">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|page=69|year=2008|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}}</ref>) is an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter. Bunzow was signed to [[Liberty Records]] and charted one single on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart.\n\n==Career==\nBunzow was signed to [[Liberty Records]] (which was then the name of the [[Capitol Records Nashville|Nashville subsidiary of Capitol Records]]) and released his debut single, \"Easy as One, Two, Three\", in 1995.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hurst|first=Jack|title=Getting Personal|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/1995/04/09/getting-personal-16/|access-date=February 9, 2014|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=April 9, 1995}}</ref> Deborah Evans Price of ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' gave the song a favorable review, writing that \"Bunzow plays it simple, but keeps things interesting by throwing in some nifty chord-change curves.\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Price|first=Deborah Evans|title=Single Reviews|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3QsEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22john%20bunzow%22%20%22easy%20as%20one%22&pg=PT58|accessdate=February 9, 2014|newspaper=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=March 11, 1995}}</ref> It peaked at number 69 on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart.<ref name=\"whitburn\" /> Liberty planned to release Bunzow's album, ''Stories of the Years'', on May 23, 1995.<ref>{{cite web|title=''Stories of the Years'' \u2013 John Bunzow|url={{AllMusic|class=album/release|id=mr0000852324|pure_url=yes}}|work=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=February 9, 2014}}</ref> Pemberton Roach of [[AllMusic]] gave the album three stars out of five, calling it \"a refreshingly direct, no-nonsense country record that had more in common with [[Steve Earle]]'s best work than with any dance-club pretty boys.\"<ref>{{cite web|last=Roach|first=Pemberton|title=''Stories of the Years'' review|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000644440|pure_url=yes}}|work=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=February 9, 2014}}</ref> [[Alanna Nash]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the album an A grade, writing that Bunzow blends \"an amiable tenor with economy of language and the minimalistic production of [[Dwight Yoakam]] collaborator [[Pete Anderson]].\"<ref>{{cite news|last=Nash|first=Alanna|title=Stories of the Years Review|url=https://ew.com/article/1995/08/25/stories-years/|access-date=February 9, 2014|newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=August 25, 1995}}</ref> After [[Jimmy Bowen]] left Liberty Records in March 1995 and the label returned to its Capitol Nashville name, the album was shelved and Bunzow was dropped.<ref name=\"depression\">{{cite news|last=Griffith |first=Paul |title=John Bunzow \u2013 Liberated from the dark |url=http://archives.nodepression.com/2002/11/liberated-from-the-dark/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110830071056/http://archives.nodepression.com/2002/11/liberated-from-the-dark/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=August 30, 2011 |accessdate=February 9, 2014 |newspaper=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]] |date=November 2002 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Cox|first=Pasti Bale|title=The Garth Factor: The Career Behind Country's Big Boom|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OQPa4BAIVxQC&q=%22john%20bunzow%22&pg=PT129|publisher=[[Hachette Book Group USA|Hachette Digital, Inc.]]|date=May 28, 2009|isbn=978-1-599-95275-8}}</ref>\n\nBunzow continued writing and performing.<ref name=\"depression\" /> A compilation of material Bunzow wrote for publishing companies in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], ''Off the Shelf'', was released by ZoDog Records in 2000.<ref name=\"tribune\">{{cite news|last=Cullivan|first=Rob|title=Bunzow: Will play for food|url=http://cni.pmgnews.com/component/content/article?id=80390|accessdate=February 9, 2014|newspaper=[[Portland Tribune]]|date=December 23, 2008}}</ref> In 2002, Bunzow recorded an album, ''Darkness and Light'', which was released by independent label Sideburn Records.<ref name=\"depression\" /> Bob Gottlieb of [[AllMusic]] gave the album four stars out of five, calling it \"a strong disc that rips into each new song with a strong ferocity that brings the song home.\"<ref>{{cite web|last=Gottlieb|first=Bob|title=''Darkness and Light'' review|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=mw0000221054|pure_url=yes}}|work=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=February 9, 2014}}</ref> Bunzow also released a live album, ''Alive at O'Connor's'', in 2004.<ref name=\"tribune\" />\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"honeyhoney","to":"Honeyhoney"}],"pages":{"42632810":{"pageid":42632810,"ns":0,"title":"Honeyhoney","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American musical group}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = honeyhoney\n| image           =\n| caption         =\n| years_active    = 2006\u20132017\n| origin          = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], United States\n| genre           = [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[alternative country]], [[indie rock]]\n| label           = [[Ironworks (record label)|Ironworks]]<br>honeyhoney Records/Lost Highway<br>[[Rounder Records|Rounder]]\n| current_members = Benjamin Jaffe - Guitar, Vocals<br>Suzanne Santo - Vocals, Banjo, Violin\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.honeyhoneyband.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Honeyhoney''' (stylized as honeyhoney) was an [[Americana (music)|Americana]] group based in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], United States.\n\n==History==\nThe band was formed in 2006 by musician [[Benjamin Jaffe]] and musician/model/actress [[Suzanne Santo]].  The two met at a costume party and signed a record deal a year later.<ref name=\"pastemagazine1\">{{cite news |last=Leahey |first=Andrew |url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2008/12/band-of-the-week-honeyhoney.html |title=Band of the Week: honeyhoney |work=Paste |date=December 1, 2008 |accessdate=May 1, 2014 |archive-date=May 2, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502013430/http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2008/12/band-of-the-week-honeyhoney.html |url-status=dead }}</ref>  They originally performed under the name Zanzibar Lewis and were under that name when they signed with the now-defunct [[Ironworks (record label)|Ironworks]] record label.<ref name=\"Bluegrass\">{{cite web |url=http://www.thebluegrassspecial.com/archive/2009/march2009/honeyhoneymarch09.php |title=Opposites Attract, And honeyhoney Settles In For a Long Run |work=The Bluegrass Special |date=March 2009 |accessdate=August 2, 2016 |author=McGee, David}}</ref>\n\nTheir debut album, ''[[First Rodeo]]'', was released by Ironworks on November 4.<ref name=\"Bluegrass\"/>  Ironworks co-owner [[Kiefer Sutherland]] directed and starred in the group's music video for their song \"Little Toy Gun\".<ref>{{cite news |last=Zouves |first=Natasha |url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/the-scene/events/Honeyhoney-Makes-Sweet-Sexy-Music-99580479.html |title=Honeyhoney Makes Sweet, Sexy Music |work=KNBC |date=July 30, 2010 |accessdate=May 1, 2014}}</ref>  Honeyhoney toured with [[Lifehouse (band)|Lifehouse]], another Ironworks band, at the start of their career.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mousertime.blogspot.com/2011/08/honeyhoney-interview-with-suzanne-santo.html |title=HoneyHoney Interview with Suzanne Santo and Ben Jaffe |website=Mousertime.blogspot.com |date=August 25, 2011 |accessdate=May 1, 2014}}</ref>  The band released their second studio album, ''[[Billy Jack (album)|Billy Jack]]'', on Oct 24, 2011 under their own honeyhoney Records/Lost Highway label.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://theboot.com/honeyhoney-billy-jack-new-album/ |title=honeyhoney to Release 'Billy Jack' Album With Lost Highway |work=The Boot |date=August 23, 2011 |accessdate=August 2, 2016 |author=Galperinia, Marina}}</ref>\n\nTheir third album, ''[[3 (honeyhoney album)|3]]'', was produced by Dave Cobb and released June 9, 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.glidemagazine.com/137163/honeyhoney-iii-album-review/ |title=HoneyHoney - 3 (Album Review) |first=Jeff |last=Strowe |work=Glide Magazine |date=June 9, 2015 |accessdate=July 16, 2015}}</ref>  The website ''[[American Songwriter]]'' reviewed it writing, \"with a singer-songwriter that exudes the magnetic passion and swaggering star power of Santo, this is a group whose time has come.\"<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2015/06/honeyhoney-iii/ |title=HoneyHoney: 3 |first=Hal |last=Horowitz |work=American Songwriter |date=June 9, 2015 |accessdate=July 16, 2015}}</ref>\n\nThe duo parted with Rounder and disbanded in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2018-05-11 |title=Benjamin Jaffe Dives Into \u2018Oh, Wild Ocean of Love\u2019 While HoneyHoney Take Deep Breath, PopMatters |url=https://www.popmatters.com/benjamin-jaffe-honeyhoney-2567493784.html |access-date=2023-09-20 |website=PopMatters |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Carroll |first=Felix |date=2022-03-04 |title=On a break from a world tour, Benjamin Jaffe will join old friends at The Egremont Barn spaghetti western soundtracks and swampy blues.\"<ref name=\"pastemagazine1\"/>\n\n''Glide Magazine'' stated that \"honeyhoney deftly mixes elements of folk, soul, country, pop, and rock.\"<ref>{{cite 2014}}</ref>\n\n==Outreach==\nIn April 2014, the band traveled to [[Williamstown, Massachusetts]], where Jaffe was raised, to perform a concert on behalf of local music programs.  The band is planning a similar concert for schools in Santo's hometown of [[Cleveland, Ohio]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iberkshires.com/story/46183/Mount-Greylock-Alum-Jaffe-Returns-to-Perform-Benefit-Concert.html?source=most_read |title=Mount Greylock Alum Jaffe Returns to Perform Benefit Concert Cambridge Folk Festival 50th Anniversary.jpg\n| image_upright     = 1.1\n| alt               = \n| caption           = Jason Isbell performing at the [[Cambridge Folk Festival]], August 2014\n| birth_name        = Michael Jason Isbell<ref name=BMI-RepertoireProfile>{{cite web|url=http://repertoire.bmi.com/Catalog.aspx?detail=writerid&page=1&fromrow=1&torow=25&keyid=887074&subid=0|title=Songwriter/Composer: Isbell Michael Jason |work=[[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI]] |access-date=July 3, 2017}}</ref>\n| birth_date        = {{birth date and age|1979|02|01}}\n| birth_place       = [[Green Hill, Alabama]], U.S.\n| genre             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Americana (music)|Americana]]\n* [[Folk music|folk]]\n* [[Southern rock]]\n}}\n| occupation        = Musician\n| instrument        = {{flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* guitar\n* piano\n}}\n| years_active      = 1995\u2013present\n| label             = {{flatlist|\n* Lightning Rod\n* [[New West Records|New West]]\n* Southeastern\n* [[Thirty Tigers]]\n}}\n| current_member_of = The 400 Unit\n| past_member_of    = [[Drive-By Truckers]]\n| spouse            = {{plainlist|\n* {{Marriage|[[Shonna Tucker]]|2002|2007|reason=div}}\n* {{Marriage|[[Amanda Shires]]|2013|2024|reason=div}}\n}}\n| website           = {{URL|jasonisbell.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Michael Jason Isbell''' ({{IPAc-en|\u02c8|\u026a|z|b|\u028a|l|}};<ref name=\"WTF-Maron-2014\">{{cite web|url=http://www.wtfpod.com/podcast/episodes/episode_482_-_jason_isbell|title=Episode 482 \u2013 Jason Isbell|last=Maron|first=Marc|date=March 26, 2014|format=podcast|url-access=subscription |work=[[WTF with Marc Maron]]|access-date=March 27, 2014}}</ref> born February 1, 1979) is an American singer-songwriter. He is known for his solo career, his work with the band The 400 Unit, and as a member of [[Drive-By Truckers]] for six years, from 2001 to 2007.<ref name=AllMusic-bio>{{cite web|last=Monger|first=James Christopher|title=Jason Isbell \u2013 Biography|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/jason-isbell-mn0000562615/biography|work=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=March 27, 2014}}</ref><ref name=GQ-3CountryBadasses-2016>{{cite news|last1=Welch|first1=Will|title=Meet Three Country Badasses Who Are Shaking Up the Nashville Establishment|url=https://www.gq.com/story/meet-the-country-badasses-from-nashville|access-date=January 10, 2016|work=[[GQ]]|date=January 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name=GQ-KingAmericana-2016>{{cite news|last1=Welch|first1=Will|title=The GQ&A: Jason Isbell, the New King of Americana Music|url=https://www.gq.com/story/jason-isbell-king-of-americana-music|access-date=January 10, 2016|work=[[GQ]]|date=January 7, 2016}}</ref> Isbell has won six [[Grammy Award]]s.\n\nOutside of music, Isbell has appeared in roles in the television series ''[[Squidbillies]]'' and ''[[Billions (TV series)|Billions]]'', as well as the films ''[[Deadwood: The Movie]]'' and ''[[Killers of the Flower Moon (film)|Killers of the Flower Moon]]''.\n\nHis most recent album with his band The 400 Unit, ''[[Weathervanes (Jason Isbell and the 400 Unit album)|Weathervanes]]'', was released in June 2023.\n\n== Early life ==\nIsbell was born in [[Green Hill, Alabama]], two miles ({{convert|2|mi|km|0|disp=out}}) from the [[Alabama]]/[[Tennessee]] state line,<ref name=\"SpinItLoud-2009\">{{cite web|url=http://spinitloud.com/?p=61|title=Jason Isbell|year=2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140327234639/http://spinitloud.com/?p=61|archive-date=March 27, 2014|work=Spin It Loud|access-date=March 27, 2014}}</ref> the son of interior designer Angela Hill Barnett and house painter Mike Isbell.<ref name=NYT-Mag-2013>{{cite news|last=Garner|first=Dwight|title=Jason Isbell, Unloaded|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/02/magazine/jason-isbell-unloaded.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|access-date=March 27, 2014|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 31, 2013}}</ref><ref name=CarthelIsbell-obit-2002>{{cite web|title=Carthel E. Isbell|url=http://www.timesdaily.com/archives/article_da82aae8-fbfe-5442-bd58-3b12e009e648.html?mode=jqm|work=Florence Times Daily|date=September 19, 2002}}</ref> Isbell's mother was only 17 years old (and his father 19 years old) when he was born<ref name=\"HuffPo-SMTF-2015\">{{cite news|last1=Bialas|first1=Michael|title=During the Long, Hot Summer, Jason Isbell Warms Up to Become One Glad Dad|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/michael-bialas/during-the-long-hot-summe_b_7966884.html|access-date=August 11, 2015|work=[[Huffington Post]]|date=August 10, 2015}}</ref> and is the subject of a song, \"Children of Children\".<ref name=\"CBS-SMTF-2015\">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/videos/the-fall-and-rise-of-jason-isbell/|title=The fall and rise of Jason Isbell|last=Mason|first=Anthony|date=August 9, 2015|work=[[CBS News]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150810043151/http://www.cbsnews.com/videos/the-fall-and-rise-of-jason-isbell/|archive-date=August 10, 2015|access-date=August 9, 2015}}</ref> Isbell's parents divorced, and he has two much younger half-siblings.<ref name=\"WTF-Maron-2014\" />\n\nIsbell grew up in [[North Alabama]]. His grandparents lived on a farm down the road next to the school that Isbell attended; they looked after him while his parents were at work. His grandfather and uncle taught him to play various instruments,<ref name=\"CBS-SMTF-Extra-2015\">{{cite news|last1=Mason|first1=Anthony|title=Jason Isbell on his musical education (web extra)|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/videos/jason-isbell-on-his-musical-education/|access-date=August 9, 2015|work=[[CBS News]]|date=August 8, 2015}}</ref> including the [[mandolin]] when he was six years old, as it was easier for him to grip as a small child. They enjoyed [[gospel music]], [[bluegrass music]], and the [[Grand Ole Opry]]. In high school, he played [[trumpet]] and [[French horn]].<ref name=\"WTF-Maron-2014\" /> Isbell's family would get together and play music every week, sometimes twice a week.<ref name=\"CharlestonCity-2011\">{{cite news|last=Booth|first=Jared|title=Jason Isbell talks writing, war, and family life|url=http://www.charlestoncitypaper.com/charleston/jason-isbell-rests-his-case/Content?oid=3345499|access-date=March 29, 2014|newspaper=[[Charleston City Paper]]|date=May 11, 2011}}</ref><ref name=\"IllEnt-2007\">{{cite web|last=Dodds|first=M.S.|title=Jason Isbell interview|url=http://illinoisentertainer.com/2007/06/jason-isbell-interview/|work=Illinois Entertainer|access-date=March 27, 2014|date=June 28, 2007}}</ref> Isbell's paternal grandfather, who came from a musical family, was a [[Pentecostalism|Pentecostal]] preacher and played guitar in church. Isbell spent his childhood attending both the Pentecostal church and the stricter [[Churches of Christ|Church of Christ]], which permitted only singing without musical instruments.<ref name=\"WTF-Maron-2014\" /><ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/jason-isbell-5-things-we-learned-from-new-interview-119150/|title=Jason Isbell: 5 Things We Learned From New Interview|first=Jeff|last=Gage|date=June 9, 2017|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=October 19, 2018}}</ref>\n\nIsbell started playing in a [[garage band]] and a country cover band when he was 14 or 15 years old with his friend, songwriter [[Chris Tompkins]].<ref name=\"RStone-Sober-2013\">{{cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jason-isbell-theres-still-just-as-much-awe-in-sobriety-20130801|title=Jason Isbell: 'There's Still Just as Much Awe' in Sobriety|last=Sullivan|first=James|date=August 1, 2013|newspaper=[[Rolling Stone]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160430095942/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jason-isbell-theres-still-just-as-much-awe-in-sobriety-20130801|archive-date=April 30, 2016|access-date=March 30, 2014}}</ref> They played at the [[Grand Ole Opry]] when Isbell was 16.<ref name=\"WTF-Maron-2014\" />\n\nIsbell attended the [[University of Memphis]],<ref name=\"ConnectSavannah-2014\">{{cite web|last=DeYoung|first=Bill|title=SMF review: Jason Isbell|url=http://www.connectsavannah.com/savannah/smf-review-jason-isbell/Content?oid=2369820|work=[[Connect Savannah]]|access-date=March 30, 2014|date=March 19, 2014}}</ref> studying English and creative writing. He dropped out, being short one credit, to go on tour.<ref name=\"WTF-Maron-2014\" /> In September 2023, after discussions with the University of Memphis about his career experience, he was awarded his bachelor's degree in English.<ref name=WaitWait>{{cite web|title='Wait Wait' for January 13, 2024: With Not My Job guest Jason Isbell|url=https://www.npr.org/programs/wait-wait-dont-tell-me/1224508708/wait-wait-for-january-13-2024-with-not-my-job-guest-jason-isbell?showDate=2024-01-13|work=National Public Radio|date=January 13, 2024}}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\nWhen Isbell was a teenager, many musicians took him under their wing.<ref name=RollingStone-SXSW-2011 /> He got to know session bassist [[David Hood]], father of [[Drive-By Truckers]] co-founder [[Patterson Hood]], because David Hood was in the [[Florence, Alabama]] area and played around town on Friday and Saturday nights in local restaurants and bars. By this time, Patterson Hood and his future Drive-By Truckers co-founder, [[Mike Cooley (musician)|Mike Cooley]],  were older and had moved out of town. Isbell would go watch David Hood and others perform. After he eventually found the nerve to tell them he played the guitar, they invited him to join them onstage, which resulted in friendship and mentorship.<ref name=WTF-Maron-2014 />\n\nIsbell submitted demos and eventually got a publishing deal with [[FAME Studios]] of [[Muscle Shoals, Alabama]], when he was 21. He worked with FAME for 15 years, through his solo album ''Southeastern''. Isbell also recorded pieces of his solo albums at FAME Studios, as well as the Drive-By Truckers' ''The Dirty South''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://famestudios.com/jason-isbell/|title = Jason Isbell & the 400 Unit \u2013 Fame Studios| date=September 28, 2018 }}</ref>\n\n=== Drive-By Truckers ===\n[[File:JasonIsbell.JPG|thumbnail|Isbell performing with the Drive-By Truckers in Auburn, Alabama, in 2005]]\nIn 2001, at age 22, Isbell joined the Drive-By Truckers while they toured in support of their album ''[[Southern Rock Opera]]''.<ref name=\"LostWriters-2006\">{{cite web|url=http://www.lostwriters.net/archive_popup.php?c=czozOiIyNDkiOw==|title=An Artist Revealed: Interview with Jason Isbell |last=Schmergel |first=Daniel Patrick |date=April 24, 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311124053/http://www.lostwriters.net/archive_popup.php?c=czozOiIyNDkiOw%3D%3D |archive-date=March 11, 2007 |work=Lost Writers |access-date=March 27, 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The band operated out of [[Athens, Georgia]], where Isbell lived while with the band. Co-founder [[Patterson Hood]] recalls that he met Isbell through Dick Cooper, a mutual friend from Muscle Shoals.<ref name=\"WTF-Maron-Hood-2014\">{{cite web|url=http://www.wtfpod.com/podcast/episodes/episode_483_-_patterson_hood|title=Episode 483 \u2013 Patterson Hood|last=Maron|first=Marc|date=March 28, 2014|format=podcast|url-access=subscription |work=[[WTF with Marc Maron|WTF Podcast]]|access-date=March 30, 2014}}</ref> Hood invited Isbell to join the Drive-By Truckers after he sat in with the group at an acoustic house party when guitarist Rob Malone did not show up.<ref name=\"AmSongwriter-2013\">{{cite web|last=Leahey|first=Andrew|title=Jason Isbell Keeps on Truckin'|url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2013/09/jason-isbell-keeps-on-truckin/|work=[[American Songwriter]]|access-date=March 30, 2014|date=September 17, 2013}}</ref>\n\nIsbell recorded and contributed many songs to the Drive-By Truckers for their next three albums, 2003's ''[[Decoration Day (album)|Decoration Day]],'' 2004's ''[[The Dirty South (album)|The Dirty South]],'' and 2006's ''[[A Blessing and a Curse]].'' The title track of ''Decoration Day'' was revealed by Isbell in the 2014 ''[[Live from Lincoln Center]]'' concert to be a true story about his family members.<ref name=\"LiveLincCenter-2014\">{{cite web|url=http://video.pbs.org/video/2365214488/|title=Live From Lincoln Center \u2013 Jason Isbell: Moving Forward|work=[[PBS]]|date=April 11, 2014|access-date=May 6, 2014}}</ref>\n\nFor most of his time as a band member, Isbell was married to [[Shonna Tucker]], who joined the band after Isbell as bassist. The two were part of the band's documentary, ''The Secret to a Happy Ending''.<ref name=\"ref name=SecretHappyEnd-2011\">{{cite web|last=Weissman|first=Barr|title=The Secret to a Happy Ending|work=The Secret to a Happy Ending: A Documentary About the Drive-By Truckers|url=http://thesecrettoahappyending.com/|publisher=Full House Films / [[ATO Records]]|access-date=May 7, 2014|format=DVD release of the 2009 motion picture|year=2011}}</ref> The two later divorced.<ref name=\"BostonGlobe-2007\">{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/music/articles/2007/07/15/hell_keep_on_trucking_but_solo/|title=He'll keep on trucking, but solo|last=Mitter|first=Siddhartha|date=July 15, 2007|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|url-access=subscription |access-date=March 27, 2014}}</ref>\n\nOn April 5, 2007, Isbell announced that he was no longer a member of the Drive-By Truckers. The following day, Patterson Hood confirmed the break on the band's official site. In his letter to the fans, Hood described the parting of ways as \"amicable\" and expressed the hope that fans would continue to support the Drive-By Truckers as well as Isbell's solo efforts.<ref name=Grantland-IsbellFired-2014>{{cite news|last1=Hyden|first1=Steven|title=Drive-By Truckers Carry On|url=http://grantland.com/features/drive-by-truckers-carry-on/|access-date=August 9, 2015|work=[[Grantland]]|date=March 4, 2014}}</ref> Isbell had been with the Drive-By Truckers for six years.<ref name=CBS-SMTF-2015 />\n[[File:Jimbo Hart and Jason Isbell.jpg|thumb|Jimbo Hart (left) and Isbell at Hardly Strictly Bluegrass in [[San Francisco]] on October 5, 2014]]\n\nOn June 15, 2014, Isbell teamed with Hood and Mike Cooley for a benefit at the Shoals Theater in [[Florence, Alabama]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Ells |first=Blake |url=http://countryfriedrock.org/hood-isbell-cooley-reunite-at-the-shoals-theater/#.Vzo0hk32bcs |title=Hood \u2013 Isbell \u2013 Cooley reunite at the Shoals Theater |publisher=Country Fried Rock |date=June 19, 2014 |access-date=June 16, 2017 |archive-date=September 18, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918235652/http://countryfriedrock.org/hood-isbell-cooley-reunite-at-the-shoals-theater/#.Vzo0hk32bcs |url-status=dead }}</ref> The sold-out acoustic performance was the first time Isbell had performed with his former bandmates since they split in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesdaily.com/life/music/article_527f311e-dc68-11e3-b2e4-0017a43b2370.html |title=Benefit show with Truckers, Isbell sold out |website=Timesdaily.com |date=May 15, 2014 |access-date=June 16, 2017}}</ref> In August 2015, Hood joined Isbell onstage and played a couple of Drive-By Truckers songs together in Hood's new adopted hometown of [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Oregon]].<ref name=\"Oregonian-IsbellHood-2015\">{{cite news|last1=Baker|first1=Jeff|title=Jason Isbell plays Drive-By Truckers songs with Patterson Hood at amazing Portland concert|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/music/index.ssf/2015/08/jason_isbell_plays_drive-by_tr.html|access-date=August 9, 2015|work=[[The Oregonian]]|date=August 9, 2015}}</ref>\n\n=== Solo work ===\nIsbell released his first solo album, ''[[Sirens of the Ditch]]'', on July 10, 2007. In 2012, Isbell supported singer-songwriter [[Ryan Adams]] on his tour. Both played solo acoustic sets.\n\nOn June 11, 2013, Isbell released his fourth solo album, ''[[Southeastern (album)|Southeastern]].'' Produced by [[Dave Cobb]] and featuring accompanying vocals by [[Kim Richey]] and Isbell's wife, [[Amanda Shires]], ''Southeastern'' received overwhelmingly positive critical reviews, earning a score of 87<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/southeastern/jason-isbell|title=Southeastern by Jason Isbell|website=Metacritic|access-date=May 10, 2016}}</ref> on [[Metacritic]].<ref name=\"CMT-Ryman-2013\">{{cite web|last=Parton|first=Chris|title=Jason Isbell Leaves a Mark at Ryman|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1712559/jason-isbell-leaves-a-mark-at-ryman.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130824071042/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1712559/jason-isbell-leaves-a-mark-at-ryman.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=August 24, 2013|work=[[CMT (TV channel)|CMT]]|publisher=Country Music Television, Inc.|access-date=March 30, 2014|date=August 19, 2013}}</ref> ''Southeastern'' led to Isbell's clean sweep of the [[Americana Music Honors & Awards|2014 Americana Music Awards]]. ''Southeastern'' won Album of the Year, Isbell was named Artist of the Year, and the song \"[[Cover Me Up]]\" was named Song of the Year.<ref name=\"NPR-Americana-2014\">{{cite web | title = Jason Isbell, Live at the 2014 Americana Music Awards |work= [[NPR]] | url = https://www.npr.org/event/music/364769222/jason-isbell-live-at-the-2014-americana-music-awards |author=Ann Powers|date=November 18, 2014| access-date = November 19, 2014}}</ref> It was later certified Gold by [[RIAA]] in 2022.<ref name=RIAA>{{cite certification|region=United States|artist=Jason Isbell|access-date=February 19, 2022}}</ref> [[NPR]] rock critic Ken Tucker listed ''Southeastern'' at No. 1 on his top ten albums of 2013. Isbell's record received praise by artists like [[Bruce Springsteen]] and [[John Prine]].<ref name=\"RollingStone-SMTF-2015\">{{cite magazine|last=Doyle|first=Patrick|title=Jason Isbell's New Morning|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/jason-isbells-new-morning-20150807|access-date=August 9, 2015|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=August 7, 2015}}</ref> The music video for the song \"Traveling Alone\" features the Jackson House, a historic home in [[Moulton, Alabama]].<ref name=TimesDaily-MusicVid-2013>{{cite news|last=Qualls|first=Meredith|title=Isbell's music video filmed in Moulton|url=http://www.timesdaily.com/life/music/article_d768c810-0b65-11e3-8caa-10604b9f7e7c.html|access-date=March 29, 2014|newspaper=TimesDaily|date=August 24, 2013|location=Florence, AL}}</ref>\n\nIsbell's fifth solo record, ''[[Something More Than Free]],'' was released on July 17, 2015, on Southeastern Records. [[Dave Cobb]] again produced the album, which was recorded at [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]]'s [[Sound Emporium Studios]] with a full band.<ref name=\"American-Songwriter-SMTF-2015\">{{cite news|last1=McKenna|first1=Brittney|title=Jason Isbell Announces New Album 'Something More Than Free'|url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2015/04/jason-isbell-announces-new-album-something-free/|access-date=April 17, 2015|work=[[American Songwriter]]|date=April 16, 2015}}</ref> During the summer of 2015, Isbell was on a North American tour to promote the album, with four consecutive sold-out nights at the [[Ryman Auditorium]] in Nashville at the end of October.<ref name=\"Radio-SMTF-2015\">{{cite web|url=http://radio.com/2015/04/16/jason-isbell-new-album-something-more-than-free-track-list-tour-dates/|title=Jason Isbell's New Album 'Something More Than Free' Coming in July|last=Wolff|first=Kurt|date=April 16, 2015|website=Radio.com|access-date=May 5, 2015}}</ref><ref name=\"GratefulWeb-SummerDates-2015\">{{cite web|url=http://www.gratefulweb.com/articles/jason-isbell-summer-tour-dates-announced |title=Jason Isbell Summer Tour Dates Announced |work=Grateful Web|date=May 4, 2015 |access-date=May 5, 2015}}</ref> In April 2016, Isbell appeared on the [[BBC]] live-music show ''[[Later... with Jools Holland|Later With Jools Holland]],'' singing \"The Life You Chose\", one of the tracks from ''Something More Than Free''.\n\nIsbell said that compared to ''Southeastern,'' ''Something More Than Free'' has a feeling of celebration,<ref name=\"RStone-SMTF-2015\">{{cite magazine|last1=Leahey|first1=Andrew|title=In the Studio With Jason Isbell Making 'Celebratory' New Album |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/in-the-studio-with-jason-isbell-making-celebratory-new-album-20150326|access-date=June 1, 2015|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=March 26, 2015}}</ref><ref name=\"FOLIOWkly-SMTF-2015\">{{cite news|last1=McGregor|first1=Nick|title=Jason Isbell's Workmanlike Genius|url=http://folioweekly.com/Jason-Isbells-Workmanlike-Genius,12502|access-date=June 1, 2015|work=FOLIO Weekly|date=May 6, 2015|archive-date=July 30, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150730233703/http://folioweekly.com/JASON-ISBELLS-WORKMANLIKE-GENIUS,12502|url-status=dead}}</ref> which reflects his upcoming fatherhood and a forward-facing momentum.<ref name=\"DailyTimes-SMTF-2015\">{{cite news|last1=Wildsmith|first1=Steve|title=Freedom Songs: Singer-songwriter Jason Isbell builds a better album than 'Southeastern'|url=http://www.thedailytimes.com/entertainment/freedom-songs-singer-songwriter-jason-isbell-builds-a-better-album/article_e18ba738-5f7c-53da-a784-f1c800de2aa1.html|access-date=June 1, 2015|work=The Daily Times (Maryville, TN)|date=May 6, 2015}}</ref> One track on the record, \"To a Band I Loved\", is a love-letter to the band [[Centro-Matic]], a now defunct band from [[Denton, Texas]], Isbell played with back in his Drive-By Truckers days.<ref name=\"RStone-SMTF-2015\" />\n\n''Something More Than Free'' debuted at number 1 on [[Billboard Magazine]]'s rock, folk and country record charts.<ref name=\"CBS-SMTF-2015\" /><ref name=\"Diffuser-SMTF-2015\">{{cite news|last=Kellmurray|first=Beth|title=Jason Isbell Celebrates the Chart Success of 'Something More Than Free'|url=http://diffuser.fm/jason-isbell-celebrates-the-chart-success-of-something-more-than-free/|access-date=August 9, 2015|work=[[Diffuser.fm]]|date=July 27, 2015}}</ref> Although Isbell had had critical success in the [[Americana (music)|Americana]] genre, this was the first time he received such high ranking across genres.<ref name=\"Billboard-SMTF-2015\">{{cite news|last=Hight|first=Jewly |title=Country Star (and Expectant Dad) Jason Isbell 'Glad to Have My Baby on the Brain'|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/6649631/jason-isbell-interview-something-more-than-free-parenthood-amanda-shires|access-date=August 9, 2015|work=[[Billboard Magazine]]|date=August 5, 2015}}</ref> The album was well received, winning two Grammy awards for Best Americana Album and Best American Roots Song (\"24 Frames\").<ref name=\"WSJ-SMTF-2015\">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/something-more-than-free-by-jason-isbell-review-1438726208|title='Something More Than Free' by Jason Isbell Review|date=August 4, 2015|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|url-access=subscription |last1=Mazor|first1=Barry|access-date=August 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2016 Grammy Awards: Complete list of winners and nominees|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-grammys-2016-nominees-winners-list-story.html|access-date=March 12, 2016|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=February 15, 2016}}</ref> On May 11, 2016, Isbell, a four-time winner, was nominated for three more [[Americana Music Honors & Awards]]: Album of the Year (''Something More Than Free''), Song of the Year (\"24 Frames\"), and Artist of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americanamusic.org/news/americana-honors-awards-nominees-announced |title=Americana Honors & Awards Nominees Announced |website=AmericanaMusic.org |date=September 21, 2016 |access-date=June 16, 2017}}</ref> He won the first two, while [[Chris Stapleton]] won Artist of the Year.\n\n==== Emergence of The 400 Unit ====\nIsbell's band, The 400 Unit, is primarily made up of musicians from the [[Muscle Shoals, Alabama]], area.<ref name=RollingStone-SXSW-2011>{{cite news|last=Helton|first=Eric|title=SXSW Interview: Jason Isbell|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/sxsw-interview-jason-isbell-20110318|access-date=March 27, 2014|newspaper=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=March 18, 2011|format=video interview}}</ref> {{as of|2023}}, the band's lineup was:<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Hudak |first=Joseph |date=2023-11-27 |title=Jason Isbell's Longtime Bassist Jimbo Hart Leaves the 400 Unit |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/jason-isbell-bassist-jimbo-hart-leaves-400-unit-1234899639/ |access-date=2024-01-14 |magazine=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref>\n* [[Sadler Vaden]], guitar, backup vocals \u2013 also of [[Drivin' N Cryin']]\n* Anna Butterss, bass guitar, upright bass\n* [[Derry deBorja]], keyboard, accordion, backup vocals \u2013 formerly of [[Son Volt]]\n* [[Chad Gamble]], drums, backup vocals \u2013 brother of [[Al Gamble]]\n* [[Will Johnson (musician)|Will Johnson]], guitar, backing vocals, drums/percussion, gong\n\nThe band's name comes from the 400 Unit, a colloquial name for the psychiatric ward of Eliza Coffee Memorial Hospital in [[Florence, Alabama]]. It was originally called the 400 Unit because it was in a separate building from the main three-story hospital. After renovation in the 1980s, the ward was renamed as the Behavioral Health Center, also known as 1st North, and is located on the hospital's first floor.<ref name=FAME-Isbell-400Unit>{{cite web|title=Jason Isbell \u2013 Current Artists|url=http://www.fame2.com/current-artists/|work=FAME Music Group|access-date=March 27, 2014|archive-date=March 12, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170312062820/http://www.fame2.com/current-artists/|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nJason Isbell and the 400 Unit's [[Jason Isbell and The 400 Unit (album)|eponymous album]] was released on February 17, 2009, on Lightning Rod Records. ''Jason Isbell and The 400 Unit'' was Isbell's second solo release and his first release with The 400 Unit. [[Matt Pence]] of [[Centro-Matic]] co-produced and engineered the record, as well as playing drums on the record. The band released their self-recorded and produced second album, ''[[Here We Rest]],'' on April 12, 2011, on Lightning Rod Records. The song \"Alabama Pines\" was named Song of the Year at the 2012 [[Americana Music Award]]s.\n\nOn March 13, 2017, Isbell announced a new album with the 400 Unit, ''[[The Nashville Sound]]'', which released in June of that year.<ref>{{Cite tweet|user=JasonIsbell|number=841317531491192832|title=June 16.|date=March 13, 2017}}</ref> The album was a critical success, with Isbell and the band winning the [[Grammy Award for Best Americana Album]] and Isbell capturing the [[Grammy Award for Best American Roots Song]] at the [[60th Annual Grammy Awards]]. In October 2017, Isbell was announced to be the official artist-in-residence at the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2017/10/16/jason-isbell-named-country-music-hall-fames-artist-in-residence/761975001/|title=Jason Isbell to perform at Country Music Hall of Fame as Artist-in-Residence|website=Tennessean.com}}</ref> The following year he made a guest appearance on [[John Prine]]'s album ''[[The Tree of Forgiveness]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/allsongs/2018/02/08/584219320/john-prine-to-release-his-first-album-of-new-songs-in-13-years|title=John Prine To Release His First Album Of New Songs In 13 Years|website=NPR|date=February 8, 2018|access-date=October 19, 2018|last1=Ganz|first1=Jacob}}</ref> Isbell also contributed the ballad \"Maybe It's Time\" to the soundtrack of the 2018 film ''[[A Star Is Born (2018 film)|A Star Is Born]]'', where it was performed by actor [[Bradley Cooper]]'s character, Jackson Maine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2018/08/a-star-is-born-soundtrack-release-date/|title='A Star Is Born' Soundtrack Announced}}</ref>\n\n''[[Reunions (album)|Reunions]]'', the band's next album, was announced in February 2020 and released on May 15 of that year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/jason-isbell-announces-new-album-reunions-share-new-song-be-afraid-listen/|title=Jason Isbell Announces New Album Reunions, Share New Song \"Be Afraid\": Listen|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|first=Sam|last=Sodomsky|date=February 10, 2020|access-date=February 11, 2020}}</ref> Isbell once again worked with producer [[Dave Cobb]] on the album which featured guest vocals by [[David Crosby]] as well as Jay Buchanan of [[Rival Sons]]. The album announcement was made alongside the release of the first song of the album, \"Be Afraid\", which peaked at an Isbell career high number 5 on the [[Adult Alternative Songs]] chart. The album's second single, \"Dreamsicle\" peaked at number 20 on the same chart.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/jason-isbell-new-song-be-afraid-950171/|title=Jason Isbell Previews New Album 'Reunions' With Urgent Anthem 'Be Afraid'|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|first=Joseph|last=Hudak|date=February 10, 2020|access-date=February 11, 2020}}</ref>\n\nOn November 5, 2020, Isbell announced on [[Twitter]] that if [[Joe Biden]] won the state of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] in the [[2020 United States presidential election]], he would record a charity album featuring covers of songs by Georgia artists, such as [[R.E.M.]] and [[Gladys Knight]]. After it was projected that Biden had [[2020 United States presidential election in Georgia|won the state]], he reaffirmed his pledge and said work would begin on the album shortly.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jason Isbell Says He'll Record a Georgia Covers Album If Biden Wins the State|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/jason-isbell-georgia-album-joe-biden-1086810/|website=Rollingstone.com|date=November 6, 2020}}</ref> The album, entitled ''[[Georgia Blue]]'', was formally announced on September 14, 2021, with release dates of October 15 for the digital version and November 26 for CD and vinyl.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Freeman, Jon |date=September 14, 2021 |title=Jason Isbell to Sing R.E.M., Otis Redding on ''Georgia Blue'' Covers Album |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/jason-isbell-georgia-blue-covers-album-songs-1225993/ |access-date=October 17, 2021 |magazine=Rolling Stone}}</ref> Isbell and the 400 Unit also contributed a cover of the Metallica song \"[[Sad but True]]\" to the charity tribute album ''[[The Metallica Blacklist]]'', released in September 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|last=He|first=Richard S.|date=2021-09-10|title=Every Metallica Blacklist cover ranked from worst to best|url=https://www.loudersound.com/features/every-metallica-blacklist-cover-ranked-from-worst-to-best|access-date=2021-10-22|website=loudersound|language=en}}</ref>\n\nIn June 2023, Isbell and the 400 Unit released the album, ''Weathervanes,'' on Isbell's own Southeastern Records label. The album, produced by Isbell, included the singles, \"Strawberry Woman,\" \"Cast Iron Skillet,\" and \"Miles.\" In February 2024, Isbell was nominated and won two grammy's for Best Americana Song, \"Cast Iron Skillet,\" and Best Americana album, \"Weathervanes.\"\n\n=== Acting ===\nIsbell's first acting role came in 2016 when he guest starred in the animated TV series ''[[Squidbillies]]'', providing the voice of pastor Kyle Nubbins. The show has featured other Americana singers in cameo roles, including [[Elizabeth Cook]], [[Todd Snider]], and the Drive-By Truckers, among others.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/see-jason-isbell-play-a-tattooed-preacher-on-squidbillies-101934/|title=See Jason Isbell Play a Tattooed Preacher on 'Squidbillies'|magazine=Rolling Stone|last=Leahey|first=Andrew|date=August 18, 2016|access-date=April 20, 2021}}</ref> In 2019, Isbell had a cameo as a guitar-playing wedding guest in the [[HBO]] film ''[[Deadwood: The Movie]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2021/04/06/jason-isbell-sturgill-simpson-cast-in-martin-scorseses-star-studded-killers-of-the-flower-moon/|title=Jason Isbell & Sturgill Simpson Cast In Martin Scorsese's Star-Studded \"Killers Of The Flower Moon\"|work=Whiskey Riff|last=Mies|first=Andrew|date=April 6, 2021|access-date=April 30, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/jason-isbell-deadwood-hbo-movie-827858/|title=Jason Isbell on 'Deadwood': W. Earl Brown Talks Americana Star's Cameo|magazine=Rolling Stone|last=Hudak|first=Joseph|date=April 26, 2019|access-date=April 30, 2021}}</ref> ''[[Billions (TV series)|Billions]]'', another TV series known for giving cameo roles to musicians, featured Isbell in a 2021 episode, with Isbell playing himself viewing an art exhibit.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stereogum.com/2160067/jason-isbell-on-billions/news/|title=Watch Jason Isbell Play Jason Isbell On Billions|work=Stereogum|last=Deville|first=Chris|date=September 8, 2021|access-date=October 29, 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn 2021, Isbell was cast in [[Martin Scorsese]]'s epic Western crime drama film ''[[Killers of the Flower Moon (film)|Killers of the Flower Moon]]'' (2023) as Bill Smith, a victim of the [[Osage Indian murders]]. Bill Smith was the white husband of an Osage woman who was a victim in the murder conspiracy that led to the deaths of many Osage.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.shortform.com/blog/bill-smith-osage/ | title=Bill Smith & Osage Terror (Killers of the Flower Moon) | date=June 14, 2020 }}</ref> Isbell's role in the film was announced on April 6, 2021, and marks his major on-screen acting debut; fellow country singer [[Sturgill Simpson]] was also announced as being part of the cast.<ref name=\"nme\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/en_asia/news/music/jason-isbell-and-sturgill-simpson-cast-in-scorseses-killers-of-the-flower-moon-2915534|title=Jason Isbell and Sturgill Simpson cast in Martin Scorsese's 'Killers Of The Flower Moon'|work=NME|last=Triscari|first=Caleb|date=April 7, 2021|access-date=April 7, 2021}}</ref>\n\n== Musical influences ==\nIsbell has spoken about the importance of his northern Alabama roots: \"I definitely don't feel like I would be the musician that I am, or the type of songwriter, had I not come from that particular place,\" he said in 2012. \"The soul music that came out of there, and a lot of the soul-influenced rock and roll and country music that came out of the studios in north Alabama in the 1960s and 1970s had a big influence on me.\"<ref name=Flagpole-Live-2012>{{cite web|last=Bailey|first=Rachel|title=Jason Isbell: That New Southern Style|url=http://flagpole.com/music/music-features/2012/11/28/jason-isbell|work=[[Flagpole Magazine]]|access-date=March 29, 2014|date=November 28, 2012}}</ref> Isbell said that working at FAME Studios was \"everything\" to him, that it was \"a gateway towards the music that he wanted to play.\"<ref name=CBS-SMTF-2015 /> In addition to citing [[Neil Young]] as a big influence, Isbell is a fan of singer-songwriter [[Ben Howard]] and guitarist [[Blake Mills]].<ref name=HuffPo-SMTF-2015 />\n\n== Personal life ==\nIsbell was previously married to [[Shonna Tucker]], a fellow musician from the [[Muscle Shoals, Alabama|Muscle Shoals]] community and a former bass player for [[Drive-By Truckers]]. They were married in 2002 and divorced in 2007.<ref name=\"NYT-Mag-2013\" />\n\nIn February 2012, [[Amanda Shires]], Isbell's manager Traci Thomas, and [[Ryan Adams]] initiated an [[intervention (counseling)|intervention]], leading to Isbell entering a rehabilitation treatment program at Cumberland Heights in Nashville.<ref name=\"NYT-Mag-2013\" /> Isbell has discussed getting [[sobriety|sober]] extensively, saying he drank [[Jack Daniel's]] and did [[cocaine]] during his time with Drive-By Truckers in his late 20s\u2014a time he does not remember very clearly.<ref name=\"FreshAir-NPR-2013\">{{cite web|last=Gross|first=Terry|title=Jason Isbell Locates His Musical Compass On 'Southeastern'|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/07/17/202369759/jason-isbell-locates-his-musical-compass-on-southeastern|work=[[Fresh Air]]|publisher=[[NPR]]|access-date=March 30, 2014|date=July 17, 2013}}</ref><ref name=\"HuffPo-Hangout-2013\">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/michael-bialas/hangout-and-about-part-1_b_3205051.html|title=Hangout and About, Part 1: Jason Isbell is Solo, But Not Alone|last=Bialas|first=Michael|date=May 3, 2013|newspaper=[[Huffington Post]]|access-date=March 30, 2014}}</ref> ''Southeastern'', Isbell's 2013 solo album, is reflective of his newfound sober lifestyle.<ref name=\"NPR-SE-sobriety-2013\">{{cite web|last=Block|first=Melissa|title=Jason Isbell: A 'Southeastern' Songwriter's Path To Sobriety|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/06/10/190372187/jason-isbell-a-southeastern-songwriters-path-to-sobriety|work=[[All Things Considered]]|publisher=[[NPR]]|access-date=May 7, 2014|format=Audio interview|date=June 10, 2013}}</ref>\n\nIsbell moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] in 2011 \u2013 where he has remained since.<ref name=\"AmSongwriter-2013\" /><ref name=\"SeriousEats-2012\">{{cite web|last=Portman|first=Jed|title=Down South: Southern Rock Star Jason Isbell on Cracker Barrel, Cornbread Poetry, and 9, 2012|access-date=March 30, 2014|newspaper=[[CMT (TV channel)|CMT]]|date=July 25, 2012}}</ref> He married the singer-songwriter and [[violinist]] Shires, with whom he had worked on and off for a decade, in February 2013 \u2013 two days after they finished work on ''Southeastern.''<ref name=\"LATimes-2013\" /><ref name=\"LubbockAvJourn-2012\">{{cite web |last=Kerns |first=William |date=July name=\"Instagram-Baby-2015\">{{cite web |last1=Isbell |first1=Jason |date=September 1, 2015 |title=jasonisbell on Instagram: \"Today\" |url=https://instagram.com/p/7GRGleFDyh/ |url-access=registration |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/s/instagram/7GRGleFDyh |archive-date=December 26, 2021 |access-date=September 1, 2015 |website=[[Instagram]]}}{{cbignore}}</ref> On February 8, 2024, news was released that Isbell had filed for divorce from Shires in December 2023.<ref name=\"People\">{{cite news|last=DeSantis|first=Rachel|title=Jason Isbell Files for Divorce from Amanda Shires
