2024}}</ref>\n\nIsbell was friends with [[Justin Townes Earle]] and played guitar on several of Earle's albums, including [[Harlem River Blues]]. Isbell and Shires both performed in a 2023 tribute concert to Earle after his death from a fentanyl overdose in 2020.\n\nIsbell has a tattoo on the inside of his left arm with a quotation from the lyrics of the [[Bob Dylan]] song \"[[Boots of Spanish Leather]]\": \"Just carry yourself back to me unspoiled, from across that lonesome ocean.\"<ref name=\"LATimes-2013\">{{cite news|last=Lacher|first=Irene|title=The Sunday Conversation: A sobering change for singer Jason Isbell|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-jason-isbell-conversation-story.html|access-date=March 27, 2014|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=September 7, 2013}}</ref> He said that the quote \"reminds him about the idea of salvaging things\", that for him it \"evokes the idea of loss as well as learning and growing from the experience\".<ref name=\"CBS-SMTF-2015\" /> During the 2015 [[Newport Folk Festival]], Isbell cited Dylan as a huge influence on his writing.<ref name=\"Relix-DylansGuitar-2015\">{{cite news|title=Watch: Jason Isbell Plays Bob Dylan's Guitar from the 1965 Newport Folk Festival|url=https://www.relix.com/blogs/detail/watch_jason_isbell_plays_bob_dylans_guitar_from_the_1965_newport_folk_festival|access-date=August 9, 2015|work=[[Relix]]|date=August 6, 2015}}</ref>\n\nIsbell is politically [[left-wing]], frequently expressing his support for [[gun control]][[abortion-rights movements|, abortion rights]], [[Defund the police|policing reform]], [[LGBTQ rights movement|LGBTQ and transgender rights]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Uitti |first1=Jacob |title=Jason Isbell on Gun Control: \"I Know it Sometimes Seems Hopeless, but Let's Keep Trying\" |url=https://americansongwriter.com/jason-isbell-on-gun-control-i-know-it-sometimes-seems-hopeless-but-lets-keep-trying/ |website=American Songwriter |date=June 24, 2022 |access-date=12 July 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Whitfield |first1=Mark |title=Amanda Shires and Jason Isbell record pro-choice song |url=https://americana-uk.com/amanda-shires-and-jason-isbell-record-pro-choice-song-listen |website=Americana UK |date=October 2020 |access-date=12 July 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title='Love Rising': Moments from Nashville's all-star LGBTQ benefit concert |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2023/03/21/love-rising-moments-from-nashvilles-all-star-lgbtq-benefit-concert/70020390007/ |access-date=2024-01-14 |website=The Tennessean |language=en-US}}</ref> In one instance of the former, Isbell posted the following to [[Twitter]] on the day of the [[2019 Dayton shooting]]: \"If you're on here arguing the definition of '[[assault weapon]]' today you are part of the problem. You know what an assault weapon is, and you know you don't need one.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Thomas |first1=Elizabeth |title=Country music stars amplify calls for gun reform following deadly mass shootings |url=https://abcnews.go.com/US/country-music-stars-amplify-calls-gun-reform-deadly/story?id=64992475 |website=ABC News |access-date=12 July 2023}}</ref> A Twitter user by the name of William McNabb responded to Isbell, asking what he as a \"[[Rural areas in the United States|rural American]]\" should use to kill the \"30-50 [[feral pig|feral hogs]]\" in his yard. McNabb's tweet itself soon became an [[internet meme]], with Twitter users widely mocking him for what was perceived to be an absurd hypothetical question that was quizzically worded.<ref>{{cite web |title=30-50 Feral Hogs |url=https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/30-50-feral-hogs |website=Know Your Meme |date=August 5, 2019 |access-date=12 July 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Shafer |first1=Ellise |title=Jason Isbell Accidentally Started the Feral Hogs Twitter Meme |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/rock/jason-isbell-started-feral-hogs-twitter-meme-8526434/ |magazine=Billboard |access-date=12 July 2023}}</ref>\n\nIsbell performed at the [[2024 Democratic National Convention]] on August 19, 2024.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/politics/elections/2024/08/19/jason-isbell-mickey-guyton-set-to-perform-at-2024-dnc-what-to-know/74865857007/ | title=Mickey Guyton, Jason Isbell set to perform at the DNC Monday. Here's what to know | website=[[The Tennessean]] }}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:16em;\"| Title\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Nora_Jane_Struthers","to":"Nora Jane Struthers"}],"pages":{"45261856":{"pageid":45261856,"ns":0,"title":"Nora Jane Struthers","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Nora Jane Struthers\n| image            = Nora Jane Struthers promo.jpg\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1983|11|11}}\n| birth_place      = [[Fairfax, Virginia]], U.S.\n| origin           = [[Ridgewood, New Jersey]]\n| instruments      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre            = [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[folk rock]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/nora-jane-struthers-mw0001996773 | title=Nora Jane Struthers \u2013 Nora Jane Struthers | publisher=[[AllMusic]] | accessdate=February 18, 2015 | author=Henderson, Alex}}</ref> [[Country music|country]]\n| occupation       = Singer, songwriter, band leader\n| years_active     = 2008\u2013present\n| label            = Blue Pig Music\n| website          = [[URL|norajanestruthers.com]]\n}}\n\n'''Nora Jane Struthers''' (born November 11, 1983) is an American singer-songwriter based in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] who is notable for her critically acclaimed [[Americana (music)|Americana]] and roots rock. ''Rolling Stone Country'' debuted a video for \"Let Go\" from Struthers' album ''Wake'' with an article in which Stephen L. Betts wrote that \"the ever-widening scope of Nora Jane Struthers' musicality means that placing a neat, easy label on the genre she best represents is virtually impossible.\"<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Betts |first=Stephen L. |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/premieres/nora-jane-struthers-and-the-party-line-shatter-societal-pressure-in-let-go-video-20150114 |title=Watch Nora Jane Struthers and the Party Line's 'Let Go' Video |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=January 14, 2015 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref> In a post for [[Amy Poehler]]'s blog ''Smart Girls'', Alexa Peters wrote that \"Nora Jane is entirely and unequivocally herself, and wants to encourage you to do the same.\"<ref name=\"amysmartgirls1\">{{cite web |author=Alexa Peters |url=http://amysmartgirls.com/2015/01/smartists-norah-jane-struthers/ |title=Smartists: Nora Jane Struthers &#124; Smart Girls at the Party |publisher=Amysmartgirls.com |accessdate=February 19, 2015 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20150201232436/http://amysmartgirls.com/2015/01/smartists-norah-jane-struthers/ |archivedate=February 1, 2015 }}</ref> [[National Public Radio (United States)]] described Struthers as \"quietly brilliant\" in article headlined \"Country Music's Year of the Woman.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/therecord/2013/06/06/188997881/country-musics-year-of-the-woman |title=Country Music's Year of the Woman : The Record |publisher=NPR |date=n.d.|accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref> Struthers' 2013 album ''Carnival,'' recorded with her touring band The Party Line, spent more than three months in the Top 20 of Americana Radio charts and peaked at No. 7.<ref name=\"engine2\">{{cite web |url=http://www.engine145.com/sideshows-and-sequins-nora-jane-struthers-carnival |title=Sideshows and Sequins: Nora Jane Struthers' Carnival |publisher=Engine 145 |date=September 5, 2013 |accessdate=February 19, 2015 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218215221/http://www.engine145.com/sideshows-and-sequins-nora-jane-struthers-carnival/ |archivedate=February 18, 2015 }}</ref> ''Carnival'' ranked 24th on the 2013 Americana Airplay Top 100 list.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://americanamusic.org/americana-announces-2013-top-10-top-100-jason-isbells-southeastern-tops-chart|title=Americana announces 2013 Top 10/ Top 100; Jason Isbell's, Southeastern Tops chart!|publisher=Americana Music|accessdate=February 19, 2015|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218182055/http://americanamusic.org/americana-announces-2013-top-10-top-100-jason-isbells-southeastern-tops-chart|archivedate=February 18, 2015}}</ref> In a review of ''Carnival'', the ''Tampa Bay Times'' wrote that Struthers' unique brand of \"rich storytelling, repeat-worth melodies and a modern mashup of traditional, bluegrass folk, country and rock influences\" sets her apart from many roots-inspired contemporaries.<ref name=\"tampabay1\">{{cite web|url=https://www.tampabay.com/things-to-do/music/nora-jane-struthers-and-the-party-lines-carnival-is-an-americana-gem/2115516/ |title=Nora Jane Struthers and the Party Line's 'Carnival' is an Americana gem |work=Tampa Bay Times |date=n.d.|access-date=February 19, 2015}}</ref>\n\n==Early life and education==\nStruthers was born in [[Fairfax, Virginia]] six months before her family moved to [[Avon, Connecticut|Avon, Conn]]. When Struthers was four years old the family moved again to [[Ridgewood, New Jersey]]. She grew up singing and playing music with her father Alan Struthers, a bluegrass musician.<ref name=\"engine2\"/> Struthers was named Nora by her parents after [[Nick and Nora Charles|Nora Charles]], a character in Dashiell Hammett's novel [[The Thin Man]], and Jane after English author [[Jane Austen]]. Her family called her Jane, but Nora stuck in school when that name was used for calling roll in kindergarten.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norajanestruthers.com/biography/ |title=Biography |publisher=Nora Jane Struthers |date=June 20, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>\n\nStruthers said as a little girl she would often watch out the front window for her father at the end of the day and greet him with a yodel and the two frequented bluegrass festivals and fiddler conventions along the East Coast as she got older.<ref name=\"engine2\"/>\n\nStruthers was diagnosed with dyslexia at the age of four, when a reading specialist told her parents that Nora Jane would never go to college.<ref name=\"amysmartgirls1\"/> She ultimately proved the reading specialist wrong, however, studying English Education and Africana Studies at New York University's School of Education. After graduating in 2005, Struthers worked as a teacher at The Williamsburg Charter High School in [[Brooklyn]], New York until 2008.<ref name=\"huffingtonpost1\">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/michael-bialas/faces-of-telluride-part-3_b_877219.html |title=Faces of Telluride, Part 3: Nora Jane Struthers, Fresh Face &#124; Michael Bialas |work=HuffPost |date=June 15, 2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nStruthers played shows with her father under the name Dirt Road Sweetheart and the duo released an album titled ''I Heard The Bluebirds Sing'' on May 11, 2008. In 2008, Struthers gave up her job as a teacher and moved to Nashville to pursue a career as a full-time musician. She soon began touring with a band of rotating musicians she dubbed The Bootleggers and ultimately won the prestigious [[Telluride Bluegrass Festival]] band contest in June 2010.<ref name=\"engine2\"/>\n\nStruthers released a self-titled debut solo album on July 10, 2010. ''Nora Jane Struthers'', produced by Brent Truitt, featured established musicians such as multi-instrumentalist Tim O'Brien and fiddler Stuart Duncan.<ref name=\"huffingtonpost1\"/>\n\nStruthers joined [[Americana music|Americana]] acoustic quintet [[Bearfoot (American band)|Bearfoot]] later in 2010 and the group released the album ''[[American Story (album)|American Story]]'' in 2011, which featured six songs written or co-written by Struthers. One of them, \"Tell Me a Story,\" became a top-rated video on [[Country Music Television|CMT]].<ref name=\"huffingtonpost1\"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eventseeker.com/artist/49984-nora-jane-struthers|title=Nora Jane Struthers \u2013 Artist Profile|date=n.d.|website=eventseeker.com|access-date=March 4, 2020}}</ref>\n\nStruthers had written a collection of songs for a new solo album by 2012 and launched a Kickstarter campaign that raised $22,000 in less than four weeks to help fund it. She formed a touring band called The Party Line and released the 14-track ''Carnival'' on April 16, 2013, again produced by Truitt.<ref name=\"huffingtonpost1\"/>\n\nStruthers and The Party Line gave nearly 150 live performances across the U.S. in 2013. Struthers said she achieved a childhood dream by playing in the Saturday Night All Star Jam at the Grey Fox Bluegrass Festival in [[Oak Hill, New York]] that year.<ref>{{cite web |author=Paul Wallen |url=http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/nora-jane-struthers-banner-year |title=Nora Jane Struthers' Banner Year |publisher=The Bluegrass Situation |date=January 14, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219165254/http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/nora-jane-struthers-banner-year |archive-date=February 19, 2015 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\nStruthers and The Party Line released a six-song record titled ''Country EP No. 1'' in July 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norajanestruthers.com/discography/country-ep-no-1/ |title=Country EP No. 1 |publisher=Nora Jane Struthers |date=July 1, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref> One of the tracks, a cover of [[The Everly Brothers]] classic \"(Til) I Kissed You\" was featured on a collection of Americana music called ''Native: Americana Spotlight'', released on September 9, 2014 on Tone Tree Music.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/native-americana-spotlight/id912894515 |title=iTunes Music \u2013 Native: Americana Spotlight by Various Artists |publisher=iTunes Store |date=September 9, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>\n\nStruthers and The Party Line have recorded a new full-length studio album called ''Wake'', featuring 11 original songs. ''Wake'' is slated to be released in February 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norajanestruthers.com/discography/wake/ |title=Wake |publisher=Nora Jane Struthers |date=June 20, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>\n\nDirt Road Sweetheart a father-daughter duo (Nora Jane and Alan Struthers) released a new album 'Rose of My Heart' on June 16, 2019 under the label of Blue Pig Music.\n\nIn February 2020, Nora announced her fifth studio album titled 'Bright Lights, Long Drives, First Words'.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/nora-jane-struthers-new-song-nice-to-be-back-home-new-album-915757/|title=Nora Jane Struthers Previews New Album With Contented 'Nice to Be Back Home'|date=November 21, 2019|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=March 4, 2020}}</ref>\n\n==Reception==\nReception\nGrammy Award-winning musician Tim O'Brien said \"Old time music continues to reinvent itself in the able hands of young artists like Nora Jane Struthers.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norajanestruthers.com/press/ |title=Press Kit |publisher=Nora Jane Struthers |date=November 20, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>\n\nKim Ruehl wrote for [[NPR Music]] that Struthers has a \"voice as sweet as honeysuckle.\"<ref>{{cite web|last=Ruehl |first=Kim |url=https://www.npr.org/event/music/176172165/nora-jane-struthers-the-party-line-hootenanny-anyone |title=Nora Jane Struthers & The Party Line: Hootenanny, Anyone? |publisher=NPR |date=April 13, 2013 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>\n\nA ''[[Tampa Bay Times]]'' reviewer called Carnival an \"Americana gem\" writing that \"the album never fades through 14 tracks, a testament to the songwriting and musical arrangements.\"<ref name=\"tampabay1\"/>\n\nThe video for Struthers' song \"Bike Ride\" from the album ''Carnival'' debuted at No. 1 on [[Country Music Television]] Pure's 12-Pack Countdown in November 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norajanestruthers.com/bike-ride-debuts-at-1/ |title=Bike Ride Debuts at #1!!! |publisher=Nora Jane Struthers |date=November 23, 2013 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n;Studio albums\n*''I Heard The Bluebirds Sing'', as Dirt Road Sweetheart, a duo with her father Alan Struthers (2008)\n*''Nora Jane Struthers'' (2010)\n*''Carnival'' (2013)\n*''Wake'' (2015)\n*''Champion'' (2017)\n*''Bright Lights, Long Drives, First Words'' (2020)\n*''Back To Cast Iron'' (2023)\n\n;EPs\n*''Country EP No. 1'' (2014)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n{{authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Struthers, Nora Jane}}\n[[Category:1983 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:People from Fairfax, This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"The_War_and_Treaty","to":"The War and Treaty"}],"pages":{"61384852":{"pageid":61384852,"ns":0,"title":"The War and Treaty","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American music duo}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = The War and Treaty\n| image             = TheWarAndTreaty_2021.png\n| caption           = Tanya and Michael, 2021\n| image_size        = \n| alias             = \n| origin            = [[Albion, Michigan|Albion]], [[Michigan]], [[United States|US]]\n| genre             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Americana (music)|Americana]]\n* [[Southern soul]]\n* [[Blues music|blues]]\n* [[Folk music|folk]]\n* [[Rock music|rock]]\n* [[Gospel music|gospel]]\n}}\n| years_active      = 2014\u2013present\n| label             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Universal Music Group Nashville|UMG Nashville]]\n* [[Mercury Nashville]]\n}}\n| associated_acts   = {{flatlist|\n* [[Jason Isbell]]\n* [[Jerry Douglas]]\n* [[Chris Eldridge]]\n* [[Emmylou Harris]]\n}}\n| website           = {{URL|thewarandtreaty.com}}\n| current_members   = * Michael Trotter Jr.\n* [[Tanya Trotter]]\n}}\n'''The War and Treaty''' are an American husband and wife duo consisting of singer-songwriters Michael Trotter Jr. and [[Tanya Trotter]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-war-and-treaty-mn0003749672/biography|title=The War and Treaty Biography|website=[[AllMusic]]|first=Marcy|last=Donelson|accessdate=October 18, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Bernstein|first=Jonathan|date=2020-09-18|title=The War and Treaty's Journey Toward Hope|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/war-treaty-hearts-town-interview-1059146/|access-date=2021-03-03|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}}</ref> Their debut studio album ''[[Healing Tide]]'' (2018), received critical acclaim upon its release. Soon afterwards, they released their sophomore album ''Hearts Town'' (2020), which featured a collaboration with American singer [[Emmylou Harris]], and spawned the [[Adult Alternative Songs|Triple A]] top 40 hit single \"Five More Minutes\".<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-10-26 |title=Music is a matter of life, death, redemption for The War and Treaty's lead singers, Tanya and Michael Trotter |url=https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/entertainment/music/story/2022-10-26/music-a-matter-of-life-and-death-for-the-war-and-treatys-tanya-trotter-and-michael-trotter-jr |access-date=2023-11-11 |website=San Diego Union-Tribune |language=en-US}}</ref> In 2022, they signed to [[UMG Nashville]], and released their major label debut  ''[[Lover's Game]]'' (2023). Their collaboration with [[Zach Bryan]] on the song \"[[Zach Bryan (album)|Hey Driver]]\" reached the top 20 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. \n\nIn 2023, The War and Treaty became the first black duo to be nominated for the [[Country Music Association Award for Vocal Duo of the Year|Country Music Association Award for Duo of the Year]];<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-10-17 |title=CMA Awards 2023: Nominees, Host and How to Watch |url=https://wwd.com/pop-culture/culture-news/cma-awards-2023-how-to-watch-1235880149/ |access-date=2023-11-10 |website=WWD}}</ref> along with being the first black duo to be nominated for the [[Academy of Country Music Awards|Academy of Country Music Award]] for Duo of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-04-13 |title=Nominations Announced for the 58th Academy of Country Music Awards |url=https://www.acmcountry.com/news/nominations-announced-for-the-58th-academy-of-country-music-awards |access-date=2023-11-10 |website=www.acmcountry.com |language=en}}</ref> They have received two nominations for the [[66th Annual Grammy Awards]], including [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]]. An upcoming biopic based on the group\u2019s life is set to be released.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Willman |first=Chris |date=2024-01-16 |title=The War and Treaty: How the Best New Artist Grammy Nominees Came to Be \u2018Friends\u2019 With the Emmys, Too, and Win Over Superfan Zach Bryan |url=https://variety.com/2024/music/news/war-and-treaty-grammys-best-new-artist-nominee-emmys-in-memoriam-1235874511/ |access-date=2024-01-16 |website=Variety |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=D'Alessandro |first=Anthony |date=2022-06-06 |title=Gilbert Films, Get Lifted Film Co & Harvey Mason Media Producing \u2018The War And Treaty\u2019; Numa Perrier Directing |url=https://deadline.com/2022/06/the-war-and-treaty-numa-perrier-directing-1235039133/ |access-date=2024-01-16 |website=Deadline}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\nIn 2016, Michael Trotter Jr. and Tanya Blount released the duet album ''Love Affair'' as Trotter & Blount.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blackandmarriedwithkids.com/2013/06/power-couple-michael-tanya-trotter-blount/|title=Power Couple: Michael & Tanya Trotter (Blount)|work=Black and Married With Kids|first=Christine|last=St. Vil|date=13 June 2013|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref> In 2017, The War and Treaty released the EP ''Down to the River'', described as a mix of 'blues, gospel, soul, bluegrass, country' and heralded by Estey as 'a splendidly made immediate classic about conflict and redemption'.<ref name=\"Soul Bounce EP\">{{cite web|url=http://www.soulbounce.com/2017/07/the-war-and-treaty-down-to-the-river-video/|title=The War & Treaty \"Down To The River\" A Sight To Behold|work=Soul Bounce|date= July 17, 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref><ref name=\"Paste\">{{cite web|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2017/07/the-war-and-treaty-down-to-the-rivermp4.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190403231339/https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2017/07/the-war-and-treaty-down-to-the-rivermp4.html |archive-date=April 3, 2019 |title=The War & Treaty \"Down To The River\" A Sight To Behold|work=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|first=Chris |last=Estey|date= July 17, 2017|accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref> Yet the two can sensually help heal the wounds from those confessional blasts with a sweet ballad like \"Till The Mornin\u2019\" \u2014 they truly live up to the dynamic tension of their moniker.'<ref name=\"Paste\"/>\n\nIn 2018, ''[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]'' reported The War and Treaty's debut album ''[[Healing Tide]]'' is due for release on August 10, 2018, describing the lead single as a 'joyfully relentless title track, reminiscent of classic [[Ike and Tina Turner]] rock-infused soul'.<ref name=\"RS\"/>\n\nOn September 25, 2020, The War and Treaty released their sophomore studio album, ''Hearts Town'', on [[Rounder Records]]. On April 18, 2021 they joined [[Dierks Bentley]] for a performance of [[U2]]'s \"[[Pride (In the Name of Love)]]\" for the 56th [[Academy of Country Music Awards]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1832840/see-all-the-performers-and-presenters-for-the-2021-academy-of-country-music-awards/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210419005838/http://www.cmt.com/news/1832840/see-all-the-performers-and-presenters-for-the-2021-academy-of-country-music-awards/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=April 19, 2021 | title=See All the Performers and Presenters for the 2021 Academy of Country Music Awards }}</ref>\n\nThe group signed a major label deal with [[Universal Music Group Nashville]] in May 2022.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.udiscovermusic.com/news/the-war-and-treaty-sign-umg-nashville/ | title=Husband and Wife Americana Duo the War and Treaty Sign to UMG Nashville | date=23 May 2022 }}</ref> They performed a cover of \"[[It's Only Rock 'n Roll (But I Like It)]]\" alongside [[Brothers Osborne]] at the [[56th Annual Country Music Association Awards]] on November 9, 2022 and surprise-released their second EP ''Blank Page'' on the same day.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/cma-awards-brothers-osborne-war-and-treaty-1234627204/ | title=The War & Treaty and Brothers Osborne Cover a Rolling Stones Classic at the CMA Awards | magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=10 November 2022 }}</ref> Their major label debut album ''[[Lover's Game]]'', was released on March 10, 2023. \n\nThe duo collaborated with American country star [[Zach Bryan]] on the track \"Hey Driver\" from his [[Zach Bryan (album)|self-titled]] fourth studio album. The song debuted at number 14 on the [[Billboard Hot 100]] marking the duo's first appearance on the chart.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Zellner |first=Xander |date=2023-09-06 |title=Hot 100 First-Timers: Sierra Ferrell & The War And Treaty Debut With Zach Bryan Features |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/chart-beat/hot-100-first-timers-sierra-ferrell-the-war-and-treaty-debut-zach-bryan-features-1235407419/ |access-date=2024-01-14 |website=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|}\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\" border=\"1\"\n|+ List of albums, with selected chart positions\n|-\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Paul_Thorn","to":"Paul Thorn"}],"pages":{"17261894":{"pageid":17261894,"ns":0,"title":"Paul Thorn","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter and boxer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name                = Paul Thorn\n| image               = Paul Thorn.jpg\n| caption             = Thorn at [[Grand Opera House (Wilmington, Delaware)|The Grand]] in Wilmington, Delaware, 2008\n| birth_name          = \n| alias               =\n| birth_date          = <!-- Valid citation required for date of birth for BLP. (WP:BLPPRIVACY) --> \n| birth_place         = \n| origin              = [[Tupelo, Mississippi]], U.S.\n| death_date          =\n| death_place         =\n| instrument          = Vocals, guitar\n|occupation = {{flatlist|\n* Singer\n* songwriter\n* [[Boxing|boxer]]\n}}\n| genre               = [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Southern rock]], [[Country music|Country]], [[Blues]], [[Blues rock]]\n| years_active        = 1997\u2013present\n| label               = [[A&M Records]], Perpetual Obscurity\n| website             = {{URL|www.paulthorn.com | www.paulthorn.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Paul Thorn''' <!-- Valid citation required for date of birth for BLP. (WP:BLPPRIVACY) -->  is an American [[Southern rock]], [[Country music|country]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]], and [[blues]] singer-songwriter,<ref name=\"GAC1\">{{Cite web |title=Paul Thorn Biography |work=Artists A to Z |publisher=Great American Country |url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,gac_26071_5363345_,00.html |access-date=July 23, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303122408/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,gac_26071_5363345_,00.html |archive-date=March 3, 2012 |url-status=dead}}</ref> whose style is a mix of blues, country, and rock.<ref name=\"TD1\">{{Cite news |last=Crossley |first=Jennifer |title=Ready to jam |newspaper=Times Daily |location=Florence, AL |date=September 24, 2009 |url=http://www.timesdaily.com/article/20090924/articles/909245005?Title=Ready-to-jam |access-date=July 23, 2010}} {{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}</ref>\n\n==Biography==\nThorn was raised in [[Tupelo, Mississippi]].{{citation needed|date=February 2023}} Before his professional music career began, he was a professional boxer, where he established a respectable 14\u20134 record.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_I-S8pmpMjc|title=Episode #3: Paul Thorn - Former Pro Boxer and Musician|access-date=May 10, 2021|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref> Boxing career highlights include winning the Mid-South Middleweight Championship in [[Memphis, Tennessee]] and culminated with a nationally televised bout with former world champion [[Roberto Dur\u00e1n]],<ref name=\"GAC1\" /> After a few years of working in a Tupelo furniture factory and playing in local clubs, he was discovered by music professional [[Miles Copeland III|Miles Copeland]] (brother of [[The Police (band)|The Police]] drummer [[Stewart Copeland]]).\n\nIn 1997, while performing at a singer-songwriters night at a local pizza shop (Vanelli's), Roger Sovine, representing [[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI]], overheard Thorn and was impressed with his singing and songwriting ability. He asked Thorn if he had his permission to share his name with other record companies in Nashville. A couple weeks later, Thorn called vOz Vanelli (owner of Vanelli's) and mentioned that several record companies were coming to Tupelo to hear him perform. Thorn asked if he could come and play at Vanelli's which vOz agreed to. After hearing Thorn perform, Wyatt Easterling (an associate of [[Miles Copeland III]]) brought Thorn to Nashville and within thirty days, Thorn opened for [[Sting (musician)|Sting]]. Thorn was subsequently signed to a recording contract with [[A&M Records]] and recorded his first album, ''Hammer & Nail,'' in 1997. He left A&M soon after and followed ''Hammer & Nail'' with thirteen more albums, all self-released and self-produced with his writing and production partner, Billy Maddox.\n\nThorn's 2010 album ''Pimps and Preachers'' debuted at No.&nbsp;83 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] [[record chart|chart]], his highest chart position to date. His 2012 album ''What the Hell Is Going On'' was the 12th Most Played Album of 2012 on the Americana Music Association Year-End Chart.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jambands.com/news/2012/03/22/bernie-williams-ruthie-foster-susan-tedeschi-and-more-join-the-allman-brothers-band/ |title=Bernie Williams, Ruthie Foster, Susan Tedeschi and More Join The Allman Brothers Band |date=March 22, 2012 |access-date=January 30, 2013}}</ref> ''What the Hell Is Going On'' was Thorn's first album to feature the songwriting of other artists<ref name=\"Bio--Paul Thorn\">{{cite web|title=Bio\u2014Paul Thorn|url=http://www.paulthorn.com/bio/|website=Paulthorn.com|access-date=August 2, 2016}}</ref> and the second record of his to debut on the Billboard Top 100 during its first week of release.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mississippilegends.com/articles/tupelo%E2%80%99s-paul-thorn/ |title=Tupelo's Paul Thorn |last=Corbett |first=Stephen |date=July 18, 2012 |url-status=dead |access-date=January 30, 2013 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130216121828/http://mississippilegends.com/articles/tupelo%E2%80%99s-paul-thorn/ |archive-date=February 16, 2013}}</ref>\n\nThorn has toured as an opening act for [[Huey Lewis & the News]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], [[John Prine]], [[Marianne Faithfull]], [[Mark Knopfler]], [[Robert Cray]], [[Bonnie Raitt]], [[Jerry Jeff Walker]], [[Toby Keith]] and [[Jeff Beck]].\n\nIn 2014, Thorn released ''Too Blessed to Be Stressed'', which he described as a collection of \"positive anthem songs.\"<ref>from an interview on the [http://americanamusicshow.com/episode212 Americana Music Show #212], published September 25, 2014.</ref> \"I wrote these songs hoping they might put people in a positive mindset and encourage them to count their own blessings, like I count mine,\" Thorn observes. \"There's no higher goal I could set for myself than to help other people find some happiness and gratitude in their lives.\"<ref name=\"Bio--Paul Thorn\"/>\n\nIn March 2018, Thorn released an album, titled ''Don't Let the Devil Ride'', featuring several covers of gospel songs that were inspiration to him during his youth and adolescence.<ref name=\"npr.org\">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/03/17/594260751/paul-thorn-revisits-his-gospel-roots|title=Paul Thorn Revisits His Gospel Roots|website=NPR.org |access-date=April 7, 2018}}</ref> The album features several prominent artists in that genre such as the [[Blind Boys of Alabama]], [[The McCrary Sisters]], [[Bonnie Bishop]], and the [[Preservation Hall Jazz Band]].<ref name=\"npr.org\"/> The album peaked at No. 1 in the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Blues Albums Chart.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/blues-albums|title=Blues Music: Top Blues Albums Chart|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=April 7, 2018}}</ref>\n\nLater that month, the [[Mississippi House of Representatives]] named March 27 'Paul Thorn Day' in recognition of his constant support of his home state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.djournal.com/news/mississippi-house-honors-tupelo-s-thorn/article_c11fc244-44d5-5033-a0a7-eb3590e8d4c3.html|title=Mississippi House honors Tupelo's Thorn|author=Bobby Harrison|website=Djournal.com|access-date=May 22, 2018}}</ref> On May 7, 2018, [[Mississippi Public Broadcasting]] premiered a special featuring Thorn's current tour titled \"Mission Temple Fireworks Revival,\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mpbonline.org/blogs/mississippi-public-broadcasting/paul-thorns-first-gospel-album-comes-to-life-on-mpb-television-may-7/|title=MPB : Mississippi Public Broadcasting|website=Mpbonline.org|access-date=May 22, 2018}}</ref> which features special guests such as the [[Blind Boys of Alabama]], [[The McCrary Sisters]], [[Bonnie Bishop]], and the [[Preservation Hall Jazz Band]].\n\nIn 2019, Thorn's lead electric guitarist of 30 years, Bill Hinds, parted ways with the band. In a statement on Thorn's website, Hinds explains that he is starting a new chapter in his life, but will remain a musician.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.paulthorn.com/blog/2019/5/15/a-farewell-from-guitarist-bill-hinds|date=May 15, 2019|title=A Farewell From Guitarist Bill Hinds|last=Hinds|first=Bill|website=Paulthorn.com}}</ref> Hinds spot in the Paul Thorn Band has been filled by Chris Simmons, a guitarist from Alabama, who played in [[Leon Russell]]'s band for five years.\n\nIn May 2020, multi-Grammy award-winning vocalist and pianist [[Diane Schuur]] released an album, featuring a cover of Thorn's, \"Everybody Looks Good at the Starting Line.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=https://glidemagazine.com/243272/multi-grammy-award-winning-vocalist-pianist-diane-schuur-releases-stunning-bluesy-running-on-faith-album-review/?fbclid=IwAR19A97qUlKcqCs581CvRNq11MNjltnD16WNZ94S1tjfBjUCkylXBve-6i4 |title=MULTI-GRAMMY AWARD WINNING VOCALIST/PIANIST DIANE SCHUUR RELEASES STUNNING & BLUESY 'RUNNING ON FAITH' (ALBUM REVIEW) |website=Glidemagazine.com|date=May 5, 2020 |access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref>\n\n===''Tales & Ales''===\nOn February 1, 2019, Thorn released the first episode of his interview and performance style video series, ''Tales & Ales''. Since then, the show has featured several artists including [[John Oates]], [[John Paul White]], [[Foy Vance]], [[Tommy Emmanuel]], and [[Christone \"Kingfish\" Ingram|Kingfish]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.paulthorn.com/tales-ales |title=PAUL THORN'S \"TALES & ALES\": A bi-weekly video series featuring Paul Thorn trading stories with a wide range of guests. Sponsored by Lagunitas Brewing Co.|website=Paulthorn.com |access-date=January 16, 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Mark_Erelli","to":"Mark Erelli"}],"pages":{"3123836":{"pageid":3123836,"ns":0,"title":"Mark Erelli","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name             = Mark Erelli\n| image            = MarkErelli.jpg\n| caption          = Erelli performing at the Woody Guthrie Folk Festival in July 2009.\n| background       = solo_singer\n| landscape        = yes\n| birth_name       = \n| alias            = \n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1974|06|20|df=y}}\n| birth_place      = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], U.S.\n| death_date       = \n| death_place      = \n| instrument       = {{hlist|[[Singing|Vocals]]|[[guitar]]|[[mandolin]]|[[harmonica]]}}\n| genre            = {{hlist|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]|[[Folk music|folk]]|[[Pop music|pop]]|[[Country music|country]]}}\n| occupation       = {{hlist|[[Musician]]|[[songwriter]]}}\n| years_active     = 1999\u2013present\n| label            = [[Signature Sounds Recordings|Signature Sounds]]\n| associated_acts  = \n| website          = {{URL|markerelli.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Mark Erelli''' (born June 20, 1974) is an American singer/songwriter, multi-instrumentalist,<ref name=\"Chilton\">Chilton, Martin. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/worldfolkandjazz/8907878/Mark-Erelli-and-the-pursuit-of-excellence.html Mark Erelli and the pursuit of excellence.] ''The Telegraph'' (UK), November 22, 2011.</ref> and touring [[folk music|folk]] musician from [[Reading, Massachusetts]] who earned a master's degree in evolutionary biology from the [[University of Massachusetts Amherst]] before pursuing a career in music.  Erelli has released nine solo albums and three collaborative albums.   His self-titled debut album was released in 1999, the same year that he won the [[Kerrville Folk Festival|Kerrville Folk Festival's]] New Folk Award.  His first recording for the [[Signature Sounds]] label, ''Compass & Companion,'' spent ten weeks in the Top Ten on the Americana Chart.<ref name=\"Wood\">Wood, Arthur. [http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/pawtrait/folkville Mark Erelli Biography.] ''Folkville: Thirty Years Writing About the Folk Process'', Retrieved February 12, 2013.</ref>  Erelli has worked as a side musician for [[singer songwriters]]  [[Lori McKenna]] and [[Josh Ritter]].<ref>Webb, Jela.  [http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/mark-erelli-stuyvesant-oval-new-york-city-7-21-12 Mark Erelli, Stuyvesant Oval (New York City, 7/21/12)], \u2018\u2019No Depression\u2019\u2019, August 6, 2012.</ref>  He has performed at various music festivals and shared the stage with [[John Hiatt]], [[Dave Alvin]], and [[Gillian Welch]].<ref>Daily Voice Staff. [http://leicester.dailyvoice.com/news/mark-erelli-multi-instrumentalist-sideman-and-singer-songwriter-months-hezekiah-stones-featured Mark Erelli - the multi-instrumentalist sideman and singer-songwriter is this month\u2019s Hezekiah Stone\u2019s featured artist.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140724142356/http://leicester.dailyvoice.com/news/mark-erelli-multi-instrumentalist-sideman-and-singer-songwriter-months-hezekiah-stones-featured |date=2014-07-24 }} \u2018\u2019The Leicester Daily Voice\u2019\u2019, October 5, 2012.</ref>  Erelli's song \u201cPeople Look Around\u201d, which he co-wrote with [[Catie Curtis]],  was the Grand Prize winner at the 2005  International Songwriting Competition.<ref name=\"ISC\">International Songwriting Competition.[http://www.songwritingcompetition.com/previouswinners#2005 International Songwriting Competition: Previous Winners.]</ref> His songs have been recorded by [[Ellis Paul]], [[Vance Gilbert]], [[Antje Duvekot]], and [[Red Molly]].\n\n==Early life and education==\nErelli was born in Boston and grew up in the town of Reading,  Massachusetts.<ref name=\"Wood\"/> Erelli performed in numerous high school musicals and founded the band, Freddie and Slip.  Later he was a member of the band Organic Ice Cube and wrote his first song \"Hell In the Sky\" as a member of the band Dead Flowers (Greg Pothier, Scott Collins, Brian Moynihan, Kevin Larimore, Kris Tuscano, Chris Kerrigan Borning).<ref name=\"Wood\"/> Erelli was introduced to the music of [[Patty Larkin]], [[Chris Smither]], and other singer-songwriters by listening to  the radio station [[WBOS]].<ref name=\"WBUR2011\">WBUR Radio. [http://radioboston.wbur.org/2011/03/17/mark-erelli Evolutionary Biologist Mark Erelli Turns To Music.] March 17, 2011</ref> He formed the Mark Erelli Band and in 1997 released the album ''Long Way From Heaven''. After attending the North East [[Folk Alliance]] Conference in 1997, Erelli signed a recording contract with [[Signature Sounds Recordings]].<ref name=\"Wood\"/> He was awarded the Iguana Music Fund Fellowship award from Cambridge's [[Club Passim]] and used the proceeds to build a home studio.<ref name=\"WBUR2011\"/>\n\nErelli attended [[Bates College]] in [[Lewiston, Maine]] and in 1997 enrolled at the  [[University of Massachusetts Amherst]] where he obtained a master's degree in evolutionary biology in 1999.<ref name=\"Wood\"/>\n\n==Career==\nErelli's self-titled debut CD was released on the Signature Sounds label in 1999. Produced by [[Lorne Entress]], Erelli was backed by musicians [[Duke Levine]], [[Kevin Barry]], Jim Lamond, Dave Dick, Joe Barbato, Roger Williams, and Mike Dinallo and guest vocalists, [[Rani Arbo]], [[Louise Taylor (singer)|Louise Taylor]], and Ben Demerath. He later won the [[Kerrville Folk Festival|Kerrville Folk Festival's]] New Folk Award in the same year.\n\nThe following year, Erelli's sophomore recording for Signature Sounds, ''Compass & Companion'' was released. Again produced by Entress, it features a title-song duet with country artist [[Kelly Willis]]. Duke Levine and Kevin Barry once again lent support on guitar along with Dave Dick on banjo and Entress on the jaw harp and percussion.<ref name=\"Schwartz2001\">Schwartz, Roberta. [http://www.acousticmusic.com/fame/p01704.htm FAME review of ''Compass & Companion''.] ''Folk and Acoustic Music Exchange'', 2001.</ref> The album charted for ten weeks in the Top Ten of the Americana Music Chart.  Later that year Erelli was nominated for two Boston Music Awards.<ref name=\"Wood\"/>\n\nErelli's next project was to forego the traditional studio and instead gather a group of musicians to play within the walls of the Civil War era Memorial Hall in [[Monson, Massachusetts]]. Over the course of four days in May 2001, Erelli sat down in a semi-circle on the stage of the hall with Lorne Entress, Joe Barbato, Kevin Barry, [[Jim Henry (musician)|Jim Henry]], and Jim Lamond.  The recording machines were turned on and everything was captured over the next four days.<ref name=\"Ross\">Ross, Janice. [http://www.acousticmusic.com/fame/p02098.htm FAME review of ''The Memorial Hall Recordings''.] ''Folk and Acoustic Music Exchange'', 2002.</ref> The recording sessions were also captured on film and later aired as a documentary on [[PBS]].<ref>O'Brien, Nicholas. [http://www.bates.edu/magazine/back-issues/y2002/summer02/departments/class-notes-5/class-of-1996 Class of 1996.], ''Bates (College) Magazine'', April 23, 2010.</ref>\n\nIn 2004, Erelli hooked up with Boston-based country band The Spurs<ref name=\"Wood\"/> to delve into the worlds of [[Western swing]], [[Country music|country]], and [[rockabilly]] with the release of ''Hillbilly Pilgrim''. [[Erin McKeown]] is a guest vocalist on \"Pretend.\" \"For folk fans, this disc may take some getting used to, but its pleasures are many.\"<ref name=\"Lewis\">Lewis, Alan. [http://www.boston.com/ae/music/cd_reviews/articles/2004/01/30/mark_erelli_hillbilly_pilgrim/?camp=pm Mark Erelli: ''Hillbilly Pilgrim''.] ''Boston Globe'', January 30, 2004.</ref>\n\nErelli co-produced, with Lorne Entress, his fifth Signature Sounds album ''Hope & Other Casualties,'' which was released in 2006. When Erelli was asked if it was a concept album, he said: \"The country has been through a lot, since 2000 really. Before September 11, that election of 2000 was a major thing. So, all the songs come out of that context. If the songs seem related, they all come out of that context over the last four years and they\u2019re all coming through my lens and how I\u2019m looking at the world. They all, in kinda one way or another, deal with the issue of how do you keep on keepin\u2019 on when things seem really grim.\"<ref name=\"Barber\">Barber, Greg. [http://www.expressnightout.com/2006/07/qa_mark_erelli Q&A: Mark Erelli.] ''The Washington Post'', July 6, 2006.</ref> Sometimes viewed as his most political album, \"Hope & Other Casualties\" is \"an attentive examination of current times interwoven with matters of the heart. His emotions straddle the ground between the personal and the political.\"<ref name=\"Smyers\">Smyers, Darryl. Review: Hope & Other Casualties. ''No Depression'', July\u2013August, 2006, p. 118.</ref> Guest vocalists include [[Kris Delmhorst]] and [[Jeffrey Foucault]].  ''Hope & Other Casualties'' was voted the number one album of 2006 by [[WUMB]] radio member listeners.<ref>WUMB. [http://www.wumb.org/music/countdowns.php?CountdownID=5 Top Ten of 2006.] Retrieved October 30, 2012.</ref>\n\n''Innocent When You Dream'', released in 2007, is a collection of lullabies and love songs, which features solo acoustic performances by Erelli as well as covers by [[Shawn Colvin]], [[Townes Van Zandt]], and others.<ref name=\"Wood\"/> Also in 2007, Erelli toured with [[Lori McKenna]] in support of [[Tim McGraw]] and [[Faith Hill]] on their Soul 2 Soul tour which included appearances on [[Good Morning America]] and at the [[Grand Ole Opry]].<ref name=\"Rodman2007\">Rodman, Sarah. [http://www.boston.com/ae/music/articles/2007/06/24/a_long_way_from_passim A long way from Passim.] ''Boston Globe'', June 24, 2007.</ref> Later that year Erelli invited fans to finance his next studio album - ''Delivered'' - referring to the project as a [[barn raising]]. The project succeeded and the 11-song album produced by Josh Ritter's bassist, Zack Hickman, was released in 2008.<ref name=\"Wood\"/> In his review of ''Delivered'' for ''The Huffington Post'', entertainment writer Mike Ragogna said:<blockquote>\"This is powerful stuff, and it's a shame that over the six or so albums Mark Erelli has created, he hasn't grown into a more popular artist. But we all know about marketing challenges and how difficult it is these days to cut through the cacophony of TMZ-style stories our mainstream media prefers. As Erelli points out, nothing much has changed here. But as he also reminds us by that song's title, \"Hope Dies Last.\"<ref name=\"Ragogna2008\">Ragogna, Mike. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mike-ragogna/folkin-around-with-benjam_b_129492.html Folkin' Around with Benjamin Taylor, His Dad James, Dar Williams and That Guy Mark Erelli]. ''The Huffington Post'', September 26, 2008.</ref></blockquote>\n\nIn 2009, Erelli was a member of [[Josh Ritter|Josh Ritter's]] band when Ritter opened shows for [[Ray Lamontagne]] in the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name=\"Dean\">Dean, Jessica. [http://consequenceofsound.net/2009/09/ray-lamontagne-and-josh-ritter-silence-sheffield-uk-912 Ray Lamontagne and Josh Ritter silence Sheffield, UK (9/12).] ''Consequence of Sound'', September 14, 2009.</ref> Tour dates included performances in [[Sheffield]]<ref name=\"Dean\"/> and the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in [[London]].<ref>Resident Media Pundit. [http://residentmediapundit.com/?p=1479 Mark Erelli's ''Little Vigils''.] March 29, 2010.</ref>\n\n''Little Vigils'' - again produced by Zack Hickman - was released in 2010. The title is taken from a line in the lead-off track \"August.\"<ref name=\"Ragogna\">Ragogna, Mike. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mike-ragogna/emparadiseem-emlittle-vig_b_679529.html Paradise & Little Vigils: Conversations with Judy Collins and That Guy Mark Erelli.] ''The Huffington Post'', August 12, 2010.</ref>\n\nIn the spring of 2014, Erelli announced a [[Kickstarter]] campaign to fund his [[Bill Morrissey]] tribute CD titled ''Milltowns''. On June 26, 2014, Erelli announced that the Kickstarter campaign had exceeded his initial $20,000 goal with donations received from more than 400 supporters of the project.<ref>Kickstarter website. [https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/671912229/mark-erellis-milltowns-a-tribute-to-bill-morrissey Mark Erelli's MILLTOWNS, a tribute to Bill Morrissey.]</ref> ''Milltowns'' was released on September 9, 2014.<ref name=\"Reed2014\">Reed, James. [https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2014/09/12/erelli-pays-homage-bill-morrissey-onstage-and-disc/XMrbxWzMEYYex3mpHI6CDJ/story.html Erelli pays homage to Bill Morrissey onstage, on disc.] ''The Boston Globe'', September 5, 2014.</ref> In her review for Folk Alley, Kim Ruehl wrote: \"''Milltowns'' doesn't come off as a covers record or a tribute album, though, so much as it does a thank-you note for the songs Morrissey put out into the world. With each performance, Erelli gives himself over to the song and seems to be simply following along and learning from where the song takes him. Backed by Sam Kassirer on piano, Charlie Rose on pedal steel and banjo, and Zack Hickman on upright bass, Erelli also welcomes backing vocals from the area's finest singers: [[Rose Cousins]], Kris Delmhorst, Jeffrey Foucault, [[Ana\u00efs Mitchell]], [[Peter Mulvey]], and [[Rose Polenzani]].\"<ref name=\"FolkAlley2014\">Ruehl, Kim for Folk Alley.com. [http://www.folkalley.com/archives/001328.php Hear It First at Folk Alley - Mark Erelli, 'Milltowns'.] Folk Alley, September 3, 2014.</ref>\n\nOn January 4, 2016, Erelli announced a second Kickstarter campaign in support of ''For A Song'' - his first solo album of original material in six years. One month later, Erelli announced that the project was successfully funded, having raised more than $36K from 469 backers.<ref>Kickstarter website. [https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/671912229/for-a-song-the-new-mark-erelli-record. Mark Erelli. For A Song.]</ref>  ''For A Song'' was released on April 8, 2016. In a review of ''For A Song'' for ''No Depression'', Red Line Roots compared Erelli's songs to those of [[Paul Simon]] or [[Jackson Browne]] and went on to say: \"''For A Song'' reflects Erelli's incredible craftsmanship. The arrangements are tight and spare, leaving plenty of room for his voice to convey the sincerity of each song.\"<ref name=\"NoDepression2016\">Red Line Roots.[http://nodepression.com/interview/song-interview-mark-erelli For A Song: An Interview with Mark Erelli.] ''No Depression, ''March 25, 2016.</ref> In CD HotList's Picks of the Month, Rick Anderson wrote that \"The whole album is gorgeous and at times borders on heartbreaking.\"<ref name=\"CDHotlist\">Anderson, Rick.[http://cdhotlist.com/?s=mark+erelli Mark Erelli: For A Song.] CD HotList, Picks of the Month, April 4, 2016.</ref> The week of April 25, 2016, ''For A Song'' was #34 on the [[Americana Music Association]] chart.<ref>Americana Music Association.[http://www.americanaradio.org/AMA/displaychart_beforetracks.asp?mode=lw&dtkey= Archive Playlist for week of Monday, April 25, 2016 ] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140731182008/http://americanaradio.org/AMA/displaychart_beforetracks.asp?mode=lw&dtkey= |date=July 31, 2014 }}. Retrieved April 28, \n2016.</ref>\n\n==Collaborations==\n\n===Barnstar!===\n''Barnstar!'' is Erelli's bluegrass band collaboration with father and son Taylor Armerding and [[Jake Armerding]], Charlie Rose, and Zack Hickman.  The band's debut release - ''C'mon!'' - was released in 2011. The album includes several well-known songs such as [[Neil Young|Neil Young's]] \"Cowgirl in the Sand\" and the [[Louvin Brothers|Louvin Brothers']] \"Cash on the Barrelhead\" as well as three songs penned by Erelli.<ref name=\"Chilton\"/>\n\nThe collaboration continued with the 2015 release of ''Sit Down! Get Up! Get Out!''. In his review for ''The Boston Globe'', Stuart Munro wrote that the release is \"genre-bending music filled with jawdropping harmonizing, emotive ensemble playing, and a raucous immediacy.\"<ref name=\"Munro2015\">Munro, Stuart. [https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2015/02/03/barnstar-sit-down-get-get-out/JbqlP2j4EefIALsSidMxcP/story.html Barnstar!, \u2018Sit Down! Get Up! Get Out!\u2019] ''The Boston Globe'', February 3, 2015.</ref>\n\n===Seven Curses===\nIn 2010, Erelli paired-up with Jeffrey Foucault to release ''Seven Curses: A Killer Selection of Americana Murder Ballads''.  Other than the closing track,\"Wyoming Wind\" written by Erelli, the collection of songs are covers. They include [[Woody Guthrie|Woody Guthrie's]] \"[[Philadelphia Lawyer (song)|Philadelphia Lawyer]],\" [[Bruce Springsteen|Bruce Springsteen's]] \"[[Johnny 99 (song)|Johnny 99]],\" and Kevin \"Blackie\" Farrell's \"[[Sonora's Death Row]],\" to name three. \"Whether sweet and mellow or raw and raucous sounding, this homicidal assortment is bleeding great!\"<ref name=\"Wood\"/>\n\n===Darwin Song Project===\nErelli was chosen to join seven other songwriters in a songwriting retreat called the Darwin Song Project, one of many events that took place in 2009 to commemorate [[Charles Darwin|Charles Darwin's]] bicentennial.  The event - organized by the [[Shrewsbury Folk Festival]] - took place in Darwin's hometown of [[Shrewsbury, England]] when the group of musicians gathered to write songs that \"have a resonance and relevance to the life of Darwin.\" The other Darwin artists are Chris Wood, Karine Polwart, Rachael McShane, Jez Lowe, Stu Hanna, Krista Detor and Emily Smith.\nA concert at the Theatre Severn in March 2009 was recorded and later released as a live CD, and the artists reunited in August 2009 for a performance at the Shrewsbury Folk Festival.<ref name=\"Darwin\">Darwin Song Project. [http://www.darwinsongproject.com The Darwin Song Project: Shrewsbury 2009.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921063050/http://www.darwinsongproject.com/ |date=2013-09-21 }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n'''Studio Albums'''\n:{|class=\"wikitable\"\n!Year\n!Title\n!Record Label\n|-\n|2023\n|''Lay Your Darkness Down''\n|Self-released\n|-\n|2020\n|''Blindsided''\n|Self-released\n|-\n|2018\n|''Mixtape''\n|Self-released\n|-\n|2016\n|''For A Song'' \n|Self-released\n|-\n|2015\n|''Sit Down! musician}}\n{{Other people|Jerry Douglas}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist<!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name            = Jerry Douglas\n| image           = Jerry Douglas 2009 Rivercity.jpg\n| caption         = Douglas in 2009\n| image_upright   = 1.1\n| background      = non_vocal_instrumentalist\n| birth_name      = Gerald Calvin Douglas\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1956|5|28}} \n| birth_place     = [[Warren, Ohio]], U.S.\n| genre           = [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[Country music|country]]\n| occupation      = Musician\n| instrument      = [[Dobro]], [[resonator guitar]], [[lap steel guitar]], [[guitar]]\n| years_active    = 1970s\u2013present\n| label           = [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], [[MCA Records|MCA]], [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill]], [[Entertainment One Music|Entertainment One]], [[Koch Records|Koch]]\n| current_member_of =[[Alison Krauss & Union Station]]\n| past_member_of =[[The GrooveGrass Boyz]]\n| website         = {{URL|jerrydouglas.com}}\n}}\n'''Gerald Calvin \"Jerry\" Douglas''' (born May 28, 1956) is an American [[Dobro]] and [[lap steel guitar]] player and [[record producer]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jambase.com/Articles/2424/AN-INTERVIEW-WITH-JERRY-DOUGLASBluegrass-For-A-New-Century |title=An Interview with Jerry Douglas: Bluegrass for a New Century |website=Jambase.com |date=11 May 2002 |access-date=3 October 2015 |author=Geoff Harrison |url-status=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130519200702/http://www.jambase.com/Articles/2424/AN-INTERVIEW-WITH-JERRY-DOUGLASBluegrass-For-A-New-Century |archive-date=19 May 2013}}</ref> He is widely regarded as \"perhaps the finest Dobro player in contemporary acoustic music, and certainly the most celebrated and prolific\".<ref name=\"AllMusic\">{{cite web |last1=Huey |first1=Steve |title=Jerry Douglas Biography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/jerry-douglas-mn0000327130/biography |website=AllMusic.com |access-date=5 February 2023}}</ref> A fourteen-time Grammy winner, he has been called \"dobro's matchless contemporary master\" by The New York Times, and is among the most innovative recording artists in music,<ref>{{cite web |title=Artist Information - Jerry Douglas |url=https://www.opry.com/artists/jerry-douglas/ |website=OPRY.com |access-date=5 February 2023}}</ref> both as a solo artist and member of numerous bands, such as [[Alison Krauss and Union Station]] and [[The Earls of Leicester]]. He has been a co-director of the [[Transatlantic Sessions]] since 1998.\n\n==Career==\n[[File:Jerry Douglas (26955774667).jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|{{center|Watson Stage - MerleFest 2018}}]]\n[[File:Jerry Douglas 2006.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Jerry Douglas playing one of his [[resonator guitar]]s]]\n\nIn addition to his fourteen solo recordings, Douglas has played on more than 1,600 albums.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jerrydouglas.com/disc.cfm |title=Welcome to the Official Jerry Douglas Website |website=Jerrydouglas.com |access-date=2016-01-10 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126194102/http://jerrydouglas.com/disc.cfm |archive-date=2016-01-26}}</ref><ref>[https://thestarphoenix.com/entertainment/local-arts/review-jerry-douglas-gives-bluegrass-the-cordon-bleu-treatment \"REVIEW: Jerry Douglas gives bluegrass the cordon bleu treatment\"]. Cam Fuller, ''Saskatoon StarPhoenix'', June 28, 2018</ref>  As a sideman, he has recorded with artists as diverse as [[Garth Brooks]], [[Ray Charles]], [[Eric Clapton]], [[Phish]], [[Dolly Parton]], [[Susan Ashton]], [[Paul Simon]], [[Mumford & Sons]], [[Keb' Mo']], [[Ricky Skaggs]], [[Elvis Costello]], [[Tommy Emmanuel]], [[James Taylor]] and [[Johnny Mathis]], as well as performing on the ''[[O Brother, Where Art Thou?]]'' soundtrack and the follow-up \"Down From the Mountain\" tour with [[Alison Krauss and Union Station]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/mountain-summer-tour-dates-come-on-down-76425/ |title='Mountain' Summer Tour Dates Come on Down |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=March 18, 2002}}</ref> He has collaborated with various groups including [[The Whites]], [[New South (band)|New South]], [[The Country Gentlemen]], [[Strength in Numbers (band)|Strength in Numbers]], and [[Elvis Costello]]'s \"Sugar Canes\".\n\nFrom 1996 to 1998, Douglas was a member of [[The GrooveGrass Boyz]].<ref name=\"groovegrass\">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p350665/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=GrooveGrass biography |accessdate=2008-08-21 |last=Ankeny |first=Jason |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>\n\nDouglas produced a number of records, including some at [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]]. He oversaw albums by [[Alison Krauss]], the [[Del McCoury Band]], [[Maura O'Connell]], [[Jesse Winchester]] and the [[Nashville Bluegrass Band]], [[The Earls of Leicester]], [[Gary Morris]], [[The Steep Canyon Rangers]]. Along with [[Aly Bain]], he serves as Music Director of the popular BBC Television series, \"[[Transatlantic Sessions]]\".\n\nSince 1998, Douglas has been a member of Alison Krauss and Union Station, touring extensively and playing on a series of platinum-selling albums. When not on the road with Alison Krauss and Union Station, Douglas tours in support of his extensive body of work with his bands The Jerry Douglas Band and The Earls of Leicester, following the continued success of the latter's 2014 release ''The Earls of Leicester'' and 2015's ''Rattle and Roar''.{{cn|date=August 2024}}\n\nJerry Douglas appeared with Vince Gill on Eric Clapton's Crossroads Guitar Festival 2004 (\"Oklahoma Borderline\" and \"What the Cowgirls Do\").{{cn|date=August 2024}}\n\nDouglas also made a cameo in the third \"United Breaks Guitars\" consumer protest video, all of which went viral.{{cn|date=August 2024}}\n\n==Personal life==\nDouglas was born in [[Warren, Ohio]],<ref name=\"AllMusic\" /> and now lives in Nashville, Tennessee, with his wife, Jill.\n\n==Awards and honors==\nAs of 2021, Douglas has been nominated for thirty-two [[Grammy Award]]s, winning fourteen.<ref name=\"grammy\">{{cite web |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/jerry-douglas |title=Artist: Jerry Douglas |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2021 |website=www.grammy.com |publisher=The Recording Academy |access-date=January 3, 2021}}</ref>\n\nHe has received the [[Country Music Association]]'s 'Musician of the Year' award three times, in 2002, 2005 and 2007.{{cn|date=August 2024}}\n\nDouglas is a 10-time recipient of the [[International Bluegrass Music Association]] (\"IBMA\") Dobro Player of the Year Award.{{cn|date=August 2024}}\n\nIn 2004, the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] awarded Douglas a [[National Heritage Fellowship]], which is the United States' highest honor in the folk and traditional arts.<ref name=\"nhf\">{{cite web |url=https://www.arts.gov/honors/heritage/jerry-douglas |title=Jerry Douglas: Dobro player |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=n.d. |website=www.arts.gov |publisher=National Endowment for the Arts |access-date=January 3, 2021}}</ref>\n\nDouglas was named Artist in Residence for the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum]] in 2008.{{cn|date=August 2024}}\n\nDouglas was honored at the 36th annual [[Telluride Bluegrass Festival]] in Colorado for his twenty-fifth consecutive year playing in and at the festival.{{cn|date=August 2024}}\n\nDouglas received the Bluegrass Star Award, presented by the Bluegrass Heritage Foundation of Dallas, Texas, on October 15, 2016. The award is bestowed upon bluegrass artists who do an exemplary job of advancing traditional bluegrass music and bringing it to new audiences while preserving its character and heritage.<ref>\"Bluegrass Heritage Foundation official website\". 2016. Retrieved 2016-10-18.</ref>\n\nThe [[Americana Music Association]] honored Douglas with a Lifetime Achievement Award in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://americanamusic.org/robert-plant-buddy-miller-and-justin-townes-earle-win-big-10th-annual-americana-honors-awards-show |title=Robert Plant, Buddy Miller and Justin Townes Earle Win Big at 10th Annual Americana Honors & Awards Show |publisher=Americana Music |access-date=2016-01-10 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114214542/http://americanamusic.org/robert-plant-buddy-miller-and-justin-townes-earle-win-big-10th-annual-americana-honors-awards-show |archive-date=2016-01-14}}</ref>\n\nDouglas received the key to the city of [[Manchester, Tennessee]], as well as to [[Coffee County, Tennessee|Coffee County]] during a performance at the 2015 Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival.<ref>{{cite web |author=/ By Brittney McKenna |url=http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/dispatches-bgs-stage-bonnaroo-2015 |title=Dispatches From The BGS Stage at Bonnaroo 2015 |publisher=The Bluegrass Situation |date=2015-06-15 |access-date=2016-01-10 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151009000012/http://www.thebluegrasssituation.com/read/dispatches-bgs-stage-bonnaroo-2015 |archive-date=2015-10-09}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio recordings===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n!
