This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Emmylou_Harris","to":"Emmylou Harris"}],"pages":{"123572":{"pageid":123572,"ns":0,"title":"Emmylou Harris","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer, songwriter, and musician}}\n{{good article}}\n{{Redirect|Emmylou}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2024}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name               = Emmylou Harris\n| image              = Emmylou Harris - Yellowstone National Park, 2016.jpg\n| alt                = Singer Emmylou Harris with her arms extended, and singing into a microphone.\n| caption            = Harris performing in 2016\n| birth_date         = {{Birth date and age|1947|04|02}} \n| birth_place        = [[Birmingham, Alabama]], U.S.\n| education          = [[Gar-Field Senior High School]]\n| occupation         = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|musician|activist}}\n| years_active       = 1969\u2013present\n| spouse             = {{ubl|{{marriage|Tom Slocum|1969|1971|reason=divorced}}|{{marriage|[[Brian Ahern (producer)|Brian Ahern]]|1977|1984|reason=divorced}}|{{marriage|[[Paul Kennerley]]|1985|1993|reason=divorced}}}}\n| children           = 2\n| awards             = [[List of awards and nominations received by Emmylou Harris|Awards and nominations]]\n| module             = {{Infobox musical artist\n| embed              = yes\n| origin             = [[Washington, D.C.]]\n| genre              = {{hlist|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]||[[Country music|country]]|[[country rock]]|[[Folk music|folk]]|[[outlaw country]]|[[progressive country]]}}\n| instrument         = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}}\n| label              = {{hlist|[[Jubilee Records|Jubilee]]|[[Reprise Records|Reprise]]\u2013[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]|[[Asylum Records|Asylum]]\u2013[[Elektra Records|Elektra]]|Eminent|[[Mercury Records|Mercury]]|[[Nonesuch Records|Nonesuch]]}}\n| website            = {{URL|emmylouharris.com}}\n| module             = {{Infobox person|child=yes\n| signature          = Emmylou Harris' signature.png }}\n}}\n}}\n'''Emmylou Harris''' (born April 2, 1947)<ref name=\"Hall of Fame\">{{cite web |title=Emmylou Harris |url=https://www.countrymusichalloffame.org/hall-of-fame/emmylou-harris |website=[[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum]] |access-date=July 25, 2023 |archive-date=July 3, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220703112825/https://www.countrymusichalloffame.org/hall-of-fame/emmylou-harris |url-status=live }}</ref> is an American singer, songwriter, musician, bandleader, and activist. She is recognized for having a consistent artistic direction. Harris is considered one of the leading music artists behind the [[country rock]] genre in the 1970s and the [[Americana (music)|Americana]] genre in the 1990s. Her music united both country and rock audiences in live performance settings. Her characteristic voice, musical style and songwriting have been acclaimed by critics and fellow recording artists.\n\nHarris developed an interest in folk music in her early years, which led to her performing professionally. After moving to New York City in the 1960s, she recorded a folk album and performed regionally. She was discovered by [[Gram Parsons]], who influenced her country rock direction. Following his 1973 death, Harris obtained her own recording contract from [[Reprise Records|Reprise]]\u2013[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]] Her second album, ''[[Pieces of the Sky]]'' (1975), found both critical acclaim and commercial success. Follow-up 1970s albums further elevated Harris' career, such as ''[[Elite Hotel]]'' (1976), ''[[Quarter Moon in a Ten Cent Town]]'' (1978) and ''[[Blue Kentucky Girl (Emmylou Harris album)|Blue Kentucky Girl]]'' (1979). By 1980, she had acquired four number-one songs on the US and Canadian country charts: \"[[Together Again (Buck Owens song)|Together Again]]\", \"[[Sweet Dreams (Don Gibson song)|Sweet Dreams]]\", \"[[Two More Bottles of Wine]]\" and \"[[Beneath Still Waters (song)|Beneath Still Waters]]\".\n\nHarris had a continued string of commercially and critically successful albums like ''[[Roses in the Snow]]'' (1980), ''[[Evangeline (Emmylou Harris album)|Evangeline]]'' (1981) and ''[[Last Date (Emmylou Harris album)|Last Date]]'' (1982). Her backing group, the Hot Band helped establish a musical foundation for her concerts and albums. Her 1980s albums spawned the top ten singles \"[[The Wayfaring Stranger (song)|Wayfaring Stranger]]\", \"[[Born to Run (Emmylou Harris song)|Born to Run]]\" and \"[[Last Date (song)|Last Date]]\". The 1985 album ''[[The Ballad of Sally Rose]]'' was among Harris' first self-written projects. The album (along with its follow-ups) failed to sustain the commercial momentum of previous albums. Harris then collaborated with [[Dolly Parton]] and [[Linda Ronstadt]] on ''[[Trio (1987 album)|Trio]]'' (1987). The platinum-selling album was also a critical success that spawned four top ten singles.\n\nIn 1992, Warner Bros. released the live album ''[[At the Ryman]]''. It garnered critical praise and renewed interest in its live venue, the [[Ryman Auditorium]]. Harris was inspired to move in a new musical direction with 1995's ''[[Wrecking Ball (Emmylou Harris album)|Wrecking Ball]]''. She then reunited with Dolly Parton and Linda Ronstadt for ''[[Trio II]]'' (1999). By the 2000s, Harris had signed with [[Nonesuch Records]] and recorded several albums of self-composed material like ''[[Red Dirt Girl]]'' (2000), ''[[All I Intended to Be]]'' (2008) and ''[[Hard Bargain (Emmylou Harris album)|Hard Bargain]]'' (2011). She also found collaborative partnerships, such as with [[Mark Knopfler]] on the internationally successful ''[[All the Roadrunning]]'' (2006). She then collaborated with Rodney Crowell on the critically acclaimed ''[[Old Yellow Moon]]'' (2013) and ''[[The Traveling Kind]]'' (2015). She also became involved in activism during this time, including starting her own [[Animal rescue group|dog rescue]] called Bonaparte's Retreat.\n\nHarris has been estimated to have sold over 15 million records worldwide.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sturges |first1=Fiona |title=Emmylou Harris: 'I smoked country music but I didn't inhale' |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/emmylou-harris-i-smoked-country-music-but-i-didn-t-inhale-2267867.html |access-date=August 2, 2023 |work=[[The Independent]] |date=April 17, 2011 |archive-date=August 2, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230802031020/https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/emmylou-harris-i-smoked-country-music-but-i-didn-t-inhale-2267867.html |url-status=live }}</ref> She has also earned 13 [[Grammy Awards]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Emmylou Harris: Artist |url=https://www.grammy.com/artists/emmylou-harris/13460 |website=[[Grammy Awards]] |access-date=August 2, 2023 |archive-date=July 5, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220705191559/https://www.grammy.com/artists/emmylou-harris/13460 |url-status=live }}</ref> placed 27 singles into the top ten of the US [[Hot Country Songs|country chart]],<ref name=\"Country Songs\">{{cite magazine |title=Emmylou Harris chart history (Country Songs) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/emmylou-harris/chart-history/csi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=July 18, 2023 |archive-date=April 4, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230404170929/https://www.billboard.com/artist/emmylou-harris/chart-history/csi/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and several of her albums have received [[Recording Industry Association of America|gold]] certifications in the US.<ref name=\"RIAA\">{{cite web |title=Gold & Platinum: Emmylou Harris |url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&se=emmylou+harris#search_section |website=[[Recording Industry Association of America]] |access-date=July 26, 2023}}</ref> She was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]] in 2008 and was ranked among ''[[Rolling Stone]]'''s list of the 200 Greatest Singers of All Time in 2022.\n\n==Early life==\nHarris was born in [[Birmingham, Alabama]], in 1947.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363}} She was one of two children born to Walter Rutland Harris and Eugenia Harris.<ref name=\"eugenia\">{{Cite news |url=https://www.legacy.com/obituaries/washingtonpost/obituary.aspx?n=eugenia-m-harris&pid=172203831&fhid=11637 |title=Eugenia Harris Obituary (1921 - 2014) - Nashville, TN |date=August 22, 2014 |newspaper=The Washington Post |access-date=July 12, 2021 |via=legacy.com |archive-date=May 10, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210510144304/https://www.legacy.com/obituaries/washingtonpost/obituary.aspx?n=eugenia-m-harris&pid=172203831&fhid=11637 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=\"bucky\">{{cite web |url=https://www.moaa.org/content/about-moaa/scholarship-fund/faces-of-donorsFolder/Maj--Walter-Rutland-%E2%80%9CBucky%E2%80%9D-Harris,-USMC-Ret- |title=Maj. Walter Rutland \"Bucky\" Harris, USMC Ret. |publisher=Military Officers Association of America |access-date=July 12, 2021 |url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161101164638/http://www1.moaa.org/Main_Menu/About_MOAA/Scholarship_Fund/Faces_of_Donors/Maj__Walter_Rutland_%E2%80%9CBucky%E2%80%9D_Harris,_USMC_Ret_.html|archive-date=November 1, 2016}}</ref> Her older brother (Walter Harris Jr.)<ref name=\"Alabama Encyclopedia\">{{cite web |title=Emmylou Harris |url=https://encyclopediaofalabama.org/article/emmylou-harris/ |website=[[Encyclopedia of Alabama]] |access-date=July 25, 2023 |archive-date=July 25, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230725030550/https://encyclopediaofalabama.org/article/emmylou-harris/ |url-status=live }}</ref> enjoyed country music in his youth.<ref name=\"Musician Guide\">{{cite web |last1=Janette Johnson |first1=Annette |title=Emmylou Harris Biography |url=https://musicianguide.com/biographies/1608003196/Emmylou-Harris.html |website=Musician Guide |access-date=July 25, 2023 |archive-date=October 2, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231002020811/https://musicianguide.com/biographies/1608003196/Emmylou-Harris.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Her father was a [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps officer]]<ref name=\"Alabama Encyclopedia\"/> who served in both [[World War II]] and the [[Korean War]]. In the latter, he was taken as a [[Prisoner of War]] and was reported as [[missing in action]]. He was later released. \"I never talked to him about his experiences. He wouldn't ever talk about it,\" she later reflected.<ref name=\"Guardian\">{{cite news |last1=McMahon |first1=James |title=Emmylou Harris: 'There are things I don't think we'll ever know the answers to' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/mar/10/emmylou-harris-country-singer-interview-there-are-things-we-will-never-know-the-answers-to |access-date=July 25, 2023 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=March 10, 2018}}</ref> The Harris family lived in Birmingham through their daughter's first grade school year. Her father was then transferred to [[Cherry Point, North Carolina]], and later to [[Quantico, Virginia]].<ref name=\"Alabama Encyclopedia\"/>\n\nHarris took piano lessons as a child but did not enjoy them.<ref name=\"MHF\">{{cite web|url=https://youtube.com/watch?v=nqtirRn3bBk&pp=ygUYZW1teWxvdSBoYXJyaXMgaW50ZXJ2aWV3|title=Musicians Hall of Fame Backstage: Emmylou Harris Full Interview|publisher=Musicians Hall of Fame & Museum|website=YouTube|year=2020|accessdate=24 August 2024}}</ref> During her high school years, the family eventually settled in nearby [[Woodbridge, Virginia]]. Harris was a straight-A high school student at [[Gar-Field Senior High School]], a cheerleader and a [[saxophone|saxophonist]] in the marching band. She also won the \"Miss Woodbridge\" beauty pageant during her teen years.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363}} Classmates considered Harris unusual because she was devoted to her studies.<ref name=\"Country Music Encyclopedia\">{{cite book |editor1-last=McCall |editor1-first=Michael |editor2-last=Rumble |editor2-first=John |editor3-last=Kingsbury |editor3-first=Paul |title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music |date=1998 |publisher=Country Music Foundation |isbn=0-19-511671-2 |page=230}}</ref> Harris was among many adolescents interested in the [[American folk music revival]] of the 1960s.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363}} She became fascinated with folk artists of the era such as [[Joan Baez]], [[Bob Dylan]] and [[Buffy Sainte-Marie]]. Her grandfather gave Harris her first guitar, which she learned to play.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Simpson |first1=Dave |title=Emmylou Harris's teenage obsessions: 'The Beatles parted the clouds after JFK's assassination' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2021/aug/26/emmylou-harriss-teenage-obsessions-the-beatles-parted-the-clouds-after-jfks-assassination |access-date=July 25, 2023 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=August 26, 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn 1965, Harris graduated from Gar-Field (which was desegregated shortly before she left) as the class [[valedictorian]].{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363}}<ref name=\"Alabama Encyclopedia\"/> Her original intention was to become an actress<ref name=\"Q&A\">{{cite news |last1=Greenstreet |first1=Rosanna |title=Q&A: Emmylou Harris, country singer-songwriter |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/apr/18/emmylou-harris-q-and-a |access-date=July 25, 2023 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=April 20, 2015}}</ref> and she received a drama scholarship from the [[University of North Carolina at Greensboro]]. She began taking classes in the fall of 1965. Harris participated in the school's productions of ''[[The Tempest]]'' and ''The Dancing Donkey''. She also helped form a folk music duo called the Emerald City. The duo worked a series of gigs in the local area, most of which were [[coffeehouse]]s.<ref name=\"UNC\">{{cite web |title=Emmylou Harris |url=https://encyclopedia.uncg.edu/emmylou-harris/ |website=[[University of North Carolina at Greensboro]] |date=July 7, 2016 |access-date=July 25, 2023 |archive-date=December 1, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231201162719/https://encyclopedia.uncg.edu/emmylou-harris/ |url-status=live }}</ref> She also played coffeehouses as a solo performer, primarily in one known as \"The Corner\".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Harris |first1=Mike |title=The story behind that iconic Emmylou Harris photograph |url=https://www.uncg.edu/featured/the-story-behind-that-iconic-emmylou-harris-photograph/ |website=[[University of North Carolina at Greensboro]] |date=January 9, 2020 |access-date=July 25, 2023 |archive-date=July 25, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230725030550/https://www.uncg.edu/featured/the-story-behind-that-iconic-emmylou-harris-photograph/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nIn 1967, Harris dropped out of the University of North Carolina. She then enrolled at [[Boston University]] but would soon drop out as well.<ref name=\"Alabama Encyclopedia\"/> She ultimately chose to pursue a career as a folk singer full-time. Harris briefly moved to [[Virginia Beach, Virginia|Virginia Beach]], where she worked as a waitress and as a folk singer.<ref name=\"UNC\"/> She then left for [[New York City]]'s [[Greenwich Village]] neighborhood where there was a popular folk music scene.<ref name=\"Alabama Encyclopedia\"/> In 1969, Harris married her first husband Tom Slocum and soon gave birth to her first child.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363}}\n\n==Career==\n===1969\u20131974: Folk music and collaborations with Gram Parsons===\nHarris regularly worked the Greenwich Village music scene and developed friendships with fellow artists [[Jerry Jeff Walker]], [[Dave Bromberg]] and [[Paul Siebel]].<ref name=\"Allmusic\">{{cite web |last1=Ankeny |first1=Jason |title=Emmylou Harris Biography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/emmylou-harris-mn0000159699/biography |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=July 25, 2023 |archive-date=July 24, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230724181349/https://www.allmusic.com/artist/emmylou-harris-mn0000159699/biography |url-status=live }}</ref> She worked at several notable Greenwich Village clubs, including [[The Bitter End]].{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363}} She also supported herself by working as a waitress and bookstore cashier. Along with her husband and daughter, Harris lived at a nearby [[YWCA]].<ref name=\"Alabama Encyclopedia\"/> Harris got her first manager and signed with [[Jubilee Records]] in 1969.<ref name=\"Musician Guide\"/> The label released her debut studio album, ''[[Gliding Bird]]'', in 1970.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> The disc featured several recordings penned by Harris herself, along with one penned by her first husband, Tom Slocum. Unlike her later recordings, ''Gliding Bird'' was released under the name \"Emmy Lou Harris\".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Harris |first1=Emmy Lou |title=''Gliding Bird'' (Liner Notes) |journal=[[Jubilee Records]] |date=1969 |id=JGS-8031}}</ref>\n\nJubilee Records declared [[bankruptcy]] shortly after ''Gliding Bird'' was released. Harris and her husband then decided to attempt a music career in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. The couple divorced while in Nashville.<ref name=\"Biography\">{{cite web |title=Emmylou Harris - Spouse, Songs & Age |url=https://www.biography.com/musicians/emmylou-harris |website=[[Biography (TV program)|Biography]] |date=April 27, 2021 |access-date=July 25, 2023 |archive-date=July 24, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230724181357/https://www.biography.com/musicians/emmylou-harris |url-status=live }}</ref> Harris attempted to support herself and her daughter by working as a waitress. However, she was surviving on [[Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program|food stamps]] and [[Medicaid]]. Ultimately, she went back to live with her parents in the Maryland suburb of [[Clarksville, Maryland|Clarksville]], near [[Washington, D.C.]].{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363-364}}<ref name=\"bucky\"/><ref name = \"People-Arrington-1982-11-15\"/> Harris then obtained a hostessing job in [[Columbia, Maryland]].{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=364}}\n\nAt the same time, Harris developed a following performing at clubs in Washington, D.C. and its surrounding suburbs.<ref name=\"Country Music Encyclopedia\"/> Yet, she was unconvinced she could make it as a music artist. \"At that point, I'd retired forever from the music business,\" she recalled.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=364}} Among the clubs Harris worked during this period was [[Clyde's Restaurant Group|Clyde's]] and [[The Cellar Door]].<ref name=\"Country Music Encyclopedia\"/> In 1971, she performed the country song \"[[It Wasn't God Who Made Honky Tonk Angels]]\" one evening at The Cellar Door,  \"almost as a joke\", as she knew little about country music at that time. [[The Flying Burrito Brothers]] noticed her performing while drinking after a show and thought she had potential.<ref name=\"MHF\"/> Though singer-songwriter [[Gram Parsons]] had left  [[the Byrds]] and the Flying Burrito Brothers at this time, he was establishing a solo career and mentioned to the Burritos and friends that he was looking for a harmony singer. A conversation about her at a DC nightclub was overheard by the babysitter of Harris's daughter, who passed on her details, and Parsons got in contact the next day.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sandall |first1=Robert |title=The Ballad of Emmylou Harris |url=https://www.thetimes.com/article/the-ballad-of-emmylou-harris-p5j75sxsrht |access-date=29 June 2024 |work=[[The Times]] |date=July 25, 2014 |archive-date=June 29, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240629152754/https://www.thetimes.com/article/the-ballad-of-emmylou-harris-p5j75sxsrht |url-status=live }}</ref> \n<ref name=\"MHF\"/> Parsons went to hear Harris and was drawn to her singing ability. One year later, he sent her a plane ticket to [[Los Angeles, California]] where she recorded harmony vocals for his debut album ''[[GP (album)|GP]]'' in September-October, 1972. After its release, the album failed to become successful and find a mainstream audience.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=364}}\n\nHarris also toured as a member of Parsons's band (the Grevious Angels) in 1973, and performed vocal harmonies and duets with him.<ref name=\"Alabama Encyclopedia\"/> Through recording and touring, the pair found an instant musical connection.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Parsons had become known for his fusion of [[country rock]] and had a fascination with classic [[country music]]. His passion for the genre was influential on Harris and she soon learned about the country genre. Harris would later credit Parsons for helping her find her artistic direction as well as her passion for authentic country music.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=364}} In 1973, Harris returned to the recording studio to make Parsons' next album, titled ''[[Grievous Angel]]''. Weeks following the album's sessions, Parsons died from a drug and alcohol overdose in a hotel room near [[Joshua Tree National Park]].<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Parsons's ''Grievous Angel'' was released posthumously in 1974, and three more tracks from his sessions with Harris were included on another posthumous Parsons album, ''[[Sleepless Nights (Gram Parsons album)|Sleepless Nights]]'', in 1976. One more album of recorded material from that period was packaged as ''[[Live 1973]]'' but was not released until 1982.<ref name=\"Southern Culture\">Wilson, Charles Reagan; Ferris, William R. (eds.). ''Encyclopedia of Southern Culture'' {{ISBN|978-0-807-81823-7}} p. 1075</ref>\n\n===1975\u20131980: Solo breakthrough===\nAlthough affected by Gram Parsons' death,{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=364}} Harris continued on as a solo artist. She decided to carry on the [[country rock]] legacy left by Parsons for her own career. \"Once I started singing country music with Gram there was no turning back for me,\" she recounted. Harris formed her own band and got a weekly job performing at the Red Fox Inn in [[Bethesda, Maryland]]. Meanwhile, Parsons\u2019 former A&R representative at [[Warner Bros. Records]] (Mary Martin) attempted to launch Harris's own career. She contacted Canadian-based producer [[Brian Ahern (producer)|Brian Ahern]], who had recent success working alongside [[Anne Murray]]. Impressed by her, Ahern agreed to produce Harris.<ref name=\"Washington Post\">{{cite news |last1=Himes |first1=Geoffrey |title=Emmylou Harris, back where it all started |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/going-out-guide/wp/2015/01/08/emmylou-harris-back-where-it-all-started/ |access-date=July 26, 2023 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=January 8, 2015 |archive-date=July 27, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727133904/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/going-out-guide/wp/2015/01/08/emmylou-harris-back-where-it-all-started/?noredirect=on |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> The pair would later marry in 1977<ref name = \"People-Arrington-1982-11-15\">{{cite magazine | url = http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20083549,00.html | date = November 15, 1982 | issue = 20 | title = Singer Emmylou Harris and Producer Brian Ahern Make (and Record) Beautiful Music Together | first = Carl | last = Arrington | magazine = People | volume = 18 | access-date = August 7, 2013 | archive-date = June 30, 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160630014225/http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20083549,00.html | url-status = live }}</ref> and Harris then signed with Warner Bros.\u2013[[Reprise Records|Reprise]].<ref name=\"Biography\"/>\n\n[[File:Emmylou Harris at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|160px|Harris in 1976]]\nAhern produced Harris's next several albums<ref name=\"Biography\"/> beginning with 1975's ''[[Pieces of the Sky]]''.<ref name=\"Washington Post\"/> It featured covers of songs by [[The Beatles]] and [[Merle Haggard]],<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> along with originals like Harris' \"[[Boulder to Birmingham]]\", which reflected her emotions surrounding Parsons's death.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=364}} The disc was a commercial success,{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=364-365}}<ref name=\"No Depression Elite Hotel\">{{cite journal |last1=Alden |first1=Grant |title=Emmylou Harris \u2013 Pieces Of The Sky / Elite Hotel / Luxury Liner / Quarter Moon In A Ten Cent Town / Blue Kentucky Girl |journal=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]] |date=March 1, 2004 |url=https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/emmylou-harris-pieces-of-the-sky-elite-hotel-luxury-liner-quarter-moon-in-a-ten-cent-town-blue-kentucky-girl/ |access-date=July 26, 2023 |archive-date=July 26, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230726024136/https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/emmylou-harris-pieces-of-the-sky-elite-hotel-luxury-liner-quarter-moon-in-a-ten-cent-town-blue-kentucky-girl/ |url-status=live }}</ref> reaching number seven on the American ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums|country LP]]'s chart<ref name=\"Country Albums\">{{cite book |last1=Whitburn |first1=Joel |title=Joel Whitburn Presents Hot Country Albums, 1964-2007 |date=2008 |publisher=Record Research, Inc. |isbn=978-0898201734 |page=301}}</ref> and number 45 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200 all-genre chart]].<ref name=\"Billboard 200\">{{cite magazine |title=Emmylou Harris chart history (Billboard 200) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/emmylou-harris/chart-history/tlp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=July 22, 2023 |archive-date=July 22, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230722005102/https://www.billboard.com/artist/emmylou-harris/chart-history/tlp/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Its second single, \"[[If I Could Only Win Your Love]]\" reached number four on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs|country songs]] chart<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> and topped the Canadian ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' country chart.<ref name=\"Canada Country Songs\">{{cite magazine|title=Search results for \"Emmylou Harris\" under \"Country Singles\"|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-110.01-e.php?PHPSESSID=gmrhouli7kvfvaeu848ka389j0&q1=emmylou+harris&q2=Country+Singles&interval=20|magazine=RPM|access-date=July 13, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121016041153/http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-110.01-e.php?PHPSESSID=gmrhouli7kvfvaeu848ka389j0&q1=emmylou+harris&q2=Country+Singles&interval=20|archive-date=October 16, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> It was followed by 1975's ''[[Elite Hotel]]''.<ref name=\"Washington Post\"/> It was her first to top the ''Billboard'' country chart<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> while also climbing into ''Billboard'' 200 top 25.<ref name=\"Billboard 200\"/> The disc's covers of [[Buck Owens]]'s \"[[Together Again (Buck Owens song)|Together Again]]\" and [[Don Gibson]]'s \"[[Sweet Dreams (Don Gibson song)|Sweet Dreams]]\" topped the ''Billboard'' country chart.<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/><ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Harris formed a new backing group for the project called The Hot Band. The group featured [[James Burton]], [[Glen D. Hardin]] (both members of [[Elvis Presley]]'s [[TCB Band]]) and [[Rodney Crowell]].<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>\n\nHarris' albums received critical and commercial success.<ref name=\"Cullman Times\">{{cite news |last1=Gillespie |first1=Loretta |title=SOUTHERN STYLE: Always a lady, Emmylou Harris |url=https://www.cullmantimes.com/community/southern-style-always-a-lady-emmylou-harris/article_e598834e-86ea-5f0f-8ef2-57985e700a7a.html |access-date=July 26, 2023 |work=[[The Cullman Times]] |date=April 6, 2014 |archive-date=July 26, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230726040952/https://www.cullmantimes.com/community/southern-style-always-a-lady-emmylou-harris/article_e598834e-86ea-5f0f-8ef2-57985e700a7a.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Adam Sweeting of ''[[The Guardian]]'' found ''Pieces of the Sky'' to have \"many brilliant songs\".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sweeting |first1=Adam |title=Emmylou Harris, Pieces of the Sky |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2004/apr/09/popandrock.shopping |access-date=July 26, 2023 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=April 8, 2004 |archive-date=January 30, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200130102159/https://www.theguardian.com/music/2004/apr/09/popandrock.shopping |url-status=live }}</ref> Grant Alden of ''[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]'' concluded that when both LP's are played 'front to back' it makes for \"an astonishing, almost blemish-free collection\".<ref name=\"No Depression Elite Hotel\"/> ''Elite Hotel'' also brought Harris the [[Grammy Award for Best Female Country Vocal Performance]].<ref name=\"Biography\"/> Additionally, both LPs were certified gold in the United States for selling over half a million copies each.<ref name=\"RIAA\"/>\n\nHarris's next several studio collections included both traditional country cover tunes and new material.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=365-366}} In 1976, Warner Bros. issued her fourth album, ''[[Luxury Liner (album)|Luxury Liner]]'',<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Harris |first1=Emmylou |title=''Luxury Liner'' (Liner Notes) |journal=[[Warner Bros. Records]] |date=December 29, 1975 |id=BS-2998 (LP); M5-2998 (Cassette)}}</ref> which was her second number-one US country album.<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> It also was her second to make the top 20 in the [[UK Albums Chart|United Kingdom]]<ref name=\"UK Albums\">{{cite web |title=EMMYLOU HARRIS: Official Charts Company |url=https://www.officialcharts.com/artist/15667/emmylou-harris/ |website=[[Official Charts Company]] |access-date=July 22, 2023 |archive-date=April 20, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190420203556/https://www.officialcharts.com/artist/15667/emmylou-harris/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and third to certify gold in the US.<ref name=\"RIAA\"/> Jason Ankeny named it \"one of her most engaging efforts\".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ankeny |first1=Jason |title=''Luxury Liner'': Emmylou Harris: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/luxury-liner-mw0000197652 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=July 26, 2023 |archive-date=July 20, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180720165659/https://www.allmusic.com/album/luxury-liner-mw0000197652 |url-status=live }}</ref> Warner Bros. followed it with 1978's ''[[Quarter Moon in a Ten Cent Town]]'',<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Harris |first1=Emmylou |title=''Quarter Moon in a Ten Cent Town'' (Liner Notes) |journal=[[Warner Bros. Records]] |date=January 6, 1978 |id=BSK-3141 (LP); BSK-3141 (Cassette)}}</ref> which was considered to have \"over-careful production\", according to Grant Alden.<ref name=\"No Depression Elite Hotel\"/> It made the top five of the US country chart,<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> the top 25 of the US all-genre chart,<ref name=\"Billboard 200\"/> the top ten of the Canadian country chart<ref name=\"RPM Country Albums\">{{cite magazine|title=Search results for \"Emmylou Harris\" under \"Country Albums/CD's\"|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-110.01-e.php?PHPSESSID=gmrhouli7kvfvaeu848ka389j0&q1=emmylou+harris&q2=Country+Albums%2FCDs&interval=20|magazine=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]|access-date=July 12, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121016041116/http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-110.01-e.php?PHPSESSID=gmrhouli7kvfvaeu848ka389j0&q1=emmylou+harris&q2=Country+Albums%2FCDs&interval=20|archive-date=October 16, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> and later certified gold in sales.<ref name=\"RIAA\"/> The albums spawned the number one US and Canadian country singles \"[[Making Believe]]\", \"[[To Daddy]]\" and \"[[Two More Bottles of Wine]]\". They also spawned a top ten cover of \"[[You Never Can Tell (song)|You Never Can Tell (C'est La Vie)]]\" and the US top 20 original tune \"[[Easy From Now On]]\".<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/><ref name=\"Canada Country Songs\"/>\n\nHarris' record label proposed shifting her career towards [[country pop]] [[crossover (music)|crossover stardom]].{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=365}} Instead, Harris recorded two traditionally-oriented albums, beginning with 1979's ''[[Blue Kentucky Girl (Emmylou Harris album)|Blue Kentucky Girl]]''.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=365}}<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> It was a top-ten disc on the North American country charts and received a gold certification.<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/><ref name=\"RPM Country Albums\"/><ref name=\"RIAA\"/> It also won a Grammy Award for Best Female Country Vocal Performance.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=365}} The follow-up was 1980's ''[[Roses in the Snow]]'', which was considered to embed [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] sounds.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=365}} Like its predecessor, ''Roses in the Snow'' went gold<ref name=\"RIAA\"/> and reached the number two on the country charts in the US and Canada.<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/><ref name=\"RPM Country Albums\"/> Harris' new bluegrass sound was credited to the new Hot Band member [[Ricky Skaggs]], who replaced Rodney Crowell.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Both albums spawned top ten US and Canadian country singles: \"[[Save the Last Dance for Me]]\", \"[[Blue Kentucky Girl (song)|Blue Kentucky Girl]]\", \"[[The Wayfaring Stranger (song)|Wayfaring Stranger]]\". Additionally, \"[[Beneath Still Waters (song)|Beneath Still Waters]]\" went to the number one spot in both countries.<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/><ref name=\"Canada Country Songs\"/> ''Billboard'' named ''Blue Kentucky Girl'' among its April 1979 \"Top Album Picks\", calling Harris' voice \"crystal clear\",<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Billboard's Top Album Picks: Pop |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=April 28, 1979 |page=110 |url=https://worldradiohistory.com/hd2/IDX-Business/Music/Billboard-Index/IDX/1979/1979-04-28-Billboard-Page-0110.pdf#search=%22emmylou%20harris%20blue%20kentucky%20girl%20lp%20review%22 |access-date=July 26, 2023 |archive-date=July 26, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230726161812/https://worldradiohistory.com/hd2/IDX-Business/Music/Billboard-Index/IDX/1979/1979-04-28-Billboard-Page-0110.pdf#search=%22emmylou%20harris%20blue%20kentucky%20girl%20lp%20review%22 |url-status=live }}</ref> while ''[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]]'' magazine highlighted Harris's \"beautiful, sensitive voice\" on ''Roses in the Snow''.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=COUNTRY: Album Reviews |magazine=[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]] |date=May 10, 1980 |page=41 |url=https://worldradiohistory.com/hd2/IDX-Business/Music/Archive-Cash-Box-IDX/80s/1980/CB-1980-05-10-OCR-Page-0041.pdf#search=%22emmylou%20harris%20roses%20in%20the%20snow%20lp%20review%22 |access-date=July 26, 2023 |archive-date=July 26, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230726161815/https://worldradiohistory.com/hd2/IDX-Business/Music/Archive-Cash-Box-IDX/80s/1980/CB-1980-05-10-OCR-Page-0041.pdf#search=%22emmylou%20harris%20roses%20in%20the%20snow%20lp%20review%22 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nHarris gave birth to a second daughter during this period and briefly stopped touring. Shortly beforehand, the [[Christmas music|Christmas]]-themed ''[[Light of the Stable]]'' (1979) was released and was followed by ''[[Evangeline (Emmylou Harris album)|Evangeline]]'' (1981). The latter was a studio collection compiled from songs that were \"left off\" former albums.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> ''Evangeline'' certified gold in sales<ref name=\"RIAA\"/> and reached number five on the US country chart.<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> It spawned a cover of \"[[Mr. Sandman|Mister Sandman]]\", which topped the Canadian country chart,<ref name=\"Canada Country Songs\"/> reached the US country top ten<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/> and made the US pop top 40.<ref name=\"Hot 100\">{{cite magazine |title=Emmylou Harris charts history (Hot 100) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/emmylou-harris/chart-history/hsi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=July 18, 2023 |archive-date=April 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230405021728/https://www.billboard.com/artist/emmylou-harris/chart-history/hsi/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Although the song's album version featured harmony vocals from [[Dolly Parton]] and [[Linda Ronstadt]], Harris harmonized with herself for the single version.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Leszczak |first1=Bob |title=Who Did It First?: Great Pop Cover Songs and Their Original Artists |date=2014 |publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]] |isbn=978-1442230675 |page=134}}</ref> Harris also collaborated with [[Roy Orbison]] during this time for the 1980 single \"That Lovin' You Feeling Again\". It would later win the Grammy for [[Best Country Vocal Performance by a Duo or Group]].<ref name=\"fixed\">{{cite web |title=Emmylou Harris: Artist |url=https://www.grammy.com/artists/emmylou-harris/13460 |website=[[Grammy Awards]] |access-date=29 June 2024 |archive-date=July 5, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220705191559/https://www.grammy.com/artists/emmylou-harris/13460 |url-status=live }}</ref> Harris also won the [[Country Music Association Award for Female Vocalist of the Year|Female Vocalist of the Year]] award from the [[Country Music Association]].{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=365}}\n\n===1981\u20131990: Commercial decline, comeback with ''Trio'' and further Warner Bros. releases===\nAround 1981, Ricky Skaggs left the Hot Band and was replaced by [[Barry Tashian]].<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Drummer John Ware also left Harris' backing group, which prompted her to reform the Hot Band with new members. Her next studio album, ''[[Cimarron (album)|Cimarron]]'' (1981) was cut with the new Hot Band.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=63}} It made the US country albums top ten and the US all-genre top 50.<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/><ref name=\"Billboard 200\"/> It spawned the US and Canadian top ten country songs \"[[Born to Run (Emmylou Harris song)|Born to Run]]\" and \"[[Tennessee Rose]]\". A duet with [[Don Williams]] called \"[[If I Needed You]]\" topped the Canadian country chart.<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/><ref name=\"RPM Country Songs\">{{cite web|url=http://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/list.aspx?OCRText=Nanci+Griffith&ChartEn=Country+Singles&|title=Results \u2013 RPM \u2013 Library and Archives Canada \u2013 Country Singles|work=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]|date=July 17, 2013|access-date=July 27, 2023|archive-date=June 26, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220626210933/https://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/list.aspx?OCRText=Nanci+Griffith&ChartEn=Country+Singles&|url-status=live}}</ref> In 1982, Harris and the Hot Band recorded her first [[live album]], titled ''[[Last Date (Emmylou Harris album)|Last Date]]''.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=63}} Its lead single was a vocal version of [[Floyd Cramer]]'s instrumental original song \"[[Last Date (song)|Last Date]]\". The single topped the US country chart and was followed by the top-five single \"[[I'm Moving On (Hank Snow song)|I'm Movin' On]]\".<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>{{sfn|Dicaire|p=63}} Both albums received mixed reviews, with Grant Alden of ''No Depression'' finding that ''Cimarron'' and ''Last Date'' are no \"monumental artistic statement\" but occasionally \"have their moments\".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Alden |first1=Grant |title=Emmylou Harris \u2013 ''Cimarron'' / ''Last Date'' |journal=[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]] |date=July 1, 2000 |url=https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/emmylou-harris-cimarron-last-date/ |access-date=July 27, 2023 |archive-date=April 11, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190411085635/https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/emmylou-harris-cimarron-last-date/ |url-status=live }}</ref> William Ruhlmann of [[AllMusic]] gave ''Last Date'' 2.5 stars, explaining that Harris failed to create original styles and arrangements that previously set her apart.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ruhlmann |first1=William |title=''Last Date'': Emmylou Harris: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/last-date-mw0000605460 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=July 27, 2023 |archive-date=July 20, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180720165904/https://www.allmusic.com/album/last-date-mw0000605460 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nHarris' final album under Brian Ahern's production (the pair would then divorce) was released in 1983, called ''[[White Shoes]]''.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=63}} The disc featured a collection of cover songs.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Among its tracks were the singles \"[[Pledging My Love]]\" and \"[[In My Dreams (Emmylou Harris song)|In My Dreams]]\", both of which reached the US and Canadian country top ten.<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/><ref name=\"Canada Country Songs\"/> ''White Shoes'' was among her lowest-peaking albums to date on the US country chart, stalling at number 22.<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> Harris then relocated to Nashville, where she collaborated with new producer [[Paul Kennerly]] (whom she later married). The pair composed ''[[The Ballad of Sally Rose]]'', which was released by Warner Bros. in 1985.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=63}} Featuring compositions written by Harris herself, ''The Ballad of Sally Rose''. The record was loosely based on her time with Gram Parsons.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Emmylou Harris: The Ballad of Sally Rose |magazine=Guitar Girl |date=April 2, 2018 |url=https://guitargirlmag.com/news/music-news/emmylou-harris-ballad-sally-rose/ |access-date=29 June 2024 |archive-date=June 29, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240629153921/https://guitargirlmag.com/news/music-news/emmylou-harris-ballad-sally-rose/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Despite reaching the US country top ten<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> the album ultimately resulted in poor record sales and was considered a commercial failure.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/><ref name=\"Biography\"/> Yet its embedding of various musical styles was praised by critics.<ref name=\"Biography\"/>{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=366}}\n{{multiple image\n | width1 = 143\n | image1 = Dolly Parton with square red earrings.jpg\n | width2 = 148\n | image2 = 19810800-05-LindaRonstadt.jpg\n | footer = In the middle 1980s, Harris collaborated alongside friends [[Dolly Parton]] (left) and [[Linda Ronstadt]] (right)  to record the album ''[[Trio (1987 album)|Trio]]''. The album was critically acclaimed and a commercial success.\n}}\n\nIn 1986, Warner Bros. released her next studio album, ''[[Thirteen (Emmylou Harris album)|Thirteen]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Harris |first1=Emmylou |title=''Thirteen'' (Liner Notes) |journal=[[Warner Bros. Records]] |date=February 1986 |id=9-25351-1 (LP); 9-25351 (CD); W1-25351-4 (Cassette)}}</ref> The disc was described by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' as a \"roots record\" with comparisons drawn to 1980's ''Roses in the Snow''. However, the album proved to be less successful.<ref name=\"Rolling Stone Book\">{{cite book |editor1-last=David Hoard |editor1-first=Christian |editor2-last=Brackett |editor2-first=Nathan |title=The New Rolling Stone Album Guide |date=2004 |publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]] |isbn=978-0743201698 |page=366}}</ref> Both of its singles reached positions outside the top 40 on the North American country charts.<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/><ref name=\"Canada Country Songs\"/> Although recorded prior to ''Thirteen'', ''[[Angel Band (album)|Angel Band]]'' followed on Warner Bros. in 1987 and was an album of [[Gospel music|gospel]] material.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=63}} ''Rolling Stone'' described it as a \"solid but [low-key]\" gospel project\".<ref name=\"Rolling Stone Book\"/> It was Harris' third album to only reach the ''Billboard'' country top 25.<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/>\n\nIn 1987, Harris collaborated with [[Dolly Parton]] and [[Linda Ronstadt]] to record the studio album, ''[[Trio (1987 album)|Trio]]''.<ref name=\"Biography\"/><ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> The women had been friends for over a decade and had intentions to record an album together for years. Several tracks that had originally been laid down were scrapped and replaced by a new studio collection of country\u2013folk songs. ''Trio'' featured Harris, Parton and Ronstadt singing together in harmony and often featured one of the women singing lead vocals.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rockwell |first1=John |title=Three of Pop's Best Go Romping in the Country |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/01/arts/three-of-pop-s-best-go-romping-in-the-country.html |access-date=July 28, 2023 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 1, 1987 |archive-date=November 8, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108195609/http://www.nytimes.com/1987/03/01/arts/three-of-pop-s-best-go-romping-in-the-country.html |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> ''Trio'' became a commercial success and is the best-selling disc of Harris' career.<ref name=\"Biography\"/><ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Following its March 1987 release, ''Trio'' reached number one on the US country chart,<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> number six on the US all-genre list,<ref name=\"Billboard 200\"/> number 12 in Australia<ref name=\"Australia Albums\">Australian chart peaks:\n*Top 100 ([[Kent Music Report]]) peaks to June 12, 1988: {{cite book|last=Kent|first=David|author-link=David Kent (historian)|title=Australian Chart Book 1970\u20131992|edition=Illustrated|publisher=Australian Chart Book|location=St Ives, N.S.W.|year=1993|pages=132|isbn=0-646-11917-6}} N.B. The Kent Report chart was licensed by [[Australian Recording Industry Association|ARIA]] between mid-1983 and June 12, 1988.\n*Top 100 (ARIA) peaks from January 1990 to December 2010: {{cite book|last=Ryan|first=Gavin|title=Australia's Music Charts 1988\u20132010|year=2011|publisher=Moonlight Publishing|location=Mt. Martha, VIC, Australia|edition=pdf}}</ref> and number four in Canada.<ref name=\"RPM Top Albums\">{{cite magazine|title=Search results for \"Emmylou Harris\" under \"Top Albums/CD's\"|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-110.01-e.php?PHPSESSID=gmrhouli7kvfvaeu848ka389j0&q1=emmylou+harris&q2=Top+Albums%2FCDs&interval=20|magazine=RPM|access-date=July 12, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121016041146/http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-110.01-e.php?PHPSESSID=gmrhouli7kvfvaeu848ka389j0&q1=emmylou+harris&q2=Top+Albums%2FCDs&interval=20|archive-date=October 16, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\"Billboard Canadian Albums\"/> Spawned from the disc were the North American top ten country songs \"[[To Know Him Is to Love Him]]\", \"[[Telling Me Lies]]\", \"[[Those Memories of You]]\" and \"[[Wildflowers (Dolly Parton song)|Wildflowers]]\".<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/><ref name=\"Canada Country Songs\"/>\n\nIn 1989, Warner Bros. released the solo album ''[[Bluebird (Emmylou Harris album)|Bluebird]]''. It included material penned by songwriters [[Kate McGarrigle]] and [[Anna McGarrigle]], and two songs penned by Harris herself.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Harris |first1=Emmylou |title=''Bluebird'' (Liner Notes) |journal=[[Warner Bros. Records]] |date=July 7, 1987 |id=9-25776-1 (LP);9-25776-2 (CD); 9-25776-4 (Cassette)}}</ref> Considered a [[country rock]] effort by ''Rolling Stone''<ref name=\"Rolling Stone Book\"/> the album peaked in the top 20 of both the US and Canadian country charts.<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/><ref name=\"RPM Country Albums\"/> Its lead single, \"[[Heartbreak Hill (song)|Heartbreak Hill]]\", returned Harris to the top ten as a solo artist and was followed by the top 20 single, \"[[Heaven Only Knows (Emmylou Harris song)|Heaven Only Knows]]\".<ref name=\"Country Songs\"/><ref name=\"Canada Country Songs\"/> Her final studio album with Warner Bros. was released in 1990, titled ''[[Brand New Dance]]''. It was categorized as an \"uninspired misfire\" by Rolling Stone<ref name=\"Rolling Stone Book\"/> while AllMusic drew similar comparisons to Harris seeming disengaged with the material.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Deming |first1=Mark |title=''Brand New Dance'': Emmylou Harris: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/brand-new-dance-mw0000310110 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=July 28, 2023 |archive-date=July 28, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230728034904/https://www.allmusic.com/album/brand-new-dance-mw0000310110 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n===1991\u20131999: New artistic directions and further collaborations===\nAround 1991, Harris deformed the Hot Band and formed a new backing group called the Nash Ramblers. The group included [[Sam Bush]] playing [[fiddle]], [[Al Perkins]] playing [[banjo]] and guitar, and [[Jon Randall]] performing various instruments.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=64}} Harris then intended to record a live album of material she had never performed before. It was suggested by music executive Bonnie Garner to record the set at the [[Ryman Auditorium]] (the former site of the [[Grand Ole Opry]], which was becoming increasingly dilapidated). In spring 1991, Harris and the Nash Ramblers recorded the live project over three nights with only 200 guests in attendance.<ref name=\"At the Ryman\">{{cite news |last1=Thanki |first1=Juli |title=How Emmylou Harris helped bring magic back to the Ryman |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2017/04/28/how-emmylou-harris-helped-bring-magic-back-ryman/100700596/ |access-date=July 28, 2023 |work=[[The Tennessean]] |date=May 2, 2017}}</ref> The live disc was released in 1992 and was titled ''[[At the Ryman]]''<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> and was met with critical acclaim.<ref name=\"Country Music Encyclopedia\"/><ref>{{cite book |last1=Kronenburg |first1=Robert |title=Live Architecture Venues, Stages and Arenas for Popular Music |date=2013 |publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]] |isbn=978-1135719166 |page=36}}</ref> Writers have since speculated the project brought renewed interest to the Ryman Auditorium and several months following the album, the venue was refurbished.<ref name=\"Country Music Encyclopedia\"/>\n\nHarris was also president of the [[Country Music Foundation]] in the early 1990s{{sfn|Dicaire|p=64}} and became an official member of the Grand Ole Opry in 1992.<ref>{{cite web | title = EmmyLou Harris | url = http://www.opry.com/artists/h/Harris_Emmylou.html | publisher = Grand Ole Opry | access-date = June 29, 2012 | archive-date = May 14, 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170514083526/http://www.opry.com/artists/h/Harris_Emmylou.html | url-status = dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web\n |title=Opry Members List\n |url=http://www.opry.com/img/Opry%20Members%20List.pdf \n |date=April 23, 2012 |access-date=June 29, 2012 |url-status=dead | publisher = Grand Ole Opry \n |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607030858/http://www.opry.com/img/Opry%20Members%20List.pdf \n |archive-date=June 7, 2012 }}</ref> Harris also departed from Warner\u2013Reprise during this period and signed a new contract with [[Asylum Records]]. In 1993, the label released the studio project ''[[Cowgirl's Prayer]]''. It was Harris' last project produced by Paul Kennerley and the pair divorced shortly afterward.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=64}} The album made the top 40 of the US country albums chart<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> and the top 20 of the Canadian country albums chart.<ref name=\"RPM Country Albums\"/> Despite critical acclaim its singles received limited radio airplay. Two of its singles made the US and Canada country charts, but failed to make positions inside the top 40.<ref name=\"Cromelin1996\">{{cite web |author=Cromelin, Richard |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1996-04-11-ca-57283-story.html |title=Q & A with Emmylou Harris: Singing with a Voice That's Always True to Her Heart |date=April 11, 1996 |access-date=May 14, 2011 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |archive-date=November 6, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106223803/http://articles.latimes.com/1996-04-11/entertainment/ca-57283_1_emmylou-harris |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref><ref name=\"Country Songs\"/><ref name=\"Canada Country Songs\"/>\n\nBy the middle 1990s, Harris was feeling excluded by country music radio. Asylum Records gave her the musical freedom to record her next album. In 1995, Asylum issued the studio album ''[[Wrecking Ball (Emmylou Harris album)|Wrecking Ball]]''.<ref name=\"LA Times\">{{cite news |last1=Lewis |first1=Randy |title=Emmylou Harris recalls her 'magical' album 'Wrecking Ball' |url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-xpm-2014-apr-03-la-et-ms-emmylou-harris-20140403-story.html |access-date=July 30, 2023 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=April 3, 2014 |archive-date=July 30, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230730230451/https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-xpm-2014-apr-03-la-et-ms-emmylou-harris-20140403-story.html |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> The disc was produced by [[Daniel Lanois]] (known for producing [[U2]] and [[Peter Gabriel]]), who embedded an [[alternative rock]] style into its sound and style.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=64}} According to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', its production has been considered influential in establishing the [[Americana (music)|Americana]] music genre.<ref name=\"LA Times\"/> Although ignored by country radio, ''Wrecking Ball'' reached number 94 on the US albums chart,<ref name=\"Billboard 200\"/> number 58 in Canada<ref name=\"RPM Top Albums\"/> number 46 in the UK<ref name=\"UK Albums\"/> and received the [[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Folk Album]].<ref name=\"Biography\"/> Jason Ankeny of AllMusic called it \"a hypnotic, staggeringly beautiful work\",<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> while Allison Hussey of ''[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]'' called it \"a staggering work that defied expectations for what a middle-aged woman should be doing with her time.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hussey |first1=Allison |title=Albums: ''Wrecking Ball'' |url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/emmylou-harris-wrecking-ball/ |website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]] |access-date=July 30, 2023 |archive-date=February 14, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230214071455/https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/emmylou-harris-wrecking-ball/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nIn 1998, Harris's third live album, ''[[Spyboy (album)|Spyboy]]'', was released.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> It featured live cuts of songs that Harris had recorded throughout her career. It was recorded with Harris's new backing band, which were also called Spyboy.<ref>{{cite news |last1=White |first1=Timothy |title=Harris' SPYBOY album a labor of love |url=https://www.tampabay.com/archive/1998/08/03/harris-spyboy-album-a-labor-of-love/ |access-date=July 30, 2023 |work=[[Tampa Bay Times]] |url-access=subscription |date=August 3, 1998 |archive-date=July 30, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230730235313/https://www.tampabay.com/archive/1998/08/03/harris-spyboy-album-a-labor-of-love/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Also in 1998, Harris appeared on [[Willie Nelson]]'s ''[[Teatro (Willie Nelson album)|Teatro]]'' album, featuring production from Harris then-producer Lanois.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1998-sep-05-ca-19591-story.html |title=Willie Nelson, \"Teatro,\" Island. |author=Cromelin, Richard |date=September 5, 1998 |access-date=May 15, 2011 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |archive-date=November 6, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106225632/http://articles.latimes.com/1998/sep/05/entertainment/ca-19591 |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref>\n\nIn 1999, Asylum issued the second collaborative album by Harris, Parton and Ronstadt titled ''[[Trio II]]''. Although the project was completed in 1994, it took five years to be released.<ref name=\"Trio II\">{{cite news |last1=Harrington |first1=Richard |title=Threepeat: 'Trio II' Is the Latest from Emmylou Harris, Linda Ronstadt and Dolly Parton. And We Do Mean Late |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1999/02/10/threepeat-trio-ii-is-the-latest-from-emmylou-harris-linda-ronstadt-and-dolly-parton-and-we-do-mean-late/410e7186-8d56-4cf9-843c-e1ab84a68bfa/ |access-date=July 31, 2023 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=February 10, 1999 |archive-date=April 7, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200407164504/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1999/02/10/threepeat-trio-ii-is-the-latest-from-emmylou-harris-linda-ronstadt-and-dolly-parton-and-we-do-mean-late/410e7186-8d56-4cf9-843c-e1ab84a68bfa/ |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> ''Trio II'' rose to the number four position on the North American country album charts<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/><ref name=\"RPM Country Albums\"/> certified gold in the United States.<ref name=\"RIAA\"/> ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' called the disc \"an angelic encounter\",<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Corliss |first1=Richard |title=Music: Trio II: Emmylou Harris, Linda Ronstadt, Dolly Parton |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=March 8, 1999 |url=https://content.time.com/time/subscriber/article/0,33009,990420,00.html |access-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230731001729/https://content.time.com/time/subscriber/article/0,33009,990420,00.html |url-status=live }}</ref> while ''The Washington Post'' found it was \"not worth the wait\" due to the disc's \"sense of familiarity\".<ref name=\"Trio II\"/> Its single \"After the Gold Rush\" brought the three artists the [[Grammy Award for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals|Best Country Collaboration with Vocals]] accolade from the Grammys.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=64}} Meanwhile, Harris and Ronstadt had been wanting to make their own collaborative album together. After years of discussion and planning, the pair released ''[[Western Wall: The Tucson Sessions]]''. The album was also released on Asylum in 1999.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Newman |first1=Melinda |title=Ronstadt/Harris Do Duets |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=August 21, 1999 |page=11 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nAgEAAAAMBAJ&dq=emmylou+harris+and+linda+ronstadt+team+up+for+western+wall+the+tucson+sessions&pg=PA11 |access-date=July 31, 2023}}</ref> Within a month, the collaborative project reached number six on the US country chart and number 73 on the US ''Billboard'' 200.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Jessen |first1=Wade |title=Country Corner |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=September 11, 1999 |page=57; 104 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oggEAAAAMBAJ&dq=emmylou+harris+trio+II+took+nearly+ten+years+to+make&pg=PT58 |access-date=August 26, 2023 |archive-date=September 28, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230928222608/https://books.google.com/books?id=oggEAAAAMBAJ&dq=emmylou+harris+trio+II+took+nearly+ten+years+to+make&pg=PT58 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n===2000\u20132011: From song interpreter to singer-songwriter===\nHarris parted ways with her record label and management during this period.<ref name=\"NY Times Magazine\">{{cite magazine |last1=Menaker |first1=Daniel |title=The Romance of Remorse |magazine=[[The New York Times Magazine]] |date=September 3, 2000 |url=https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/library/magazine/home/20000903mag-emmylou.html |access-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230731033137/https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/library/magazine/home/20000903mag-emmylou.html |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2000, she signed with [[Nonesuch Records]] and that year the label released her first solo studio album in five years, called ''[[Red Dirt Girl]]''. It was Harris' first disc since ''The Ballad of Sally Rose'' that featured mostly self-written recordings.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Taylor |first1=Chuck |title=Emmylou Harris Plans Nonesuch Debut |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=July 1, 2000 |page=1; 72 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BxAEAAAAMBAJ&dq=emmylou+harris+signs+with+nonesuch+records+in+2000&pg=PA72 |access-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-date=September 28, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230928222607/https://books.google.com/books?id=BxAEAAAAMBAJ&dq=emmylou%20harris%20signs%20with%20nonesuch%20records%20in%202000&pg=PA72 |url-status=live }}</ref> It also featured [[Bruce Springsteen]] and [[Patty Griffin]] singing background vocals.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=64}} ''Time'' called it \"a surprisingly raw and confessional collection\"<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Gregg |first1=Jonathan |title=MUSIC: Pickin' Up the Pieces |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=September 21, 2000 |url=https://content.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,55535,00.html |access-date=July 31, 2023}}</ref> while ''[[The Guardian]]'' called it \"superb\".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sweeting |first1=Adam |title=The prime of Miss Emmylou Harris |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2000/nov/22/artsfeatures5 |access-date=July 31, 2023 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=November 21, 2000}}</ref> ''Red Dirt Girl'' rose to number five on the US country albums chart,<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> number 54 on the US all-genre chart,<ref name=\"Billboard 200\"/> number three on the Canadian country albums chart<ref name=\"RPM Country Albums\"/> and number 29 on the Canadian all-genre chart.<ref name=\"RPM Top Albums\"/> Its single \"I Don't Wanna Talk About It Now\" was Harris' first to make the US [[Adult Alternative Airplay]] chart.<ref name=\"AAA\">{{cite magazine |title=Emmylou Harris chart history (Adult Alternative Airplay) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/emmylou-harris/chart-history/hsi/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=July 18, 2023 |archive-date=April 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230405021728/https://www.billboard.com/artist/emmylou-harris/chart-history/hsi/ |url-status=live }}</ref> ''Red Dirt Girl'' won Harris another Grammy for Best Contemporary Folk album.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=64}} Harris also contributed to the [[O Brother, Where Art Thou? (soundtrack)|soundtrack]] of ''[[O Brother, Where Art Thou?]]'', which won a Grammy for [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=Flashback: 'O Brother, Where Art Thou' Wins Album of the Year Grammy |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=March 28, 2017 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/flashback-o-brother-where-art-thou-wins-album-of-the-year-grammy-125585/ |access-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-date=May 11, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230511020237/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/flashback-o-brother-where-art-thou-wins-album-of-the-year-grammy-125585/ |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref>\n\n[[File:Mark Knopfler and Emmylou Harris.jpg|thumb|left|150px|In 2006, Harris joined [[Mark Knopfler]] of [[Dire Straits]] fame to record ''[[All the Roadrunning]]''. Pictured is the pair performing live in The Netherlands.]]\nIn 2003, Harris followed up with her next studio release ''[[Stumble into Grace]]''.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Like its predecessor, the album contained self-penned songs. It also featured harmony vocals from Linda Ronstadt.<ref name=\"Stumble into Grace\">{{cite magazine |title=''Stumble into Grace'' |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=October 4, 2003 |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/stumble-into-grace-68909/ |access-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230731035413/https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/stumble-into-grace-68909/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Allmusic's Mark Deming commented that \"''Stumble into Grace'' shows she's still playing at the top of her game\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Deming |first1=Mark |title=''Stumble into Grace'': Emmylou Harris |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/stumble-into-grace-mw0000315894 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230731035414/https://www.allmusic.com/album/stumble-into-grace-mw0000315894 |url-status=live }}</ref> and ''Billboard'' called it \"a very affecting record\".<ref name=\"Stumble into Grace\"/> The album reached the US country top ten<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> and made the top 20 in both Norway and Sweden.<ref name=\"Norweigan charts\">{{cite web |title=Norwegian charts portal: Emmylou Harris |url=https://norwegiancharts.com/search.asp?cat=a&search=emmylou+harris |website=norwegancharts.com |access-date=July 22, 2023 |archive-date=June 26, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190626084106/https://norwegiancharts.com/search.asp?cat=a&search=Emmylou+harris |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=\"Swedish Albums\">{{cite web |title=Swedish charts portal: Emmylou Harris |url=https://swedishcharts.com/search.asp?cat=a&search=emmylou+harris |website=swedishcharts.com |access-date=July 22, 2023 |archive-date=July 22, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230722005102/https://swedishcharts.com/search.asp?cat=a&search=emmylou+harris |url-status=live }}</ref> During this period, Harris also toured frequently alongside [[Elvis Costello]] and recorded the song \"[[The Scarlet Tide]]\" (the original version of the song was featured in the [[Cold Mountain (soundtrack)|soundtrack]] of ''[[Cold Mountain (film)|Cold Mountain]]'').{{sfn|Dicaire|p=65}} In 2005, Harris recorded the song \"[[A Love That Will Never Grow Old]]\", which appeared in the LGBT film ''[[Brokeback Mountain]]''.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Brand |first1=Madeline |title=The Sound of 'Brokeback Mountain' |url=https://www.npr.org/transcripts/5044116 |access-date=July 31, 2023 |work=[[NPR]] |date=December 8, 2005}}</ref>\n\nHarris and [[Mark Knopfler]] (formerly of the band [[Dire Straits]]) spent seven years writing and recording songs, which would make up their collaborative studio effort, ''[[All the Roadrunning]]''.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dye |first1=David |title=Mark Knopfler and Emmylou Harris: Sweet Duets [circa one minute in] |url=https://www.npr.org/2008/02/14/18983237/mark-knopfler-and-emmylou-harris-sweet-duets |access-date=July 31, 2023 |work=[[NPR]] |date=February 14, 2008}}</ref> Some of the songs on the collection were originally for a different Knofler project but were instead used for ''All the Roadrunning''.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Willman |first1=Chris |title=A chat with Emmylou Harris and Mark Knopfler |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=May 2, 2006 |url=https://ew.com/article/2006/05/02/chat-emmylou-harris-and-mark-knopfler/ |access-date=July 31, 2023}}</ref> In 2006, it became a top 20 disc on the US album chart<ref name=\"Billboard 200\"/> but reached the top ten in the UK<ref name=\"UK Albums\"/> and Sweden.<ref name=\"Swedish Albums\"/> In Norway, the album topped the all-genre chart.<ref name=\"Norweigan charts\"/> Spawned from the disc was the single \"[[This Is Us (Mark Knopfler and Emmylou Harris song)|This Is Us]]\", which reached number five on the US Adult Alternative Airplay chart<ref name=\"AAA\"/> and number 17 in Norway.<ref>{{cite web|title=Norwegian charts portal - Emmylou Harris|url=http://norwegiancharts.com/search.asp?search=emmylou+harris&cat=s|publisher=norwegiancharts.com|access-date=July 13, 2010|archive-date=November 2, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102133820/http://norwegiancharts.com/search.asp?search=emmylou%20harris&cat=s|url-status=live}}</ref> ''The Washington Post'' called the album \"a smart marriage of strengths and weaknesses\"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Himes |first1=Geoffrey |title=Mark Knopfler and Emmylou Harris \"All the Roadrunning\" Nonesuch/Warner Bros. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/2006/06/16/mark-knopfler-and-emmylou-harris-all-the-roadrunning-nonesuchwarner-bros/a3b43cd2-49f1-458a-b2c0-7da070627222/ |access-date=July 31, 2023 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |archive-date=July 8, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220708231434/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/2006/06/16/mark-knopfler-and-emmylou-harris-all-the-roadrunning-nonesuchwarner-bros/a3b43cd2-49f1-458a-b2c0-7da070627222/ |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> and AllMusic found it to be a \"lush and earthy collaboration\".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Monger |first1=James Christopher |title=''All the Roadrunning'': Emmylou Harris, Mark Knopfler: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/all-the-roadrunning-mw0000408470 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812113652/https://www.allmusic.com/album/all-the-roadrunning-mw0000408470 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nIn 2008, a solo album titled ''[[All I Intended to Be]]'' was released. It featured Brian Ahern producing the project.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Contributors included [[Vince Gill]] and [[Dolly Parton]]. Harris then toured in support of the album with an ensemble she dubbed the Red Dirt Boys.<ref>{{cite web |author=Varga, George |work=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]] |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20080731/news_1w31emmylou.html |title='I'm a storyteller' |date=July 31, 2008 |access-date=May 14, 2011 |archive-date=November 8, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211108024607/https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/ |url-status=live }}</ref> It reached the top five of the US country albums chart,<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> the top 25 of the ''Billboard'' 200<ref name=\"Billboard 200\"/> and the top ten on the Swedish all-genre chart.<ref name=\"Swedish Albums\"/> In 2010, Harris re-recorded her song \"Boulder to Birmingham\" with the rock group [[the Fray]] and was issued as a single by [[Epic Records]] that year.<ref>{{cite journal |title=\"Boulder to Birmingham\" (CD Single) |journal=[[Epic Records]] |date=2010 |id=88697-79534-77}}</ref>\n\nIn 2011, Nonesuch Records released Harris' fourth self-composed album ''[[Hard Bargain (Emmylou Harris album)|Hard Bargain]]''. The project was produced by Nashville's [[Jay Joyce]]. Similar to her previous albums, its songs reflected themes about southern culture. Among its tracks was a song about the life of [[Emmett Till]], a teenage boy murdered in the American south during the 1950s.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Pareles |first1=Jon |title=A Life Digging for Veins of Gold |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/24/arts/music/emmylou-harris-releases-a-new-album-hard-bargain.html |access-date=July 31, 2023 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 22, 2011 |archive-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230731213009/https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/24/arts/music/emmylou-harris-releases-a-new-album-hard-bargain.html |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> ''Hard Bargain'' reached the US country albums top five,<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> the US all-genre top 20,<ref name=\"Billboard 200\"/> the Canadian top 20,<ref name=\"Billboard Canadian Albums\">{{cite magazine |title=Emmylou Harris chart history (Billboard Canadian Albums) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/emmylou-harris/chart-history/tlp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=July 22, 2023 |archive-date=July 22, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230722005102/https://www.billboard.com/artist/emmylou-harris/chart-history/tlp/ |url-status=live }}</ref> the UK top 30<ref name=\"UK Albums\"/> and the Norwegian top 15.<ref name=\"Norweigan charts\"/> Ken Tucker of [[NPR]] called ''Hard Bargain'' both \"invigorating\" and \"inviting\".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tucker |first1=Ken |title=Emmylou Harris: An Invigorating, Inviting 'Hard Bargain' |url=https://www.npr.org/2011/04/27/135768394/emmylou-harris-an-invigorating-inviting-hard-bargain |access-date=July 31, 2023 |work=[[NPR]] |date=April 27, 2011}}</ref> Steven Rosen of ''[[American Songwriter]]'' found Harris' songwriting on the album to occasionally \"stumble\" but also do well in \"addressing personal sadness\".<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Rosen |first1=Steven |title=Emmylou Harris: Hard Bargain |magazine=[[American Songwriter]] |date=2011 |url=https://americansongwriter.com/emmylou-harris-hard-bargain/ |access-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230731213011/https://americansongwriter.com/emmylou-harris-hard-bargain/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n===2012\u2013present: Rodney Crowell collaborations and recent endeavors===\n[[File:Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Harris teamed up with [[Rodney Crowell]] to record two albums in the 2010s. Pictured above, Crowell and Harris are seen performing in 2012.]]\nHarris agreed to contribute to the soundtrack of [[Nick Cave]]'s 2012 film ''[[Lawless (film)|Lawless]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Danton |first1=Eric R. |title=Nick Cave on His Surprising Soundtrack for 'Lawless' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=August 28, 2012 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/tv-movies/tv-movie-news/nick-cave-on-his-surprising-soundtrack-for-lawless-243479/ |access-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-date=July 31, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230731215920/https://www.rollingstone.com/tv-movies/tv-movie-news/nick-cave-on-his-surprising-soundtrack-for-lawless-243479/ |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> She recorded three songs that appeared on the soundtrack.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> The ''[[Montreal Gazette]]'' described Harris' vocal performance on ''Lawless'' as \"serene\".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Zivitz |first1=Jordan |title=New music review: Lawless soundtrack; Nick Cave, Warren Ellis et al. (Sony) |url=https://montrealgazette.com/entertainment/music/new-music-review-lawless-soundtrack-nick-cave-warren-ellis-et-al-sony |access-date=July 31, 2023 |work=[[Montreal Gazette]] |date=August 27, 2012 |archive-date=July 1, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240701202358/https://montrealgazette.com/entertainment/music/new-music-review-lawless-soundtrack-nick-cave-warren-ellis-et-al-sony |url-status=live }}</ref> Harris released an album of duets with Rodney Crowell in 2013 called ''[[Old Yellow Moon]]''. Although a duet album was discussed for years, the timing never worked out due to their different schedules.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Danton |first1=Eric R. |title=Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell Come Full Circle on 'Old Yellow Moon' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=February 20, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230801222559/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/emmylou-harris-and-rodney-crowell-come-full-circle-on-old-yellow-moon-248726/ |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> The pair re-recorded songs that had previously appeared on their individual albums.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Pajer |first1=Nicole |title=Emmylou Harris & Rodney Crowell Team Up on 'Old Yellow Moon' |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=February 14, 2013 Magazine]]'' found ''Old Yellow Moon'' to balance \"retro-country and retro-rock with a sure and satisfying sense of balance\"<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Schjenman |first1=Ted |title=Review: Emmylou |url-status=live }}</ref> and ''[[USA Today]]'' named the project one of its \"Albums of the Week\" in February 2013.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Shriver |first1=Jerry |title=Album of the week: 'Old Yellow |url-status=live }}</ref> ''Old Yellow Moon'' reached number four on the US country chart,<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/> number 29 on the US all-genre chart,<ref name=\"Billboard 200\"/> number six in Norway<ref name=\"Norweigan charts\"/> and number 42 in the UK.<ref name=\"UK Albums\"/> It later won a Grammy award.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=French |first1=Alex |title=High-Rollin' Hillbillies: How Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell Became Country Music Royalty |magazine=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] |date=May 19, 2015 |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2015/05/emmylou-harris-rodney-crowell-traveling-kind-interview |access-date=August 1, 2023 |archive-date=January 12, 2016 |url-access=subscription}}</ref> It was followed in 2015 by the pair's second album, ''[[The Traveling Kind]]'' and was a tribute to songwriters like [[Kris Kristofferson]] and [[Roger Miller]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Moss |first1=Marissa R. |title=Hear Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell Reunite for 'The Traveling Kind' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=March 25, 2015 |url-access=subscription}}</ref> ''Rolling Stone'' awarded it three stars out of five<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Cummings |first1=Corinne |title=''The Traveling Kind'' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]
