ten of the US country chart.<ref name=\"Country Albums\"/>\n\nIn 2014, Harris announced a book deal with Blue Rider, a [[Penguin Books]] publishing imprint.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Talbott |first1=Chris |title=Emmylou Harris to write memoir |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2014/03/20/emmylou-harris-write-memoir/6652497/ |access-date=August 1, 2023 |work=[[The Tennessean]] |date=March 20, 2014}}</ref> In 2017, she told ''[[The Capital Times]]'' that the piece would be a memoir of her life.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Thomas |first1=Rob |title=Emmylou Harris is going strong at 70, and she 'isn't done yet' |url=https://captimes.com/entertainment/movies/emmylou-harris-is-going-strong-at-70-and-she-isnt-done-yet/article_3087358d-9590-54cd-8c05-bc0f360e5f73.html |access-date=August 1, 2023 |work=[[The Capital Times]] |date=September 23, 2017 |archive-date=August 1, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230801224638/https://captimes.com/entertainment/movies/emmylou-harris-is-going-strong-at-70-and-she-isnt-done-yet/article_3087358d-9590-54cd-8c05-bc0f360e5f73.html |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2021, Harris told ''[[Clash (magazine)|Clash]]'' magazine that she was still writing her memoir.<ref name=\"Clash\">{{cite magazine |last1=Murray |first1=Robin |title=In Conversation: Emmylou Harris |magazine=[[Clash (magazine)|Clash]] |date=September 14, 2021 |url=https://www.clashmusic.com/features/in-conversation-emmylou-harris/ |access-date=August 1, 2023 |archive-date=August 1, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230801224638/https://www.clashmusic.com/features/in-conversation-emmylou-harris/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2021, Nonesuch Records released the live disc ''[[Ramble in Music City: The Lost Concert]]'', which was recorded with The Nash Ramblers in 1990 but was first shelved.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Thompson |first1=Richard |title=Emmylou Harris Ramble in Music City: The Lost Concert |url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/emmylou-harris-ramble-in-music-city-the-lost-concert/ |access-date=August 1, 2023 |work=Bluegrass Today |date=October 27, 2021 |archive-date=August 1, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230801224638/https://bluegrasstoday.com/emmylou-harris-ramble-in-music-city-the-lost-concert/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2021, Harris told ''Clash'' magazine that she was no longer writing songs because she didn't \"feel the need\" and have the sense of \"urgency\".<ref name=\"Clash\"/> However, she continues to perform and play shows.<ref>{{cite web |title=Emmylou Harris Official Website: Tour |url=https://www.emmylouharris.com/tour |website=Emmylou Harris.com |access-date=August 1, 2023 |archive-date=April 30, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230430080519/https://www.emmylouharris.com/tour |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n==Artistry==\n===Influences===\n{{multiple image\n| total_width = 290\n| align  = right\n| image1 = Joan Baez Hamburg 1973 2811730005.cropped.jpg\n| image2 = Pete Seeger NYWTS.jpg\n| footer = Harris' major influences include [[Joan Baez]] (left) and [[Pete Seeger]] (right)\n}}\nHarris found her first appreciation for music through the folk genre{{sfn|Dicaire|p=61}} during the [[American folk revival]].<ref name=\"Independent Influences\">{{cite news |title=Emmylou, in her own words |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/emmylou-in-her-own-words-701802.html |access-date=August 5, 2023 |work=[[The Independent]] |date=February 29, 2000 |archive-date=August 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230805153522/https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/emmylou-in-her-own-words-701802.html |url-status=live }}</ref> During her adolescence, she listened to [[American University]]'s [[WAMU]] radio station, which played folk music nightly. Harris taught herself to play the guitar, sing and follow along with the radio.<ref name=\"Influences AS\">{{cite magazine |last1=McKenna |first1=Brittney |title=Emmylou Harris Goes Full Circle |magazine=[[American Songwriter]] |date=2017 |url=https://americansongwriter.com/emmylou-harris-goes-full-circle/ |access-date=August 5, 2023 |archive-date=August 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230805153522/https://americansongwriter.com/emmylou-harris-goes-full-circle/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Harris' early folk influences included [[Ian & Sylvia]],<ref name=\"News Post\">{{cite news |title=Emmylou Harris grows finer every year |url=https://www.fredericknewspost.com/archives/emmylou-harris-grows-finer-every-year/article_e10ccf4b-a8f5-5f2e-9654-1b10821dc81c.html |access-date=August 5, 2023 |work=[[Frederick News-Post]] |date=October 26, 2006 |archive-date=August 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230805153527/https://www.fredericknewspost.com/archives/emmylou-harris-grows-finer-every-year/article_e10ccf4b-a8f5-5f2e-9654-1b10821dc81c.html |url-status=live }}</ref> [[Peter, Paul and Mary]],<ref name=\"Blue Ridge\">{{cite web |title=Emmylou Harris: Blue Ridge Music Hall of Fame |url=https://wilkesheritagemuseum.com/hall-of-fame/previous-years/emmylou-harris |website=Wilkes Heritage Museum |access-date=August 5, 2023 |archive-date=August 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230805153527/https://wilkesheritagemuseum.com/hall-of-fame/previous-years/emmylou-harris |url-status=live }}</ref> [[Buffy Sainte-Marie]],<ref name=\"Influences AS\"/> [[Judy Collins]],<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hilburn |first1=Robert |title=They Can't Help It if They're Friends |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1999-aug-15-ca-238-story.html |access-date=August 5, 2023 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=August 15, 1999 |archive-date=August 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230805153527/https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1999-aug-15-ca-238-story.html |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> and [[Bob Dylan]].{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=240}} Harris was also influenced by [[Pete Seeger]]. At age 16, she wrote him a letter wondering if her life was too privileged to be singing about the story lines in folk songs.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Cooper |first1=Peter |title=Emmylou Harris inspired at age 16 by Pete Seeger's response to her letter |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2014/02/11/emmylou-harris-inspired-at-age-16-by-pete-seegers-response-to-her-letter/5390507/ |access-date=August 5, 2023 |work=[[The Tennessean]] |date=February 11, 2014}}</ref> Another significant influence was [[Joan Baez]],<ref>{{cite book |last1=Fuqua |first1=C.S. |title=Alabama Musicians Musical Heritage from the Heart of Dixie |date=2011 |publisher=[[Arcadia Publishing]] |isbn=978-1614233480}}</ref> whom she recalled having a \"spiritual\" connection to.<ref name=\"Independent Influences\"/> \"I worshiped her. Still do in a way, because she just changed my whole focus on music,\" she told ''Rolling Stone''.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=Emmylou Harris Talks Influence of Joan Baez, Reveals New Album Details |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=November 19, 2014 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/emmylou-harris-talks-influence-of-joan-baez-reveals-new-album-details-201813/ |access-date=August 5, 2023 |archive-date=August 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230805153527/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/emmylou-harris-talks-influence-of-joan-baez-reveals-new-album-details-201813/ |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref>\n\nHarris received further exposure to country music and developed an appreciation for it through her collaborations with Gram Parsons.<ref name=\"Independent Influences\"/> She told ''[[The Columbus Dispatch]]'' that she had not take the genre seriously up to that point because she could see the artistry of it.<ref>{{cite news |title=Going country took convincing for singer Emmylou Harris |url=https://www.dispatch.com/story/entertainment/music/2013/04/03/going-country-took-convincing-for/23574922007/ |access-date=August 5, 2023 |work=[[The Columbus Dispatch]] |date=April 3, 2013 |archive-date=August 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230805155606/https://www.dispatch.com/story/entertainment/music/2013/04/03/going-country-took-convincing-for/23574922007/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Parsons exposed Harris to the music of [[the Louvin Brothers]], [[Bill Monroe]] and [[George Jones]]. Their songs became a significant influence on her. \"These were deep, emotionally troubling songs, but he opened my ears to the beauty of it, the simplicity of the poetry,\" she explained.<ref name=\"Looked Down\">{{cite news |last1=Hickling |first1=Alfred |title=Emmylou Harris: 'I looked down on country' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/mar/04/emmylou-harris-looked-down-country |access-date=August 5, 2023 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=March 4, 2013}}</ref> Harris hired Rodney Crowell to join her band when she became a solo act. His traditional Texan country background<ref>{{cite news |title=Emmylou Harris And Rodney Crowell: Harmonizing To That 'Old Yellow Moon' |url=https://www.npr.org/2013/03/28/175490125/emmylou-harris-and-rodney-crowell-harmonizing-to-that-old-yellow-moon |access-date=August 5, 2023 |work=[[NPR]] |date=March 28, 2013 |archive-date=August 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230805155605/https://www.npr.org/2013/03/28/175490125/emmylou-harris-and-rodney-crowell-harmonizing-to-that-old-yellow-moon |url-status=live }}</ref> was said by Harris to influence her country music artistry. \"I think that his presence in the early part of my career, first as a songwriter and then as a member of the band and then as kind of my soul brother, musically, was really important to getting my footing as a performing artist,\" Harris commented.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sjostedt |first1=Arne |title=How serendipity brought together Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell |url=https://www.canberratimes.com.au/story/6066214/how-serendipity-brought-together-emmylou-harris-and-rodney-crowell/ |access-date=August 6, 2023 |work=[[The Canberra Times]] |date=June 15, 2015 |archive-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230806021128/https://www.canberratimes.com.au/story/6066214/how-serendipity-brought-together-emmylou-harris-and-rodney-crowell/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n===Musical styles, musicianship and collaborations===\nWriters, editors and historians have largely identified Harris with the country rock musical style.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=362-364}}<ref name=\"Hall of Fame\"/><ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Harris took the sound of California [[folk rock]] and embedded it with traditional country.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=362-363}} Author Frank Hoffman wrote, \"Emmylou Harris has maintained a successful recording career over four decades by maintaining a steadfast allegiance to roots styles in the face of rampant technological change and media image manipulation.\"<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hoffman |first1=Frank |title=Chronology of American Popular Music, 1900-2000 |date=2016 |publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]] |isbn=978-1135868864 |page=397}}</ref> David DiMartio found that her 1970s albums merged rock with classic country in a way that helped Harris receive fans young and old.<ref>{{cite book |last1=DiMartino |first1=David |title=Music in the 20th Century (3 Vol Set) |date=2016 |publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]] |isbn=978-1317464303 |page=276}}</ref> Buzz McClain of ''The Washington Post'' said that Harris' albums helped \"define\" the country rock music style.<ref>{{cite news |last1=McClain |first1=Buzz |title=Emmylou Harris, Making Her Country Proud |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/2000/10/16/emmylou-harris-making-her-country-proud/a2abd231-fbd5-48c9-80a7-712751db58c8/ |access-date=August 6, 2023 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=October 16, 2000 |archive-date=July 8, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220708231601/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/2000/10/16/emmylou-harris-making-her-country-proud/a2abd231-fbd5-48c9-80a7-712751db58c8/ |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> Authors Mary A. Bufwack and [[Robert K. Oermann]] concluded that Harris was the \"beacon\" of the country rock movement during the 1970s and 1980s.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363}}\n\n[[File:EmmylouHarris PhilMadiera 2008.jpg|thumb|left|170px|Harris performing onstage in [[Seattle, Washington]] with [[Phil Madeira]] and [[Ricky Simpkins]], 2008.]]\nAs Harris' career progressed, she took more inspiration from the [[Alternative music|alternative]] music community.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Critics have pointed to 1995's ''Wrecking Ball'' as a turning point in her musical style.<ref name=\"Style Shift\">{{cite news |last1=Kot |first1=Greg |title=Emmylou Harris returns to 'Wrecking Ball' |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2014/04/03/emmylou-harris-returns-to-wrecking-ball/ |access-date=August 6, 2023 |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=April 3, 2014 |archive-date=June 30, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240630032400/https://www.chicagotribune.com/2014/04/03/emmylou-harris-returns-to-wrecking-ball/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=\"Country Music Encyclopedia\"/> The album's production was said to embed new aspects of rock that had not been in her music previously.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/><ref name=\"Style Shift\"/> From then on, critics credited Harris with helping to define the [[alternative country]] sub genre.<ref name=\"Rolling Stone Book\"/><ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Flippo |first1=Chet |title=Emmylou Harris Tapped for Billboard's 1999 Century Award |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=May 8, 1999 |page=75 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eQ0EAAAAMBAJ&dq=emmylou+harris+made+a+move+towards+alternative+rock+with+wrecking+ball&pg=PA75 |access-date=August 6, 2023}}</ref> Writers have also categorized her music as [[progressive country]]<ref name=Ellis>{{cite web |url=https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2011/jul/10/emmylou-harris-broadens-what-it-means-be--20110710/ |title=Emmylou Harris broadens what it means to be country |last=Ellis |first=Widner |date=July 10, 2011 |work=Northwest Arkansas Democrat-Gazette |access-date=July 23, 2023 |archive-date=July 23, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230723222300/https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2011/jul/10/emmylou-harris-broadens-what-it-means-be--20110710/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and [[outlaw country]].<ref name=Brodsky>{{cite web |url=https://www.stereogum.com/2210206/margo-price-strays/interviews/footnotes-interview/ |title=The Story Behind Every Song On Margo Price's New Album Strays |last=Brodsky |first=Rachel |date=January 12, 2023 |work=[[Stereogum]] |access-date=July 25, 2023 |quote=Price tends to be slotted into the Outlaw Country category by journalists, who liken her to genre pillars Tanya Tucker and Emmylou Harris. |archive-date=July 25, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230725192228/https://www.stereogum.com/2210206/margo-price-strays/interviews/footnotes-interview/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Her association with other genres authors to consider her a forerunner for the [[Americana (music)|Americana]] style, a genre centered on roots music.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Durchholz |first1=Daniel |last2=Graff |first2=Gary |title=Neil Young Long May You Run: The Illustrated History, Updated Edition |date=2012 |publisher=[[The Quarto Group|Voyageur Press]] |page=104}}</ref><ref name=Ellis/> ''Rolling Stone'' has since given the moniker of the \"Godmother of Americana\".<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=Flashback: See Gram Parsons, Emmylou Harris Sing 'Six Days on the Road' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=September 19, 2016 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/flashback-see-gram-parsons-emmylou-harris-sing-six-days-on-the-road-124341/ |access-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230806031323/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/flashback-see-gram-parsons-emmylou-harris-sing-six-days-on-the-road-124341/ |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref>\n\nHarris's musicianship has also been discussed and spoken about.<ref name=\"Biography\"/> She often sought out other musicians to enhance and develop her musical style.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=61-67}}{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363-365}} This started with Harris' first backing group the Hot Band, which was formed when her first record label needed studio musicians for her recordings. \"We gotta put the chick singer together with a hot band,\" Harris recalled someone at her record company saying.<ref name=\"Looked Down\"/> From then on, Harris collaborated with her backing musicians to help enhance her style and performances onstage.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=61-67}}{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363-365}} The [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum]] explained how her backing bands influenced the way her musical style shifted as years went by.<ref name=\"Hall of Fame\"/> Harris herself explained that her style of country music embedded more rock influences compared to previous interpretations of the genre.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363}}\n\nHarris' artistry has also been remembered for her collaborations with various artists. She has made appearances on songs recorded by [[Ryan Adams]], [[Neil Young]], [[Johnny Cash]], [[Sheryl Crow]], and numerous others.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=65}} \"It's likely that on her school report it was said of the young Emmylou Harris that 'she plays well with others',\" wrote Bernard Zuel of ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]''.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Zuel |first1=Bernard |title=Emmylou Harris and her eternal partnerships |url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/emmylou-harris-and-her-eternal-partnerships-20150526-gh9dob.html |access-date=August 6, 2023 |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=May 25, 2015 |archive-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230806041953/https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/emmylou-harris-and-her-eternal-partnerships-20150526-gh9dob.html |url-status=live |url-access=registration}}</ref> Noah Berlatsky of ''[[The Atlantic]]'' wrote that Harris' own career \"was never precisely solo\" because of her emphasis on collaborating with other artists. \"Her enthusiasm for finding new artists to work with has been a huge boon for her music,\" he commented.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Berlatsky |first1=Noah |title=Emmylou Harris: Better Collaborator Than Soloist (and That's a Good Thing) |magazine=[[The Atlantic]] |date=February 26, 2013 |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2013/02/emmylou-harris-better-collaborator-than-soloist-and-thats-a-good-thing/273516/ |access-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230806041954/https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2013/02/emmylou-harris-better-collaborator-than-soloist-and-thats-a-good-thing/273516/ |url-status=live |url-access=registration}}</ref> Harris herself stated, \"I think it's just a willingness to be a part of the landscape, in a way. I've been very lucky in that all (my) collaborations have been real musical and very satisfying and inspiring.\"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Cridlin |first1=Jay |title=Interview: Emmylou Harris on collaboration, inspiration, Elvis |url=https://www.tampabay.com/things-to-do/music/interview-emmylou-harris-on-collaboration-inspiration-elvis/2205065/ |access-date=August 6, 2023 |work=[[Tampa Bay Times]] |date=November 4, 2014 |archive-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230806041953/https://www.tampabay.com/things-to-do/music/interview-emmylou-harris-on-collaboration-inspiration-elvis/2205065/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n===Vocals===\nWriters have characterized Harris' singing voice as that of a [[soprano]],<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Stacey |editor1-first=Lee |editor2-last=Henderson |editor2-first=Lol |title=Encyclopedia of Music in the 20th Century |date=2014 |publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]] |isbn=978-1135929466 |page=276}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Williams |first1=Lucinda |title=Emmylou Harris by Lucinda Williams |magazine=[[Bomb (magazine)|Bomb]] |date=April 1, 1997 |issue=59 |url=https://bombmagazine.org/articles/emmylou-harris/ |access-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812222206/https://bombmagazine.org/articles/emmylou-harris/ |url-status=live }}</ref> along with being described as being both \"delicate\" and \"crystalline\".<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/><ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Hopper |first1=Alex |title=5 Deep Cuts From Emmylou Harris That You Should Be Listening To |magazine=[[American Songwriter]] |date=2022 |url=https://americansongwriter.com/5-deep-cuts-from-emmylou-harris-that-you-should-be-listening-to/ |access-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-date=October 18, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231018121546/https://americansongwriter.com/5-deep-cuts-from-emmylou-harris-that-you-should-be-listening-to/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=Flashback: See Emmylou Harris's Delicate 'Together Again' on the BBC |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=July 27, 2016 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/flashback-see-emmylou-harriss-delicate-together-again-on-the-bbc-96326/ |access-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-date=July 21, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180721043711/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/flashback-see-emmylou-harriss-delicate-together-again-on-the-bbc-96326/ |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> Stephen Holden of ''The New York Times'' wrote, \"Emmylou Harris's voice is an alloy of crystal and steel, and this mixture of delicacy and resilience lends her the aura of an idealized frontier woman.\"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Holden |first1=Stephen |title=Pop Brief |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/24/arts/pop-brief.html |access-date=August 6, 2023 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 24, 1995 |archive-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230806232347/https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/24/arts/pop-brief.html |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> Jason Ankeny of [[AllMusic]] wrote, \"Blessed with a crystalline voice, a remarkable gift for phrasing, and a restless creative spirit, few artists had as profound an impact on contemporary music as Emmylou Harris.\"<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Harris herself explained that her voice sounds unique because it is rooted in folk styles: \"I didn't have a style or a voice of my own. And in singing country, I was singing in a folk voice. I didn't have what you would consider a true country voice like [[Loretta Lynn]], [[Kitty Wells|Kitty]] [Wells] or [[Tammy Wynette|Tammy]] [Wynette], or some of the younger singers; [[Tanya Tucker]] \u2013 great voice. But my voice was always more on the side of folk.\"<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Emmylou Harris In depth interview with the country legend |magazine=[[Clash (magazine)|Clash]] |date=May 6, 2008 |url=https://www.clashmusic.com/features/emmylou-harris/ |access-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-date=August 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230806232348/https://www.clashmusic.com/features/emmylou-harris/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n==Legacy, influence and awards==\n{{main|List of awards and nominations received by Emmylou Harris}}\n\nEmmylou Harris has striven to follow a consistent music direction in her career that has helped influence modern contemporary music.<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/>{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363-366}} Through her fusion of the country and rock genres, Harris helped to unite rural country audiences and metropolitan rock audiences together in one setting.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363}}<ref name=\"Malone\">{{cite book |last1=Malone |first1=Bill |last2=Stricklin |first2=David |title=Southern Music/American Music |date=2014 |publisher=[[University of Kentucky|University Press of Kentucky]] |isbn=978-0813149158 |page=144}}</ref> Jason Ankeny of AllMusic wrote, \"She traveled a singular artistic path, proudly carrying the torch of \"cosmic American music\" passed down by her mentor, Gram Parsons, which made a profound mark on both country and rock.\"<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Mary A. Bufwack and Robert K. Oermann wrote, \"She showed Nashville that country music could succeed uncompromised, with dignity intact. She made country music hip.\"{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=363}} Harris is also credited with influencing the [[neotraditional country]] sub-genre that was established in the 1980s and 1990s.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=364}}<ref>{{cite web |last1=Burns |first1=Ken |title=Other Styles, Other Voices |url=https://www.pbs.org/kenburns/country-music/other-styles-other-voices-branches-of-country-music |website=[[PBS]] |access-date=August 11, 2023 |archive-date=February 15, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240215220204/https://www.pbs.org/kenburns/country-music/other-styles-other-voices-branches-of-country-music |url-status=live }}</ref> ''The Continuum Encyclopedia of Popular Music of the World'' wrote, \"Harris would carry the torch into the following decades as a revered country music traditionalist who respected and drew inspiration from the west coast pioneers.\"<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Horn |editor1-first=David |editor2-last=Shepherd |editor2-first=John |title=Continuum Encyclopedia of Popular Music of the World Volume 8 |date=2012 |publisher=[[Bloomsbury Publishing]] |isbn=978-1441160782 |page=174}}</ref>\n[[File:Emmylou Harris and Linda Ronstadt Honorary Doctorate From Berklee Presentation.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Accompanied by Linda Ronstadt, Harris receives an [[Honorary degree|honorary doctorate]] from the [[Berklee College of Music]], 2009.]]\n\nWriter David DiCaire called Harris one of American music's most well-remembered voices.{{sfn|Dicaire|p=65}} Jason Ankeny wrote, \"Blessed with a crystalline voice, a remarkable gift for phrasing, and a restless creative spirit, few artists had as profound an impact on contemporary music as Emmylou Harris.\"<ref name=\"Allmusic\"/> Marissa R. Moss of ''[[The Guardian]]'' called her \"one of music's most revered voices\" and \"one of America's finest interpreters of song\".<ref name=\"Guardian Influence\">{{cite news |last1=Moss |first1=Marissa R. |title=Emmylou Harris on her greatest hits: 'I was arrogant enough to think I could survive a flop' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/nov/22/emmylou-harris-on-her-greatest-hits-i-was-arrogant-enough-to-think-i-could-survive-a-flop |access-date=August 10, 2023 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=November 22, 2018}}</ref> Chuck Dauphin of ''Billboard'' wrote, \"Nobody can deliver a song aching with sadness and loneliness quite like Emmylou Harris. When she pours her heart and soul into a lyric, you are instantly grabbed emotionally in a way that few artists can.\"<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Dauphin |first1=Chuck |title=Emmylou Harris' 10 Best Songs: Critic's Picks |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=October 6, 2017 |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/emmylou-harris-songs-best-hits-list-7989738/ |access-date=August 10, 2023 |archive-date=October 18, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231018122510/https://www.billboard.com/music/country/emmylou-harris-songs-best-hits-list-7989738/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2023, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' ranked Harris at number 79 on its list of the \"200 Greatest Singers of All Time\", further commenting that she is \"arguably the greatest American harmony vocalist of the past half-century\".<ref>{{Cite magazine|date=January 1, 2023|title=The 200 Greatest Singers of All Time|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-lists/best-singers-all-time-1234642307/emmylou-harris-8-1234643075/|access-date=June 29, 2023|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|archive-date=January 7, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230107010508/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-lists/best-singers-all-time-1234642307/emmylou-harris-8-1234643075/|url-status=live|url-access=subscription}}</ref>\n\nBufwack and Oermann explained how Harris's music changed the direction of country music decades later.{{sfn|Bufwack|Oermann|p=366}} In the years following her rise to success, Harris was considered a major influence on several country artists during the 1980s and 1990s.<ref name=\"Hall of Fame\"/><ref name=\"Tribute\">{{cite news |last1=Dunham |first1=Nancy |title=Singers to pay tribute to 'iconic' Emmylou Harris |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2015/01/08/emmylou-harris/21397759/ |access-date=August 10, 2023 |work=[[USA Today]] |date=January 8, 2015 |archive-date=September 14, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220914131420/https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2015/01/08/emmylou-harris/21397759/ |url-status=live }}</ref> [[Miranda Lambert]] credited Harris as an artist determined to make her own choices and choose her own direction.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Bernstein |first1=Jonathan |title=Miranda Lambert on Emmylou Harris: 'This Girl's Here to Party and Not Take Sh-t' |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=February 25, 2023 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/miranda-lambert-emmylou-harris-tribute-1234684675/ |access-date=August 10, |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> Reflecting on her artistic decisions, [[Trisha Yearwood]] commented, \"I've had to say to myself, well, if I passed Emmylou Harris on the street, would I be able to hold my head up?\"<ref>{{cite book |last1=Wolff |first1=Kurt |title=Country Music: The Rough Guide |date=2000 |publisher=Rough Guides, Ltd. |isbn=978-1858285344 |page=547}}</ref> Harris has also been a credited influence on [[Ryan Adams]],<ref name=\"Guardian Influence\"/> [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]],<ref name=\"Tribute\"/> [[Sheryl Crow]],<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=McKenna |first1=Brittney |title=Sheryl Crow: Bearing the Torch |magazine=[[American Songwriter]] |date=2019 |url=https://americansongwriter.com/sheryl-crow-bearing-the-torch/ |access-date=August 12, 2023 |url-status=dead }}</ref> and [[Wilco]].<ref name=\"Guardian Influence\"/>\n\nIn 1999, Harris received the ''Billboard'' Century Award, which is given to \"the uncommon excellence of one artist's |work=[[MTV News]] |date=December 1, 1999}}</ref> In 2003, she was inducted into the [[Alabama Music Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Emmylou Haris Biography |url=https://www.alamhof.org/emmylou |website=[[Alabama Music Hall of Fame]] |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=August 2, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230802223918/https://www.alamhof.org/emmylou |url-status=live }}</ref> Along with [[the Statler Brothers]] and [[Tom T. Hall]], Harris was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum]] in 2008.<ref name=\"Hall of Fame\"/><ref>{{cite web |last1=Darden |first1=Beville |title=Emmylou Harris, Statler Brothers Inducted into Hall of Fame |url=https://theboot.com/emmylou-harris-statler-brothers-inducted-into-hall-of-fame/ |website=The Boot |date=February 13, 2008 |access-date=30 June 2024 |archive-date=April 12, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200412080304/https://theboot.com/emmylou-harris-statler-brothers-inducted-into-hall-of-fame/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2009, Linda Ronstadt and Earl Scruggs were present when Harris received an [[Honorary degree|honorary doctorate]] from the [[Berklee College of Music]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Edwards |first1=Margot |title=Emmylou Harris Receives Berklee Honorary Doctorate |url=https://college.berklee.edu/news/1105/emmylou-harris-receives-berklee-honorary-doctora |website=[[Berklee College of Music]] |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=July 1, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240701205635/https://college.berklee.edu/news/1105/emmylou-harris-receives-berklee-honorary-doctora |url-status=live }}</ref> At the 2012 [[Academy of Country Music]] \"Honors\" ceremony, Harris was presented with the Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Robertson |first1=Sherod |title=ACM Honors: A Night of Authenticity |magazine=[[MusicRow]] |date=September 25, 2012 |url=https://musicrow.com/2012/09/acm-honors-a-night-of-authenticity/ |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812153135/https://musicrow.com/2012/09/acm-honors-a-night-of-authenticity/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2015, Harris and [[Evelyn Glennie]] received Sweden's [[Polar Music Prize]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Bronson |first1=Fred |title=Emmylou Harris and Dame Evelyn Glennie Honored with Sweden's Polar Music Prize |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=June 9, 2015 |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/emmylou-harris-and-dame-evelyn-glennie-honored-with-swedens-polar-music-prize-6590831/ |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812151634/https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/emmylou-harris-and-dame-evelyn-glennie-honored-with-swedens-polar-music-prize-6590831/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Along with [[Tina Turner]], she was then presented the 2018 [[Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/queen-tina-turner-to-receive-grammy-lifetime-achievement-award-w515260|title=Queen, Tina Turner to Receive Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award|url-access=subscription|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180619040158/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/queen-tina-turner-to-receive-grammy-lifetime-achievement-award-w515260 |archive-date=June 19, 2018|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=March 8, 2018|first=John|last=Blistein|url-status=live|date=January 10, 2018}}</ref>\n\nSwedish folk duo [[First Aid Kit (band)|First Aid Kit]] released the song \"[[Emmylou (song)|Emmylou]]\" in 2012 as a tribute to Harris. They performed the song when she received the Polar Music Prize in 2015.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Roberts |first1=Christopher |last2=Persson |first2=Nina |title=Watch: First Aid Kit Perform \"Emmylou\" in Front of a Teary Emmylou Harris at Polar Music Prize |magazine=[[Under the Radar (magazine)|Under the Radar]] |date=June 10, 2015 |url=https://www.undertheradarmag.com/news/watch_first_aid_kit_perform_emmylou_in_front_of_a_teary_emmylou_harris_at_p |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=March 30, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230330114646/https://www.undertheradarmag.com/news/watch_first_aid_kit_perform_emmylou_in_front_of_a_teary_emmylou_harris_at_p |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2016, Harris was honored with a tribute concert entitled ''The Life & Songs of Emmylou Harris'', which was later released as both a DVD and a live CD. The concert featured several of Harris's closest friends and collaborators, including Rodney Crowell,\u00a0[[Alison Krauss]],\u00a0and\u00a0[[Lucinda Williams]]. Harris also performed at the concert which included her singing \"Boulder to Birmingham\" with other artists that were part of the program.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Life & Songs of Emmylou Harris Lineup |url=https://blackbirdpresents.com/concert/life-songs-emmylou-harris/lineup/ |website=Blackbird Presents |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812153746/https://blackbirdpresents.com/concert/life-songs-emmylou-harris/lineup/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |title=Emmylou Harris Tribute Concert Recorded for Live Album, DVD |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=September 27, 2016 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/emmylou-harris-tribute-concert-recorded-for-live-album-dvd-112768/ |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=September 2, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220902224156/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/emmylou-harris-tribute-concert-recorded-for-live-album-dvd-112768/ |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref>\n\n==Activism and dog rescue==\nIn 1997 and 1998, Harris performed in [[Sarah McLachlan]]'s [[Lilith Fair]] concert series, which promoted female music artists.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Koster |first1=Rick |title=Lilith Fair-ness |url=https://www.houstonpress.com/music/lilith-fair-ness-6570746 |access-date=August 12, 2023 |work=[[Houston Press]] |date=July 31, 1997 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812230618/https://www.houstonpress.com/music/lilith-fair-ness-6570746 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Hilburn |first1=Robert |title=They Said She Couldn't Do It |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1998-jun-21-ca-61947-story.html |access-date=August 12, 2023 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=June 21, 1998 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812230616/https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1998-jun-21-ca-61947-story.html |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> Since 1999, Harris has organized an annual benefit tour called Concerts for a Landmine-Free World.<ref>{{Cite web |date=January 17, 2002 |title=Concert for a Landmine-Free World, Glasgow |url=http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2002/jan/17/artsfeatures5 |access-date=August 4, 2022 |website=[[The Guardian]] |language=en |archive-date=July 1, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240701204423/https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2002/jan/17/artsfeatures5 |url-status=live }}</ref> All proceeds from the tours support the [[Vietnam Veterans of America Foundation]]'s (VVAF) efforts to assist innocent victims of conflicts around the world. The tour also benefits the VVAF's work to raise US awareness of the global [[land mine]] problem. Artists that have joined Harris on the road for these dates include [[Joan Baez]], [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]] and [[Willie Nelson]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kentuckyfriedcruelty.com/EmmyLouHarris.asp |title=Celebrity Support :: Emmylou Harris |publisher=Kentucky Fried Cruelty |access-date=July 15, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070303070456/http://www.kentuckyfriedcruelty.com/EmmyLouHarris.asp |archive-date=March 3, 2007 }}</ref> She became a member of the newly formed Commission in the Humanities and Social Sciences of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 2011, which started as a way to promote research with the humanities and social sciences.<ref>{{cite web |title=Duke President to Co-Chair National Commission on the Humanities |url=https://today.duke.edu/2011/02/rhbhumanities.html |website=[[Duke University]] |date=February 17, 2011 |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812230617/https://today.duke.edu/2011/02/rhbhumanities.html |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nSince childhood, Harris has enjoyed caring for dogs and fantasized about establishing a [[Animal rescue group|dog rescue]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Thanki |first1=Juli |title=Emmylou Harris' rescue gives youths, pets second chance |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/10/08/emmylou-harris-rescue-offers-youth-pets-second-chance/73373700/ |access-date=August 12, 2023 |work=[[The Tennessean]] |date=October 8, 2015 |archive-date=July 1, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240701204424/https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/10/08/emmylou-harris-rescue-offers-youth-pets-second-chance/73373700/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2004, Harris' pet dog named Bonaparte died. To remember him,\u00a0Harris decided\u00a0to establish\u00a0Bonaparte's Retreat, a dog rescue whose\u00a0purpose\u00a0was to save\u00a0stray dogs from animal shelters and house them until they found their \"forever home\".  The rescue resides in the Nashville area and often rescues dogs that are taken from the Metro Nashville Animal Care and Control facility.<ref name=\"Wide Open Country\">{{cite web |last1=Sparkman |first1=Darby |title=Emmylou Harris Establishes Bonaparte's Retreat to Support Nashville Animals |url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/bonapartes-retreat/ |website=Wide Open Country |date=November 11, 2021 |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812232445/https://www.wideopencountry.com/bonapartes-retreat/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=\"About\">{{cite web |title=About |url=https://www.bonapartesretreat.org/about |website=Bonaparte's Retreat |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=April 6, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240406062237/https://www.bonapartesretreat.org/about |url-status=live }}</ref> It also supports elderly or sickly dogs that are in need of a home. Harris helps raise funds for the program by creating concerts that sponsor the rescue.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dwyer |first1=Michael |title=The furry passion project that keeps Emmylou Harris playing |url=https://www.smh.com.au/culture/music/the-furry-passion-project-that-keeps-emmylou-harris-playing-20210923-p58u2n.html |access-date=August 12, 2023 |work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=September 23, 2021 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |url-access=registration |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812232439/https://www.smh.com.au/culture/music/the-furry-passion-project-that-keeps-emmylou-harris-playing-20210923-p58u2n.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Bonaparte's Retreat also works with a program that pairs troubled youth with foster animals. \"I think this is something that will affect their lives in a good way on into their adult lives,\" she commented.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Whitaker |first1=Sterling |title=Emmylou Harris Calls Her Work with Foster Animals 'A Sacred Responsibility' |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/emmylou-harris-shelter-me-partners-for-life-interview-2015/ |website=[[Taste of Country]] |date=October 2015 |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812232435/https://tasteofcountry.com/emmylou-harris-shelter-me-partners-for-life-interview-2015/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nHarris has been married and divorced three times and has called herself a \"really good ex-wife\".<ref>{{cite web |title=Emmylou Harris: The More Things Change |url=https://www.wbur.org/npr/135841061/emmylou-harris-the-more-things-change |website=[[WBUR-FM]] |date=April 29, 2011 |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812171136/https://www.wbur.org/npr/135841061/emmylou-harris-the-more-things-change |url-status=live }}</ref> In 1969, Harris met fellow folk artist Tom Slocum while living in New York City's Greenwich Village. They married the same year.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Einarson |first1=Jon |title=Mr. Tambourine Man The Life and Legacy of the Byrds' Gene Clark |date=2005 |publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield|Backbeat Books]] |isbn=978-0879307936 |page=204}}</ref> In 1970, she gave birth to her first daughter, Hallie.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Harrington |first1=Richard |title=Emmylou Harris -- Return of the Electric Cowgirl |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1980/07/06/emmylou-harris-return-of-the-electric-cowgirl/e42f38e2-967d-4c48-a565-d8e30cb621d9/ |access-date=August 12, 2023 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=July 6, 1980 |archive-date=July 27, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727135609/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1980/07/06/emmylou-harris-return-of-the-electric-cowgirl/e42f38e2-967d-4c48-a565-d8e30cb621d9/?noredirect=on |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> In 1971, the couple divorced.<ref name=\"Southern Culture\"/> In the early years of her career, Harris often took her daughter on the road with her. However, Hallie spent most of her time living with her grandparents in Maryland. \"I don't think the road is good for kids. Once in a while it's fun, like a trip to Disneyland. But not as a way of life,\" she commented.<ref name=\"NY Times Marriage\">{{cite news |last1=Maynard Bethel |first1=Joyce |title=Emmylou Harris-Her Heart Is Still in Country Music |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/03/12/archives/emmylou-harrisher-heart-is-still-in-country-music.html |access-date=August 12, 2023 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 12, 1978 |archive-date=July 27, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727152758/https://www.nytimes.com/1978/03/12/archives/emmylou-harrisher-heart-is-still-in-country-music.html |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> In 1977, Harris married her then-producer, [[Brian Ahern (producer)|Brian Ahern]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1985/03/27/the-ballad-of-emmylou/e97b628a-3b4b-4dec-b487-5386984ba900/|title=The Ballad of Emmylou|first=Richard|last=Harrington|date=March 27, 1985|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=June 28, 2019|archive-date=June 28, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190628022302/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1985/03/27/the-ballad-of-emmylou/e97b628a-3b4b-4dec-b487-5386984ba900/|url-status=live|url-access=subscription}}</ref> The couple married at Ahern's home in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=McPherson |first1=David |title=Brian Ahern |url=https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/brian-ahern |website=[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]] |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=May 28, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220528203744/https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/brian-ahern |url-status=live }}</ref> The couple then lived in the [[Studio City]] neighborhood of [[Los Angeles, California]].<ref name=\"NY Times Marriage\"/> Harris then welcomed her second child, Meghann, in 1979.<ref name=\"People\">{{cite magazine |last1=Jerome |first1=Jim |title=Emmylou Harris |url=https://people.com/archive/emmylou-harris-vol-35-no-1/ |magazine=People |access-date=February 9, 2021 |language=en |date=January 14, 1991 |archive-date=November 19, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201119110802/https://people.com/archive/emmylou-harris-vol-35-no-1/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In 1984, the couple divorced<ref name=\"Country Music Encyclopedia\"/> and Harris relocated to Nashville, Tennessee.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Harrington |first1=Richard |title=The Ballad of Emmylou |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1985/03/27/the-ballad-of-emmylou/e97b628a-3b4b-4dec-b487-5386984ba900/ |access-date=August 12, 2023 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=March 27, 1985 |archive-date=June 28, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190628022302/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1985/03/27/the-ballad-of-emmylou/e97b628a-3b4b-4dec-b487-5386984ba900/ |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> In 1985, Harris married songwriter and record producer [[Paul Kennerley]]. For several years, Harris and her family lived in an older home located near the [[Music Row]] neighborhood in Nashville.<ref name=\"People\"/> In 1993, Kennerley and Harris divorced.<ref name=\"Country Music Encyclopedia\"/>\n\nHarris has a granddaughter who was born in 2009 and a grandson born in 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/22/booming/a-full-circle-for-emmylou-harris.html |title=A Full Circle for Emmylou Harris |work=The New York Times |date=March 22, 2013 |access-date=April 3, 2021 |author=Joan Anderman |archive-date=February 10, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210210215104/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/22/booming/a-full-circle-for-emmylou-harris.html |url-status=live |url-access=subscription}}</ref> Harris is a [[Vegetarianism|vegetarian]].<ref>{{cite news |title='There is no magic cure for ageing, but you can slow it down with good food' |url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/life/features/there-is-no-magic-cure-for-ageing-but-you-can-slow-it-down-with-good-food/31097853.html |access-date=August 12, 2023 |work=[[Belfast Telegraph]] |date=March 27, 2015 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812175058/https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/life/features/there-is-no-magic-cure-for-ageing-but-you-can-slow-it-down-with-good-food/31097853.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Emmylou Harris (1947- ) |url=https://ivu.org/people/music/harris.html |website=[[International Vegetarian Union]] |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812175052/https://ivu.org/people/music/harris.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Harris' father died in 1993 after having an [[aortic rupture]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Maj. Walter Rutland \"Bucky\" Harris, USMC Ret. |url=https://www.moaa.org/content/about-moaa/scholarship-fund/faces-of-donorsFolder/Maj--Walter-Rutland-%E2%80%9CBucky%E2%80%9D-Harris,-USMC-Ret-/ |website=[[Military Officers Association of America]] |access-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812174540/https://www.moaa.org/content/about-moaa/scholarship-fund/faces-of-donorsFolder/Maj--Walter-Rutland-%E2%80%9CBucky%E2%80%9D-Harris,-USMC-Ret-/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Harris' mother then lived with her for 21 years until her death in 2014.<ref name=\"Q&A\"/> \"She's just about my best friend. She has an extraordinary gift of making a home a home without being intrusive\", Harris told [[CBS News]] in 2002.<ref>{{cite news |title=Catching Up With Emmylou Harris |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/catching-up-with-emmylou-harris/ |access-date=August 12, 2023 |work=[[CBS News]] |date=November 27, 2009 |archive-date=August 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230812174540/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/catching-up-with-emmylou-harris/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Emmylou Harris albums
