Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Ry_Cooder","to":"Ry Cooder"}],"pages":{"205506":{"pageid":205506,"ns":0,"title":"Ry Cooder","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musician (born 1947)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|image                 = Ry Cooder playing.jpg\n|name                  = Ry Cooder\n|caption               = Cooder performing in June 2009\n|background            = solo_singer\n|birth_name            = Ryland Peter Cooder\n|alias                 =\n|birth_date            = {{birth date and age|1947|3|15}}\n|birth_place           = [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]], U.S.\n|death_date            =\n|death_place           =\n|origin                = [[Santa Monica, California]], U.S.\n|instrument            = {{flatlist|\n*[[Guitar]]\n*[[bass guitar|bass]]\n*[[mandolin]]\n*[[bouzouki]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/16/arts/music/review-ry-cooder-ricky-skaggs-and-the-whites-a-roots-music-celebration.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|title=Review: Ry Cooder, Ricky Skaggs and the Whites, a Roots-Music Celebration|first=Nate|last=Chinen|date=November 15, 2015}}</ref>\n*[[banjo]]\n*[[slide guitar]]\n}}\n|genre                 =  {{flatlist|\n*[[Americana (music)|Americana]]\n*[[roots rock]]\n*[[folk music|folk]]\n*[[blues]]\n*[[Tejano music|Tex-Mex]]\n*[[country music|country]]\n*[[gospel music|gospel]]\n*[[world music]]\n}}\n|occupation            = {{flatlist|\n*Musician\n*songwriter\n*film score composer\n*record producer\n*writer\n}}\n|years_active          = 1967\u2013present\n|label                 = {{flatlist|\n*[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]\n*[[Nonesuch Records|Nonesuch]]\n*[[Elektra Records|Elektra]]\n}}\n|associated_acts       = {{flatlist|\n*[[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]]\n*[[Little Feat]]\n*[[Lowell George]]\n*[[Captain Beefheart]]\n*[[Buena Vista Social Club (album)|Buena Vista Social Club]]\n*[[Ali Farka Toure]]\n*[[The Rolling Stones]]\n*[[Carla Olson]]\n}}\n|website               = {{URL|http://rycooder.com|RyCooder.com}}\n}}\n'''Ryland Peter Cooder''' (born March 15, 1947) is an American musician, songwriter, film score composer, record producer, and writer. He is a multi-instrumentalist but is best known for his [[slide guitar]] work, his interest in [[traditional music]], and his collaborations with traditional musicians from many countries.\n\nCooder's solo work draws upon many genres. He has played with [[John Lee Hooker]], [[Captain Beefheart]], [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]], [[Gordon Lightfoot]], [[Ali Farka Tour\u00e9]], [[Eric Clapton]], [[the Rolling Stones]], [[Van Morrison]], [[Neil Young]], [[Randy Newman]], [[Linda Ronstadt]], [[Vishwa Mohan Bhatt]], [[David Lindley (musician)|David Lindley]], [[the Chieftains]], [[Warren Zevon]], [[Manuel Galb\u00e1n]], [[the Doobie Brothers]], [[Little Feat]], and [[Carla Olson|Carla Olson and the Textones]] (on record and film). He formed the band [[Little Village]], and produced the album ''[[Buena Vista Social Club (album)|Buena Vista Social Club]]'' (1997), which became a worldwide hit; [[Wim Wenders]] directed the [[Buena Vista Social Club (film)|documentary film of the same name]] (1999), which was nominated for an Academy Award in 2000.\n\nCooder was ranked at No. 8 on ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine's 2003 list of \"The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time\",<ref name=\"RS100\">{{cite magazine|url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-of-all-time-19691231 |title=The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time|magazine=Rolling Stone|date= September 18, 2003|access-date=August 28, 2011}}</ref> while a 2010 list by [[Gibson Guitar Corporation]] placed him at No. 32.<ref>{{cite web | title=Gibson.com Reveals Top 50 Guitarists, Plus Readers Poll Results | url=http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/Features/gibson-reveals-0528/ | publisher=Gibson Guitar Corporation | date=May 28, 2010 | access-date=June 3, 2010 |url-status = dead| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100601042203/http://www.gibson.com/en%2Dus/Lifestyle/Features/gibson%2Dreveals%2D0528/ | archive-date=June 1, 2010 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> In 2011, he published a collection of short stories called ''[[Los Angeles Stories]]''.\n\n==Early life==\nRyland Peter Cooder was born in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], on March 15, 1947,<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/135961/Ry-Cooder |title=Ry Cooder|encyclopedia=[[Encyclop\u00e6dia Britannica]] |first=Charlie |last=Gillett |author-link = Charlie Gillett|access-date=August 30, 2011}}</ref> the son of Emma Casaroli and Bill Cooder. His mother was of Italian descent. \n\nHe was raised in [[Santa Monica, California]], and graduated from [[Santa Monica High School]] in 1964.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/music/2007/mar/04/jazz.popandrock|work=[[The Guardian]]|title=Interview \u2013 From the Dust|date=March 3, 2007|access-date=February 18, 2016}}</ref> During the 1960s, he briefly attended [[Reed College]] in [[Portland, Oregon]].<ref>{{cite web | title=Who Put The Honky Tonk in 'Honky Tonk Women'? | author= Wilkinson, Alec |work=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]] | url= http://www.esquire.com/features/ESQ0699-JUN_COODER_rev_2 | date=June 1, 1999 | access-date=June 2, 2009}}</ref> He began playing the guitar when he was three years old.<ref name=rs/> \n\nAt age four, he accidentally stuck a knife in his right eye and has sported a [[Ocular prosthesis|glass eye]] ever since.<ref name=rs>{{cite encyclopedia| title= Ry Cooder| encyclopedia= The [[Rolling Stone]] Encyclopedia of Rock & Roll| publisher= Touchstone | edition= revised, updated | year= 2001| isbn=978-0743201209}}</ref>\n\n==Career==\n=== 1960s ===\nCooder performed as part of a [[pickup group|pickup trio]] with [[Bill Monroe]] and [[Doc Watson]], in which he played [[banjo]]. The trio was not successful, but reflecting his early exposure to the instrument, Cooder subsequently applied banjo tunings and the [[Scruggs style|three finger roll]] to guitar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roanoke.com/arts_and_entertainment/back-to-the-banjo-ry-cooder-returns-to-his-early/article_7a5f0c6d-d0d9-5af7-a83b-2fb2d0ea0644.html|title=Back to the banjo: Ry Cooder returns to his early instrument|website=Roanoke.com|date=August 13, 2015 |access-date=January 22, 2018}}</ref>\n\nCooder first attracted attention playing with [[Captain Beefheart|Captain Beefheart and his Magic Band]], notably on the 1967 album ''[[Safe as Milk]]'', after previously having worked with [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]] and [[Ed Cassidy]] in the [[Rising Sons]]. At a vital \"warm-up\" performance at the [[Fantasy Fair and Magic Mountain Music Festival|Mt. Tamalpais Festival]] (June 10\u201311, 1967) shortly before the scheduled [[Monterey Pop Festival]] (June 16\u201318, 1967), the band began to play \"[[Electricity (Captain Beefheart song)|Electricity]]\" and [[Don Van Vliet]] froze, straightened his tie, then walked off the {{convert|10|ft|m|abbr=on}} stage and landed on manager [[Bob Krasnow]]. He later claimed he had seen a girl in the audience turn into a fish, with bubbles coming from her mouth.<ref>French, John. ''Beefheart: Through The Eyes Of Magic'', p.253. {{ISBN|978-0-9561212-1-9}}</ref>\nThis aborted any opportunity for breakthrough success at Monterey, as Cooder immediately decided he could no longer work with Van Vliet,<ref>\n{{cite video\n | people= Elaine Shepard (Producer), Declan Smith (Film research)\n | date= 1997\n | title= The Artist Formerly Known as Captain Beefheart\n | medium= Documentary\n | publisher= BBC\n}}\n</ref>\neffectively quitting both the event and the band on the spot. Cooder also played with [[Randy Newman]], including on ''[[12 Songs (Randy Newman album)|12 Songs]]''.<ref>\n{{cite web\n | last= Deming\n | first= Mark\n | url= {{AllMusic|class=album |id=r14019 |pure_url=yes}}\n | title= 12 Songs \u2013 Randy Newman\n | website=[[AllMusic]]\n | access-date= September 5, 2011\n}}\n</ref>\n[[Van Dyke Parks]] worked with Newman and Cooder during the 1960s. Parks arranged Cooder's \"One Meatball\" according to Parks' 1984 interview with Bob Claster.\n\nCooder was a [[session musician]] on various recording sessions with [[the Rolling Stones]] in 1968 and 1969, and his contributions appear on the albums ''[[Let It Bleed]]'' ([[Yank Rachell|Yank Rachell-style]] [[mandolin]] on \"[[Love in Vain]]\"), and ''[[Sticky Fingers]]'', on which he contributed the slide guitar on \"[[Sister Morphine]]\". During this period, Cooder joined with [[Mick Jagger]], [[Charlie Watts]], [[Bill Wyman]], and longtime Rolling Stones [[sideman]] [[Nicky Hopkins]] to record ''[[Jamming with Edward!]]''. Cooder also played slide guitar for the 1970 film soundtrack ''[[Performance (soundtrack)|Performance]]'', which contained Jagger's first solo single, \"[[Memo from Turner]]\". The 1975 [[compilation album]] ''[[Metamorphosis (Rolling Stones album)|Metamorphosis]]'' features an uncredited Cooder contribution to Bill Wyman's \"Downtown Suzie\".\n\nCooder also collaborated with [[Lowell George]] of [[Little Feat]], playing [[slide guitar|bottleneck guitar]] on the original version of \"[[Willin' (Little Feat song)|Willin']]\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/little-feat-mw0000653350/credits|title=Little Feat \u2013 Little Feat &#124; Credits|website=AllMusic |access-date=February 5, 2010}}</ref> He also played bottleneck guitar and mandolin on two tracks on the Gordon Lightfoot album ''[[Sit Down Young Stranger]]'' (later re-titled ''If You Could Read My Mind''), recorded in late 1969 and released in early 1970.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rylanders.free-online.co.uk/RySite/RyPages/SitDownStranger.html |title=Gordon Lightfoot Sit Down Young Stranger |author=<!--Not stated--> |website=Rylanders: Ry Cooder Discography|access-date=September 18, 2022}}</ref>\n\n===1970s===\nThroughout the 1970s, Cooder released a series of [[Warner Bros. Records]] albums that showcased his guitar work, initially on the [[Reprise Records]] label, before being reassigned to the main Warners label along with many of Reprise's artists when the company retired the imprint. Cooder explored bygone musical [[genres]] and found old-time recordings which he then personalized and updated. Thus, on his breakthrough album, ''[[Into the Purple Valley]]'', he chose unusual instrumentations and arrangements of blues, gospel, [[calypso music|calypso]], and country songs (giving a tempo change to the cowboy ballad \"Billy the Kid\"). The album opened with the song \"How Can You Keep on Moving (Unless You Migrate Too)\" by [[Agnes \"Sis\" Cunningham]] about the [[Okie]]s who were not welcomed when they migrated west to escape the [[Dust Bowl]] in the 1930s \u2013 to which Cooder gave a rousing-yet-satirical march accompaniment. In 1970 he collaborated with Ron Nagle and performed on his ''Bad Rice'' album released on Warner Brothers. His later 1970s albums (with the exception of ''[[Jazz (Ry Cooder album)|Jazz]]'', which explored ragtime/vaudeville) do not fall under a single genre description, but his self-titled first album could be described as blues; ''Into the Purple Valley'', ''[[Boomer's Story]]'', and ''[[Paradise and Lunch]]'' as [[folk music|folk]] and blues; ''[[Chicken Skin Music]]'' and ''Showtime'' as a mix of [[Tejano music|Tex-Mex]] and [[Hawaiian music|Hawaiian]]; ''[[Bop Till You Drop]]'' as 1950s [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]]; and ''[[Borderline (Ry Cooder album)|Borderline]]'' and ''Get Rhythm'' as rock-based. His 1979 album ''Bop Till You Drop'' was the first [[popular music]] album released that was [[digital recording|recorded digitally]], using the early 3M digital mastering recorder.<ref name=\"Mixonline 2007\">{{cite web | title=1978 3M Digital Audio Mastering System | website=Mixonline | date=2007-09-01 | url=https://www.mixonline.com/technology/1978-3m-digital-audio-mastering-system-377974 | access-date=2023-03-18}}</ref> It yielded his biggest [[chart-topper|hit]], an R&B [[cover version]] of [[Elvis Presley]]'s 1960s recording \"[[Little Sister (Elvis Presley song)|Little Sister]]\".\n\nCooder is credited on [[Van Morrison]]'s 1979 album ''[[Into the Music]]'', for slide guitar on the song \"[[Full Force Gale]]\". He also played guitar on [[Judy Collins]]' 1970 concert tour, and is featured on ''[[Living (Judy Collins album)|Living]]'', the 1971 live album recorded during that tour. He also learned from and performed with [[Gabby Pahinui]] and [[Leland Isaacs, Sr.|\"Atta\" Isaacs]] in Hawaii during the [[Hawaiian Renaissance]] of the early 1970s. He is also credited for guitars on several 1971 recordings by [[Nancy Sinatra]] that were produced by Andy Wickman and Lenny Waronker \u2013 \"Is Anybody Goin' To San Antone\", \"Hook & Ladder\", and \"Glory Road\". Cooder is credited as a mandolin player on Gordon Lightfoot's ''[[Don Quixote (album)|Don Quixote]]'' album in 1972.\n\n===1980s===\nCooder has worked as a studio musician and has also scored many [[film soundtrack]]s including the [[Wim Wenders]] film ''[[Paris, Texas (film)|Paris, Texas]]'' (1984). Cooder based this soundtrack and title song \"Paris, Texas\" on [[Blind Willie Johnson]]'s \"[[Dark Was the Night (Cold Was the Ground)]]\", which he described as \"the most soulful, transcendent piece in all American music\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.austin360.com/music/content/music/blindwilliejohnson_092803.html;COXnetJSessionID=1ITtL0zcaTYPiiTPLjP1a2lrfOo25kwasby2KrVda2n1BrlyX13b!-615020192?urac=n&urvf=10701094852420.8419290445454791\"|title=The Soul of Blind Willie Johnson:Retracing the life of the Texas music icon|author=Corcoran, Michael|website=Austin360.com|access-date=September 5, 2011|url-status = dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819061919/http://www.austin360.com/music/content/music/blindwilliejohnson_092803.html|archive-date=August 19, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Musician [[Dave Grohl]] has declared Cooder's score for ''Paris, Texas'' one of his favorite albums.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pYG5eRoSTJwC&pg=PA57 |page=57| last=Greenwald |first=Andy |title=The Chosen Foo|journal=Spin|date=August 2005}}</ref> In 2018 Cooder told [[BBC Radio 4]] listeners: \"[Wenders] did a very good job at capturing the ambiance out there in the desert, just letting the microphones and the [[Nagra|nagra machine]] roll and get tones and sound from the desert itself, which I discovered was [[E\u266d tuning|E\u266d]], was in the key of E\u266d \u2013 that's the wind, you know, was nice. So we tuned everything to E\u266d.\"<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p066rj49 \"From Buena Vista to gospel and blues\"]. ''BBC Radio 4: Best of Today'', 10 May 2018.</ref>\n\n\"Dark Was the Night (Cold Was the Ground)\" was also the basis for Cooder's song \"Powis Square\" for the movie ''[[Performance (film)|Performance]]''. His other film work includes [[Walter Hill (filmmaker)|Walter Hill]]'s ''[[The Long Riders]]'' (1980), ''[[Southern Comfort (1981 film)|Southern Comfort]]'' (1981), ''[[Streets of Fire]]'' (1984), ''[[Brewster's Millions (1985 film)|Brewster's Millions]]'' (1985), ''[[Johnny Handsome]]'',<ref>''Johnny Handsome:Original Motion PictureSoundtrack'', Warner Bros. Records Inc.  CD liner notes, 1989</ref> ''[[Last Man Standing (1996 film)|Last Man Standing]]'' (1996), Hill's ''[[Trespass (1992 film)|Trespass]]'' (1992) and [[Mike Nichols]]' ''[[Primary Colors (film)|Primary Colors]]'' (1998). Cooder, along with [[Arlen Roth]], dubbed all slide and regular blues guitar parts in the 1986 film ''[[Crossroads (1986 film)|Crossroads]]'', a take on blues legend [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]]. In 1988, Cooder produced the album by his longtime backing vocalists [[Bobby King]] and [[Terry Evans (musician)|Terry Evans]] on [[Rounder Records]] titled ''Live and Let Live''. He contributed his slide guitar work to every track. He also plays extensively on their 1990 self-produced Rounder release ''Rhythm, Blues, Soul & Grooves''. Cooder's music also appeared on two episodes of the television program ''Tales From the Crypt'': \"The Man Who Was Death\" and \"The Thing From the Grave\".<ref>[http://www.allmusic.com/album/original-music-from-tales-from-the-crypt-w93724 Review of ''Tales From the Crypt''] by Steven McDonald, ''AllMusic.com''</ref>\n\nIn 1984, Cooder played on two songs on the debut album by Carla Olson & the Textones, ''Midnight Mission'' \u2013 \"Carla's Number One is to Survive\" and the previously unreleased [[Bob Dylan]] song \"Clean Cut Kid\". Shortly thereafter he was writing and recording the music for the film ''Blue City'' and asked the band to appear in the film performing. (He took them to the studio and produced \"You Can Run\" which he also played on.)\n\nIn 1985, Cooder was a guest artist on the song \"Rough Edges\" from [[Kim Carnes]]' album ''[[Barking at Airplanes]]''. Kim named her son Ry as a tribute to Ry Cooder.\n\nAlso in 1988, Cooder produced and featured in the [[Les Blank]]-directed concert documentary film ''Ry Cooder & The Moula Banda Rhythm Aces: Let's Have a Ball'' where he plays in collaboration with a selection of musicians famous in their various musical fields.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0170532/|title=Ry Cooder & The Moula Banda Rhythm Aces: Let's Have a Ball (1988)|author=RondoHatton|date=August 31, 1991|work=IMDb|access-date=January 7, 2015}}</ref> The following year, he played a janitor in the [[Jim Henson]] series ''[[The Ghost of Faffner Hall]]'', in the episode \"Music Is More Than Technique\".<ref>Archived at [https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211211/JvLkt_0dPP8 Ghostarchive]{{cbignore}} and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20130709013916/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JvLkt_0dPP8 Wayback Machine]{{cbignore}}: {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JvLkt_0dPP8 |title=The Jim Henson Company YouTube Channel |publisher=[[YouTube]]|date=January 12, 2012 |access-date=June 10, 2012}}{{cbignore}}</ref>\n\n===1990s===\nIn the early 1990s, Cooder collaborated on two [[world music]] \"crossover\" albums, which blended the traditional American musical genres that Cooder has championed throughout his career with the contemporary improvised music of India and Africa. For ''[[A Meeting by the River]]'' (1993), which also featured his son [[Joachim Cooder]] on percussion, he teamed with [[Hindustani classical music|Hindustani]] classical musician [[Vishwa Mohan Bhatt|V.M. Bhatt]], a virtuoso of the [[Mohan Veena]] (a modified 20-string [[archtop guitar]] of Bhatt's own invention) and Sukhvinder Singh Namdhari also known as Pinky Tabla Player.\n\nIn 1993 he teamed up with [[Mali]] a multi-instrumentalist [[Ali Farka Toure]] to record the album ''[[Talking Timbuktu]]'', which he also produced. The album, released in 1994, also featured longtime Cooder collaborator [[Jim Keltner]] on drums, veteran blues guitarist [[Clarence \"Gatemouth\" Brown]], jazz bassist [[John Patitucci]] and African percussionists and musicians including [[Hamma Sankare]] and Oumar Toure. Both albums won the [[Grammy Award]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Global Music Album|Best World Music Album]] in 1994 and 1995 respectively. Cooder also worked with [[Tuvans|Tuvan]] [[Overtone singing|throat singers]] for the score to the 1993 film ''[[Geronimo: An American Legend]]''.\n\nIn 1995 he performed in ''[[The Wizard of Oz in Concert: Dreams Come True]]'', a musical performance of the popular story at the [[Lincoln Center]] in New York to benefit the [[Children's Defense Fund]]. The performance was originally broadcast on both TBS and TNT. It was issued on CD and video in 1996.\n\nIn the late 1990s Cooder played a significant role in the increased appreciation of traditional [[Cuba]]n music, due to his collaboration as producer of the ''[[Buena Vista Social Club (album)|Buena Vista Social Club]]'' (1997) recording, which became a worldwide hit and revived the careers of some of the greatest surviving exponents of 20th century Cuban music. [[Wim Wenders]], who had previously directed 1984's ''[[Paris, Texas (film)|Paris, Texas]]'', directed a documentary film of the musicians involved, ''[[Buena Vista Social Club (film)|Buena Vista Social Club]]'' (1999), which was nominated for an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] in 2000.<ref name=\"NY Times\">{{cite news|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/176586/Buena-Vista-Social-Club/details |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071208064255/http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/176586/Buena-Vista-Social-Club/details |url-status=dead |archive-date=December 8, 2007 |department=Movies & TV Dept. |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2007 |title=NY Times: Buena Vista Social Club |access-date=November 22, 2008}}</ref> The enterprise cost him a $25,000 fine for violating the [[United States embargo against Cuba]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2007/mar/04/jazz.popandrock|work=[[The Guardian]]|title=Interview \u2013 From the Dust|date=March 3, 2007|access-date=May 27, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2001-feb-06-ca-21581-story.html|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|title=With Help From Up High, Cooder's Back in Cuba|author= Hancock, Jay|date=February 6, 2001|access-date=December 1, 2022}}</ref>\n\n===2000s===\nCooder's 2005 album ''[[Ch\u00e1vez Ravine (album)|Ch\u00e1vez Ravine]]'' was touted by his [[record label]] as being \"a post-World War II-era American narrative of 'cool cats', radios, UFO sightings, J. Edgar Hoover, red scares, and baseball\".<ref name=Nonesuch>{{cite web|url=http://www.nonesuch.com/albums/chavez-ravine|title= Ch\u00e1vez Ravine: About this album|date= May 29, 2008|publisher=Nonesuch Records|access-date=September 5, 2011}}</ref> The record is a tribute to the long-gone Los Angeles Latino enclave known as [[Ch\u00e1vez Ravine]]. Using real and imagined historical characters, Cooder and friends created an album that recollects various aspects of the poor but vibrant hillside [[Chicano]] community that no longer exists. Cooder says, \"Here is some music for a place you don't know, up a road you don't go. Ch\u00e1vez Ravine, where the sidewalk ends.\"<ref name=Nonesuch/> Drawing from the various musical strains of Los Angeles, including [[conjunto]], R&B, Latin pop, and jazz, Cooder and friends conjure the ghosts of Ch\u00e1vez Ravine and Los Angeles at mid-century. On this fifteen-track album, sung in Spanish and English, Cooder is joined by [[East Los Angeles, California|East L.A.]] legends like Chicano music patriarch [[Lalo Guerrero]], [[Pachuco]] boogie king [[Don Tosti]], [[Thee Midniters]] front man Little Willie G, and Ersi Arvizu, of The Sisters and [[El Chicano]].\n\nCooder's next record was released in 2007. Entitled ''[[My Name Is Buddy]]'', it tells the story of Buddy Red Cat, who travels and sees the world in the company of his like-minded friends, Lefty Mouse and Rev. Tom Toad. The entire recording is a parable of the working class progressivism<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=7719791|title=Cooder's 'Buddy' Revives Tales of a Bygone America|publisher=NPR Music|date= March 6, 2007 |access-date=August 30, 2011}}</ref> of the first half of the American twentieth century, and even has a song featuring executed unionist [[Joe Hill (activist)|Joe Hill]]. ''My Name Is Buddy'' was accompanied by a booklet featuring a story and illustration (by [[Vincent Valdez]]) for each track, providing additional context to Buddy's adventures.\n\nCooder produced and performed on an album for [[Mavis Staples]] entitled ''[[We'll Never Turn Back]]'', which was released on April 24, 2007. The [[concept album]] focused on [[Gospel music|Gospel]] songs of the [[civil rights movement]] and also included two new original songs by Cooder.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/56405/mavis-staples-gets-personal-on-anti-debut|title=Mavis Staples Gets Personal On Anti-Debut|author1=Cohen, Jonathan  |author2=Martens, Todd |name-list-style=amp |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=December 19, 2006|access-date=August 28, 2011}}</ref>\n\nCooder's album ''[[I, Flathead]]'' was released on June 24, 2008. It is the completion of his California trilogy. Based on the [[drag racing]] culture of the early 1960s, the album is set on the desert salt flats in southern California. The disc was also released as a deluxe edition with stories written by Cooder to accompany the music.\n\nIn late 2009, Cooder toured Japan, New Zealand, and Australia with [[Nick Lowe]], performing some of Lowe's songs and a selection of Cooder's own material, mainly from the 1970s. Joaquim Cooder (Ry's son) provided percussion, and [[Juliette Commagere]] and [[Alex Lilly]] contributed backing vocals.\n\nThe song \"Diaraby\", which Cooder recorded with [[Ali Farka Tour\u00e9]], is used as the theme to ''[[The World (radio program)|The World]]'s'' Geo Quiz. ''The World'' is a radio show distributed by [[Public Radio International]].\n\nIn 2009, Cooder performed in ''[[The People Speak (film)|The People Speak]]'', a documentary feature film that uses dramatic and musical performances of the letters, diaries, and speeches of everyday Americans, based on historian [[Howard Zinn]]'s ''[[A People's History of the United States]]''. Cooder performed with Bob Dylan and Van Dyke Parks on the documentary broadcast on December 13, 2009, on the [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]]. They played \"[[Do Re Mi (Woody Guthrie song)|Do Re Mi]]\" and reportedly a couple of other [[Woody Guthrie|Guthrie]] songs that were excluded from the final edit. He also traveled with the band [[Los Tigres del Norte]] and recorded the 2010 album ''[[San Patricio (album)|San Patricio]]'' with the Chieftains, [[Lila Downs]], [[Liam Neeson]], [[Linda Ronstadt]], [[Van Dyke Parks]], [[Los Cenzontles]], and Los Tigres.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2010/05/24/100524fa_fact_wilkinson |title=Onward and Upward with the Arts, \"Immigration Blues\"|author= Wilkinson, Alec |magazine=The New Yorker|date=May 24, 2010|access-date=June 3, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/review/1069640/the-chieftains-featuring-ry-cooder-san-patricio|title=The Chieftains featuring Ry Cooder, \"San Patricio\"|publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|author= Wood, Mikael|date=March 5, 2010 |access-date=June 3, 2010}}</ref>\n\n===2010s===\n[[File:Ry Cooder 19Aug2015 (2).jpg|thumb|right|Cooder playing the electric [[bouzouki]] in August 2015]]\nIn June 2010, responding to the passage of [[Arizona SB 1070]], he released the single \"Quicksand\", which tells the story of Mexicans attempting to emigrate to Arizona through the desert.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/ry-cooders-quicksand-response-arizona-immigration-law-available-itunes-proceeds-donated-maldef-2010-06-29|title=Ry Cooder's 'Quicksand', Response to Arizona Immigration Law, Now Available on iTunes; Proceeds Donated to MALDEF|publisher=Nonesuch Journal, [[Nonesuch Records]]|date=June 29, 2010|access-date=April 2, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/reviews/2010-06-28-playlist29_N.htm|work=USA Today|title=The playlist: Sia's 'Fight,' Marah's 'Problem,' Cooder's 'Quicksand'|author= Gundersen, Edna|date= June 28, 2010|access-date=April 2, 2011}}</ref>\nCooder's critically acclaimed<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/album-ry-cooder-pull-up-some-dust-and-sit-down-nonesuch-2347604.html|title=Album: Ry Cooder, Pull Up Some Dust And Sit Down (Nonesuch)\n|author= Gill, Andy|work=The Independent |date= September 2, 2011|access-date=September 4, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2011/sep/01/ry-cooder-pull-up-review|title=Ry Cooder: Pull Up Some Dust and Sit Down \u2013 review|author=Spencer, Neil|work=The Guardian |date=September 4, 2011|access-date =September 4, 2011}}</ref> new album ''[[Pull Up Some Dust and Sit Down]]'', released on August 30, 2011, contains politically charged songs such as \"No Banker Left Behind\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-15037331|title=Ry Cooder takes on the bankers|author= Stanbridge, Nicola ([[Today (BBC Radio 4)|Today programme]]) |work=[[BBC Online]]|date= September 24, 2011|access-date=September 25, 2011}}</ref> which was inspired by a [[Robert Scheer]] column.<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.marketplace.org/2011/08/29/life/art-money/ry-cooder-protest-songs-today |title=Ry Cooder on the protest songs of today |journal=Marketplace |publisher=American Public Media |date=August 29, 2011 |access-date=May 8, 2018 }}</ref>\n\nIn 2011, he published a collection of short stories called ''[[Los Angeles Stories]]'', written about people living in Los Angeles in the 1940s and 1950s. The book's characters are mostly talented or skilled, clever or hardworking people living in humble circumstances.  With story titles such as \"La vida es un sue\u00f1o\" and \"Kill me, por favor\", the collection's stories often have a Hispanic theme, and the book deals partially with Latinos living in Los Angeles during this time.\n\nAn ''[[American Songwriter]]'' article in 2012 suggested that Cooder's recent string of solo albums have often taken on an allegorical, sociopolitical bent. Music journalist Evan Schlansky said that \"Cooder's latest effort, ''[[Election Special]]'' (released August 21, 2012, on Nonesuch/Perro Verde) doesn't mince words. It's designed to send a message to the 'deacons in the High Church of the Next Dollar'\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2012/06/ry-cooder-breaks-down-the-songs-on-election-special/|title=Ry Cooder Breaks Down The Songs On Election Special|date=June 7, 2012|publisher=[[American Songwriter]]|access-date=June 8, 2012}}</ref> The album was composed in support of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] and President [[Barack Obama]] in the 2012 election.\n\nOn September 10, 2013, Cooder released ''[[Live in San Francisco (Ry Cooder and Corridos Famosos album)|Live in San Francisco]]'', featuring the Corridos Famosos band, including [[Joachim Cooder]] on drums; [[Robert Francis (musician)|Robert Francis]] on bass; vocalists Terry Evans, [[Arnold McCuller]], and [[Juliette Commagere]]; [[Flaco Jim\u00e9nez]] on accordion; and the Mexican brass band La Banda Juvenil. The album was recorded during a two-night run at [[Great American Music Hall]] in [[San Francisco]], August 31 and September 1, 2011. It is Cooder's first official live recording since ''Show Time'' in 1977 (which had also been recorded at Great American Music Hall).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nonesuch.com/journal/nonesuch-perro-verde-records-release-ry-cooder-corridos-famosos-live-in-san-francisco-september-10-2013-07-23|title=Nonesuch / Perro Verde Records Release Ry Cooder and Corridos Famosos' \"Live in San Francisco\" September 10|date=July 23, 2013 |publisher=[[Nonesuch Records]]|access-date=August 19, 2013}}</ref>\n\nIn 2015, Cooder toured with [[Ricky Skaggs]], Sharon White and other members of [[the Whites]] with their \"Music for The Good People\" show.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cozy Up To Warm Sounds for Fall with 'Cooder White Skaggs' Tour|url=http://www.rickyskaggs.com/news/09-09-15/cozy-warm-sounds-fall-cooder-white-skaggs-tour/|publisher=Ricky Skaggs website|access-date=September 14, 2015\n}}</ref> The tour continued through into 2016.\n\nOn May 11, 2018, Cooder released his first solo album in six years entitled ''[[The Prodigal Son (Ry Cooder album)|The Prodigal Son]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/ry-cooder-details-new-lp-the-prodigal-son-w517235|title=Ry Cooder Previews New LP 'The Prodigal Son' With 'Shrinking Man' Song|date=March 2018|publisher=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=May 29, 2018}}</ref> The subsequent tour featured opening performances by his son, Joachim, who also accompanied Cooder on drums.<ref name=\"Prodigal Son tour\">{{cite web | last=Lewis | first=Randy | title=Review: Ry Cooder preaches his gospel on the Prodigal Son tour stop in Escondido | website=Los Angeles Times | date=2018-08-20 | url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-ry-cooder-prodigal-son-tour-review-20180820-story.html | access-date=2023-03-18}}</ref>\n\nIn 2019, he toured with Rosanne Cash on a brief tour as a tribute to Johnny Cash called \"Cooder and Cash on Cash\".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/rosanne-cash-ry-cooder-johnny-cash-tribute-tour-809387 |title=Rosanne Cash, Ry Cooder Announce New Johnny Cash Tribute Shows|date=March 2018|publisher=[[Rolling Stone]]}}</ref>\n\n===2020s===\nOn April 22, 2022, Cooder and Taj Mahal released ''Get on Board: The Songs of Sonny Terry & Brownie McGhee''.<ref>{{cite web\n|url=https://www.nonesuch.com/albums/get-board\n|title=Get On Board by Taj Mahal + Ry Cooder\n|website=nonesuch\n|date=April 22, 2022\n|publisher=Nonesuch Records\n|access-date=August 4, 2022}}</ref>\n\n==Awards==\n* 1988 [[Grammy Award]] (Best Recording for Children) \u2013 ''Pecos Bill'', producer ([[Rabbit Ears This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Allison_Moorer","to":"Allison Moorer"}],"pages":{"4276893":{"pageid":4276893,"ns":0,"title":"Allison Moorer","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter (born 1972)}}\n{{About|the musician|similarly named people|Alison Moore (disambiguation){{!}}Alison Moore}}\n{{Use American English|date=August 2023}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2023}}\n{{BLP sources|date=April 2010}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Allison Moorer\n| image           = Moorer2018.jpg\n| image_upright   = 1.2\n| caption         = Moorer in 2018\n| birth_name      = \n| birth_date      = {{Birth date and age|1972|6|21}}\n| birth_place     = [[Mobile, Alabama]], U.S.\n| origin          = [[Monroeville, Alabama]], U.S.\n| genre           = {{Flatlist|\n*[[Americana music|Americana]]\n*[[Country music|country]]\n*[[Folk music|folk]]\n}}\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| instrument      = {{Flatlist|\n*Vocals\n*guitar\n*piano\n}}\n| years_active    = 1998\u2013present\n| spouse          = {{marriage|[[Hayes Carll]]|May 12, 2019}}\n| label           = [[MCA Nashville Records]]<br />[[Universal South]]<br />[[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill]]<br />[[New Line Records|New Line]]<br />[[Rykodisc]]\n| website         = {{URL|allisonmoorer.com}}\n}}\n'''Allison Moorer''' (born June 21, 1972) is an American [[Country music|country]] singer-songwriter. She signed with [[MCA Nashville]] in 1997 and made her debut on the U.S. [[Billboard Country Chart]] with the release of her debut single, \"A Soft Place to Fall\", which she co-wrote with [[Gwilym Emyr Owen III|Gwil Owen]]. The song was featured in [[Robert Redford]]'s ''[[The Horse Whisperer (film)|The Horse Whisperer]]'' and was nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Original Song]] in 1999. Moorer performed at the Oscars ceremony the same year. She has made ten albums and her songs have been recorded by [[Trisha Yearwood]], [[Kenny Chesney]], [[Miranda Lambert]], [[Steve Earle]], and [[Hayes Carll]].\n\n== Early life ==\nMoorer was born in [[Mobile, Alabama]] on June 21, 1972.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.allison-moorer.com/bio.html|title=Biography|website=Allison-moorer.com|access-date=October 28, 2019}}</ref> She was raised in [[Frankville, Alabama]], and later [[Monroeville, Alabama]], after the deaths of her parents. Growing up, Moorer and her sister also lived in [[Jackson, Alabama]] at various times.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Moorer|first=Allison|title=Blood: A Memoir|publisher=Da Capo Press|year=2019|isbn=978-0-306-92268-8}}</ref>  Music was an important part of the Moorer family. Moorer's father was a heavy drinker who abused his wife. In 1985, her mother fled with the two girls to nearby Mobile, but her father soon discovered their whereabouts. In 1986, when Moorer was 14 and her older sister Shelby (now [[Shelby Lynne]]) was 17, he shot and killed his wife before taking his own life.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.npr.org/2010/12/15/132082946/shelby-lynne-and-allison-moorer-musical-sisters | title=Shelby Lynne and Allison Moorer: Musical Sisters | publisher=NPR | date=December 15, 2010}}</ref> Moorer graduated from the [[University of South Alabama]] in Mobile in June 1993 and then moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], without even collecting her diploma to join her sister, singer/songwriter Shelby Lynne, who lived there and had already released three albums. Moorer began singing backgrounds in Lynne's band full time and toured extensively with her.\n\n== Career ==\nIn June 1996, Moorer took part in a tribute to her songwriter friend, the late [[Walter Hyatt]], singing his \"Tell Me Baby\" at Nashville's [[Ryman Auditorium]]. Nashville agent Bobby Cudd was in attendance and subsequently introduced her to renowned producer and MCA Nashville president [[Tony Brown (record producer)|Tony Brown]]. After a few meetings, Brown asked her to cut some demos for the label. Two tracks\u2014\"Pardon Me\" and \"Call My Name\"\u2014 from that session were included on her first MCA album, ''[[Alabama Song (album)|Alabama Song]]''.\n\nWhen Brown moved from [[MCA Records]] to sister label [[Universal South]], Moorer followed. Her 2002 album, ''[[Miss Fortune (album)|Miss Fortune]]'', earned more raves, but didn't meet sales expectations. It contained the ballad \"Tumbling Down,\" which was featured on the soundtrack of the popular 2002 film ''[[The Rookie (2002 film)|The Rookie]]''.\n\nHer live album [[Show (Allison Moorer album)|''Show'']] was recorded in one night at 12th and Porter in Nashville.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Allison Moorer \u2013 Show |url=https://www.nodepression.com/album-reviews/allison-moorer-show/ |access-date=February 19, 2023 |website=No Depression |language=en-US}}</ref> It features the first recorded collaboration between Moorer and Lynne. After releasing ''Show'' and a DVD on Universal South, Moorer moved to independent label [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]]. With a slightly rougher edge than past efforts, ''[[The Duel (Allison Moorer album)|The Duel]]'' was released in April 2004. Moorer's first husband, Doyle Lee Primm, was featured as a songwriter on her first four albums. They divorced in 2005. After serving as his opening act on a European tour, Moorer married fellow singer/songwriter [[Steve Earle]]. Earle produced her 2006 album, ''[[Getting Somewhere]]''. Moorer wrote all the songs, with the exception of one co-written with Earle. They were both nominated for the Best Country Collaboration with Vocals Grammy, for the song \"Days Aren't Long Enough\" from Earle's ''Washington Square Serenade'' in 2008. The song was also nominated for an [[Americana Music Association]] award. Moorer gave birth to the couple's first child, John Henry Earle, on April 5, 2010,<ref>{{Cite web |date=June 6, 2011 |title=Steve Earle: Hardcore Troubador Page 3 |url=https://www.stereophile.com/content/steve-earle-hardcore-troubador-page-3 |access-date=February 19, 2023 |website=Stereophile.com |language=en}}</ref> but they separated in 2012 and divorced in 2015.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Hattenstone |first=Simon |date=June 14, 2017 |title=Steve Earle: 'My wife left me for a younger, skinnier, less talented singer' |language=en-GB |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/jun/14/steve-earle-so-you-wanna-be-an-outlaw-interview |access-date=February 19, 2023 |issn=0261-3077}}</ref>\n\nMoorer released the [[Buddy Miller]]-produced ''Mockingbird'' in February 2008;[4] an album mainly of covers of songs by female singer/songwriters including her sister, Shelby Lynne.\n[[File:Allison Moorer.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|Moorer performing in 2009]]\nIn 2009, Moorer performed in ''[[The People Speak]]'', a documentary feature film that uses dramatic and musical performances of the letters, diaries, and speeches of everyday Americans, based on historian [[Howard Zinn]]'s ''A People's History of the United States''.[5] She appeared in the off-Broadway ''Rebel Voices'', a dramatization of Howard Zinn and Anthony Arnove's ''Voices of a People's History of the United States'' in late 2007. Also, in 2009, she appeared on the [[BBC]] series ''[[Transatlantic Sessions]]'', Series 4, Episodes 4 and 5, performing a version of the Irish folk song, \"Carrickfergus\". She toured with the [[Jerry Douglas]] and Ally Bain led Transatlantic Sessions band in early 2011.\n\nIn 2015, Moorer released her ninth album, ''Down to Believing'', which marked a return to collaborating with [[Kenny Greenberg]].\n\nIn August 2017, Moorer released her tenth album, ''Not Dark Yet'', in collaboration with her sister. Produced by British folk singer [[Teddy Thompson]], it featured covers of songs by [[Merle Haggard]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]] and [[The Killers]] as well as one original song written by Moorer and Lynne, \"Is It Too Much.\" During an extended interview at the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]], the duo revealed that they were planning a second collaborative album which would instead feature all original material and that they were to begin writing together for the new project in 2018.\n\nMoorer co-produced the 2019 [[Hayes Carll]] record ''[[What It Is (Hayes Carll album)|What It Is]]''.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Gage |first=Jeff |date=February 26, 2019 |title=Hayes Carll on Harnessing Humor, Dance-Hall Vibe of New Album 'What It Is' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/hayes-carll-times-like-these-video-800244/ |access-date=February 19, 2023 |magazine=Rolling Stone}}</ref> She and Carll were married on May 12, 2019.<ref>{{Cite web |date=May 14, 2019 |title=Hayes Carll and Allison Moorer Get Married |url=https://www.thecountrydaily.com/2019/05/14/hayes-carll-and-allison-moorer-get-married/ |access-date=February 19, 2023 |website=The Country Daily}}</ref> Moorer's album ''Blood'' was to be released October 25, 2019; her book, ''Blood: A Memoir'', was scheduled for publication on October 29, 2019, on [[Da Capo Press]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/allison-moorer-new-album-memoir-blood-the-rock-and-the-hill-873608/|title=Allison Moorer Previews New Album and Memoir With Visceral Song 'The Rock and the Hill'|first1=Stephen L.|last1=Betts|publisher=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=August 19, 2019}}</ref> \n\nIn May 2024, Moorer announced that she had taken a job as a writer-editor at the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Willman |first1=Chris|title=Allison Moorer on Setting Performing Aside to Take a Job With the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum: 'It's a Way to Give Back to What Saved Me'|magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=May 10, 2024 |url=https://variety.com/2024/music/news/allison-moorer-country-music-hall-fame-museum-1235998654/|access-date=11 May 2024}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n=== Studio albums ===\n{| class=\"wikitable The song was co-written and originally recorded with [[Sheryl Crow]]. Rock's label, [[Atlantic Records]], was unable to obtain permission from Crow's label, [[A&M Records]], to release the original version as a single, thus it was rerecorded with Moorer.\n*Has often toured and recorded vocals with [[Steve Earle]] since 2006, and was a member of his band the Dukes and Duchesses.\n* Duets with [[Josh Turner]] on the [[Hank Williams]] song \"[[Alone and Forsaken]]\", which appears on his 2020 album ''Country State of Mind''.\n\n== Bibliography ==\n*''Blood: A Memoir'' (2019) \u2013 published by [[Hachette Book Group]]\n*''I Dream He Talks to Me: A Sky Crunch, [[New West Records|New West]], [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill]], Thirty Tigers, [[Dualtone Records|Dualtone]], [[Proper Records|Proper]]\n| associated_acts  = [[Robert Hunter (lyricist)|Robert Hunter]], [[Buddy Miller]], [[Ralph Stanley]], [[Donna the Buffalo]]\n| website          = {{URL|jimlauderdalemusic.com}}\n}}\n\n'''James Russell Lauderdale'''<ref name=Dad-obit-GN /> (born April 11, 1957) is an American [[country music|country]], [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]], and [[Americana (music)|Americana]] singer-songwriter.<ref name=EncycCountryMusic /> Since 1986, he has released 31 studio albums, including collaborations with artists such as [[Ralph Stanley|Dr. Ralph Stanley]], [[Buddy Miller]], and [[Donna the Buffalo]]. A \"songwriter's songwriter,\"<ref name=NPR-WorldCafe-2013 /> his songs have been recorded by dozens of artists, notably [[George Strait]], [[Gary Allan]], [[Elvis Costello]], [[Blake Shelton]], the [[Dixie Chicks]], [[Vince Gill]], and [[Patty Loveless]].\n\n[[File:JimLauderdaleMCR.jpg|thumb|Jim Lauderdale hosting Music City Roots]]\n\n== Early life ==\nLauderdale was born in [[Troutman, North Carolina]], the son of Barbara Ann Lauderdale (n\u00e9e Hobson)<ref name=Mom-obit>{{cite web|title=Barbara Hobson Lauderdale (July 10, 1930 \u2013 8 March 2011)|url=http://www.chandlerjacksonfh.com/services.asp?page=odetail&id=5260&locid=1#.UqvoI2RDs1N|work=Chandler-Jackson Funeral Home and Cremation Services|access-date=December 14, 2013|archive-date=October 6, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006164632/http://www.chandlerjacksonfh.com/services.asp?page=odetail&id=5260&locid=1#.UqvoI2RDs1N|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=Mom-obit-GN>{{cite news|title=Barbara Lauderdale Obituary|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/greenvilleonline/obituary.aspx?page=lifestory&pid=149159540|access-date=December 14, 2013|newspaper=The Greenville News|date=March 9, 2011}}</ref> and Dr. Wilbur \"Chap\" Chapman Lauderdale.<ref name=Dad-obit-GN>{{cite news|title=Wilbur Lauderdale Obituary|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/greenvilleonline/obituary.aspx?n=wilbur-lauderdale&pid=140744706|access-date=December 14, 2013|newspaper=The Greenville News|date=September 8, 2004}}</ref><ref name=Dad-obit>{{cite web|title=Wilbur \"Chap\" Chapman Lauderdale (August 29, 1924 \u2013 7 September 2004)|url=http://www.chandlerjacksonfh.com/services.asp?page=odetail&id=4868&locid=1#.Uqvdn2RDs1M|work=Chandler-Jackson Funeral Home and Cremation Services|access-date=December 14, 2013|archive-date=October 6, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006165742/http://www.chandlerjacksonfh.com/services.asp?page=odetail&id=4868&locid=1#.Uqvdn2RDs1M|url-status=dead}}</ref> Lauderdale's mother was originally from [[Kansas]].<ref name=Mom-obit-GN /> In addition to her work as a public school and piano teacher, she was active in the [[Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church]]es in [[Troutman, North Carolina|Troutman]], [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]], and [[Due West, South Carolina]], where she served as music director, church organist, and choir director.<ref name=Mom-obit /> His father was born in [[Lexington, VA]], the son of Reverend David Thomas and Sallie Ann Lauderdale (n\u00e9e Chapman).<ref name=Dad-obit /> Lauderdale's father was a [[Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church#Members and Ministers|noted minister]] in the [[Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church]].<ref name=Dad-obit /> Lauderdale has one sister.\n\nHe grew up in Due West, South Carolina.<ref name=EncycCountryMusic>{{cite book|last=Shone|first=Mark|title=The Encyclopedia of Country Music|year=2012|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|location=Oxford, MS|isbn=9780199920839|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLZz02EzmBYC&q=The%20Encyclopedia%20of%20Country%20Music%20jim%20lauderdale&pg=PT1132|edition=2nd|editor=Michael McCall|access-date=December 14, 2013}}</ref> Both of his parents were singers. He too sang in his early years, and learned the drums at 11, the harmonica at 13, and the banjo at 15.<ref name=TwangNation2013 /> He has cited the influence of [[Ralph Stanley]] and bluegrass music from an early age. He played a variety of music, including bluegrass, Grateful Dead, and folk in a duo with best friend Nathan Lajoie as a teenager.<ref name=DO-1999 />\n\nDuring his childhood in Due West, many music acts came to [[Erskine College]]. Lauderdale remembers enjoying the album ''[[Will the Circle be Unbroken (Nitty Gritty Dirt Band album)|Will the Circle be Unbroken]]'' by the [[Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]] and [[Neil Young]]'s ''[[Harvest (Neil Young album)|Harvest]].''<ref name=HometownHeart-1999>{{cite web|last=Cooper|first=Peter|title=Hometown Heart: Due West native Jim Lauderdale comes to Greenville for an important performance |url=http://web.cln.com/archives/greenville/newsstand/archives/051097/vibes2.htm |work=Greenville / Spartanburg Arts & Entertainment|publisher=Creative Loafing Online|access-date=December 14, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/19991009193946/http://web.cln.com/archives/greenville/newsstand/archives/051097/vibes2.htm|archive-date=October 9, 1999}}</ref> He attended the [[Carolina Friends School]] in Durham NC and then went on to the [[North Carolina School of the Arts]] in [[Winston-Salem, NC]], studying theater. He played in country and bluegrass bands during college.<ref name=DO-1999 />\n\nLauderdale is a long-time resident of [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name=ATC-12-2013>{{cite web|last=Ochs|first=Meredith|title=For The Bloodiest Tales In American Music, A Revenge-Themed Sequel|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/12/12/250535539/for-the-bloodiest-tales-in-american-music-a-revenge-themed-sequel?sc=fb&cc=fmp|work=[[All Things Considered]]|publisher=[[National Public Radio]]|access-date=December 14, 2013|format=radio show|date=December 12, 2013}}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\n[[File:Lauderdale-fls.jpg|thumb|left|Jim Lauderdale at MerleFest in 2007.]]\n\nAfter graduating from college, Lauderdale lived in Nashville for five months in the summer of 1979 while he tried to get a recording or publishing deal. He hung out a lot with [[Roland White]], an accomplished mandolin player, with whom he cut a record. But things never took off, so he decided to move to New York,<ref name=NPR-WorldCafe-2013>{{cite web|last=Dye|first=David|title=Buddy Miller And Jim Lauderdale On World Cafe |url=https://www.npr.org/2013/04/11/176161225/buddy-miller-and-jim-lauderdale-on-world-cafe|work=[[NPR]]|publisher=[[National Public Radio]]|access-date=January 3, 2014|format=audio interview|date=April 11, 2013}}</ref> where he played in [[Floyd Domino]]'s band and performed as a solo artist. In 1980 he met singer-songwriter [[Buddy Miller]].<ref name=NPR-WorldCafe-2013 /> He played in Miller's band in the active twang music scene that was evolving at the time.<ref name=DO-1999 />\n\nDuring his time in New York City, he also worked in the mailroom and as a messenger at ''[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]'' magazine.<ref name=NPR-Buddy&JimTDC /> He often was assigned to pick up and drop off photographer [[Annie Leibovitz]]'s equipment.<ref name=DO-1999 />\n\nLauderdale joined the national touring production of ''[[Pump Boys & Dinettes]]'', which eventually reached Los Angeles where he met musicians [[Rosie Flores]], Billy Bremmer, [[Pete Anderson]], [[Lucinda Williams]], [[Dale Watson (singer)|Dale Watson]], and others.<ref name=DO-1999 /> John Ciambotti became Lauderdale's manager and Lauderdale relocated to Los Angeles in the late 1980s, recording an album for CBS (which was later released as ''The Point of No Return''). The record was influenced by the [[Bakersfield, California|Bakersfield]] sound of [[Buck Owens]].<ref name=DO-1999 />\n\nArmed with a catalog of a few hundred songs he had written, Lauderdale was able to get a publishing deal with a small company called Blue Water Music (based in Houston, with a small office in Nashville). Living in Los Angeles he made a record with Anderson producing, but it was never released.<ref name=NPR-WorldCafe-2013 />\n\nLauderdale then got a publishing deal with Reprise and moved into the second floor of Buddy and Julie Miller's house until he got his own place in Nashville.<ref name=NPR-WorldCafe-2013 />\n\nIn 2013, Lauderdale started his own record label, Sky Crunch, so that he could release his many albums on a schedule that suited him.<ref>from an interview on [http://americanamusicshow.com/episode275 Americana Music Show #275], published December 1, 2015</ref>\n\nIn April 2018, Lauderdale signed to Yep Roc Records.<ref name=Yep-Roc-Records>{{cite web|title=Yep Roc Records Welcomes Jim Lauderdale!|url=http://www.yeproc.com/yep-roc-records-welcomes-jim-lauderdale|access-date=May 23, 2018|date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>\n\n=== Solo career ===\n\nLauderdale's solo debut, ''Planet of Love'', was produced by [[Rodney Crowell]] and [[John Leventhal]] and released in 1991.<ref name=DO-1999 /><ref name=MusicMonitor-TurnLeft>{{cite web |last=Winkworth |first=Bruce |title=Go to the Country, Turn Left |url=http://www.penduluminc.com/MM/articles/lauderdale.html |work=The Music Monitor|access-date=December 14, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061106152010/http://www.penduluminc.com/MM/articles/lauderdale.html|archive-date=November 6, 2006}}</ref> ''Lost in the Lonesome Pines'', a 2002 collaboration with [[Ralph Stanley]], won the [[Grammy Award for Best Bluegrass Album]]. ''The Bluegrass Diaries'' won the same award in 2008. In 2003, Lauderdale was joined by roots/jam band [[Donna the Buffalo]] on the album ''Wait 'Til Spring''. ''Could We Get Any Closer?'' was nominated for a Grammy in 2009.\n\nIn 2013, Lauderdale released ''Old Time Angels'' (a bluegrass album) and his first solo acoustic album, ''Blue Moon Junction'', followed by ''Black Roses,'' with the [[North Mississippi All-Stars]].<ref name=Bristol-NewTunes-2014>{{cite web|last=Netherland|first=Tom|title=Lauderdale brings new tunes, standbys to town|url=http://www.tricities.com/news/local/article_39009100-792c-11e3-bbd5-0019bb30f31a.html|work=Tri Cities \u2013 Bristol Herald Courier (Bristol, VA)|access-date=January 20, 2014|date=January 9, 2014}}</ref> Lauderdale appears on [[Laura Cantrell]]'s 2013 release ''No Way There From Here''.<ref name=BW-Cantrell-2014>{{cite web|title=Laura Cantrell to Release New Album No Way There From Here, 1/28; Plays Joe's Pub in NYC, 1/29|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Laura-Cantrell-to-Release-New-Album-NO-WAY-THERE-FROM-HERE-128-Plays-Joes-Pub-in-NYC-129-20140107|work=Broadway World|access-date=January 20, 2014|date=January 7, 2014}}</ref> 2014 saw the release of his album ''I'm A Song''.<ref name=MiamiNewTimes-2014>{{cite news|last=Zimmerman|first=Lee|title=Jim Lauderdale: \"Slugging Along and Slugging It Out\"|url=http://blogs.miaminewtimes.com/crossfade/2014/02/jim_lauderdale_interview_grassroots_festival_miami_2014.php|access-date=February 25, 2014|newspaper=[[Miami New Times]]|date=February 19, 2014}}</ref> Lauderdale will release his new album ''Time Flies'' on August 3, 2018, along with ''Jim Lauderdale and Roland White.''<ref name=RollingStone-2018>{{cite news|last=Gage|first=Jeff|title=Hear Americana King Jim Lauderdale's Rippling New Ballad 'Time Flies'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/hear-americana-king-jim-lauderdales-new-song-time-flies-w520371|access-date=May 23, 2018|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=May 16, 2018}}</ref>\n\n=== Collaborations ===\nIn 2007, he began a collaboration with [[Larry Campbell]], the band Olabelle, and others in the ''American Beauty Project,'' a loose collection of musicians dedicated to reimagining in performance the [[Grateful Dead]]'s two classic 1970 albums, ''[[Workingman's Dead]]'' and ''[[American Beauty (album)|American Beauty]]''.\n\nIn 2011, Lauderdale toured with [[Hot Tuna]], an ensemble act that included [[Jorma Kaukonen]], [[Jack Casady]], Barry Mitterhof, [[G.E. Smith]], and, for a time, [[Charlie Musselwhite]]. He has also toured with [[Elvis Costello]], [[Rhonda Vincent]], [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]], and others.\n\n==== Dr. Ralph Stanley ====\nLauderdale wrote and produced two bluegrass records with [[Ralph Stanley]]. Their first collaboration, ''I Feel Like Singing Today'', was nominated for a Grammy.\n\n==== Buddy Miller ====\n\nLauderdale released a record called ''Buddy and Jim'' with long-time friend and collaborator [[Buddy Miller]] in 2013.<ref name=NPR-Buddy&JimTDC>{{cite web|title=Buddy Miller & Jim Lauderdale: Tiny Desk Concert|url=https://www.npr.org/event/music/183595144/buddy-miller-jim-lauderdale-tiny-desk-concert|work=Tiny Desk Concert|publisher=[[National Public Radio]]|access-date=December 14, 2013|format=video performance and interview|date=May 13, 2013}}</ref> Lauderdale said they recorded it in three days in Miller's home studio. Miller did the mixing and producing.<ref name=MiamiNewTimes-2014 />\n\n==== Robert Hunter ====\nLauderdale has often collaborated with [[Grateful Dead]] lyricist [[Robert Hunter (lyricist)|Robert Hunter]].<ref name=MiamiNewTimes-2014 />\n\nLauderdale's first collaboration with Hunter was ''Headed for the Hills'' and the second was ''Patchwork River'' in May 2010. The June 2011 release ''Reason and Rhyme'' was their third collaboration. Additionally, they wrote songs for a [[North Mississippi Allstars]] record that was released in the fall of 2013.<ref name=TwangNation2013 />\n\nTwo 2013 releases, ''Black Roses'' and ''Blue Moon Junction,'' were co-written with Hunter. ''Black Roses'' features North Mississippi Allstars' Cody and [[Luther Dickinson]], whom Lauderdale met in Nashville at the Americana Music Festival,<ref name=CMTEdge-2014>{{cite web|last=Atkinson|first=Brian T.|title=Jim Lauderdale Teams Up for New Albums, Grammy Nod|url=http://www.cmtedge.com/2014/01/09/jim-lauderdale-teams-up-for-new-albums-grammy-nod/|work=CMT Edge|publisher=[[Viacom (2005\u2013present)|Viacom]] / [[Country Music Television|Country Music Television, Inc.]]|access-date=January 20, 2014|date=January 9, 2014}}</ref> as well as [[Muscle Shoals]] musicians [[Spooner Oldham]] and [[David Hood]]. The album was recorded at their father [[Jim Dickinson]]'s studio, Zebra Ranch in Mississippi.<ref name=CMTEdge-2014 />\n\n2013's ''Blue Moon Junction'' features Lauderdale's work as a singer and songwriter, some of them co-written with Hunter in a solo, acoustic format. Lauderdale produced the record.<ref name=CMTEdge-2014 /> Lauderdale says that they have more material that might make a good follow-up album, and hopes they will have time to collaborate again soon.<ref name=MiamiNewTimes-2014 />\n\n==== Nick Lowe ====\nLauderdale performed solo as the opening act for [[Nick Lowe]] on the latter's 1995 tour of the U.S. and Europe with the Impossible Birds. He later recorded with longtime members of Lowe's band and other British musicians at London's Goldtop Studio, sessions resulting in the 2017 album ''London Southern''.<ref name=MiamiNewTimes-2014 />\n\n==== Roland White ====\n\nOn August 3, 2018, Lauderdale released ''Jim Lauderdale and Roland White,'' a previously lost record made with mandolin master [[Roland White]]. The disc was recorded in Earl Scruggs' basement in 1979, and the songs were only found recently by White's wife.<ref name=RollingStone-2018/>\n\n=== The Jim Lauderdale Phenomenon ===\nThe term \"the Jim Lauderdale Phenomenon\", coined by singer-songwriter [[Kim Richey]] and cited in an April 2000 article in ''[[The Tennessean]]'' by writer Peter Cooper, is an ironic reference to the fact that Lauderdale was nominated for a [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] for his work with Stanley but was released from a record deal with [[RCA Records Nashville|RCA]] not long after. He was also released from contracts with Warner Bros., Columbia, and Atlantic Records.<ref name=Tennessean-RCA-drop>{{cite web|last=Cooper|first=Peter|title=Without 'star-level' clout, Lauderdale released from RCA|url=http://www.insurgentcountry.com/jim_lauderdale_dropped_from_rca.txt|work=[[The Tennessean]]|access-date=December 14, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010221172233/http://www.insurgentcountry.com/jim_lauderdale_dropped_from_rca.txt|archive-date=February 21, 2001}}</ref><ref name=CL-Whisper-review>{{cite web|last=Kelly|first=James|title=Music: Jim Lauderdale, Whisper|url=http://web.cln.com/archives/atlanta/newsstand/030798/v_rec7.htm|work=[[Creative Loafing]]|access-date=December 14, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010222041342/http://web.cln.com/archives/atlanta/newsstand/030798/v_rec7.htm|archive-date=February 22, 2001}}</ref> The article notes that many country artists that were signed to major labels in the 1990s failed to get radio airtime and had their contracts dropped after making one or two albums.<ref name=Tennessean-RCA-drop/> The problem became widespread in Nashville during this period, when a lot of good music was being created and recorded, but the megastars dominated the airwaves.<ref name=DO-PenPal-1998>{{cite news|last=Rowland|first=Hobart|title=Pen pal: Jim Lauderdale is the write man in the wrong place|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/1998-05-21/music/pen-pal/|access-date=December 14, 2013|newspaper=Dallas Observer|date=May 21, 1998}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\nLauderdale has had a long-time, successful<ref name=MusicMonitor-TurnLeft /> career on [[Music Row]] writing songs for many mainstream country music artists (and others); and has had four separate major-label record deals: with CBS, Warner/Reprise, Atlantic, and RCA/BMG.<ref name=DO-1999>{{cite news|last=Patterson|first=Rob|title=The grass is blue: Writing hits for the Dixie Chicks has given Jim Lauderdale his own wide open space|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/1999-11-25/music/the-grass-is-blue/|access-date=December 14, 2013|newspaper=Dallas Observer|date=November 25, 1999|archive-date=December 14, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214072710/http://www.dallasobserver.com/1999-11-25/music/the-grass-is-blue/|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=Discogs-writing>{{cite web|title=Jim Lauderdale \u2013 Credits \u2013 Writing & Arrangement|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/Jim+Lauderdale#t=Credits_Writing-Arrangement&q=&p=1|work=[[Discogs]]|access-date=December 14, 2013}}</ref>\n\n=== Songwriting ===\n* [[Gary Allan]]: \"Forever And A Day\", \"Wake Up Screaming\", \"What's On My Mind\", \"We Touched the Sun\"\n* [[Mark Chesnutt]]: \"Gonna Get a Life\" (co-written with Frank Dycus) \u2013 hit No. 1 in 1995<ref name=EncycCountryMusic />\n* [[Elvis Costello]]: \"I Lost You\", \"Poor Borrowed Dress\"\n* [[The Dixie Chicks]]: \"Hole in My Head\" (co-written with Buddy Miller)\n*[[Sara Douga]]: \"I'll Forgive You if You Don't\" from ''Joe & Gin'' (2020) (co-written with Sara Douga)\n* [[Dave Edmunds]]: \"[[Halfway Down]]\"\n* [[Vince Gill]]: \"Sparkle\"\n* [[Patty Loveless]]: \"Halfway Down\", \"To Feel That Way at All\", \"You Don't Seem To Miss Me\"\n* [[George Strait]]:\n** \"The King of Broken Hearts\", \"Where the Sidewalk Ends\" from [[Pure Country (soundtrack)|''Pure Country'' Soundtrack]] (1992)\n** \"I Wasn't Fooling Around\", \"Stay Out of My Arms\" from ''[[Easy Come, Easy Go (George Strait album)|Easy Come, Easy Go]]'' (1993)\n** \"Nobody Has to Get Hurt\", \"What Am I Waiting For\" from ''[[Lead On]]'' (1994)\n** \"Do the Right Thing\" from ''[[Blue Clear Sky]]'' (1996)\n** \"[[We Really Shouldn't Be Doing This]]\" the Same]]'' (1999)\n** \"Don't Make Me Come Over There (and Love You)\" from ''[[George Strait (album)|George Strait]]'' (2000)\n** \"Twang\", \"I Gotta Get to You\" from ''[[Twang (album)|Twang]]'' (2009)\n** \"Two More Wishes\" from ''[[Honky Tonk Time Machine]]'' (2019)\n* [[Lee Ann Womack]]: \"The King of Broken Hearts\"\n* [[Blake Shelton]]: \"What's On My Mind\"\n\n=== Albums ===\n{| On Me\"\n|\n|-\n|2019\n|\"The Secrets of the Pyramids\"\n|\n|}\n\n=== Contributions ===\n*''A Town South of Bakersfield Vol. II'' (1988) \u2013 \"What Am I Waiting For\"\n*''Happy Birthday, Buck! A Texas Salute to Buck Owens'' (2002) \u2013 \"Sweet Rosie Jones\"\n*''Touch My Heart: A Tribute to Johnny Paycheck'' (2005) \u2013 \"I Want You To Know\"\n*''[[Born to the Breed: A Tribute to Judy Collins]]'' (2008) \u2013 \"Easy Times\"\n\n== Other activities ==\nLauderdale has hosted the [[Americana Music Honors & Awards|Americana Music Awards]] since winning their first Artist of the Year and Song of the Year awards in 2002.<ref name=RollingStone-LeftofCenter-2014>{{cite news|last1=Durchholz|first1=Daniel|title=Jim Lauderdale Reflects on Legendary, 'Left of Center' Career|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/jim-lauderdale-interview-new-album-im-a-song-20140929|access-date=September 30, 2014|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=September 29, 2014}}</ref> He was a judge for the second,<ref name=IMAJudge-Past>[http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/pastjudges.asp Independent Music Awards \u2013 Past Judges] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713024722/http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima_new/pastjudges.asp |date=July 13, 2011 }}</ref> 10th and 11th<ref name=IMAJudge-11th>[http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima/judges/11th-annual-ima-judges/ \"11th Annual IMA Judges]. Independent Music Awards. Retrieved on September 4, 2013.</ref> annual Independent Music Awards to support independent artists' careers. He is Honorary Chairperson for the Chris Austin Songwriting Contest each April at MerleFest in Wilkesboro, NC.\n\nHe hosted \"The Jim Lauderdale Show\" on [[WSM Radio]]. He hosts, along with Buddy Miller, \"The Buddy & Jim Show\" on [[SiriusXM]] Outlaw Country. Lauderdale is also a frequent host and performer on \"Music City Roots\", a weekly Americana music show web-streamed live from The Factory at Franklin just outside Nashville.<ref name=TwangNation2013>{{cite web|last=Lane|first=Baron|title=A Song of Perseverance \u2013 An Interview With Jim Lauderdale|url=http://www.twangnation.com/2013/05/10/a-song-of-perseverance-an-interview-with-jim-lauderdale/|work=Twang Nation|access-date=December 14, 2013|date=May 10, 2013}}</ref>\n\n=== Jim Lauderdale: The King of Broken Hearts ===\nA documentary film called ''Jim Lauderdale: The King of Broken Hearts'', directed by Jeremy Dylan, was released in 2013. Using interviews with [[Elvis Costello]], [[Buddy Miller]], [[John Oates]], [[Gary Allan]], [[Tony Brown (record producer)|Tony Brown]], and [[Jerry Douglas]], the film describes Lauderdale's successes and failures as a recording artist.<ref name=Jim-doc-about>{{cite web|title=About the Film|url=http://jimlauderdalemovie.com/about|work=Jim Lauderdale: The King of Broken Hearts|access-date=December 14, 2013|archive-date=December 14, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214090137/http://jimlauderdalemovie.com/about|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n== References This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Uncle_Earl","to":"Uncle Earl"}],"pages":{"5271194":{"pageid":5271194,"ns":0,"title":"Uncle Earl","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American old-time music group}}\n{{about|the music group|\"Uncle Earl\" as a nickname|Earl Long}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Uncle Earl\n| image             = Earl-fls-1.jpg\n| caption        = Uncle Earl in 2007; from left to right: [[Rayna Gellert]], [[Abigail Washburn]], [[KC Groves]] and [[Kristin Andreassen]]\n| image_size        =\n| landscape       = Yes\n| background      = group_or_band\n| alias           = \n| origin          = [[United States]]\n| genre           = [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Old-time music]]\n| years_active    = 2000&ndash;present\n| label           = [[Rounder Records|Rounder]]\n| website             = [http://www.uncleearl.net/ uncleearl.net]\n| associated_acts = [[Sparrow Quartet]], [[Sometymes Why]], Footworks Percussive Dance Ensemble\n| current_members = [[KC Groves]], [[Kristin Andreassen]], Stephanie Coleman, Paula Bradley, Rachel Eddy\n| past_members    = Jo Serrapere,Tahmineh Gueramy, Amanda Kowalski, [[Sharon Gilchrist]], Casey Henry, Sally Truitt, [[Rayna Gellert]], [[Abigail Washburn]], Bryn Davies\n}}\n\n'''Uncle Earl''' is an American [[old-time music]] group, formed in 2000<ref name=\"faq\"/> by [[KC Groves]] and Jo Serrapere.<ref name=\"newsletter\"/> Currently the lineup consists of four women, all of whom share vocal duties: KC Groves, [[Kristin Andreassen]], [[Abigail Washburn]], and [[Rayna Gellert]]. They have released three albums and two EPs, and their fifth album ''Waterloo, Tennessee'' was produced by [[John Paul Jones (musician)|John Paul Jones]] of [[Led Zeppelin]].\n\n==History==\n\n===1999-2002: Founding===\nGroves and Serrapere, both American songwriters and multi-instrumentalists, started the band in 2000.<ref name=\"faq\"/> The Uncle Earl biography, however, states 1999 as founding year. According to the founders, they had no original interest in starting a band. Instead, they wanted to promote a CD with traditional material they had recorded, and put together a small temporary lineup to play a few shows. After the initial performances went well, the group decided to stay together.<ref name=\"biouncleearl\"/> Until the end of 2003 the line-up of the band had changed several times. Amongst the members in this period where Tahmineh Gueramy (fiddle, vocals), Amanda Kowalski (bass, vocals), Casey Henry (banjo, vocals) and Sally Truitt (bass, vocals).<ref name=\"webarchive\"/>\n\nGroves mentioned in an interview how the band got its name, \"We just thought it would be a funny name for an all-women's group,\" she says. \"But we are fans of [[Earl Scruggs]], [[Steve Earle]], and [[Uncle Tupelo]]. It did come up in our discussion that there's some important Earls in this business. And Uncles.\"<ref name=\"realcountry\"/> They refer to themselves as \"the g'Earls,\" while their fans have been nicknamed \"g'Earlfriends.\"<ref name=\"newsletter\"/>\n\n===2002-2010: Albums===\n{{ external media\n| float  =right \n| video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L6ed6p74dM4 Music Video for \"Streak o' Lean, Streak o' Fat\" by Uncle Earl] (Nov 20, 2009)\n| video2 = \n}}\nIn 2002 the band released their album ''She Went Upstairs''.\n\nFounding member Serrapere left in 2003, and as of 2008 played with the Willie Dunns.<ref name=\"Willie Dunns\"/> By the end of 2003 a long-lasting lineup was in place, with all the band members serving as co-vocalists.  The 2003 lineup consisted of KC Groves on [[mandolin]] and [[guitar]], [[Abigail Washburn]] on [[banjo]], [[Rayna Gellert]] on [[fiddle]] and [[Kristin Andreassen]], [[guitarist]], [[fiddler]], and [[clogging]].  There was no permanent [[bassist|bass player]].<ref name=\"blogsa\"/>\n\nIn 2004, the group released their first EP, titled ''Going to the Western Slope.'' Several months later, they released their sophomore EP ''Raise a Ruckus.'' In 2005 the band was signed to [[Rounder Records]], who released their first full-length album, ''She Waits for Night'', later that year. Their second full-length album, ''Waterloo, TN'', was released on Rounder Records in 2007.\n\nIn late 2009, the band failed to go on tour, quoting trouble coordinating band members' schedules.<ref name=\"blogsa\"/>\n\n===2010-present===\nIn 2010, the band announced that Gellert and Washburn had left on amicable terms, and were pursuing other musical projects.<ref name=\"blogsa\"/> The new Uncle Earl line up is Andreassen, Groves, Stephanie Coleman on [[fiddle]], Paula Bradley on [[banjo]], [[banjo ukulele]] and [[clogging]], and Rachel Eddy on [[banjo]], [[fiddle]], and [[Bass (guitar)|bass]].<ref name=\"Introductions and Updates\"/> The lineup toured in support of their previous album in 2010, and continue to periodically perform.\n\n==Members==\n\n===Current as of 2014===\n[[File:Uncle Earl 01.jpg|thumb|right|280px|European tour 2010 at ''Kult'', [[Niederstetten]]; from left to right: Rachel Eddy, [[KC Groves]], [[Kristin Andreassen]], Stephanie Coleman and Paula Bradley]]\n*[[KC Groves]] <small>(1999\u2013present)</small> - vocals, [[mandolin]] and [[guitar]]\n*[[Kristin Andreassen]] <small>(2003\u2013present)</small> - vocals, [[guitarist]], [[fiddler]], and [[clogging]]\n*Stephanie Coleman <small>(2010\u2013present)</small> - [[fiddle]]\n*Paula Bradley <small>(2010\u2013present)</small> - [[banjo]], [[banjo ukulele]] and [[clogging]]\n*Rachel Eddy <small>(2010\u2013present)</small> -  [[banjo]], [[fiddle]], and [[Bass (guitar)|bass]]\n\n===Past members===\n*Jo Serrapere <small>(1999-2003)</small> - vocals, etc.\n*Amanda Kowalski <small>(~2000-2003)</small> - bass, vocals\n*Casey Henry <small>(~2000-2003)</small> - banjo, vocals\n*Sally Truitt <small>(~2000-2003)</small> - bass, vocals\n*Tahmineh Gueramy <small>(~2000-2003)</small> - fiddle, vocals\n*[[Rayna Gellert]] <small>(2003-2010)</small> - vocals, fiddle\n*[[Abigail Washburn]] <small>(2003-2010)</small> - banjo, vocals\n*[[Sharon Gilchrist]] <small>(2004-2005, 2010)</small> - bass\n*[[Bryn Davies (musician)|Bryn Davies]] - bass\n\n===Bass players===\nThe band has had a mostly rotating line-up of bass players. For nearly four years Amanda Kowalski played [[Double bass|upright bass]] with Uncle Earl. [[Sharon Gilchrist]] joined the band in late 2004 and can be heard on the seven song [[Extended play|EP]] ''Raise a Ruckus''.<ref name=\"ruckus\">{{cite web | title=Raise a Ruckus Liner Notes | work=Uncle Earl | url=http://www.uncleearl.net/ruckus.htm | date=April 2005 | access-date=2007-06-14 | url-status=dead | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070704061747/http://uncleearl.net/ruckus.htm | archive-date=2007-07-04 }}</ref> There is a long list of other bassists with whom Uncle Earl have performed. On their website the band mentions Eric Thorin, Sally Truitt, Erin Coats Youngberg, Alana Rocklin, Mary Lucey, [[Bryn Davies (musician)|Bryn Davies]], [[Laura Cortese]], Kyle Kegerreis, [[Missy Raines]], and Dan Rose, with whom they recorded the album ''She Waits for Night''.<ref name=\"faq\"/><ref name=\"newsletter04\">{{cite web | title=Uncle Earl Newsletter Nov. 2004 | work=Uncle Earl | url=http://www.uncleearl.net/newsletterarchives/newsletternov04.htm | access-date=2007-06-12 | url-status=dead | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928013645/http://www.uncleearl.net/newsletterarchives/newsletternov04.htm | archive-date=2007-09-28 }}</ref> Youngberg and Thorin play bass on the album ''Waterloo, Tennessee''.\n\nBassist [[Sharon Gilchrist]] left the band in early 2005 to play [[mandolin]] in the [[Peter Rowan]] and [[Tony Rice]] Quartet. However Gilchrist played again at their 2010 Australian Tour. Rachel Eddy joined so [[KC Groves]] largely handles the bass.<ref name=\"Introductions and Updates\"/>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Uncle Earl discography}}\n\n;Studio albums\n*[[2002 in music|2002]]:
