|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nWilliams was inducted into the [[Austin City Limits]] Hall of Fame in October 2021. [[Jason Isbell]], who inducted Williams, credited her with creating a map for other singer-songwriters to follow; \"A lot of my songs wouldn't exist if I hadn't spent so much time trying to rip her off\", he stated in his speech. Isbell also performed Williams' \"I Envy the Wind\" from her 2002 album ''Essence''.<ref name=\"austinhallfame\">[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/lucinda-williams-margo-price-austin-city-limits-1280308/] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220106182506/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/lucinda-williams-margo-price-austin-city-limits-1280308/|date=January 6, 2022}}. ''[[Rolling Stone]]''. January 7, 2022.</ref> Williams also performed at the ceremony, she sang \"Crescent City\" with [[Rosanne Cash]] and \"Changed the Locks\" with [[Margo Price]].<ref name=austinhallfame/> Later that year, she appeared on the [[Robert Plant]] and [[Alison Krauss]] album ''[[Raise the Roof (album)|Raise the Roof]]'' as a backing vocalist.<ref name=\"AMcredits\">{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/raise-the-roof-mw0003575140/credits |title=Raise the Roof: Credits |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2021 |website=AllMusic |access-date=January 26, 2023}}</ref>\n\n===2022\u2013present: Honorary accolades and ''Stories from a Rock n Roll Heart''===\nOn November 17, 2021, it was announced that Williams would receive the Americana Music Association-UK International Lifetime Achievement Award in January 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Lucinda Williams To Receive AMA-UK International Lifetime Achievement Award |url=https://www.udiscovermusic.com/news/lucinda-williams-ama-uk-lifetime-achievement/ |access-date=August 17, 2022 |website=www.udiscovermusic.com |date=November 17, 2021 |archive-date=November 20, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211120195849/https://www.udiscovermusic.com/news/lucinda-williams-ama-uk-lifetime-achievement/ |url-status=live}}</ref> The ceremony was held on January 27, 2022.<ref name=uklifetime>{{Cite web |title=UK Americana Awards 2022 |url=https://theamauk.org/UK-Americana-Awards-2022 |access-date=August 17, 2022 |website=theamauk.org |archive-date=February 6, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220206152347/https://theamauk.org/UK-Americana-Awards-2022 |url-status=live}}</ref> On September 12, 2022, Williams was the recipient of the [[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI]] Troubadour Award.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Willman |first1=Chris |title=Lucinda Williams Feted at BMI Troubadour Award Dinner by Jason Isbell, Angel Olsen, More |url=https://variety.com/2022/music/news/lucinda-williams-bmi-troubadour-award-nashville-jason-isbell-angel-olsen-1235371587/ |access-date=March 29, 2023 |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=September 14, 2022}}</ref> The award celebrates songwriters who have made a lasting impact on their community and who \"craft for the sake of the song, setting the pace for generations of songwriters who will follow.\" Past recipients include [[John Hiatt]], [[John Prine]], and [[Robert Earl Keen]].<ref name=bmiaward>{{Cite web |title=Lucinda Williams To Be 2022 Recipient Of BMI Troubadour Award |url=https://www.udiscovermusic.com/news/lucinda-williams-bmi-troubadour-award-2022/ |access-date=August 17, 2022 |website=www.udiscovermusic.com |date=August 16, 2022 |archive-date=August 16, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220816194258/https://www.udiscovermusic.com/news/lucinda-williams-bmi-troubadour-award-2022/ |url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nOn February 4, 2023, Williams was honored with the AMERICANAFEST Pre-Grammy Salute to Lucinda Williams, which was held at the [[Troubadour (West Hollywood, California)|Troubadour]] and live-streamed on Mandolin.com.<ref name=AMERICANAFEST>{{Cite web |title=Lucinda Williams Gets Tribute Fit for an Americana Queen From Mumford & Sons, Dwight Yoakam, Allison Russell and a Cast of Roots Luminaries |url=https://variety.com/2023/music/news/lucinda-williams-tribute-americana-troubadour-salute-1235516384/ |access-date=February 12, 2023 |website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=February 7, 2023 |archive-date=February 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230212211204/https://variety.com/2023/music/news/lucinda-williams-tribute-americana-troubadour-salute-1235516384/ |url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nOn April 4, 2023, Williams announced that her 15th studio album, ''[[Stories from a Rock n Roll Heart]]'', would be released on June 30, 2023. The lead single \"New York Comeback\" was released simultaneously with the album announcement.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Rettig |first1=James |title=Lucinda Williams Announces New Album, Shares \"New York Comeback\" Feat. Bruce Springsteen & Patti Scialfa |url=https://www.stereogum.com/2219153/lucinda-williams-new-york-comeback-feat-bruce-springsteen-patti-scialfa/music/ |website=Stereogum |access-date=4 April 2023 |language=en |date=4 April 2023}}</ref>\n\n==Backing bands==\nFrom 1985 to 1996, Williams' band included guitarist [[Gurf Morlix]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=25 years later, Lucinda Williams and Gurf Morlix look back at breakthrough record |last=Blackstock |first=Peter |url=https://www.statesman.com/story/news/2014/01/13/25-years-later-lucinda-williams-and-gurf-morlix-look-back-at-breakthrough-record/10157234007/ |access-date=September 23, 2022 |website=Austin American-Statesman |date=January 12, 2014 |archive-date=September 23, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220923234940/https://www.statesman.com/story/news/2014/01/13/25-years-later-lucinda-williams-and-gurf-morlix-look-back-at-breakthrough-record/10157234007/ |url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nFrom before 2012 into 2022, Williams has called her backing band the Buick 6, whose name was inspired by [[Bob Dylan]]'s song \"[[From a Buick 6]]\". Since 2012, Buick 6 has been [[Jonathan Norton|Butch Norton]], drums, who joined Williams in 2007; [[Stuart Mathis]], guitar; and David Sutton, bass.<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |title=Lucinda Williams' Buick is in town, and it's hot |last=Dickinson |first=Chrissie |date=December 20, 2016 |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/music/ct-buick-6-ott-1223-20161219-story.html |access-date=2022-08-07}}</ref> Buick 6 has occasionally performed and recorded separately from Williams.<ref>{{cite web |website=butchdrums.com |publisher=Butch Norton |title=Butch Norton: Biography |date=2022 |url=http://butchdrums.com/biography/ |access-date=2022-08-07}}</ref> For Williams' 2022 tours, Jim Oblon joined on guitar and keyboards.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Lucinda Williams Announces Summer Tour Dates |url=https://jambandnews.net/2022/05/24/lucinda-williams-announce-summer-tour-dates/ |access-date=September 23, 2022 |website=www.jambandnews.com |date=May 24, 2022 |archive-date=September 23, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220923234324/https://jambandnews.net/2022/05/24/lucinda-williams-announce-summer-tour-dates/ |url-status=live}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nIn 1986, Williams married [[The Long Ryders|Long Ryders]] drummer [[Greg Sowders]], but the couple divorced within eighteen months.<ref name=nytimes/> In September 2009 she married Tom Overby, an executive from [[Best Buy]]'s music department, who is also her manager. The marriage ceremony was performed on stage at [[First Avenue (nightclub)|First Avenue]] by her father.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Lucinda Williams Bio |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/lucinda-williams/biography |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110920072223/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/lucinda-williams/biography |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 20, 2011 |access-date=April 8, 2018 |magazine=Rolling Stone}}</ref>\n\nOn November 17, 2020, Williams had a stroke in her home in Nashville.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Hudak |first=Joseph |date=May 3, 2021 |title=Lucinda Williams Had a Stroke Last Year. She's Ready to Sing Again |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/lucinda-williams-stroke-1164015/ |access-date=July 20, 2021 |magazine=Rolling Stone |archive-date=2021-07-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210720175858/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/lucinda-williams-stroke-1164015/ |url-status=live}}</ref> Doctors discovered a blood clot, and she was discharged five weeks later. Though at the time she needed to walk with a cane and still could not play guitar, she subsequently recovered in time for her summer 2021 tour with Jason Isbell.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tour |url=https://www.lucindawilliams.com/tour |access-date=July 20, 2021 |website=Lucinda Williams |archive-date=July 20, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210720175900/https://www.lucindawilliams.com/tour |url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nIn 2023, Williams released her autobiography titled ''Don't Tell Anyone the Secrets I Told You: A Memoir''. The book details her traumatic childhood, her relationships with her father and mother, and her struggle to forge a sustainable career in the music industry.<ref name=\"Betts\">{{cite magazine |last=Betts |first=Stephen L. |date=April 24, 2023 |title=Lucinda Williams Bit Ryan Adams and Other Big Reveals in Her New Memoir |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/lucinda-williams-book-dont-tell-anybody-the-secrets-i-told-you-review-1234722664/ |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=May 5, 2024}}</ref><ref name=\"secrets\">{{cite book |last=Williams |first=Lucinda |date=2023 |title=Don't Tell Anyone the Secrets I Told You: A Memoir |url= |location=New York |publisher=Crown |edition=1st |isbn=9780593136492 |oclc=1350093959}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Lucinda Williams discography}}\n{{div col}}\n* ''[[Ramblin' on My Mind (Lucinda Williams album)|Ramblin' on My Mind]]'' (1979)\n* ''[[Happy Woman Blues]]'' (1980)\n* ''[[Lucinda Williams (album)|Lucinda Williams]]'' (1988)\n* ''[[Sweet Old World]]'' (1992)\n* ''[[Car Wheels on a Gravel Road]]'' (1998)\n* ''[[Essence (Lucinda Williams album)|Essence]]'' (2001)\n* ''[[World Without Tears]]'' (2003)\n* ''[[West (Lucinda Williams album)|West]]'' (2007)\n* ''[[Little Honey]]'' (2008)\n* ''[[Blessed (Lucinda Williams album)|Blessed]]'' (2011)\n* ''[[Down Where the Spirit Meets the Bone]]'' (2014)\n* ''[[The Ghosts of Highway 20]]'' (2016)\n* ''[[This Sweet Old World]]'' (2017)\n* ''[[Vanished Gardens]]'' (with [[Charles Lloyd (jazz musician)|Charles Lloyd]] and the Marvels) (2018)\n* ''[[Good Souls Better Angels]]'' (2020)\n* ''[[Stories from a Rock n Roll Heart]]'' (2023)\n{{end div col}}\n\n==Awards and legacy==\n===Americana Music Honors and Awards===\nThe [[Americana Music Honors & Awards]] are presented annually by the [[Americana Music Association]] and celebrate outstanding achievement in [[Americana (music)|Americana]] music.<ref>[https://americanamusic.org/about About Us] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211019081758/https://americanamusic.org/about |date=October 19, 2021 }} americanamusic.org. Americana Music Association. Retrieved November 6, 2021.</ref> Established in 2002, Williams is one of the most nominated artists in the awards history, with eleven. She has received two awards (one competitive, one honorary).\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\n|-\n! colspan=\"5\" align=\"center\"| [[Americana Music Honors & Awards|Americana Awards]]\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:1em;\"| Year\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:20em;\"| Nominated work\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:20em;\"| Category\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:5em;\"| Result\n! scope=\"col\" style=\"width:1em;\"| Ref.\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\" align=\"center\"|2003\n| align=\"left\"| Herself\n| align=\"left\"| Artist of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n| rowspan=\"2\" align=\"center\"|<ref>[https://americanamusic.org/awards/2003 Americana Awards \u2013 2003] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211016174039/https://americanamusic.org/awards/2003 |date=October 16, 2021 }} americanamusic.org. Americana Music Association. Retrieved April 27, 2020.</ref>\n|-\n| align=\"left\"| Herself\n| align=\"left\"| Artist of the Year\n| {{nom}}\n|-\n|}\n\n===Grammy Awards===\nThe [[Grammy Award]]s are awarded annually by [[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences|The Recording Academy]] of the United States for outstanding achievements in the music industry. Often considered the highest music honour, the awards were established in 1958.<ref>{{cite book |last=O'Neill |first=Thomas |title=The Grammys: The Ultimate Unofficial Guide to Music's Highest Honor |publisher=Perigee Trade |year=1999}}</ref> Williams has received three awards in three separate categories ([[Country music|country]], [[Contemporary folk music|folk]] and rock), from 17 nominations that span five genres (country, folk, pop, rock, and [[Americana (music)|Americana]]).\n\n{| class=\"wikitable\n|-\n! colspan=\"5\" align=\"center\"| [[Grammy Awards]]\n|-\n! scope=\"col\" ===\n* 1999&nbsp;\u2013 Ranked No. 97 on [[VH1]]'s [[The Greatest (TV series)|100 Greatest Women in Rock & Roll]].<ref name=rockonthenet/>\n* 2002&nbsp;\u2013 Named \"America's best songwriter\" by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''.<ref name=time/>\n* 2002&nbsp;\u2013 Ranked No. 36 on [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]]'s 40 Greatest Women of Country Music.<ref name=cmt40/>\n* 2015&nbsp;\u2013 Ranked No. 79 on [[Rolling Stone's 100 Greatest Songwriters of All Time|''Rolling Stone's'' 100 Greatest Songwriters of All Time]].<ref name=rswriter/>\n* 2017&nbsp;\u2013 Received the [[Berklee College of Music]] Honorary Doctorate of Music Degree.<ref name=berklee/>\n* 2017&nbsp;\u2013 Ranked No. 91 on [[Rolling Stone|''Rolling Stone's'']] 100 Greatest Country Artists of All Time.<ref name=rscounty/>\n* 2020&nbsp;\u2013 ''Car Wheels on a Gravel Road'' ranked No. 97, and ''Lucinda Williams'' ranked No. 426, on [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Albums of All Time|''Rolling Stone's'' 500 Greatest Albums of All Time]].<ref name=rscar/><ref name=rslu/>\n* 2021&nbsp;\u2013 Inducted into the [[Austin City Limits]] Hall of Fame.<ref name=austinhallfame/>\n* 2021&nbsp;\u2013 \"Passionate Kisses\" ranked No. 437 on [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time|''Rolling Stone's'' 500 Greatest Songs of All Time]].<ref name=rspk/>\n* 2022&nbsp;\u2013 Received the Americana Music Association-UK International Lifetime Achievement Award.<ref name=uklifetime/>\n* 2022&nbsp;\u2013 Received the [[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI]] Troubadour Award.<ref name=bmiaward/>\n* 2023&nbsp;\u2013 Honored with the AMERICANAFEST Pre-Grammy Salute to Lucinda Williams.<ref name=AMERICANAFEST/>\n* 2023&nbsp;\u2013 Awarded Best Roots Rock / Americana Artist, and Best Roots Rock / Americana Album (for ''Stories from a Rock n Roll Heart'') in [[OffBeat (music magazine)|''OffBeat'']]'s Best of the Beat Awards.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2011-09-08 |title=Best of the Beat Award Winners: Complete List |url=https://www.offbeat.com/best-of-the-beat-award-winners-complete-list/,%20https://www.offbeat.com/best-of-the-beat-award-winners-complete-list/ |access-date=2024-02-29 |website=[[OffBeat (music magazine)|OffBeat Magazine]] |language=en-US}}</ref>\n*2024&nbsp;\u2013 Ranked No. 8 on ''[[American Songwriter]]'s'' list of the 10 Greatest Female Songwriters of All Time.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://americansongwriter.com/the-10-greatest-female-songwriters-of-all-time-period/ |title=The 10 Greatest Female Songwriters of All Time, Period |magazine=[[American Songwriter]] |access-date=2024-04-16}}</ref>\n*2024&nbsp;\u2013 Elected as a member of the [[Texas Institute of Letters]].<ref name=TIL>{{cite news|url=https://texasinstituteofletters.org/twelve-new-members-elected-to-til/|date=March 3, 2024|title=Twelve New Members Elected to TIL|work=Texas Institute of Letters}}</ref>\n\n===In popular culture===\n* 1991&nbsp;\u2013 \"Lucinda Williams\" is the title of a song on the [[Vic Chesnutt]] album ''West of Rome''.<ref name=vicwest/>\n* 2008&nbsp;\u2013 The American folk/rock band [[Augustana (band)|Augustana]] references the musician in the song \"Meet You There\", on their album ''[[Can't Love, Can't Hurt]]''. The lyrics state \"Just put on Lucinda, Baby, and dance with me.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metrolyrics.com/meet-you-there-lyrics-augustana.html |last1=Layus |first1=Dan |last2=Flynn This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Shelly_Fairchild","to":"Shelly Fairchild"}],"pages":{"1881198":{"pageid":1881198,"ns":0,"title":"Shelly Fairchild","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American musician (born 1977)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->\n| name         = Shelly Fairchild\n| image        = Shelly Fairchild Wikipedia 2020.jpg\n| caption      = \n| image_size   = \n| background   = solo_singer\n| birth_name   = \n| birth_place  = \n| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|1977|08|23}}\n| origin       = [[Clinton, Mississippi]], U.S.\n| instrument   = Vocals\n| genre        = [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[alternative country]], [[alternative Rock]], pop, rock, [[folk rock]], [[country music|country]],\n| occupation   = [[Singer-Songwriter]]\n| years_active = 2004\u2013present\n| label        = [[Columbia Records|Columbia Nashville]]\n| website      = [https://shellyfairchild.com/ www.shellyfairchild.com]\n}}\n'''Shelly Fairchild''' (born August 23, 1977) is an American music recording artist. Signed to [[Columbia Records]] in 2004, she released her first album, ''[[Ride (Shelly Fairchild album)|Ride]]'', in early 2005. It included the single \"You Don't Lie Here Anymore\", a No.&nbsp;35 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts.\n\n==Biography==\nFairchild was born in [[Clinton, Mississippi]], to a musical family.<ref name=\"allmusic\">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p682231|pure_url=yes}} |title=Shelly Fairchild biography |accessdate=June 11, 2008 |last=Leggett |first=Steve |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> She began performing at an early age in church and later in her high school's show choir. Fairchild studied communications, theater and music at [[Mississippi College]] and subsequently starred in local stage shows including ''[[Grease (musical)|Grease]]'' and ''Always Patsy Cline''. She also traveled with the national touring company for ''Beehive: The 60's Musical''.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>\n\n==Personal life==\nOn July 29, 2017, Fairchild married the music executive Deborah DeLoach<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.vevasound.com |title=VEVA Sound |accessdate= January 19, 2017}}</ref> in [[Vail, Colorado]]. Their elopement was covered in ''[[Brides (magazine)|Brides]]'' which included venue and catering by Collective Vail, Fairchild's dress by [[Free People]], DeLoach's dress by Thread & Needle, from BHLDN, officiant Susie Kincade and photography by Mackenzie Neville.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.brides.com/story/country-musician-boho-elopement-in-colorado|title=A Country Musician's Boho Elopement in Colorado |author=Jaimie Mackey |work=Brides |accessdate=November 6, 2017}}</ref> Their wedding was voted by ''Brides'' as the Top 50 Favorite Real Wedding Photos of 2017.{{citation needed|date=May 2023}} The couple resides in Nashville, Tennessee.{{citation needed|date=May 2023}}\n\n==Career==\nIn 2004, Fairchild signed to [[Columbia Records]].<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Her first album, ''[[Ride (Shelly Fairchild album)|Ride]]'', was issued in early 2005. Its lead-off single, \"You Don't Lie Here Anymore\", co-written with Clay Mills, peaked at No.&nbsp;35 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, although subsequent singles failed to chart. She toured in support of the album including an opening spot on [[Rascal Flatts]]' sold-out ''Here's to You'' tour which also featured [[Blake Shelton]], but was dropped from Columbia by the end of the year.\n\nIn 2008, Fairchild signed a record deal with [[Stroudavarious Records]] which was founded by producer [[James Stroud]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roughstock.com/audio/shelly-fairchild-its-all-gonna-work-out|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106212430/http://www.roughstock.com/audio/shelly-fairchild-its-all-gonna-work-out|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 6, 2009|title=Shelly Fairchild \u2014 \"It's All Gonna Work Out\"|work=Roughstock|accessdate=January 5, 2009}}</ref> Her first release was the song \"It's All Gonna Work Out\", which she released for a charity album called ''We Are Enterprise''.\n\nOn April 11, 2011, Fairchild's second album,, ''Ruby's Money'', was released. Free from the confines of a major label, she set out to take control of her music and released \"Ruby\u2019s Money\" on her own label, Revelation Nation Records. She took her unstoppable voice to another level, creating an album that reflected a \"Memphis kind of feel\" with horns. She co-wrote a song called \"Love Everybody\", which was an anchor for this record.<ref name=\"Shelly Fairchild \u2014 Sip Magazine\">{{cite web|url=https://thesipmag.com/shelly-fairchild/|title=Shelly Fairchild |author=Lauchlin Fields |date=November 2, 2015|work=The 'Sip |accessdate=October 5, 2015}}</ref>\n\nIn 2014, Fairchild was one of three background singers for [[Martina McBride]]'s \"Everlasting Tour\". Touring with McBride, Fairchild explained, was a huge highlight of her career. \"If someone thinks I\u2019m good enough to come and sing backgrounds for them, I\u2019m like, \u2018Yeah\u2019 \u2014 especially if it's music I love. Martina is somebody I\u2019ve looked up to as a singer my whole life.\"<ref name=\"Shelly Fairchild \u2014 Sip Magazine\"/>\n\nIn 2016, Fairchild did a [[PledgeMusic]] campaign and surpassed her goal by 41% in just two days to record her latest album Buffalo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pledgemusic.com/projects/shellyfairchild|title=Shelly Fairchild PledgeMusic|work=PledgeMusic|accessdate=May 15, 2016}}</ref> \nHer third studio album, ''Buffalo'', was released December 2016. This record entered the Top 100 Country albums on [[iTunes]] in the first week.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/shellyfairchild/photos/buffalo-broke-through-top-100-on-the-top-country-albums-chart-on-itunes-i-cant-b/10154624416711147/ |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/facebook/32934371146/10154624416711147 |archive-date=2022-02-26 |url-access=limited|title=Shelly Fairchild|work=iTunes Chart|accessdate=December 2, 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref> Fairchild went on to release her first single, \"Mississippi Turnpike\" which she debuted in her first music video in ten years. It premiered exclusively on Taste Of Country<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/shelly-fairchild-mississippi-turnpike-video/|title=Shelly Fairchild|work=Taste of Country|accessdate=June 17, 2017}}</ref> and went on to play repeatedly on [[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT]] making this her first independent play on the major network since her first album ''Ride''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BVkVTjllI9f/|title=Shelly Fairchild|work=Instragram|accessdate=June 20, 2017}}</ref>\n\nIn July 2017, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine listed Shelly has the Top 10 New Country Artists You Need To Know.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country-lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-july-2017-201932/shelly-fairchild-205203/|title=Shelly Fairchild|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=July 11, 2017|accessdate=July 11, 2017}}</ref> Shelly is asked to sing regularly on the ''[[Grand Ole Opry]]'' and has her own designated artist page on the ''Opry'' website.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.opry.com/artist/shelly-fairchild/shelly-fairchild-205203/|title=Shelly Fairchild |work=Grand Ole Opry|accessdate=January 11, 2017}}{{dead link|date=May 2023}}</ref>\n\nShelly is also an active writer and artist for TV and Film. In January 2017 Shelly signed with Nashville-based Licensing Firm Resin8. Working with various songwriters and producers \u2013 Shelly is consistently writing and recording for new film and TV opportunities.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://resin8music.com/artists/|title=Shelly Fairchild Resin8|work=Resin8|accessdate=January 31, 2017}}</ref>\n\nIn July 2020, Fairchild was awarded the LGBTQ Rising Star Award at [[Ty Herndon]] \"Love and Acceptance\" show streamed on [[Country Music Television]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/life/entertainment/a33001049/how-to-watch-stream-concert-for-love-and-acceptance-cmt/ |title=How to Watch and Stream the CMT Benefit 'Concert for Love and Acceptance' |author=Selena Barrientos |date=June 30, 2020 |work=Good Housekeeping |accessdate=June 30, 2020}}</ref>\n\nIn August 2020, Fairchild was featured in Brandon Stansell's documentary ''Three Chords and A Lie'' which dos not sugarcoat the truth about coming out in many parts of America \u2500 depicting some truly heart-wrenching moments in his story. It streams on [[OutTV (Canadian TV channel)]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/news/brandon-stansell-talks-emotional-documentary-three-chords-and-lie/ |title=Brandon Stansell Talks Emotional Documentary, 'Three Chords And A Lie'|author=Jason Scott |publisher=GRAMMYs |date=August 26, 2020|accessdate=May 24, 2023}}</ref>\n\nIn June 2021, Fairchild sang at the [[Ryman Auditorium]] participating as a featured artist in the Nashville and Austin LGBT Chamber of Commerce Pride Event. Streaming on all of its social channels, Tina Cannon, executive director of Austin LGBT Chamber of Commerce, said in a statement, \"Working together with Nashville, we are combining the talent of two of the greatest musical communities in the world to produce an amazing live show that directly supports LGBTQ+ artists.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.austin360.com/story/entertainment/music/2021/06/01/lgbtq-pride-month-austin-nashville-livestream-pinkstar-patrice-pike-pleasure-venom-alanna-royale/5290914001/ |title=Austin and Nashville artists team up for Pride livestream featuring Patrice Pike, p1nkstar |author=Deborah Sengupta Stith |website=Austin 360 |date=June 1, 2021 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20210622082107/https://www.austin360.com/story/entertainment/music/2021/06/01/lgbtq-pride-month-austin-nashville-livestream-pinkstar-patrice-pike-pleasure-venom-alanna-royale/5290914001/ |archivedate=June 22, 2021 |accessdate=May 24, 2023 }}</ref>\n\nIn July 2021, Fairchild began touring with [[Lennon Stella]] as one of her background singers for her festival dates including Wonderstruck, Bonnaroo, Roots N Blues and Moon Crush.<ref>{{cite Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Patty_Griffin","to":"Patty Griffin"}],"pages":{"803317":{"pageid":803317,"ns":0,"title":"Patty Griffin","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter and musician|bot=PearBOT 5}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2014}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n|name          = Patty Griffin\n|image         = Central_Park_Sound_Stage.jpg\n|caption       = Griffin performing at Sound Stage in [[Central Park]], New York, September 17, 2008\n|background    = solo_singer\n|birth_name    = Patricia Jean Griffin\n|birth_date    = {{birth date and age|1964|03|16|df=yes}} \n|origin        = [[Old Town, Maine]], U.S.\n|instrument    = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar|piano}}\n|genre         = {{hlist|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]|[[folk music|folk]]|[[folk rock]]|[[country folk]]|[[Gospel music|gospel]]|[[alternative country|alt-country]]}}\n|occupation    = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|musician}}\n|years_active  = 1992\u2013present\n|label         = {{hlist|[[A&M Records|A&M]]|[[ATO Records|ATO]]|[[Credential Recordings|Credential]]|[[New West Records|New West]]}}\n|associated_acts= {{hlist|[[The Chicks]]|[[Emmylou Harris]]|[[Sweet Harmony Traveling Revue]]|[[Buddy Miller]]|[[Robert Plant]]|[[Joshua Radin]]|[[Band of Joy]]}}\n|website       = {{URL|http://pattygriffin.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Patricia Jean Griffin''' (born March 16, 1964) is an American singer, songwriter, and musician.<ref name=\"Griffin\">Griffin, Patricia [http://www.pattygriffin.net/PattyBio.html Fan website biography] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180728051703/http://www.pattygriffin.net/PattyBio.html |date=July 28, 2018 }}</ref> She is a vocalist and plays guitar and piano. She is known for her stripped-down songwriting style in the [[folk music]] genre. Her songs have been covered by numerous musicians, including [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Ellis Paul]], [[Kelly Clarkson]], [[Rory Block]], [[Dave Hause]], [[Sugarland]], [[Bette Midler]] and [[The Chicks]].\n\nIn 2007, Griffin received the Artist of the Year award from the [[Americana Music Association]], and her album ''[[Children Running Through]]'' won the award for Best Album. She received the Lifetime Achievement Award for Songwriting at the [[2023 Americana Music Honors & Awards]]. In 2011, Griffin's album ''[[Downtown Church]]'' won the [[Grammy Award for Best Traditional Gospel Album]] and her 2019 [[Patty Griffin (album)|self-titled album]] won the [[Grammy Award for Best Folk Album]].\n\n==Biography==\nGriffin is from [[Old Town, Maine]], United States, next to the [[Penobscot people|Penobscot]] [[Native American reservation]]. The youngest child in her family, with six older siblings, she bought a guitar for $50 at age 16. She sang and played but had no inclination to become a professional musician. After a 6-year marriage, which ended in 1994, Griffin began playing in Boston coffee houses and was \"scouted\" by [[A&M Records]], which signed her on the strength of her demo tape. When the finished studio recordings were submitted to A&M, the company executives thought it was overproduced, so producer [[Nile Rodgers]] and A&M instead released a stripped-down reworking of her demo tape as the album ''[[Living with Ghosts]].''<ref name=\"Harris\">Harris, Craig (accessed March 17, 2008) [{{BillboardURLbyName|artist=patty griffin|bio=true}} Billboard com]</ref>\n\nGriffin's second album, ''[[Flaming Red]]'', released in 1998, was a departure from the [[acoustic music|acoustic]] sound of ''Living with Ghosts'', with a mix of mellow songs and high-tempo [[rock and roll]] songs. The title track, \"Flaming Red\", is an example of the latter, beginning with an even beat until it increases to a fevered pitch of emotion. Another song from the album, \"Tony\", is also featured on the charity benefit album ''[[Live in the X Lounge]]''.\n\nHer third album, ''[[Silver Bell (album)|Silver Bell]]'', has a sound similar to its predecessor. It was released by A&M in 2013, 13 years after it was recorded (and well after bootlegged copies had been circulated). A&M dropped Griffin's contract after ''Silver Bell'' was recorded, and she was then signed by [[Dave Matthews]]' [[ATO Records]]. Griffin re-recorded songs from that album for later releases, such as \"Making Pies\", \"Mother of God\", \"Standing\", and \"[[Top of the World (Dixie Chicks song)|Top of the World]]\". Copies of the unreleased ''Silver Bell'' were leaked and bootlegged and can be easily acquired by the B&P ([[blanks and postage]]) method on [[message boards]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pattynet.net/forum/|title=PattyNet \u2022 Index page|website=Pattynet.net|access-date=March 9, 2019|archive-date=January 5, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180105172653/http://pattynet.net/forum/|url-status=dead}}</ref> In August 2013, it was announced that [[Universal Music Enterprises|UM<sup>e</sup>]] planned to release ''Silver Bell'', mixed by producer [[Glyn Johns]], in October 2013.<ref name=\"Billboard 20130731\">{{cite magazine|last=Votaw|first=Emily|title=Patty Griffin's Lost 'Silver Bell' Album to Be Released in October|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=July 31, 2013|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/5327862/patty-griffins-lost-silver-bell-album-to-be-released-in-october|access-date=August 4, 2013}}</ref>\n\nFour albums followed on ATO: ''[[1000 Kisses (album)|1000 Kisses]]'' (2002), ''[[A Kiss in Time]]'' (2003), ''[[Impossible Dream (Patty Griffin album)|Impossible Dream]]'' (2004), and ''[[Children Running Through]]'' (2007).\n\nIn 2004, Griffin toured with Emmylou Harris, [[Buddy Miller]], [[Gillian Welch]] and [[David Rawlings]] as the [[Sweet Harmony Traveling Revue]]. On February 6, 2007, she released ''[[Children Running Through]]''. The album debuted at number 34 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], with 27,000 copies sold.<ref name=\"Zuel\">{{Cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1054981/fall-out-boy-hits-high-note-with-no-1-debut |title=Fall Out Boy Hits 'High' Note with No. 1 Debut &#124; Billboard |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=March 24, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130305115440/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1054981/fall-out-boy-hits-high-note-with-no-1-debut |archive-date=March 5, 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Of the album, Griffin told ''Gibson Lifestyle'', \"I just kind of felt like singing what I wanted to sing, and playing how I wanted to play. It's not all dark and tragic. It's a different way for me to look at things. Getting old\u2014older, I should say, I'm not so serious all the time.\"<ref name=\"Mallernee\">Ellen Mallernee, Ellen [http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/Features/PattyGriffin/ Gibson Lifestyle article] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520040118/http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/Features/PattyGriffin/ |date=May 20, 2011 }}</ref> It was also said that the album was inspired by her childhood.<ref>{{cite news | first=Katherine | last=Cole | title=Childhood Reflections Inspire Patty Griffin on Latest CD | date=February 20, 2007 | publisher=Voice of America | url=http://www.voanews.com/english/archive/2007-02/2007-02-20-voa71.cfm | work=VOA News | access-date=January 1, 2009 | url-status=dead | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116120609/http://www.voanews.com/english/archive/2007-02/2007-02-20-voa71.cfm | archive-date=January 16, 2009 | df=mdy-all }}</ref>\n\nGriffin's songs have been recorded by numerous artists, including the Irish-born singer [[Maura O'Connell]] (\"Long Ride Home\"), [[Linda Ronstadt]] (\"Falling Down\"), [[The Chicks]] (\"Truth No. 2\", \"Top of the World\", \"Let Him Fly\", \"Mary\"), [[Bette Midler]], [[Melissa Ferrick]] and [[Missy Higgins]] (\"Moses\"), [[Beth Nielsen Chapman]], [[Christine Collister]], and [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]] (\"Dear Old Friend\"), [[Jessica Simpson]] (\"Let Him Fly\"), [[Martina McBride]] (\"Goodbye\"), Emmylou Harris (\"One Big Love\", \"Moon Song\"), [[Bethany Joy Galeotti]] (\"Blue Sky\"), [[the Wreckers]] (\"One More Girl\"), [[Keri Noble]] and [[Ruthie Foster]] (\"When It Don't Come Easy\"), [[Joan Osborne]] (\"What You Are\"), [[Solomon Burke]] (\"[[Up to the Mountain (MLK Song)|Up to the Mountain]]\"), [[Miranda Lambert]] (\"Getting Ready\"), and [[Drew Holcomb & The Neighbors]] (\"Long Ride Home\"). [[Kelly Clarkson]] performed \"[[Up to the Mountain (MLK Song)|Up to the Mountain]]\" with [[Jeff Beck]] on guitar, accompanied by some orchestration on the \"[[Idol Gives Back]]\" episode of ''[[American Idol]]'', and the live recording was released as a single immediately afterwards, reaching number 56 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] in its first week and giving Griffin her highest-charting position as a songwriter. (The audience gave Clarkson a [[standing ovation]] following her performance.) Griffin's version of the song was featured in episode 11 of the fourth season of the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] television show ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]''.\n\n==Instruments, effects, and sound==\n* 1965 Gibson J-50 Guitar\n* 1993 Gibson J-200 Junior Guitar<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fretbase.com/blog/2008/06/play-guitar-l-1/|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120905131400/http://www.fretbase.com/blog/2008/06/play-guitar-l-1/|url-status=dead|title=Play Guitar Like Patty Griffin - Fretbase|date=September 5, 2012|archive-date=September 5, 2012|website=Archive.is|access-date=March 9, 2019}}</ref>\n*Charles Fox Guitar<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://music.blog.austin360.com/2018/04/10/weekend-music-picks-jack-ingram-patty-griffin-and-more-swap-songs-at-acl-live/|title=Weekend music picks: Jack Ingram, Patty Griffin and more swap songs at ACL Live \u2013 Austin Music Source|language=en|access-date=2019-11-03}}</ref>\n\n==Recent work==\n[[File:PattyGriffin2006.jpg|thumb|230px|left|Griffin performing at the North Carolina Museum of Art in 2006]]\nIn September 2008, Griffin sang \"You Got Growing Up to Do\" in a duet with indie artist [[Joshua Radin]] on his album ''Simple Times''. In October 2008, she sang background vocals on [[Todd Snider]]'s cover of John Fogerty's \"[[Fortunate Son]]\" for Snider's ''Peace Queer'' album. In February 2009, she was featured on the album ''Feel That Fire'', by [[Dierks Bentley]], in a duet on the song \"Beautiful World\". In 2009, Griffin, along with [[Mavis Staples]] and the Tri-City Singers released a version of the song \"Waiting for My Child to Come Home\" on the compilation album ''[[Oh Happy Day: An All-Star Music Celebration]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/musicNews/idUSTRE52Q6WQ20090327|title=Jon Bon Jovi, Queen Latifah go gospel for \"Day\"|date=March 27, 2009|publisher=Reuters}}</ref>\n\n[[File:DIG13607-147.jpg|thumb|210px|right|Griffin performing \"Up To the Mountain\" at the Carter Reception Dinner during the Civil Rights Summit at the [[LBJ Presidential Library]] in 2014]]\nThe collaboration with Staples led [[EMI]]'s Peter York to suggest Griffin make an album of [[gospel music|gospel]] songs. Griffin agreed on the condition that friend and bandmate [[Buddy Miller]] produced the record.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bighassle.com/publicity/a_patty_griffin.html|title=Downtown Church Press Release|date=December 7, 2009|publisher=Big Hassle|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091220084848/http://bighassle.com/publicity/a_patty_griffin.html|archive-date=December 20, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The album, ''[[Downtown Church]]'' (her sixth studio album), recorded at the Downtown Presbyterian Church in Nashville, was released on January 26, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Downtown-Church-Patty-Griffin/dp/B0029F2G7E/|title=Patty Griffin \u2013 Downtown Church|date=December 7, 2009|publisher=Amazon}}</ref> The album, featuring [[Shawn Colvin]], [[Emmylou Harris]], and Griffin's long-time friends Buddy and [[Julie Miller]], contains songs by [[Hank Williams]], [[Big Mama Thornton|Willie Mae \"Big Mama\" Thornton]], and \"All Creatures of Our God and King\" (credited to [[St. Francis of Assisi]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pattycentral.com/2009/07/01/downtown-church|title=Patty's Next Album: Downtown Church|date=December 7, 2009|publisher=Patty Central|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091103183124/http://pattycentral.com/2009/07/01/downtown-church/|archive-date=November 3, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref>\n\nIn July 2010, [[Robert Plant]] toured the United States with [[Band of Joy]] (reprising the name of his band in the 1960s), with Griffin as a backing vocalist and singer-guitarist [[Buddy Miller]], multi-instrumentalist and vocalist [[Darrell Scott]], bassist-vocalist Byron House, and drummer-percussionist-vocalist [[Marco Giovino]]. She is also featured on Plant's solo album ''[[Band of Joy (album)|Band of Joy]]'', released in September 2010 by Rounder Records.<ref name=\"rs_bandofjoy\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2010/03/26/robert-plants-new-band-of-joy-plot-lp-summer-tour/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100329010511/http://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2010/03/26/robert-plants-new-band-of-joy-plot-lp-summer-tour/|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 29, 2010|title=Robert Plant's New Band of Joy Plot Album, Summer Tour|last=Kreps|first=Daniel|date=March 26, 2010|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=April 10, 2010}}</ref>\n\nIn 2014 Griffin parted with Plant after a long relationship; they had lived together and divided their time between Austin, Texas, and England.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2014/09/01/343144827/first-listen-robert-plant-lullaby-and-the-ceaseless-roar?autoplay=true&eml=2014September2%2F1789121%2F6286235 |title=First Listen: Robert Plant, \"Lullaby and... the Ceaseless Roar\" |publisher=NPR |date=September 11, 2014}}</ref> In 2019, Griffin released \"River\", a track from her upcoming self-titled album and her first new music since battling breast cancer. ''Patty Griffin'' was released on March 8, 2019.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://people.com/music/patty-griffin-breast-cancer-new-album-tour-river/|title=Patty Griffin Debuts New Single 'River' from Latest Album \u2014 Her First Since Battling Breast Cancer|website=People|access-date=March 9, 2019}}</ref>\n\nOn January 11, 2019, along with an official announcement of her new album release ''[[Patty Griffin (album)|Patty Griffin]]'' (on her PGM Recordings label via Thirty Tigers), a new song, \"River\", she announced a 2019 concert tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.musicnewsnet.com/2019/01/music-news-grammy-award-winner-patty-griffin-has-announced-the-release-of-her-long-awaited-new-album-the-acclaimed-singer-s.html|title=PATTY GRIFFIN ANNOUNCES 3/8 RELEASING ALBUM, \"PATTY GRIFFIN\" via Thirty Tigers|website=Musicnewsnet.com|access-date=March 9, 2019}}</ref> She followed this with [[Tape (album)|''Tape'']] in 2022.\n\n==Film, television, and theater==\nIn 1997, Griffin's song \"Not Alone\", from the album ''[[Living with Ghosts]]'', was used in the final scene and ending credits for the 1997 film ''[[Niagara, Niagara]]''. It was also used at the end of episode 6 (\"Believers\") of season 1 of the television series ''[[Crossing Jordan]]'', broadcast on October 29, 2001; on the 2009 release of the soundtrack from the television series ''[[Without a Trace]]''; and at the end of episode 12 of season 10 of the television series ''[[NCIS (TV series)|NCIS]]'', which aired on January 15, 2013.\n\nGriffin has appeared in several movies, including ''[[Cremaster 2]]'' and [[Cameron Crowe]]'s ''[[Elizabethtown (film)|Elizabethtown]]'', the soundtrack of which includes her song \"Long Ride Home\" and a cover of \"[[Moon River]]\", by [[Johnny Mercer]] and [[Henry Mancini]].\n\nIn 1997 her song \"One Big Love\", from the album ''[[Flaming Red]]'', was used in the final scenes and credits of the film ''[[Digging to China]]''.\n\nIn 2004, her song \"Rowing Song\" was used in episode 9 (\"The Trick Is to Keep Breathing\") of season 2 of the television series ''[[One Tree Hill (TV series)|One Tree Hill]]''.\n\nIn 2005, her songs \"Cold As It Gets\", \"Rowing Song\" and \"Forgiveness\" were featured in [[Tim Kirkman]]'s film [[Loggerheads (2005 film)|''Loggerheads'']] starring [[Bonnie Hunt]], [[Tess Harper]], [[Chris Sarandon]], [[Michael Learned]], [[Kip Pardue]], and [[Michael Kelly (actor)|Michael Kelly]].  Only \"Cold As It Gets\" and \"Forgiveness\" appear on its soundtrack.\n\nThe 2006 film ''Griffin and Phoenix included \"Nobody's Crying\" and \"Rain.\"''\n\nIn 2006, her song \"Rain\" was used in episode 17 (\"The Skull in the Desert\") of season 1 of the television series ''[[Bones (TV series)|Bones]]''.\n[[File:Lincoln Center Out of Doors - Yola, Patty Griffin (48511447886).jpg|alt=Griffin playing an acoustic guitar and singing|thumb|Griffin in 2019]]\n\nIn 2007, her song \u201cHeavenly Day\u201d was featured prominently at the end of episode 16 (\u201cPromise\u201d) of season 6 of the television series \u201c[[Smallville]]\u201d.\n\nIn 2007, the Atlantic Theater Company produced ''10 Million Miles'', an [[Off Broadway|off-Broadway]] musical, directed by Michael Mayer, with music and lyrics by Griffin.\n\nIn 2009, her song \"Mary\" was used in episode 10 of season 2 of ''Sons of Anarchy'', and \"When It Don't Come Easy\" closed out season 2, episode 8 of ''In Plain Sight''.\n\nGriffin's first DVD, ''Patty Griffin: Live From the Artists Den'', was filmed on February 6, 2007, at the [[Angel Orensanz Center|Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts]] on New York's [[Lower East Side]] and released later that year. Selections from the DVD were featured on the program ''[[The Artists Den|Live from the Artists Den]]'' on [[Ovation (U.S. TV channel)|Ovation TV]], beginning January 24, 2008.\n\nIn 2007, Griffin was named Artist of the Year by the [[Americana Music Association]], the top honor bestowed by the association, and her album ''Children Running Through'' was selected as Best Album. At the awards ceremony she performed \"Trapeze\" with [[Emmylou Harris]] harmonizing.<ref name=\"Shelburne\">Shelburne, Craig (accessed March 14, 2008) [https://web.archive.org/web/20071104045452/http://www.cmt.com/news/articles/1573373/20071102/patty_griffin.jhtml CMT:  Patty Griffin Wins Americanas Highest Honor]</ref>\n\nOn June 13, 2008, Griffin performed an acoustic-in-the-round set in Nashville with [[Kris Kristofferson]] and [[Randy Owen]] ([[Alabama (American band)|Alabama]]), for a taping of a [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] songwriters series aired in December 2008. Each of them played five songs; Griffin performed \"Top of the World,\" \"Making Pies,\" \"No Bad News,\" \"Up to the Mountain,\" and \"Mary.\"\n\nIn Jan 2013, the song \"You Are Not Alone\" was featured in episode 12 of season 10 of ''[[NCIS (TV series)|NCIS]]''.\n\nIn May 2013, her song \"Heavenly Day\" was used in a commercial for [[Chevy]]'s new [[Chevy Volt|Volt]] line of automobile, entitled \"[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C9c38boYVfY Volt: Silent Statement]\".\n\nIn May 2015, her song \"Go Wherever You Wanna Go\" was used in episode 22 of season 10 of the television series ''[[Supernatural (U.S. TV series)|Supernatural]]''.\n\nIn 2015, the song \"Let him fly\" was a turning point for Nick Yarris in the documentary \"The Fear of Thirteen\".\n\nIn 2018, the song \"Heavenly Day\" was featured in episode 5 of season one in the [[Netflix]] series ''[[The Haunting of Hill House (TV series)|Haunting of Hill House]]''.\n\nIn 2023, Patty's 2013 performance of her song \"I'm Gonna Miss You When You're Gone\" in the Bing Lounge at 101.9 KINK.FM.<ref>{{Citation |title=Patty Griffin - I'm Gonna Miss You When You're Gone (Bing Lounge) | date=April 15, 2013 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jqih9M-Xj08 |access-date=2023-11-13 |language=en}}</ref> was included in [[Nick Cassavetes]]'s action-thriller film [[God Is a Bullet (film)|God is a Bullet]].\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Rita_Hosking","to":"Rita Hosking"}],"pages":{"19046864":{"pageid":19046864,"ns":0,"title":"Rita Hosking","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Rita Hosking\n| image           =\n| caption         = Rita Hosking\n| background      = solo_singer\n| birth_name      = Rita Corinne Hosking<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/898455948 |title=A BETTER DAY |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=March 13, 2023}}</ref>\n| birth_place     = [[Davis, California]]\n| origin          = \n| genre           = [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Country music|country]], [[Folk music|folk]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]\n| associated_acts = \n| occupation      = Singer, songwriter, guitarist\n| years_active    = 2003\u2013present\n| label           = [[Independent record label|independent]]\n| website         = {{URL|http://www.ritahosking.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Rita Corinne Hosking''' is an American composer and musician based in [[Davis, California]].  She plays [[Americana (music)|Americana]] and [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] styles of music with both standards and original songs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/rita_hosking_and_cousin_jack/local/Band?oid=288062 |title=Rita Hosking and Cousin Jack |publisher=Newsreview.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>  Since the release of ''Are You Ready?'', she has been performing around the country at concerts, festivals, and other venues.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ritahosking.com/schedule.php |title=Rita Hosking homepage |publisher=Ritahosking.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304104821/http://www.ritahosking.com/schedule.php |archive-date=2012-03-04 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.napavalleyregister.com/articles/2008/05/28/arts/doc483ccce3003cb396119897.txt |title=Article about benefit performance in Napa by Rita Hosking & Cousin Jack |publisher=Napavalleyregister.com |date=2008-05-28 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>\n\n\"Hosking's music isn't like the polished, over-produced music found in pop culture. Hers is a minimalist sound that reflects a simpler time and place: a little country town, rather than a big city.\"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:DVEB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=1106562C5F3184F8&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0FCEDEB95BD4D563 |title=Channeling simpler times - Folksinger records her own life and upbringing in old-style ballads by Landon Christensen |publisher=Docs.newsbank.com |date=2006-03-14 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>\n\nLeading up to her 2010 performance tour of Great Britain, she received increasing attention on the \"East Side\" of the pond.   Reviewer Paul Kerr of Americana-UK remarked that she is \". . . a very talented artist with the ability to step up to that pantheon of great female country folk singers and writers.\"  <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.americana-uk.com/auk/modules.php?op=modload&name=Reviews&file=index&req=showcontent&id=5177 |title=Review by Paul Kerr in Americana-UK, ''Superb country folk from a brilliant singer/songwriter'' 2010 |publisher=Americana-uk.com |date=2010-01-11 |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929220958/http://www.americana-uk.com/auk/modules.php?op=modload&name=Reviews&file=index&req=showcontent&id=5177 |archive-date=2011-09-29 |url-status=dead }}</ref>  In the summer of 2010, Hosking played to packed venues in England, Wales, and Cornwall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mythankyoupage.com/2010/07/28/rita-hosking-at-no8-cafe-in-launceston/ |title=Review of Hosking and Feder's performance on July 22, 2010, at No8 Cafe in Launceston, Cornwall |publisher=Mythankyoupage.com |date= 28 July 2010|accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>\n\n==Influences and inspirations==\nHosking grew up in a rural area in [[Shasta County, California]].  Her father worked the night shift at a sawmill as part of the area's logging industry. Her great-grandfather, from [[Cornwall]], southwest of England, was an underground coal miner in the region. Her grandmother's family had headed there in a covered wagon on the Oregon Trail, from Virginia.\n\nHosking says old-time music was strong in her mountain area, as well as country. She grew up hearing neighbors play their simple instruments by ear, as a group called the Mountaineers. And the school cook took several girls from the school, taught them songs and they performed as the Farmerettes; with the Farmerettes, Hosking played washboard and sang her first solo.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.californiachronicle.com/articles/yb/146046838 |title=Article by Patrick S. Pemberton, The Tribune, San Luis Obispo, California. Friday, June 18, 2010. |publisher=Californiachronicle.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312055628/http://www.californiachronicle.com/articles/yb/146046838 |archive-date=March 12, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n''\"I'm no expert on the Appalachians at all, but I figure there are similarities -- the economy and some traditions, logging and mining. So, as a songwriter, you focus on that. You take the human struggle to survive, particularly in a beautiful place they love, and you've pinned down a lot of artistic inspiration.\"''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/saginawnews/index.ssf?/base/entertainment-1/1217654410164730.xml&coll=9 |title=California singer understands folk roots |publisher=Mlive.com |date=2008-08-02 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>\n\n==Performances==\n\nBy invitation, she has appeared at the White Crow Conservatory of Music in Saginaw, Michigan,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/saginaw/index.ssf/2008/08/on_stage_rita_hosking_white.html |title=Rita Hosking brings mountain music, California style, to Saginaw's White Crow by Janet I. Martineau, The Saginaw News |publisher=Mlive.com |date=2008-08-01 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref> the 17th Annual [https://archive.today/20110715002124/http://www.onemorebluegrassshow.com/Home_Page.html/ \u201cMidsummer in the Northwoods\u201d Bluegrass Festival] in Wisconsin, high in the Colorado Rockies at the [https://web.archive.org/web/20090531084110/http://www.bluegrass.com/telluride/index.html Telluride Bluegrass Festival], and many other locations.\n\nOn July 16, 2010, she performed at the [[Larmer Tree Festival]] in England, at the famed Victorian pleasure garden on the Wiltshire/Dorset border.  On July 22, she was the featured guest on the BBC radio show ''Bob Harris Country''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b00t38hp/Bob_Harris_Country_Rita_Hosking_in_session/ |title=Bob Harris Country on BBC Radio |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2010-07-22 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref> On November 3, 2010, she performed at [[The Freight and Salvage]] Coffeehouse in Berkeley, California.<ref>{{cite web|date=|title=Announcement of Freight & Salvage performance of November 3, 2010|url=http://www.thefreight.org/rita-hosking-cousin-jack-anderson-family-bluegrass|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928054652/http://www.thefreight.org/rita-hosking-cousin-jack-anderson-family-bluegrass|archive-date=September 28, 2011|accessdate=2011-11-04|publisher=Thefreight.org}}</ref>\n\nHosking has also performed at many popular festivals including the Strawberry Music Festival, Live Oak Music Festival, Kate Wolf Music Festival and [[Sisters Folk Festival]].\n\n==Recognition and awards==\nRita was the ''2007 Emerging Artist Winner'' at the Bluegrassin' In The Foothills festival in [[Plymouth, California]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.landspromotions.com/plymouthhome.htm |title=Homepage of the annual music festival in Plymouth, California ''Bluegrassin' in the Foothills'' |publisher=Landspromotions.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>\n\nOn September 6, 2008, Rita was selected the winner of the nationally respected ''Dave Carter Memorial Songwriting Contest'' at the [[Sisters Folk Festival]] in [[Sisters, Oregon]].<ref>[http://www.sistersfolkfestival.org Sisters Folk Festival homepage]</ref>\n\nOn June 18, 2009, Rita performed as a finalist at the acclaimed Telluride Troubadour Competition, held in conjunction with the [[Telluride Bluegrass Festival]].  The Competition judges songs based on composition, vocal delivery, and overall performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bluegrass.com/telluride/contests.html |title=Telluride Bluegrass competitions |publisher=Bluegrass.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>\n\n\"Come Sunrise\" was nominated in November 2009 as one of the five finalists for Album of the Year in the category of \"country music\" by the 9th annual Independent Music Awards.<ref>[http://www.independentmusicawards.com/ima/rita-hosking-9th-ima-country-album-nominee/ Artist Spotlight, nominee for Country Music ''album of the year'', 9th Annual Independent Music Awards.]{{dead link|date=November 2011}}</ref>  Hosking won the 9th annual Independent Music Awards Vox Pop / Peoples Choice / Best Country Album award for \"Come Sunrise\".\n\n==Soloist and with groups==\nRita is versatile, performing either as a soloist, or in duos, trios or quartets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ritahosking.com/about.html |title=Overview of Rita Hosking and her music on the Rita Hosking Homepage |publisher=Ritahosking.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>\n\nRita is sometimes supported by a back-up group named Cousin Jack<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/rita_hosking_and_cousin_jack/local/Band?oid=288062 |title=Article about Rita Hosking and Cousin Jack in ''Sacramento News & Review'' |publisher=Newsreview.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7oQAuE8BHG8  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/7oQAuE8BHG8 |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=video of Rita Hosking and Cousin Jack performing in Berkeley, California |publisher=Youtube.com |date=2009-08-10 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}{{cbignore}}</ref> that includes:\n* Sean Feder - banjo, [[dobro]], bass, percussion, vocals\n* Bill Dakin - bass, guitar, vocals\n* Andy Lentz - fiddle\n* Kora Feder - mandolin, banjo, guitar, vocals\n\n==Songs written by Rita Hosking==\n\nThe following singles were written by Rita Hosking and performed by others:\n\n*Kati Penn \u2013 \"I'm Going Home\" on the album \"My Turn to Cry\" produced by [[Rob Ickes]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/katipenn2 |title=Page showing Kati Penn's album \"My Turn to Cry\" |publisher=Cdbaby.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>\n\n==Come Sunrise==\nDuring the spring of 2008 at the [https://web.archive.org/web/20090428021851/http://www.strawberrymusic.com/home.asp Strawberry Music Festival] Rita heard a performance of Mississippi native [[Caroline Herring]].  Hosking bought Herring's album and discovered that [http://www.richbrotherton.com/ Rich Brotherton], longtime mandolin and guitar player in [[Robert Earl Keen]]'s band, had produced it.  \"I loved it,\" says Hosking, \"so I 'My Spaced' him and said, 'Hi, my name is Rita. Would you be interested in producing my next album?' He wrote right back and said, 'Sure.'\"   In addition to Brotherton, she was backed by such musicians as [[Lloyd Maines]] (father of [[Dixie Chicks]] lead singer Natalie Maines and a well-known musician and record producer), Warren Hood of the Waybacks,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.waybacks.com/ |title=Homepage of the Waybacks |publisher=Waybacks.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref> and Tom Van Schaik and Marty Muse from Keen's band.<ref>[https://archive.today/20130815204617/http://www.sacbee.com/music/story/1509681.html Pop Music: Rita Hosking: Down from the mountains, Davis singer-songwriter's sound mines a rich, generations-old vein, By Dixie Reid, Published: Friday, Jan. 02, 2009]</ref>\n\nThis collaboration evolved into \"Come Sunrise\", which was released in June 2009 and is available through CD Baby, Digstation, and iTunes.   It was recorded and produced at Ace Recording <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acerecording.net/ |title=Ace Recording homepage |publisher=Acerecording.net |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref> in Austin, Texas.\n\nAs described by Stuart Mason:    \"''On her new release Come Sunrise, singer-songwriter Rita Hosking reflects her upbringing in rural Shasta County. Her breed of Nor Cal country folk ain\u2019t quite old-timey, and it ain\u2019t quite bluegrass, but damn it\u2019s sweet. For fans of Emmylou and Gillian, this one\u2019s a safe bet. The songs of Rita Hoskings are as fragile as a newborn baby, and defiant as a West Virginia coal miner''.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fiddlefreak.com/2009/10/21/rita-hosking/ |title=Review of ''Come Sunrise'' on the Fiddlefreak Folk Music Blog, October 21, 2009 |publisher=Fiddlefreak.com |date=2009-10-26 |accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref>\n\nAs described by Neil Spencer of the Guardian (UK):   \"''Hosking . . . hits impressive form on this album.  Her songs are compassionate tales about ordinary folk from her north Californian background \u2013 loggers, miners, the mothers of lost sons \u2013 but there is anger as well as warmth in her voice. \"Montgomery Creek Blues\" and \"Promise Land\" in particular meld the personal and political to become state-of-the-nation songs''.\"<ref>{{cite news|author=Neil Spencer |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/jan/03/rita-hosking-come-sunrise-review/ |title=Review of ''Come Sunrise'' in the Music Section of the Guardian (UK), January 3, 2010 |publisher=Guardian |date= 2010-01-03|accessdate=2011-11-04 |location=London}}</ref>\n\nIn July 2009 \"Come Sunrise\" placed Number 12 on the national Freeform American Roots Chart.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tcmnradio.com/far/far120.htm |title=Freeform American Roots Chart of July 2009 |publisher=Tcmnradio.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131126065540/http://www.tcmnradio.com/far/far120.htm |archive-date=2013-11-26 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n\"Come Sunrise\" was selected as one of five contenders for the country music \"album of the year\" of the 9th annual Independent Music Awards, announced in November 2009 (see description under ''Recognition and Awards'').\n\n==Discography==\n*''For Real'' (2018)\n*''Frankie and the No-Go Road'' (2015)\n*''Little Boat'' (2013)\n*''Burn'' (2011) self released.<ref>{{cite California, is on scorching form in her new CD Burn\" |accessdate=2011-10-31 | location=London }}{{dead link|date=July 2021|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>\n*''Come Sunrise'' (2009) self (2005) self released.<ref>{{cite web |author=Johnny J. Arguelles |url=http://www.cbaontheweb.org/reviews_read2.asp?messageID=601&curPage=1&search |title=Are You Ready?
