This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Charley_Crockett","to":"Charley Crockett"}],"pages":{"59960023":{"pageid":59960023,"ns":0,"title":"Charley Crockett","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musician (born 1984)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Charley Crockett\n| image             = CharleyCrockettCropped.jpg\n| caption           = Crockett in 2020\n| image_size        = \n| birth_name        = \n| alias             = \n| birth_date        = {{Birth date and age|1984|03|24}}\n| birth_place       = [[San Benito, Texas]], United States\n| instrument        = {{flatlist|\n* Vocals\n* guitar\n}}\n| genre             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Americana music|Americana]]\n* [[Country music|country]]\n* [[blues]]\n* [[Southern soul]]\n* [[Tejano music|Tex-Mex]]\n}}\n| occupation        = Musician\n| years_active      = 2005\u2013present\n| label             = {{flatlist|\n* Son of Davy\n* [[Thirty Tigers]]\n}}\n| website           = {{URL|charleycrockett.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Matthew Charles Crockett''' (born March 24, 1984)<ref>{{Cite web |title=Matthew Charles Crockett - Texas, U.S., Birth Index, 1903-1997 |url=https://www.ancestry.com/discoveryui-content/view/14356442:8781 |access-date= |website=Ancestry.com}}</ref> is an American [[blues]], [[Country music|country]], and [[Americana music|Americana]] singer, guitarist, and songwriter. He has released twelve studio albums since 2015, with ''Lil G.L.'s Blue Bonanza'' peaking at number 11 on the US ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard charts|Blues Albums]] chart<ref name=\"Chart\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/blues-albums|title=Blues Music: Top Blues Albums Chart|magazine=Billboard|access-date=February 14, 2019}}</ref> and ''The Man from Waco'' breaking into the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200.]]<ref>{{Cite web |last=Cox |first=Brady |date=2022-09-20 |title=Charley Crockett Has Best Sales Week To Date With Latest Album 'The Man From Waco' |url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2022/09/20/charley-crockett-has-best-sales-week-to-date-with-latest-album-the-man-from-waco/ |access-date=2023-11-01 |website=Whiskey Riff |language=en-US}}</ref> \n\nIn September 2023, Crockett was nominated for Artist of the Year, Album of the Year, and Song of the Year at the [[2023 Americana Music Honors & Awards]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Hudak |first=Joseph |date=2023-05-09 |title=Margo Price, Charley Crockett Lead 2023 Americana Awards Nominations |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/2023-americana-awards-nominees-margo-price-charley-crockett-1234732016/ |access-date=2023-11-01 |magazine=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Early life==\nCharley was born in [[San Benito, Texas]] to Branton Eddens Crockett and Jan Onda Applehans.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Matthew Charles Crockett - Texas, U.S., Birth Index, 1903-1997 |url=https://www.ancestry.com/discoveryui-content/view/14356442:8781 |access-date= |website=Ancestry.com}}</ref> Crockett's paternal grandfather is [[chemical engineer]] and [[Ranch|rancher]], Charles Hayes \"Charlie\" Crockett Sr.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Parker |first=Bryan C. |date=2022-09-28 |title=Rising Country Star Charley Crockett is a Legend in the Making |url=https://www.austinmonthly.com/rising-country-star-charley-crockett-is-a-legend-in-the-making/ |access-date=2024-07-25 |website=Austin Monthly Magazine |language=en-US}}</ref> and his paternal grandmother is the daughter of Texas senator George Clark Purl Sr. and Patricia May Purl.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Raggio |first=Eva |title=Charley Crockett Tapped the Soul of Dallas Blues By Traveling the Country |url=https://www.dallasobserver.com/music/charley-crockett-tapped-the-soul-of-dallas-blues-by-traveling-the-country-7400786 |access-date=2024-07-25 |website=Dallas Observer |language=en}}</ref> His mother is of [[Volga Germans|Volga German]] descent.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Appelhans |url=https://www.volgagermans.org/who-are-volga-germans/origins/surnames/appelhans-appelhanz |access-date=2024-07-25 |website=Welcome to the Volga German Website |language=en}}</ref> His third great grandfather was Jacob Goodwin Crockett of [[New Hampshire]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Doctors of Sebastian Co Ar |url=https://www.argenweb.net/sebastian/Doctors/MoultonHerbert.html |access-date=2024-07-25 |website=argenweb.net}}</ref>\n\nRaised by a single mother<ref name=\"Austin\" /> with an older brother and sister, Crockett grew up in a trailer park in [[Los Fresnos, Texas]].<ref name=\"AMG\" /><ref name=\"Rolling\" /> He has claimed to be a descendant of [[Davy Crockett]], mixed-race, and Jewish.<ref>{{Cite web |last=clairewilson |date=2021-07-30 |title=Charley Crockett's Valley |url=https://txliving.com/charley-crocketts-valley/ |access-date=2023-12-06 |website=Texasliving |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Parker |first=Bryan C. |date=2022-09-28 |title=Rising Country Star Charley Crockett is a Legend in the Making |url=https://www.austinmonthly.com/rising-country-star-charley-crockett-is-a-legend-in-the-making/ |access-date=2023-12-06 |website=Austin Monthly Magazine |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Zuel |first=Bernard |date=2023-02-28 |title=NO TICKET REQUIRED - CHARLEY CROCKETT RIDING MYTHS, RACE, TRAINS AND THE TRUTH |url=https://www.bernardzuel.net/post/no-ticket-required-charley-crockett-riding-myths-race-trains-and-the-truth |access-date=2024-06-09 |website=bernardzuel |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Cooper |first=Leonie |date=2020-07-10 |title=Charley Crockett: \u2018I don\u2019t look like what a country audience expects\u2019 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2020/jul/10/charley-crockett-i-dont-look-like-what-a-country-audience-expects |access-date=2024-06-09 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Darling |first=By Cary |title=Talking music, race and Texas with Charley Crockett |url=https://www.chron.com/entertainment/music/article/Talking-music-race-and-Texas-with-Charley-12898104.php |access-date=2024-06-09 |work=Chron |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Raggio |first=Eva |title=Charley Crockett Tapped the Soul of Dallas Blues By Traveling the Country |url=https://www.dallasobserver.com/music/charley-crockett-tapped-the-soul-of-dallas-blues-by-traveling-the-country-7400786 |access-date=2024-06-09 |website=Dallas Observer |language=en}}</ref> His mother relocated the family to [[Dallas]],<ref name=\"Rolling\" /> and Crockett spent the summer months with his uncle, who lived in the [[French Quarter]] of [[New Orleans]].<ref name=\"Dmag\" /> Upon leaving high school at the age of 17, Crockett decided to travel with his guitar acquired by his mother from a pawn shop.  Crockett noted \"I taught myself how to play and started to write songs immediately, without any chord knowledge or anything. I didn't know what key I was in for 12 years, but my ear was really good, and I could play in any key and any chord. I just didn't know what it was.\"<ref name=\"Austin\" /> His early musical influences came from hearing [[Hip hop music|hip hop]], and he became fascinated with the [[sampling (music)|samples]] used.  Crockett said, \"I got into [[Curtis Mayfield]] through samples of his songs by other artists, and [[Nina Simone]] was through a sample. Even [[J. Cole]], I was listening to a song of his (\"Kenny Lofton\"), and it was based on the sample from [[the Manhattans]] version of '[[Hurt (Roy Hamilton song)|Hurt]]{{'\"}}.<ref name=\"Chron\" />\n\nCrockett played music on the streets in the French Quarter of New Orleans and in [[Deep Ellum, Dallas]] as a teenager. Later he traveled further afield by hitchhiking and riding freight, and by 2009 he was busking in New York City.<ref name=\"Dmag\"/><ref name=\"AMG\"/> As he improved his performance skills, Crockett organized a street band called the Trainrobbers, which caught the attention of a Manhattan-based representative for [[Sony Music]].  She signed the 26-year-old Crockett to a two-year management contract, although he rejected a publishing deal.<ref name=\"Austin\"/><ref name=\"Dmag\"/> Eventually tired of life on the streets and the pending expiration of the contract, Crockett relocated to [[Northern California]], where he combined working on farms and communes with performing for three more years.<ref name=\"Austin\"/><ref name=\"AMG\"/><ref name=\"Chron\"/> Crockett then existed on the streets in Paris, France, for a year, and briefly lived in Spain and Morocco.<ref name=\"Mystic\"/>\n\n== Career ==\nIn 2015, Crockett returned to Texas and after settling in Dallas, self-released his debut album, ''A Stolen Jewel'', in May.<ref name=\"AMG\" /> It landed him the ''[[Dallas Observer]]'' Music Award for Best Blues Act.<ref name=\"Dmag\">{{cite web|url=https://www.dmagazine.com/publications/d-magazine/2016/march/how-dallas-dresses-charley-crockett/|title=How Dallas Dresses: Charley Crockett|website=Dmagazine.com|date=February 29, 2016 |access-date=February 14, 2019}}</ref> The [[Lo-fi music|lo-fi]] collection contained a [[cover version|cover]] of [[the Flying Burrito Brothers]]' \"[[The Gilded Palace of Sin|Juanita]].\"<ref name=\"Austin\" /> Crockett also befriended [[Leon Bridges]] at this time,<ref name=\"Chron\" /> before Crockett released a blues-dominated album, ''In The Night'', in 2016.<ref name=\"Stone\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country-lists/10-new-country-artists-you-need-to-know-october-2017-199758/|title=10 New Country Artists You Need to Know: October 2017|author1=David Menconi|author2=Marissa R. Moss|author3=Robert Crawford|author4=Brittney McKenna|author5=Jeff Gage|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=October 11, 2017|access-date=February 14, 2019}}</ref> ''In The Night'' contained a selection of Crockett-penned numbers, along with a cover of his hometown hero [[Freddy Fender]]'s \"[[Wasted Days and Wasted Nights]]\".<ref name=\"Austin\" /> ''[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]'' called ''In The Night'' \"an impressive calling card, full of Crockett's plaintive soulfulness and swinging tempos\".<ref name=\"Mystic\">{{cite web|url=http://mystictheatre.tunestub.com/event.cfm?id=280095&cart|title=Charley Crockett with The Highway Poets|website=Mystictheatre.tunestub.com|access-date=February 14, 2019|archive-date=February 15, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190215063846/http://mystictheatre.tunestub.com/event.cfm?id=280095&cart|url-status=dead}}</ref> Crockett spent the next year touring to promote his work, playing over 125 shows in total.<ref name=\"AMG\" /><ref name=\"Mystic\" /> He toured with the [[Turnpike Troubadours]], [[Lucero (band)|Lucero]], [[Shinyribs]], [[Samantha Fish]], and [[Old 97's]], among others.<ref name=\"Pick\">{{cite web|url=https://pickathon.com/artist/charley-crockett/|title=Charley Crockett|website=Pickathon.com|access-date=February 14, 2019|archive-date=February 15, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190215102749/https://pickathon.com/artist/charley-crockett/|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nAfter relocating to [[Austin, Texas]],<ref name=\"Chron\"/> Crockett's next release was a collection of covers of country songs, ''Lil G.L.'s Honky Tonk Jubilee'' (2017), which was issued on [[Thirty Tigers]].<ref name=\"AMG\"/> Tracks included the [[Roy Acuff]]-penned \"Night Train to Memphis\",<ref name=\"Austin\"/> [[Tanya Tucker]]\u2019s \"The Jamestown Ferry\" and [[Hank Williams]]' \"[[Honky Tonkin']]\", all incorporating Crockett's clipped, hiccuped Texan drawl.<ref name=\"Austin\"/> Other tracks on the album were originally recorded by [[Ernest Tubb]], [[Loretta Lynn]], and [[Webb Pierce]] (\"[[I Ain't Never]]\").<ref name=\"Pick\"/>\n\nIn 2018, he released ''Lonesome as a Shadow'', a collection of purely original songs.  It was recorded at [[Phillips Recording|Sam C. Phillips Recording Studio]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee]],<ref name=\"AMG\"/> and produced by [[Matt Ross-Spang]].<ref name=\"Rolling\"/> The opening track, \"I Wanna Cry\", was written for his sister who had died from a [[methamphetamine]] overdose.<ref name=\"Rolling\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/how-charley-crocketts-hard-living-shaped-new-album-lonesome-as-a-shadow-630324/|title=How Charley Crockett's Hard Living Shaped New Album 'Lonesome As a Shadow'|author=Jeff Gage|date=April 26, 2018|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=February 14, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/lonesome-as-a-shadow-mw0003153477|title=Lonesome as a Shadow \u2013 Charley Crockett \u2013 Songs, Reviews, Credits|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 14, 2019}}</ref> The album was dedicated to [[Henry Thomas (blues musician)|Henry \"Ragtime Texas\" Thomas]].<ref name=\"Chron\"/> Following its April release date, Crockett toured again backed by his band the Blue Drifters.<ref name=\"AMG\">{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/charley-crockett-mn0003718968/biography|title=Charley Crockett \u2013 Biography & History|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 14, 2019}}</ref> His dates included venues such as the [[House of Blues]] in [[Houston]], Washington, D.C.'s [[9:30 Club]], The Mint in Los Angeles and [[The Fillmore]] in San Francisco.<ref name=\"Chron\">{{cite news|url=https://www.chron.com/entertainment/music/article/Talking-music-race-and-Texas-with-Charley-12898104.php|title=Talking music, race and Texas with Charley Crockett|first=Cary|last=Darling|date=May 8, 2018|newspaper=[[Houston Chronicle]]|access-date=February 14, 2019}}</ref> In addition, he performed at festivals such as the [[Wheatland Music Festival]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wheatlandmusic.org/2018-festival-schedule/|title=2018 Festival Schedule|website=Wheatlandmusic.org|access-date=February 14, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190215102733/https://www.wheatlandmusic.org/2018-festival-schedule/|archive-date=February 15, 2019|url-status=dead}}</ref> [[Portland, Oregon]]'s [[Pickathon]] and [[Austin City Limits Music Festival]].<ref name=\"Austin\"/>\n\nIn late 2018, Crockett issued ''Lil G.L.'s Blue Bonanza''. Crockett noted that \"Lil G.L. is my side name, like Hank [Williams] had Luke the Drifter. I use it for all my side projects and cover projects.\" He explained the moniker was given to him by a local blues drummer, Jay Moeller, in reference to the obscure R&B singer [[G. L. Crockett]].<ref name=\"Austin\"/> [[AllMusic]] stated \"''Lil G.L.'s Blue Bonanza'' is a companion of sorts to Charley Crockett's 2017 ''Lil G.L.'s Honky Tonk Jubilee''\".<ref name=\"AMG\"/> The album was primarily another compilation of cover versions, although Crockett's definition of the blues encompasses tracks including [[Jimmy Reed]]'s \"[[Bright Lights, Big City (song)|Bright Lights, Big City]]\", [[Tom T. Hall]]'s \"[[How I Got to Memphis|That's How I Got to Memphis]]\" and [[Danny O'Keefe]]'s \"[[Good Time Charlie's Got the Blues]]\".<ref name=\"Austin\">{{cite news|url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2018-12-14/honky-tonk-soul-man-charley-crockett-makes-his-move/|title=Honky-Tonk Soul Man Charley Crockett Makes His Move|author=Doug Freeman|newspaper=[[The Austin Chronicle]]|access-date=February 14, 2019}}</ref> In addition, Crockett covered work by [[Ernest Tubb]], [[George Jones]], and [[T-Bone Walker]].<ref name=\"AMG2\">{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/lil-gls-blue-bonanza-mw0003220790|title=Lil G.L.'s Blue Bonanza \u2013 Charley Crockett \u2013 Songs, Reviews, Credits|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=February 14, 2019}}</ref> ''Lil G.L.'s Blue Bonanza'' peaked at number 10 in the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Blues Albums chart.<ref name=\"Chart\"/>\n\nIn early January 2019, Crockett underwent open-heart surgery. Pre-assessments for the surgery exposed that Crockett had a congenital heart condition where his heart had two out of three aortic valve flaps fused together, leading to [[Wolff\u2013Parkinson\u2013White syndrome]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.heart.org/en/news/2019/02/21/up-and-coming-texas-singer-lucky-to-be-alive-and-still-singing-the-blues|title=Up-and-coming Texas singer lucky to be alive and still singing the blues|website=Heart.org|access-date=June 24, 2019}}</ref>\n\nCrockett released ''The Valley'' on September 20, 2019. The album features the single \"Borrowed Time\", which was co-written with Evan Felker of Turnpike Troubadours.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/charley-crockett-the-valley-new-album-borrowed-time-863544/ |title=Charley Crockett Previews New Album 'The Valley' With Contemplative 'Borrowed Time'|website=Rollingstone.com|date=July 25, 2019|access-date=July 25, 2019}}</ref>\n\n''Field Recordings, Vol. 1'' was released on April 3, 2020, and is a mixtape of 30 low-fidelity covers and originals recorded in Mendocino County, California. Crockett and Kyle Madrigal recorded the collection over the previous year using a 4-track recorder, an old [[CB radio]] microphone, and an old rotary telephone. Crockett said the songs came \"from my street stuff and folk tunes, stuff I wrote that might not necessarily be best for these studio albums.\"<ref name=\"Field\">{{cite web |last1=Hern |first1=Raoul |last2=Stitt |first2=Greg |last3=Stegall |first3=Tim |last4=Rascoe |first4=Rachel |last5=Udensi |first5=Derek |title=New Austin Music You Can Enjoy at Home |url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2020-04-03/new-austin-music-you-can-enjoy-at-home/ |website=Austin Chronicle |access-date=April 24, 2022 |date=April 3, 2020}}</ref>\n\nCrockett released his seventh album, ''Welcome to Hard Times'', on July 31, 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Welcome to Hard Times - Charley Crockett {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits |website=[[AllMusic]]|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/welcome-to-hard-times-mw0003390845|language=en|access-date=2021-06-25}}</ref> It was produced by Mark Neill and includes songwriting contributions from [[The Black Keys]]' [[Dan Auerbach]] and singer/songwriter [[Pat McLaughlin]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Freeman|first=Jon|date=2020-05-27|title=Charley Crockett Previews New Album With 'Welcome to Hard Times' Video|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/charley-crockett-welcome-to-hard-times-video-1005984/|access-date=2021-06-25|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}}</ref> The album followed a life-threatening health scare in which he was diagnosed with a congenital heart condition that required heart surgery.<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Gage|first=Jeff|date=2019-03-08|title=Charley Crockett Asks 'How Low Can You Go' in First New Song Since Heart Surgery|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/charley-crockett-heart-surgery-new-songs-805238/|access-date=2021-06-25|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}}</ref> It received glowing reviews, including from ''American Songwriter'', who raved, \"Crockett finds the sweet spot between country, soul, blues and folk on deceptively modest songs, effortless in their easy-going groove,\"<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-07-28|title=Charley Crockett Continues Streak With Modest Yet Charming, 'Welcome to Hard Times'|url=https://americansongwriter.com/charley-crockett-welcome-to-hard-times-album-review/|access-date=2021-06-25|website=American Songwriter|language=en-US}}</ref> while ''Texas Monthly'' stated, \"Crockett makes a beeline for the album's central theme: wily survival in a socially, politically, and economically rigged system.\"<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-07-31|title=Charley Crockett Wrote Songs About Hard Times in America. Then 2020 Happened.|url=https://www.texasmonthly.com/arts-entertainment/charley-crockett-welcome-to-hard-times-music/|access-date=2021-06-25|website=Texas Monthly|language=en}}</ref>\n\nOn February 26, 2021, Crockett released his next album, titled ''10 For Slim: Charley Crockett Sings James Hand'', a tribute album to [[James Hand (musician)|James \"Slim\" Hand]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Reuter|first=Annie|title=Charley Crockett Is Releasing Music His Own Way In A Pandemic And It's Working|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/anniereuter/2021/02/26/charley-crockett-is-releasing-music-his-own-way-in-a-pandemic-and-its-working/|access-date=2021-05-06|website=Forbes.com|language=en}}</ref> It was met with critical acclaim from ''Rolling Stone'',<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite magazine|last1=Bernstein|first1=Jonathan|date=2021-03-24|title=Charley Crockett's Throwback Country Sound Isn't in Fashion. That's Fine With Him.|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/charley-crockett-new-album-james-hand-1145806/|access-date=2021-05-06|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}}</ref> ''The Boot'',<ref>{{Cite web|author=Angela Stefano|title=WATCH: Charley Crockett Drives All Night in 'Midnight Run' Video|url=https://theboot.com/charley-crockett-midnight-run-music-video/|access-date=2021-06-11|website=The Boot|date=March 24, 2021 |language=en}}</ref> ''Austin American-Statesman'',<ref>{{Cite web|last=Blackstock|first=Peter|title=Austin360 On The Record: Blue Water Highway, David Ramirez, Charley Crockett|url=https://www.austin360.com/story/entertainment/music/2021/03/12/austin-360-record-new-music-blue-water-highway-more/4652602001/|access-date=2021-06-11|website=austin360|language=en-US}}</ref> ''Forbes'',<ref>{{Cite web|last=Reuter|first=Annie|title=Charley Crockett Is Releasing Music His Own Way In A Pandemic And It's Working|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/anniereuter/2021/02/26/charley-crockett-is-releasing-music-his-own-way-in-a-pandemic-and-its-working/|access-date=2021-06-11|website=Forbes|language=en}}</ref> ''Saving Country Music'',<ref>{{Cite web|last=Trigger|date=2021-02-26|title=Album Review \u2013 Charley Crockett's \"10 For Slim\"|url=https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/album-review-charley-crocketts-10-for-slim/|access-date=2021-06-11|website=Saving Country Music|language=en-US}}</ref> and ''American Songwriter''<ref>{{Cite web|date=2021-03-03|title=Charley Crockett Honors James \"Slim\" Hand: \"I Had No Choice But To Record His Music\"|url=https://americansongwriter.com/charley-crockett-honors-james-slim-hand-i-had-no-choice-but-to-record-his-music/|access-date=2021-06-11|website=American Songwriter|language=en-US}}</ref> among others.\n\nCrockett released his ninth album, ''Music City USA'', on September 17, 2021 via Son of Davy/Thirty Tigers. The lead single, \"I Need Your Love\", was featured on ''Rolling Stone''<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Freeman|first=Jon|date=2021-07-09|title=Charley Crockett Previews New Album With Soulful 'I Need Your Love'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/charley-crockett-announces-new-album-music-city-usa-song-i-need-your-love-1195011/|access-date=2021-07-14|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}}</ref> as well as ''Brooklyn Vegan'', who called it \"a sweet and sultry slice of southern soul\"<ref>{{Cite web|date=July 9, 2021|first1=Bill |last1=Pearis|title=Charley Crockett preps new LP, on tour now (listen to \"I Need Your Love\")|url=https://www.brooklynvegan.com/charley-crockett-preps-new-lp-on-tour-now-listen-to-i-need-your-love/|access-date=2021-07-14|website=BrooklynVegan|language=en}}</ref> and ''The Boot'', who named it \"a dose of horn-filled soul.\"<ref>{{Cite web|date=July 9, 2021|first=Angela|last=Stefano|title=Listen: Charley Crockett Teases New Album With Soul-Filled 'I Need Your Love'|url=https://theboot.com/charley-crockett-music-city-usa-i-need-your-love/|access-date=2021-07-14|website=The Boot|language=en}}</ref> Later that month, he earned the 2021 \"Emerging Artist of the Year\" award at the [[Americana Music Honors & Awards|Americana Music Honors and Awards]] in Nashville, TN.<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite magazine |last=Freeman |first=Jon |date=2021-09-23 |title=Brandi Carlile, Sturgill Simpson Take Top Prizes at 2021 Americana Honors and Awards |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/americana-honors-and-awards-2021-winners-1230942/ |access-date=2022-03-17 |magazine=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref> Crockett closed out the year with his debut on ''[[Austin City Limits]]'', which aired in October on [[PBS]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Charley Crockett Performs 'Goin' Back To Texas' On 'Austin City Limits': Exclusive Video Premiere |url=https://www.jambase.com/article/charley-crockett-austin-city-limits-goin-back-texas |access-date=2022-03-17 |website=JamBase |language=en-US}}</ref> He followed that up a couple months later with an appearance on ''[[CBS This Morning]]''{{'}}s \"Saturday Sessions\" performing \"I Need Your Love,\" \"Music City USA\" and \"I Feel For You\" off his latest album.\n\nIn March 2022, he announced ''Jukebox Charley'', a new album of cover songs and his third album release in just over a year. The fourth installment of his ''Lil' G.L.'' covers series, the album was released on April 22 and featured classic country tunes from [[Tom T. Hall]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[George Jones]], and more.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Freeman |first=Jon |date=2022-03-04 |title=Charley Crockett Covers Jerry Reed, Tom T. Hall on New Album 'Jukebox Charley' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/charley-crockett-new-album-jukebox-charley-1316164/ |access-date=2022-03-17 |magazine=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nCharley Crockett performed on ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' on December 9, 2022.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/charley-crockett-im-just-a-clown-jimmy-kimmel-1234644559/ | title=Charley Crockett Cuts Loose with 'I'm Just a Clown' on 'Kimmel' | magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=December 9, 2022 }}</ref>\n\nIn February 2023, Crockett performed at [[NPR]] for a [[Tiny Desk Concert]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=MUSIC\u00b7 |first=Andrew Mies\u00b7COUNTRY |date=2023-02-24 |title=Charley Crockett Drops Killer 5-Song Set For NPR's 'Tiny Desk Concert' Series |url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2023/02/24/charley-crockett-drops-killer-5-song-set-for-nprs-tiny-desk-concert-series/ |access-date=2024-02-02 |website=Whiskey Riff |language=en-US}}</ref> It was followed by an appearance on [[Comedy Central]]'s ''[[The Daily Show]]'' in April, where he was interviewed by the host [[Jordan Klepper]], along with a live performance of \"Name on a Billboard\" from his 2022 album, ''The Man from Waco''.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Hudak |first=Joseph |date=2023-04-19 |title=Charley Crockett Talks Dylan, Sings 'Name on a Billboard' on 'The Daily Show' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/charley-crockett-daily-show-interview-1234717644/ |access-date=2024-02-02 |magazine=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref> Later that summer, he was on the cover of ''[[Texas Monthly]]'', for a lengthy profile detailing the artist's background and rise to fame.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Spong |first=John |date=2023-05-15 |title=The Long Ride of Charley Crockett |url=https://www.texasmonthly.com/arts-entertainment/the-long-ride-of-charley-crockett/ |access-date=2024-02-02 |website=Texas Monthly |language=en}}</ref> In September, he released ''Live From The Ryman'', an album and concert film of his sold-out headline debut at [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville\u2019s]] [[Ryman Auditorium]] recorded on November 14, 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Trigger |date=2023-08-20 |title=Charley Crockett Reveals \"Live From The Ryman\" Album & Film - Saving Country Music |url=https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/charley-crockett-reveals-live-from-the-ryman-album-film/ |access-date=2024-02-02 |website=Savingcountrymusic.com |language=en-US}}</ref> He was also the 2023 recipient of the Stephen Bruton Award at The Lone Star Film Festival which celebrates exceptional artists whose careers are not only anchored in music, but also include artistic expression in film.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Dabney |first=Courtney |date=2023-09-26 |title=Hollywood Heavyweights, Including Local Favorite Luke Wilson, Are Headed to Fort Worth For Lone Star Film Festival |url=https://www.papercitymag.com/culture/lone-star-film-festival-brings-hollywood-stars-fort-worth-luke-wilson-marty-bowen/ |access-date=2024-02-02 |website=Papercitymag.com |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nIn early 2024, Crockett announced that his album, ''[[$10 Cowboy]]'', would be released on April 26.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Willman |first=Chris |date=2024-01-22 |title=Charley Crockett on His New '$10 Cowboy' Single, Mixing Traditional Country With 'Swamp-Pop-Soul,' and Working With Willie Nelson |url=https://variety.com/2024/music/news/charley-crockett-10-dollar-cowboy-album-single-interview-1235881463/ |access-date=2024-02-02 |website=Variety |language=en-US}}</ref> He celebrated the announcement with an appearance on ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'', where he performed the album's title track.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Young |first=Casey |date=2024-01-23 |title=Charley Crockett Debuts Title Track To New Album, ''$10 Cowboy'', On Late Night TV |url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2024/01/23/charley-crockett-debuts-title-track-to-new-album-10-cowboy-on-late-night-tv/ |access-date=2024-02-02 |website=Whiskey Riff |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Infobox artist discography\n| Artist       = Charley Crockett\n| Image        = \n| Caption      = \n| Alt          = \n| Studio Kenneth Pattengale)'|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/07/11/485275437/songs-we-love-michaela-anne-where-will-i-be-found-feat-kenneth-pattengale|publisher=[[NPR]]|access-date=11 September 2016}}</ref> Her music incorporates elements of classic country, pop, indie rock, and honky-tonk. She has released four albums to date. Her fourth album, ''Oh To Be That Free,'' was released through [[Yep Roc Records]] on June 10, 2022.\n\n==Career==\nMichaela Anne first began garnering national attention with the 2014 release of \u2018Ease My Mind,\u2019 an old-school collection hailed by ''The New York Times'' for its \u201cplain-spoken songs of romantic regret and small-town longing\u201d<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/07/arts/music/michaela-anne-country-singer-and-a-law-school-crowd.html|title=A Country Negotiation in Brooklyn|last=Caramanica|first=Jon|date=2014-06-06|work=The New York Times|access-date=2019-07-11|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> and named one of the year's best country albums by ''The Village Voice''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2014/12/15/2014s-top-country-albums-prove-the-musics-flourishing-radio-be-damned/|title=2014's Top Country Albums Prove the Music's Flourishing, Radio Be Damned|website=www.villagevoice.com|date=15 December 2014 |access-date=2019-07-11}}</ref> Michaela followed it up in 2016 with album \u2018Bright Lights and the Fame,\u2019 which featured guest appearances by [[Rodney Crowell]] and [[Punch Brothers|Punch Brother]] [[Noam Pikelny]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bmi.com/news/entry/michaela_anne_finds_her_home_in_country|title=Michaela Anne Finds Her Home in Country|date=2016-07-21|website=BMI.com|language=en|access-date=2019-07-11}}</ref> Songs from the record landed on high-profile Spotify playlists as well as the ''HBO'' series [[Divorce (TV series)|\u2018Divorce]],\u2019 and the album earned Michaela slots at Bristol Rhythm & Roots, [[MerleFest|Merlefest]], and both the US and UK iterations of AmericanaFest, along with a series of dates across the States and Europe with the likes of [[Mandolin Orange]], [[Courtney Marie Andrews]], [[Joe Pug]], [[Ron Pope]], and [[Sam Outlaw]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/07/11/485275437/songs-we-love-michaela-anne-where-will-i-be-found-feat-kenneth-pattengale|title=Songs We Love: Michaela Anne, 'Where Will I Be Found (Feat. Kenneth Pattengale)'|website=NPR.org|language=en|access-date=2019-07-11}}</ref>\n\nIn 2018, Michaela left Nashville behind to record \u2018Desert Dove\u2019 in San Clemente, CA. The record was cut slow and steady over the course of several weeks with an all-star band, which included guitarist Brian Whelan ([[Dwight Yoakam]], [[Jim Lauderdale]]), fiddler Kristin Weber ([[Kacey Musgraves]], [[Margo Price]]), and drummers Mark Stepro ([[Ben Kweller]], [[Butch Walker]]) and Daniel Bailey ([[Everest (band)|Everest]], [[Josh Tillman|Father John Misty]]).<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/michaela-anne-readies-bright-lights-and-the-fame-album-177973/|title=Michaela Anne Readies 'Bright Lights and the Fame' Album|last=Hudak|first=Joseph|date=2016-02-11|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|access-date=2019-07-11}}</ref> The production pairing of [[Sam Outlaw|Outlaw]] and Winrich also proved to be an ideal fit for Michaela, with each artist bringing their own unique skill sets and approaches to the studio. Soon after, Michaela was signed to [[Yep Roc Records]]. ''Desert Dove'' was released on September 27, 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/6vgnwa/michaela-anne-premiere-wont-go-down-country-florida-georgia-line|title=Michaela Anne Is The Answer To Bro Country v. Everyone Else With \"Won't Go Down\"|last=Domenighini|first=Annalise|date=2016-02-18|website=Vice|language=en-US|access-date=2019-07-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.michaelaanne.com/bio|title=Bio|website=michaela anne|language=en-US|access-date=2019-07-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://yeproc.com/artists/michaela-anne/|title=Michaela Anne|last=Artist|website=Yep Roc Records|access-date=2019-07-11}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n*''To Know Where'' (2011, Self Released)\n*''Ease My Mind'' (2014, Georgia June)\n*''Bright Lights and the Fame'' (2016, Kingswood)\n*''[[Desert Dove]]'' (2019, Yep Roc)\n*''Oh To Be That Free'' (2022, Yep Roc)\n\n==References==\n{{reflist}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Anne, Michaela}}\n[[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:Americana musicians]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from New York (state)]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Brooklyn]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from New York (state)]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women musicians]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Dave_Alvin","to":"Dave Alvin"}],"pages":{"484247":{"pageid":484247,"ns":0,"title":"Dave Alvin","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter and guitarist}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2022}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Dave Alvin\n| image           = Dave Alvin Eleven Eleven.jpg\n| caption         = Alvin in 2011\n| birth_name      = David Albert Alvin\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1955|11|11}}\n| origin          = [[Downey, California]], U.S.\n| genre           = [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[alternative country]],  [[rockabilly]], [[country rock]], [[folk rock]]\n| occupation      = {{flatlist|\n* Musician\n* singer\n* songwriter\n* producer\n}}\n| instrument      = Guitar, vocals\n| years_active    = 1977\u2013present\n| label           = [[Rhino Entertainment|Rhino]], [[Yep Roc Records|Yep Roc]]\n| associated_acts = [[The Blasters]]<br />[[The Knitters]]<br />[[The Flesh Eaters]]<br />[[X (American band)|X]]<br />[[Jimmie Dale Gilmore]]\n}}\n'''David Albert Alvin''' (born November 11, 1955) is an American singer-songwriter, guitarist and producer. He is a former and founding member of the [[roots rock]] band [[the Blasters]]. Alvin has recorded and performed as a solo artist since the late 1980s and has been involved in various side projects and collaborations. He has had brief stints as a member of the bands [[X (U.S. band)|X]] and [[the Knitters]]. He often refers to himself as \"Blackjack Dave,\" in reference to his 1998 album and song of the same name.\n\n== Early life ==\nAlvin grew up in [[Downey, California]]. He and his older brother, [[Phil Alvin]], as teenagers frequented [[blues]], [[rockabilly]] and [[country music]] venues.<ref name=\"All Music bio\">Deming, Mark. [http://www.allmusic.com/artist/dave-alvin-mn0000679219/biography Dave Alvin: Biography]. [[AllMusic]]</ref> Dave attended [[Long Beach State University]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.latimesmagazine.com/2011/06/troubadour-of-troubled-times.html | title=Troubadour of Troubled Times | work=[[Los Angeles Times Magazine]] | date=June 3, 2011 | access-date=June 27, 2014 | author=Barabak, Mark Z.}}</ref>\n\n== Career ==\n=== With the Blasters ===\nIn 1979, Alvin and his brother Phil formed the roots-rock band [[The Blasters]] with fellow Downey residents [[Bill Bateman (drummer)|Bill Bateman]] and [[John Bazz]].<ref name=\"All Music bio\" /><ref name=\"Blasters bio\">{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-blasters-mn0000757177/biography | title=Artist Biography: The Blasters | publisher=AllMusic.com | author=Sullivan, Denise | author-link=Denise Sullivan }}</ref> Alvin served as the group's lead guitarist and chief songwriter.<ref name=\"Blasters bio\" /> ''The Rough Guide to Rock'' noted the ever-increasing numbers of originals that Alvin wrote for the Blasters, along with his maturation into a great songwriter.<ref>{{cite book | title=The Rough Guide to Rock | publisher=Rough Guides | editor1=Buckley, Peter|editor2=Buckley, Jonathan| year=2003 | pages=[https://archive.org/details/roughguidetorock00roug/page/106 106] | isbn=978-1-85828-457-6 | url-access=registration | url=https://archive.org/details/roughguidetorock00roug/page/106 }}</ref>\n\nOther artists have covered Alvin's songs. For example, \"[[Marie Marie]]\" became a British-German top 20 hit in 1980 for [[Shakin' Stevens]] and received a [[zydeco]] treatment in 1987 from [[Buckwheat Zydeco]]. [[Dwight Yoakam]] recorded \"Long White Cadillac\" in 1989.<ref name=\"All Music bio\" />\n\nAlvin was in the original lineup until 1986. His departure reflected internal tension in the band, but ultimately he wanted to sing his own songs while his brother [[Phil Alvin]] was the established lead vocalist for the group.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.sacbee.com/entertainment/music-news-reviews/article36306066.html |author=Sculley, Alan |title=Alvin brothers: Losing no more time playing apart |work=Sacramento Bee |date=September 23, 2015 |access-date=September 17, 2019}}</ref>\n\nAlvin has rejoined the Blasters for some reunion tours and live albums with the original lineup. He has also occasionally performed with the band under other circumstances as well.<ref name=\"rosen\">{{cite news |url=https://www.latimes.com/socal/burbank-leader/entertainment/tn-blr-1216-the-blasters-frontman-phil-alvin-takes-to-the-stage-new-years-eve-after-a-scary-2012-story.html |author=Rosen, Craig |title=The Blasters' frontman Phil Alvin takes to the stage New Year's Eve after a scary 2012 |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=December 15, 2012 |access-date=September 17, 2019}}</ref>\n\n=== With X and the Knitters ===\nAlvin served a brief stint as the lead guitarist of the Los Angeles\u2013based [[alternative rock]] band [[X (American band)|X]]. He left X in 1987 to work on a solo project after the group recorded their album ''[[See How We Are]]''.\n\nAlvin was also a member of the [[country folk]] band [[The Knitters]], an offshoot of X. He appeared on their 1985 album  ''Poor Little Critter on the Road'' and their 2005 follow-up, ''The Modern Sounds of the Knitters''.<ref name=\"All Music bio\" />\n\n=== With the Flesh Eaters ===\nIn the early 1980s, Alvin, along with fellow Blasters members Bill Bateman and [[Steve Berlin]], performed on ''[[A Minute to Pray, a Second to Die (album)|A Minute to Pray, A Second to Die]]'' by the Los Angeles [[Punk rock|punk]] band [[the Flesh Eaters]]. This lineup, which also included [[John Doe (musician)|John Doe]] and [[D.J. Bonebrake]], assembled once again in 2006, performing three shows in California and one in England to mark the album's 25th anniversary. They reunited briefly in 2015 for a five-show tour and again for an eight-show run in 2018. They issued a new album, ''[[I Used to Be Pretty]]'', in 2019.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://americanahighways.org/2019/03/19/show-review-flesh-eaters-rock-dcs-union-stage-with-porcupine/ |author=Cook, Glenn. |title=Show Review: Flesh Eaters Rock DC's Union Stage With Porcupine |work=Americana Highways |date=March 19, 2019 |access-date=September 18, 2019}}</ref>\n\n=== Solo ===\n[[File:Dave Alvin.jpg|thumb|Alvin in 2007]]\nAlvin's first solo album, ''Romeo's Escape'' (entitled ''Every Night About This Time'' in England), was released in 1987. It was well received by critics but did not sell well. Because of the album's low sales, Alvin's recording contract with [[Columbia Records]] was terminated. He then toured with [[Mojo Nixon]] and [[Beat Farmers|Country Dick Montana]], billed as the Pleasure Barons; an album recorded live on their 1993 tour was released.<ref name=\"All Music bio\" />\n\nAlvin's second solo album, ''Blue Blvd'', was released by [[Hightone Records]] in 1991. It received positive reviews and had moderate sales. His album ''Museum of Heart'' was released in 1993. He recorded ''[[King of California (album)|King of California]]'', an album of [[acoustic music]], in 1994. In 2000, he recorded the album ''[[Public Domain (album)|Public Domain: Songs From the Wild Land]]'', a collection of traditional folk and blues classics, which earned him a [[Grammy]] award for Best Contemporary [[Folk music|Folk]] Album.<ref name=\"All Music bio\" />\n\nIn 2011, Alvin recorded the album ''[[Eleven Eleven (Dave Alvin album)|Eleven Eleven]]'', released by [[Yep Roc Records]]. The album marked his return to rock roots.<ref name=\"rs\">{{cite magazine|last=Scherman|first=Tony|title=Dave Alvin: Eleven Eleven|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=June 21, 2011|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/eleven-eleven-20110621}}</ref> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine, in a review of the album, called Alvin \"an underrecognized guitar hero\".<ref name=\"rs\" />\n\n=== Further recordings with Phil Alvin ===\nIn 2014, Dave and Phil Alvin, as a duo, released the album ''Common Ground'', consisting of their versions of songs by [[Big Bill Broonzy]].<ref>{{cite magazine | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5908507/the-blasters-dave-phil-alvin-talk-common-ground-album-premiere-all-by-myself-song-listen-exclusive | title=Dave Alvin & Phil Alvin Talk 'Common Ground' Album, Premiere 'All By Myself' Song: Listen Exclusively | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | date=February 19, 2014 | access-date=June 26, 2014 | author=Gallo, Phil}}</ref> It was the first studio collaboration of the brothers since the mid-1980s.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-torn-up-band-of-brothers-finally-on-the-mend-1401411544 | title=A Torn-Up Band of Brothers, Finally on the Mend | work=[[The Wall Street Journal|Wall Street Journal]] | date=May 29, 2014 | access-date=June 26, 2014 | author=Dougherty, Steve}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-alvin-brothers-20140608-story.html#page=1 | title=Dave and Phil Alvin, Former Blasters Mates, Resurrect Partnership | work=Los Angeles Times | date=June 6, 2014 | access-date=June 26, 2014 | author=Lewis, Randy}}</ref> In 2015 they released ''Lost Time'', a collection of covers including four songs by [[Big Joe Turner]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Dave Alvin: Return of the Battlin' Brothers|page=24|date=March 2016|newspaper=[[Vintage Guitar (magazine)|Vintage Guitar]]|last=Cohen|first=Elliot Stephen}}</ref>\n\nIn live performance, Alvin assumed the role of emcee and storyteller. The brothers also worked Blasters tunes into the set list.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.elmoremagazine.com/2016/09/reviews/shows/dave-and-phil-alvin-and-the-guilty-ones |title=Dave and Phil Alvin and the Guilty Ones |work=Elmore Magazine |date=September 9, 2016 |access-date=September 17, 2019}}</ref>\n\n=== With Jimmie Dale Gilmore ===\nAlvin and Texas singer-songwriter [[Jimmie Dale Gilmore]] teamed on the 2018 album ''Downey to Lubbock'' (the title is a reference to where each man grew up).\n\nAs seen in his live performances with brother Phil, Alvin's stories between songs were a notable part of the stage shows with Gilmore and their supporting musicians.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://glidemagazine.com/214083/dave-alvin-and-jimmie-dale-gilmore-prove-perfect-collaborators-in-portland-show-review-photos/ |author=Ferguson, Neil |title=Dave Alvin and Jimmie Dale Gilmore Prove Perfect Collaborators in Portland |work=Glide Magazine |date=October 1, 2018 |access-date=September 17, 2019}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2022, Alvin announced his return to public performance after a grueling two-year battle with different forms of cancer that started in May 2020. He chose to do so with Gilmore, scheduling nine dates in California for late June and early July 2022.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/dave-alvin-cancer-interview-1336284/ |author=Bernstein, Jonathan |title='I Should Have Died': Dave Alvin, Seminal California Country-Punk Guitarist, Talks Private Cancer Battle |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=April 14, 2022 |access-date=April 21, 2022}}</ref>\n\n=== Producer and collaborator ===\nAlvin has produced records for [[Chris Gaffney (musician)|Chris Gaffney]], [[Tom Russell]], the [[Derailers]], [[Big Sandy & His Fly-Rite Boys]] and [[Red Meat (band)|Red Meat]]. He collaborated with the [[rockabilly]] musician [[Sonny Burgess]].<ref name=\"All Music bio\" /> He has worked as a studio session musician accompanying [[Ramblin' Jack Elliott]], [[Little Milton]], [[Katy Moffatt]], and [[Syd Straw]].<ref name=\"All Music bio\" />\n\nAlvin has lent his guitar playing to other artists' albums over the years. For example, he played with [[the Gun Club]] and appeared on two songs from their 1984 album, ''[[The Las Vegas Story (album)|The Las Vegas Story]]''<ref name=\"All Music bio\" />\n\n=== Film ===\nAlvin appeared in the movies ''[[Border Radio]]'' and  ''Floundering'' and on the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] television series ''[[Justified (TV series)|Justified]]'' in 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/music/dave-alvin-lives-to-tell-about-his-justified-stint/article_2a4bc144-1a84-5f8e-a214-68990bc1b66b.html|title = Dave Alvin lives to tell about his 'Justified' stint|website=Stltoday.com| date=May 31, 2013 }}</ref> He also appeared in ''[[Streets of Fire]]'', with the Blasters, in 1984.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0023568/#actor | title=Dave Alvin: Filmography | publisher=[[Internet Movie Database|IMDb.com]]}}</ref>\n\n=== Poetry and other writing ===\nAlvin has published two books of poetry: ''Any Rough Times Are Now Behind You'' and ''Nana, Big Joe & the Fourth of July''. His poetry has appeared in ''Caffeine'', the ''A.K.A. Review'', ''Rattler'', ''Asymptote'' and ''Enclitic'' and in the [[anthologies]] ''Nude Erections'', ''Hit and Run Poets'' and ''Poetry Loves Poetry\u2014An Anthology of Los Angeles Poets''.\n\nA collection of Alvin's writing called ''New Highway'' was scheduled for release in September 2022. Its subtitle -- Selected Lyrics, Poems, Prose, Essays, Eulogies and Blues -- described the scope of his work.\n\n== The Blasters discography ==\n(recordings with Dave Alvin as member)\n*''[[American Music (album)|American Music]]'' (1980)\n*''[[The Blasters (album)|The Blasters]]'' (1981)\n*''Over There (Live at The Venue, London)'' (1982) 6-song EP\n*''[[Non Fiction (The Blasters album)|Non Fiction]]'' (1983)\n*''[[Hard Line (album)|Hard Line]]'' (1985)\n*''The Blasters Collection'' (1990)\n*''Testament: The Complete Slash Recordings'' (2002)\n*''Trouble Bound'' (2002)\n*''The Blasters Live: Going Home'' (2004)\n*''Live 1986'' (2011)\n*''Mandatory: The Best of The Blasters'' (2023)\n\n== The Blasters videography ==\n*''[[Streets of Fire]]'' (1984)\n*''The Blasters Live: Going Home'' (2004)\n\n== X discography ==\n*''[[See How We Are]]'' (1987)\n\n== The Knitters discography ==\n*''Poor Little Critter on the Road'' (1985)\n*''The Modern Sounds of the Knitters'' (2005)\n\n== The Pleasure Barons discography ==\n*''Live in Las Vegas'' (1993)\n\n== Gene Taylor Blues Band discography ==\n*''Live!!! 605 Boogie!!!'' This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Eilen_Jewell","to":"Eilen Jewell"}],"pages":{"15557685":{"pageid":15557685,"ns":0,"title":"Eilen Jewell","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Eilen Jewell\n| image             = Eilen Jewell 2023 Brisbane, Australia.jpg\n| caption           = \n| landscape         = yes\n| birth_name        = \n| alias             = \n| birth_date        = {{Birth date and age|1979|4|6}}\n| birth_place       = [[Boise, Idaho]], United States\n| origin            = \n| instrument        = Vocals, guitar\n| genre             = {{Flatlist|\n* [[Americana (music)|Americana]]\n* [[blues]]\n* [[country music|country]]\n* [[american folk music|folk]]\n* [[gospel music|gospel]]\n* [[honky-tonk]]\n}}\n| occupation        = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active      = 1998\u2013present\n| label             = [[Signature Sounds Recordings|Signature Sounds]]\n| associated_acts   = The Sacred Shakers\n| website           = {{URL|www.eilenjewell.com/}}\n}}\n\n'''Eilen Jewell''' (born April 6, 1979) is an American singer-songwriter from [[Boise, Idaho]]. She has released 13 albums.\n\n==Early life and education==\nJewell grew up in Boise, Idaho and attended St. John\u2019s College in [[Santa Fe, New Mexico|Santa Fe]], New Mexico.<ref name=\"Boise Weekly\">{{cite web |url=http://www.boiseweekly.com/boise/wide-open-spaces/Content?oid=933544 |title=Wide Open Spaces |author=Amy Atkins |date=August 29, 2007 |publisher=Boise Weekly |accessdate=August 22, 2011 |archive-date=September 27, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927062258/http://www.boiseweekly.com/boise/wide-open-spaces/Content?oid=933544 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://jacksonville.com/entertainment/music/2009-05-08/story/music_notes_eilen_jewell_darryl_wise_and_more |title=Music Notes: Eilen Jewell, Darryl Wise and more |publisher=Jacksonville.com |date=May 8, 2009 |accessdate=May 16, 2015}}</ref> After living in Boston for several years, she returned to Boise in 2015. Her 2015 album, Sundown Over Ghost Town, was largely inspired by her return to Boise.<ref>from an interview on [http://americanamusicshow.com/episode247 Americana Music Show #247], published May 19, 2015.</ref>\n\n==Career==\nJewell began her musical career [[busking]] on the streets of Santa Fe while attending college.<ref name=\"Boise Weekly\"/> She then moved to Los Angeles and performed on the streets of [[Venice, Los Angeles|Venice Beach]].<ref name=\"Boise Weekly\"/> Jewell moved to [[Massachusetts]] where she performed at local music clubs.<ref name=\"Boise Weekly\"/>\n\nIn December 2005, Jewell recorded a \"live demo\" album called ''Nowhere in Time'' and later recorded the album ''Boundary County'' with Jason Beek on percussion, Daniel Kellar on violin, Jerry Glenn Miller on guitars and Johnny Sciascia on upright bass.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acousticmusic.com/fame/p04027.htm |title=FAME Review: Eilen Jewell \u2013 Boundary Country |publisher=Acousticmusic.com |date= |accessdate=May 16, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{AllMusic|class=album|id=r948521|tab=review|label=Boundary County|first=Ronnie D|last=Lankford}}</ref><ref>NPR, September 3, 2007, Eilen Jewell: Songs from 'Sinners and Strangers', David Dye, Retrieved July 2011</ref>\n\n[[File:EilenJewellBand.jpg|thumb|right|Jewell and her band in Buffalo, New York, 2011.]]\n\nHer album ''Letters from Sinners & Strangers'', was recorded at the Signature Sounds studio in [[Pomfret, Connecticut]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rtrfm.com.au/stories/type/reviews/category/pop/802 |title=Pops in the Pines \u00ab RTRFM / The Sound Alternative |publisher=Rtrfm.com.au |date= |accessdate=May 16, 2015}}</ref>\n\nIn early 2009 Jewell released the album ''Sea of Tears''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/music/cd_reviews/articles/2009/04/27/eilen_jewell_sea_of_tears/ |title=Eilen Jewell, 'Sea of Tears' |date=April 27, 2009 |first=Stuart |last=Munro |work=[[The Boston Globe]]}}</ref> which was called a \"startling departure\"  by a Sydney ''Morning Herald'' music critic.<ref>The Sydney Morning Herald (Australia), May 9\u201310, 2009.{{Verify source|what is the article title? page number? url?|date=July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.dispatch.com/entertainmentlife/20180709/concert-review--eilen-jewell-singer-songwriter-displays-history-of-traditional-american-music|title= Concert review: Eilen Jewell: Singer-songwriter displays history of Traditional American Music|work= Dispatch|date= July 9, 2018}}</ref>\n\nIn 2010, Jewell released the album ''Butcher Holler'', an album of [[Loretta Lynn]] covers and in 2011, her fourth album of original music, ''Queen of the Minor Key''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/popcandy/post/2011/06/new-podcast-joseph-arthur-arctic-monkeys-and-more-new-tunes/1 |title=New podcast! Joseph Arthur, Arctic Monkeys and more new tunes |publisher=Content.usatoday.com |date=June 2, 2011|accessdate=May 16, 2015}}</ref>\n\nJewell and her band toured the U.S., Canada, Europe,<ref>{{cite web|last=\u00d6stn\u00e4s |first=Magnus |title=Folkscenens nya stj\u00e4rna i Uppsala |date=April 29, 2010 |url=http://www.unt.se/kultur-noje/folkscenens-nya-stjarna-i-uppsala-924068.aspx|publisher=Uppsala Nya Tidning |accessdate=December 22, 2016 }}</ref> the UK and Australia beginning in 2005 including performances at South by Southwest and NPR's [[World Cafe (radio program)|World Cafe]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Jewell |first=Eilen |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=14158918 |title=Eilen Jewell: Songs from 'Sinners and Strangers' : World Cafe |publisher=Npr.org |date= |accessdate=May 16, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.ksut.org/post/what-night-eilen-jewell-and-cannondolls-rocked-strater-theatre|title= What a Night! Eilen Jewell and the Cannondolls Rocked the Strater Theatre. |date= February 17, 2018|work= [[KSUT]]}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n* ''Boundary County'' (2006)\n* ''Letters from Sinners & Strangers'' (2007)\n* ''Heartache Boulevard'' (2007) EP\n* ''The Sacred Shakers'' (The Sacred Shakers) (2008)\n* ''Sea of Tears'' (2009)\n* ''Butcher Holler:  A Tribute to Loretta Lynn'' (2010)\n* ''Queen of the Minor Key'' (2011)\n* ''Live'' (The Sacred Shakers) (2014)\n* ''Live at The Narrows'' (2014) 2CD\n* ''Sundown over Ghost Town'' (2015)\n* ''Down Hearted Blues'' (2017)\n* ''Gypsy'' (2019)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/us/album/gypsy/1464038279|title=Gypsy by Eilen Jewell|website=[[Apple Music]]|accessdate=August 15, 2019}}</ref>\n*''Get Behind the Wheel'' (2023)\n\n==Notes and references==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n* {{Official website|http://www.eilenjewell.com/}}\n*{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p864329|label=Eilen Jewell}}\n\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Jewell, Eilen}}\n[[Category:1979 births]]\n[[Category:Living people]]\n[[Category:American women country singers]]\n[[Category:American country singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American women singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:American street performers]]\n[[Category:American torch singers]]\n[[Category:Musicians from Boise, Idaho]]\n[[Category:Country musicians from Idaho]]\n[[Category:St. John's College (Annapolis/Santa Fe) alumni]]\n[[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]]\n[[Category:21st-century American women singers]]\n[[Category:Signature Sounds artists]]\n[[Category:Singer-songwriters from Idaho]]"}]}}}}{"batchcomplete":"","warnings":{"main":{"*":"Subscribe to the mediawiki-api-announce mailing list at <https://lists.wikimedia.org/postorius/lists/mediawiki-api-announce.lists.wikimedia.org/> for notice of API deprecations and breaking changes. Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Rick_Shea","to":"Rick Shea"}],"pages":{"43294995":{"pageid":43294995,"ns":0,"title":"Rick Shea","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter and guitarist (born 1953)}}\n{{multiple issues |\n{{no footnotes|date=September 2014}}\n{{BLP sources|date=September 2014}}\n}}\n{{infobox musical artist\n| birth_date      = {{birth year and age|1953}}\n| birth_place     = [[Annapolis, Maryland|Annapolis]], [[Maryland]], U.S.\n| occupation      = Singer, songwriter, producer, musician, performer\n| genre           = {{hlist|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]}}\n| instrument      = Acoustic guitar, electric guitar, pedal steel, mandolin, vocals\n| name            = Rick Shea\n| birth_name      = Richard Denis Shea\n| label           = TRES PESCADORES\n| years_active    = 1971-present\n| associated_acts = Chris Gaffney, Dave Alvin, Wanda Jackson, Hank Thompson, Brantley Kearns, Patty Booker, Heather Miles\n| origin          = [[San Bernardino, California]], U.S.\n| website         = www.rickshea.com\n}}\n'''Rick Shea''' (born September 22, 1953) is an American singer-songwriter and guitarist who lives in Southern California. His career spans four decades and in that time he has worked as a solo artist and with bands such as Chris Gaffney and The Cold Hard Facts and Dave Alvin's Guilty Men. Additionally, Shea fronts his own band, the Losin' End. His influences are many and include the hardcore honky of Hank Williams as well as a myriad of American artists and international folk musicians. Eclectic in his stance, his live shows entice audiences across the United States and Europe. He has released ten albums and continues to write, record and produce both his own music and that of other artists.\n\n==Early life==\nShea was born in [[Annapolis]], [[Maryland]] to a military family and lived in several eastern states before moving to [[San Bernardino]], [[California]] at age eleven. As a teenager, he began playing in local coffeehouses and before long, many of the country bars and [[honky-tonk]]s in the area.\n\n==Musical career==\nShea draws inspiration from the folk, country, blues, and rock genres and has been compared to [[Tom Russell]], [[Jimmie Dale Gilmore]] and Chuck Pyle among others. As a solo artist, he has played at The Strawberry Festival in [[Sonora, California|Sonora]], California, [[The Canmore Folk Festival]] in Alberta Canada, The Honolulu Academy of Arts in Hawaii, and is a regular on the \"Roots on the Rails\" series of concerts along with his partner in crime, [[Dave Alvin]], as well as many other Folk and Americana venues and festivals.\n\nIn 1992, Shea was included in the ''Town South of Bakersfield'' series of albums that featured [[Dwight Yoakam]], [[Lucinda Williams]], and [[Rosie Flores]] among others. Later, in 2001, Shea collaborated with fiddler Brantley Kearns on an album of original and cover songs called ''Trouble and Me''. Shea arranged and co-produced the album with [[Dave Alvin]].\n\nIn 2003, Shea worked with country singer Patty Booker on an album of country duets called ''Our Shangri LA''. The album featured original and cover songs by [[Merle Haggard]], [[Leona Williams]], [[Pat McLaughlin]], Lee Hazlewood and others. Shea has played with Dave Alvin on his Grammy Award-winning album ''Public Domain'' and with [[R.E.M.]] for the soundtrack to ''[[Man on the Moon (film)|Man On the Moon]]''.\n\nShea has worked as a producer on his own albums and plays acoustic, electric, and steel guitar, and mandolin. He is revered as a master Telecaster player, and performs regularly in Southern California  with his group, consisting of sidemen David Hallgrimson on bass, noted percussionist  [[Steve Mugalian]]., and session whiz Stephen Patt.  Besides his own albums, Shea has also produced albums for The Good Intentions from [[Liverpool]] and Chris Richards from [[Sheboygan, Wisconsin]].\n\n==Discography==\n* ''Outside of Nashville'' (1989)\n* ''A Town South of Bakersfield'' (1992)\n* ''The Buffalo Show'' (1993)\n* ''Shaky Ground'' (1998)\n* ''Sawbones'' (1999)\n* ''Trouble and Me'' (2001)\n* ''Our Shangri LA'' (2003)\n* ''Bound for Trouble'' (2005)\n* ''Shelter Valley Blues'' (2009)\n* ''Sweet Bernardine'' (2013)\n* ''The Town Where I Live'' (2017)\n* ''Love & Desperation'' (2020)\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==External links==\n*{{cite web |url= http://midwestrecord.com/MWR690.html|title=TRES PESCADORES; Volume 37/Number 289|last1=Spector |first1=Chris |date=Aug 17, 2013 |accessdate= }}\n*http://www.allmusic.com/artist/rick-shea-mn0000300072\n*http://www.canmorefolkfestival.com/Assts/CopyDocuments/PerformersArchive-1978-2010.pdf\n*http://archives.starbulletin.com/2007/10/26/features/story06.html\n*http://www.dabelly.com/columns/lint72.htm\n*Workingman's Blues by Gerald W. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"John_Driskell_Hopkins","to":"John Driskell Hopkins"}],"pages":{"27544617":{"pageid":27544617,"ns":0,"title":"John Driskell Hopkins","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Infobox musical artist<!--See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians-->\n| name      = John Driskell Hopkins\n| image   = ZBB PNC.jpg\n| image_size = \n| background = solo_singer\n| caption = Hopkins in 2014.\n| birth_name =\n| birth_date   ={{Birth date and age|1971|05|03|mf=y}}\n| birth_place    =[[San Antonio, Texas]], United States\n| origin =\n| instrument   = {{flat list|\n* [[Guitar]]\n* [[ukulele]]\n* [[Bass guitar|bass]]\n* [[stand-up bass]]\n* [[banjo]]\n}}\n| genre  = {{flat list|\n* [[Americana (music)|Americana]]\n* [[Country music|country]]\n* [[country rock]]\n* [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]]\n* [[rock and roll]]\n}}\n| years_active  =1992\u2013present\n| label =\n| current_member_of = [[Zac Brown Band]]\n| website =            {{URL|johndriskellhopkins.com}}\n}}\n'''John Driskell Hopkins''' (born May 3, 1971) is an American musician best known for his role as a founding member, vocalist, multi-instrumentalist, and songwriter for the Grammy Award-winning group [[Zac Brown Band]]. Hopkins co-wrote, with [[Zac Brown]], Wyatt Durette, and [[Shawn Mullins]], the [[Zac Brown Band]]'s third single, \"Toes\", from their 2008 major-label debut ''[[The Foundation (Zac Brown Band album)|The Foundation]]''. It was the second number-one single for the band. \nHopkins also co-wrote, with Zac Brown, Wyatt Durette, and [[Sonia Leigh]], the second single from the band's third major-label album ''[[Uncaged]]'', entitled \"[[Goodbye in Her Eyes]]\".\nHopkins co-wrote the band's first number=one hit on the ''Billboard'' [[Mainstream Rock (chart)|Mainstream Rock chart]], \"[[Heavy Is the Head (Zac Brown Band song)|Heavy Is the Head]]\", which featured [[Chris Cornell]] and was the second single from their fourth major-label studio album, 2015's ''[[Jekyll + Hyde]]''.\n\n==Early life==\nHopkins was raised in [[Gainesville, Georgia]], the eldest of four brothers. He graduated from [[Florida State University]] 1993 with a degree in general theatre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://johndriskellhopkins.com/press |title=John Driskell Hopkins |publisher=John Driskell Hopkins |access-date=2014-06-09}}</ref>\nDuring college at Florida State University, Hopkins was the front man of a band called The Woodpeckers.\n\n==Career==\nAfter college, Hopkins moved to Atlanta. In 1996, he formed his rock band Brighter Shade, with whom he still plays. Brighter Shade recorded two albums by the early 2000s. During that time, Hopkins got involved with the production end of the scene: producing, recording, and collaborating on several projects in the Atlanta area, including one with Zac Brown.\nAfter several years of friendship with Brown, in 2005, Hopkins joined the Zac Brown Band on bass guitar and vocals.\nIn 2011, Hopkins joined forces with bluegrass band [[Balsam Range]].  In January 2013, they released their debut CD called ''Daylight'' to critical acclaim.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zacbrownband.com/john-driskell-hopkins.html |title=John Driskell Hopkins |publisher=Zac Brown Band |access-date=2014-06-09 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140509001053/http://www.zacbrownband.com/john-driskell-hopkins.html |archive-date=2014-05-09 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.johndriskellhopkins.com |title=John Driskell Hopkins |publisher=John Driskell Hopkins |access-date=2014-06-09}}</ref>\n\nIn 2019, Hopkins, along with fellow musicians Greg Lee, Mike Rizzi, Mark Dannells, and Mick Murphy, a formed heavy rock band, The Bloody Wolves of Venice.  The Bloody Wolves of Venice released a five-song EP, ''The Revelation EP'', which was featured in the 2018 film ''Adolescence''.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2019-03-04 |title=John Driskell Hopkins' Heavy Revelation With The Bloody Wolves Of Venice |url=https://atlantamusicgrapevine.com/2019/03/04/john-driskell-hopkins-heavy-revelation-with-the-bloody-wolves-of-venice/ |access-date=2022-03-21 |website=Atlanta Music Grapevine |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n===Collaborations===\nHopkins heard Balsam Range on bluegrass radio in 2011 and was so impressed, he immediately bought all their music. They later met and made an immediate personal and musical connection. They decided to join forces and record a CD. In September 2012, the album ''Daylight'' was completed, and officially released January 2013.\n{{blockquote|If you drew line graphs plotting the changes each song brings to a CD \u2013 tempo, subject, mood \u2026 \u2013 some CDs would flatline and the majority would show moderate spikes up and down. Daylight's graph would look like the EKG of a person on speed, and every song is a good one. I hope Hopkins is already planning his next CD.<ref>Larry Stephens, ''The lonesome Road Review''</ref>}}\n\nBalsam Range is a five-piece bluegrass powerhouse from [[Haywood County, North Carolina]], and include members Buddy Melton (fiddle, vocals), Darren Nicholson (mandolin, vocals), Marc Pruett (banjo), Caleb Smith (guitar, vocals), and Tim Surrett (bass, dobro, vocals). Their accolades include being voted Best Old-Time/Bluegrass Band of 2012 in Asheville's Mountain Xpress and receiving the [[International Bluegrass Music Awards|IBMA]] Song of the Year award for \"Trains I Missed 2011\" and the 2013 IBMA \"Album of the Year\" award for ''Papertown'', and  the 2014 IBMA \"Entertainer of the Year\". Hopkins and Balsam Range continue to play shows together often.\n\nDobro master and 14-time Grammy winner [[Jerry Douglas]] was also featured on Hopkins' 2013 release, ''Daylight''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Daylight \u2013 John Driskell Hopkins |url=https://johndriskellhopkins.com/music/daylight/ |access-date=2022-05-12 |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nIn 2014, Hopkins has also collaborated with Georgia native bluegrass group the \"[[Dappled Grays]]\" on several shows, including two sold-out nights at the [[Georgia Theater]] opening for [[The String Cheese Incident]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://balsamrange.com/about/ |title=About |publisher=Balsam Range |access-date=2014-06-09}}</ref>\n\n===Brighter Shade===\nHopkins formed aggressive songwriter band [[Brighter Shade]] in 1996. The original line-up consisted of Hopkins on vocals and guitar, Andy Birdsall on vocals and guitar, Sean McIntyre on bass, and Marcus Petruska on drums. They recorded their eponymous debut album in 1996.\n\nLater, a second line-up followed, featuring Hopkins and Birsdall, but added Wilder Embry on bass, Damian Cartier on keyboards, and John Woodward and Eric Sanders on drums. They recorded Brighter Shade's sophomore album, ''Divine Ignorance'', in 2001. Brighter Shade still plays periodic gigs in and around the Atlanta area.\n\nHopkins' recording studio, Brighter Shade Studios, shares the name of his band, and was where the Zac Brown album ''Home Grown'' was recorded in 1998. Brighter Shade Studios was also used in the recording of first two major albums of the Zac Brown Band - ''[[The Foundation (Zac Brown Band album)|The Foundation]]'' and ''[[You Get What You Give (album)|You Get What You Give]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://myspace.com/brightershade |title=Brighter Shade &#124; Listen and Stream Free Music, Albums, New Releases, Photos, Videos |publisher=Myspace.com |access-date=2014-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/m/cd/brightershade/from/greatindiemusic |title=CD Baby Mobile |publisher=Cdbaby.com |access-date=2014-06-09}}</ref>\n\n===Acting career===\nHopkins graduated from [[Florida State University]] in 1993 with a degree in general theatre. His first film, ''[[Careful What You Wish For (film)|Careful What You Wish For]]'', starring [[Nick Jonas]], [[Isabel Lucas]], and [[Paul Sorvino]], was released in May 2015.<ref>{{cite web |date=2022-03-21 |title=Careful What You Wish For |url=https://m.imdb.com/title/tt1629242/?ref_=nv_sr_srsg_0 |access-date=2022-03-21 |website=IMDb}}</ref> Hopkins also had a role in the 2018 film Adolescence.<ref>{{Citation |title=Adolescence (2018) - IMDb |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3220900/ |language=en-US |access-date=2022-03-21}}</ref> Hopkins has a role in the upcoming crime drama, Breakwater, expected to be released later this year.<ref>{{Cite web |title=John Driskell Hopkins |url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm4576782/ |access-date=2022-03-23 |website=IMDb}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nIn December 2021, Hopkins was diagnosed with [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]] (ALS or Lou Gehrig's disease). He did not publicly announce this diagnosis until May 20, 2022, when the rest of the Zac Brown Band and he publicly announced this during a [[YouTube]] video. In response, Hopkins founded the charity Hop on a Cure to fund research on the disease.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/zac-brown-band-john-driskell-hopkins-als-diagnosis/ | title=BREAKING: Zac Brown Band's John Driskell Hopkins Reveals ALS Diagnosis | date=20 May 2022 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/zac-brown-band-founding-member-announces-als-diagnosis?intcmp=tw_fnc | title=Zac Brown Band founding member John Driskell Hopkins announces ALS diagnosis | website=[[Fox News]] | date=22 May 2022 }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n*''Brighter Shade'' \nBrighter Shade (1996)\n\n*''Divine Ignorance'' \nBrighter Shade (2001)\n\n*''Daylight'' \nJohn Driskell This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Sam_Baker_(musician)","to":"Sam Baker (musician)"}],"pages":{"42685662":{"pageid":42685662,"ns":0,"title":"Sam Baker (musician)","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{about|the folk musician|the hip hop musician|Samiyam}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2019}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Sam Baker\n| image           = sambaker_b&w.jpg\n| image_size      = <!-- Only for images narrower than 220 pixels -->\n| landscape       = yes\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = 1954\n| birth_place     = Itasca, Texas\n| origin          =\n| death_date      =\n| genre           = [[Americana (music)|Americana]]<br>[[Folk music|Folk]]<br />[[Country music|Country]]\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar\n| years_active    = 2004 \u2013\n| label           =\n| associated_acts =\n| website         = {{url|sambakermusic.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Sam Baker''' (born 1954) is an American [[folk music|folk]] musician based in [[Austin, Texas]].<ref name=AllMusic>{{cite web |url= http://www.allmusic.com/artist/sam-baker-mn0001881021 |title= Sam Baker |last= Leggett |first= Steve |publisher= [[AllMusic]] |accessdate= May 6, 2014}}</ref> He writes sparse poetic lyrics that have gained him acclaim from other notable folk artists such as [[Gurf Morlix]] and [[Fred Eaglesmith]].\n\n==Biography==\nSam Baker was born in 1954 in [[Itasca, Texas]]. He attended [[Itasca High School (Texas)|Itasca High School]], where he played varsity football with fellow musician [[Tommy Alverson]].<ref name=Alverson>{{cite web |url= http://www.tommyalverson.com/bioprint.html |title= Tommy Alverson bio |publisher= Tommy Alverson |accessdate= May 7, 2014}}</ref> In 1986, Baker was traveling by train to [[Machu Picchu]] in Peru when a bomb placed on a luggage rack above his head by the [[Shining Path]] guerrilla group exploded, killing seven other passengers including the three people who had been sitting with him.<ref name=AllMusic/><ref name=Today>{{cite news |url= http://www.today.com/id/24794227/ns/today-today_entertainment/t/singer-sam-baker-true-survivor/ |title= Singer Sam Baker is a true survivor |work= [[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]] |date= May 23, 2008 |accessdate= May 6, 2014}}</ref><ref name=AustinChronicle>{{cite news |url= http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2007-11-16/561471/ |title= Terrible Beauty: The ballad of Sam Baker |first= Doug |last= Freeman |date=November 16, 2007 |newspaper= [[The Austin Chronicle]] |accessdate= May 6, 2014}}</ref> Baker was left with numerous injuries, including brain damage, a cut artery, and blown-in eardrums.<ref name=Huffington>{{cite web |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/steven-rosen/sam-bakers-remarkable-new_b_3837739.html |title= Sam Baker's Remarkable New Album |last= Rosen |first= Steven |work= [[HuffPost]] |date= August 30, 2013 |accessdate= May 6, 2014}}</ref> His injuries required 17 reconstructive surgeries.<ref name=HoustonChronicle>{{cite news |url= http://www.chron.com/entertainment/music/article/Surviving-tragedy-makes-Sam-Baker-s-songs-resonate-1525499.php |title= Surviving tragedy makes Sam Baker's songs resonate |last= McClelland |first= Eileen |date= February 10, 2006 |newspaper= [[Houston Chronicle]] |accessdate= May 6, 2014}}</ref> He has a constant case of [[tinnitus]] and the fingers of his left hand were left gnarled.  He did retain enough dexterity to grasp a guitar pick and over time, re-taught himself to play his guitar left-handed.<ref name=HoustonChronicle/> In a radio interview in 2020, Baker said his brain injury affected his use of language and he struggled to remember nouns. Writing helped him relearn. At the same time he was influenced by the music of [[Lightning Hopkins]] and his writing became songwriting as he discovered melody.<ref name=LeadersAmericanPie>{{cite web |url=https://www.mixcloud.com/richard-leader/leaders-american-pie-3-february-2020-the-one-with-sam-baker/ | title= Leader's American Pie with Sam Baker |date= February 3, 2020 |accessdate= March 12, 2020}}</ref> Previous to the bombing, Baker had worked as a bank examiner and whitewater river guide.<ref name=Today/><ref name=Christgau>{{cite web |url= https://www.npr.org/2013/08/27/216176074/sam-bakers-say-grace-is-at-once-beautiful-and-broken |title= Sam Baker's 'Say Grace' Is at Once Beautiful And Broken |date= August 27, 2013 |last= Christgau |first= Robert |authorlink= Robert Christgau |publisher= [[NPR]] |accessdate= May 6, 2014}}</ref>\n\n==Music==\nSam Baker's music has been compared to that of [[John Prine]].<ref name=Huffington/> Baker's 2013 album, ''Say Grace'', was listed by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' as one of the top 10 country music albums of 2013.<ref name=RS>{{cite journal |url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/10-best-country-albums-of-2013-20131210/sam-baker-say-grace-19691231 |title= Sam Baker, 'Say Grace' |series= 10 Best Country Albums of 2013 |date= December 10, 2013 |last= Hermes |first= Will |journal= [[Rolling Stone]] |accessdate= May 6, 2014}}</ref> In his review of ''Say Grace'', Jim Fusilli wrote \"In Mr. Baker's tales, the personal becomes universal through his keen-eyed writing, supported by well-chosen instrumentation and what might be called spoken-word melodies.\"<ref>Fusilli, Jim. [https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887324823804579017412103872376 Sam Baker: Bard of the Workaday World.] ''The Wall Street Journal'', August 20, 2013.</ref>\n\nAmong Baker's influences for his songwriting are [[Ken Kesey]], [[William Faulkner]], [[Ernest Hemingway]], and [[Bob Dylan]], and fellow Texans [[Lightnin' Hopkins]], [[Guy Clark]], and [[Townes Van Zandt]].<ref name=Conversation>{{cite journal |url= http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/a-converstion-with-sam-baker |title= 'say grace': A Conversation With Sam Baker |date= August 18, 2013 |last= Bogerd
